HEADLINE: Mario Cuomo, Unusually Reserved

 BODY:
Reality governed rhetoric in Mario Cuomo's 11th annual address to the State Legislature. With no money around and none in sight, the Governor kept his proposals and promises to a minimum. The result was an unusually flat presentation for the grandiloquent Mr. Cuomo. He missed a chance to set an overarching theme for the new year. But he was wise not to raise false hopes for a recession-weary state.
His most provocative proposal was to let local school districts finance their share of education costs through local income taxes instead of property taxes. That wouldn't cost the state anything, but is likely to spark more debate than change. 
 Another proposal would create jobs by spending $25 billion on infrastructure over five years. That sounds original, but it includes the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's pending capital program as well as already allocated Federal highway money. Mr. Cuomo also called for reforms to eliminate excessive borrowing, a fairer allocation of state education funds and further streamlining of some state agencies. He hasn't put much muscle behind such worthy proposals in the past; maybe this year will be different.
He said he would oppose higher broad-based taxes like income taxes. But if the state is facing a budget gap of up to $4 billion, Mr. Cuomo will need to explain how he expects to avoid them. After several bruising budget years, can New Yorkers afford more service cuts? Mr. Cuomo's budget, due in two weeks, will no doubt reveal more.
The Governor's message has often been a dazzling exercise in the art of broad-brushing. This year, he made references to what he called "The New York Proposition" -- opportunity, liberty, responsibility and family. Otherwise he was all business. After all, the Republicans he loves to beat up on are leaving the White House and Mr. Cuomo no longer flirts with national office. He may also have sensed that grand flourishes would be inconsistent with modest times.

LENGTH: 457 words

HEADLINE: Choosing a School for Chelsea

 BODY:
No one can reasonably argue with President-elect and Mrs. Clinton's desire to choose the school they think best for their daughter, Chelsea. That is their obligation as parents. But Mr. Clinton also had a larger obligation that he took on by campaigning as an advocate of public education. He has not served the spirit of that obligation by choosing a private school, and the handling of this family decision has provided ammunition for his opponents in the struggle to rebuild public schools.
The public schools are losing support because many middle-class parents have rushed to put their children in private schools. In settling on Sidwell Friends, an institution favored by affluent, liberal Democrats in Washington, the Clintons have joined that rush. Were there sound personal, educational and security reasons? Possibly. But according to news accounts, the Clintons did not even visit any public schools in the District of Columbia. 
 When one of the nation's staunchest advocates of public education chooses not to use those schools, he owes the public a clear, detailed explanation. Absent that explanation, educators and students in public schools have every reason to believe he views their institutions as second-rate -- and to question the President-elect's commitment.
That message was reinforced by the dishonest way in which the decision was announced. Mr. Clinton's spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, insisted that the Clintons "didn't reject public schools." But, of course, that is exactly what they did. The reasons were probably those that lead many middle- and upper-income parents -- even those who support public education as an important vehicle of social and economic mobility -- to opt for private or parochial schools for their own children.
The Washington schools are in big trouble. Five separate reports criticized them last year. An outside audit said the system was "unstable and mismanaged." And Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly said she would no longer throw "good money . . . after bad."
Not citing these problems as a factor in this decision damages Mr. Clinton's credibility. He has opposed taxpayer-financed vouchers that would help any student pay tuition at private or parochial schools. Now voucher proponents are needling him as a hypocrite who would prohibit poor families from making the same choice he has made. But that misses the point: Vouchers for private school tuition would drain tax dollars from the public schools, weakening them still further.
As a family, the Clintons have made a choice. That decision now makes it even more imperative that as President, Mr. Clinton fulfill his promise to restore and improve public schools so that all families will have better choices.

HEADLINE: New Cuban-Americans Also Oppose Castro;
Change Old Attitudes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "A Bridge to Cuba" (Op-Ed, Dec. 18), Prof. Ruth Behar, a second-generation Cuban-American, urges rapprochement with her native land. The United States should rethink its parochial mind-set and consider a more magnanimous attitude toward our neighbor. We should support the almost-unanimous United Nations resolution calling for an end to the Cuban embargo. 
 Fidel Castro won control of Cuba through a popularly supported revolution against the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista. The Batista reign of narrow self-interest, ruthless exploitation or degradation of the Cuban peasantry for the benefit of a small plutocracy was replaced by a more benign dictatorship. Overwhelmed by fear of Communism, the United States condemned Mr. Castro, rather than the hated regime he replaced.
In retrospect, our defensive antagonism toward the small island nation at our doorstep appears inordinate. Had we been more reasonable or less parochial and extended at least a conditional hand of friendship to the young Fidel Castro, who knows what might have happened? The Bay of Pigs and missile crisis might never have occurred. Cuba might have lessened or avoided its servitude to Moscow. At any rate, in a matter of a few short years, there will be a new government in Cuba.
A small coterie based in Miami would like to hasten that day and substitute its own oligarchy to control the island's people and their future. A return to a Batistalike, far-right regime, however, is clearly not in the best interests of either Cuba or the United States. We can discourage these more polished despots and help assure a democratic successor to Fidel Castro if we extend a tentative hand of cooperation to the economically desperate Cuban people.
Persuasion and friendship are apt to be far more effective in promoting democracy than hostility and coercion. Tourism and trade would soften the hard edges of pride and prejudice, and benefit both economies.
Let us celebrate in meaningful and generous fashion the passing of narrow ideologies, the end of the cold war. We should act with self-confidence, rather than insecurity, as we discard another, symbolically important relic of that war. An era of a new and truer pan-Americanism should be encouraged.
 
WALTER HEWITT
Southampton, N.J., Dec. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: In the South Bronx, the Grass Roots Grow Up;
Organizations Born in Protest Uncomfortably Find They're Now the Establishment

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Nearly two decades ago, a band of urban homesteaders intent on blocking the city from demolishing the South Bronx apartment building they were painstakingly renovating linked arms, stood firm and stared down the city's bulldozers. They won the confrontation and their building, and in the process spawned the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, named for the curved block of Kelly Street where they made their stand.
Like pioneering urban groups all over the country, they succeeded where government had failed, providing spotless buildings, low-income cooperatives and greatly needed social services. And nowhere has that success been more evident than in the South Bronx, where Banana Kelly and others helped revive an area that arson and political inaction had consigned to the depths of urban chaos and despair. 
 Yet as they became major players in neighborhood development, taking problem buildings off the hands of the city and adding a slew of social services to their portfolio, these groups have been transformed into landlords and corporations caught between the community of their birth and the government agencies and foundations that sustain them.
In many ways, they have become like the very government they set out to fight. And some people worry that by doing so, the groups have lost some of their all-important edge.
"A lot of the groups have become, for better or worse, surrogates for government in terms of delivery of services and have become part of the establishment," said Harry DeRienzo, a founding organizer and past director of Banana Kelly who now provides assistance to other such groups. "It goes from a grass-roots organization responsible locally to one responsible to institutional needs and where its money comes from."
 
A New Role
 As the groups take on added management responsibilities, they are finding themselves in the sometimes uncomfortable position of having to evict free-loading tenants or others who sell drugs from their apartments. Like landlords anywhere, they also must deal with angry tenants and worry if rental income will cover the cost of repairs. And as providers of social services, they must balance their compassion for a client's problems with their organization's self-interest as a landlord.
They have changed and grown so much that about the only thing they don't do is the old-fashioned organizing that was the heart of their mission.
"We gave up our right to advocate and organize in this community," said Yolanda Rivera, Banana Kelly's executive director, whose group now has a multimillion-dollar budget and 92 employees. "It's the responsibility of the residents to organize like in the early days."
According to the National Center for Community Economic Development, an organization in Washington that assists these groups, the nation's 2,000 or so community-development corporations have developed more than 320,000 low-income apartments and helped create or keep more than 90,000 jobs.
The record of these groups is startlingly evident in areas like the Morrisania section of the Bronx, where Charlotte Street once cut a grim swath through a jumbled moonscape of empty lots and buildings weakened by neglect and the flight of many hard-working families.
This was the birthplace of the MBD Housing Development Corporation, a group started in the mid-1970's by local residents unwilling or unable to move from their community. The group's name came from its attitude -- desperate to see a change for the better, they called themselves the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes.
Alarmed by the seemingly incessant fires and lack of city services, residents banded together, trooped to various city agencies and demanded to know what plans those agencies had for the neighborhood. The frustrating reply was, in a word, none.
But an official at the Department of Housing Preservation and Development turned the tables on them and asked what plans they had. Over time, the group agreed to take over city-owned buildings, renovating and eventually managing them.
 
Taking the Place Of the Government
 "Most of the not-for-profits got started because of a lack of city policy and the city not having the will to implement any policy," said Genevieve Brooks, an organizer of the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes who is now the deputy borough president of the Bronx. "We saw what was wrong and saw an opportunity if we became part of the policy-making group. We could make a difference."
The changes are evident along blocks where MBD helped bring ranch houses with tidy lawns and clean sidewalks as well as rows of squat but well-kept town houses. A few blocks away, the fresh-scrubbed brick facades of renovated apartment buildings stand in contrast to the graffiti-marred walls of city housing projects across the street.
The successes have not gone unnoticed.
"Government learned a long time ago it is the most inefficient producer of housing," said Angelo J. Aponte, the Commissioner of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal. "We found that community-based organizations had the pulse of the community. Groups like Banana Kelly and MBD have become very sophisticated as to what it takes to rehab and develop."
Part of the effectiveness of groups like MBD is the attention paid to sizing up prospective tenants, interviewing them and visiting their homes as part of the application process. The interviews give them a sense of the family's strengths and potential problems, some of which can be addressed through social services offered by the group in its buildings. The families range from single mothers fresh from the city's shelter system to blue-collar workers and elderly residents who have lived in the buildings for decades.
 
Suddenly Learning To Be Landlords
 But while they are seen as having a greater stake in their community's future than absentee landlords, the groups have nonetheless faced some of the same frustrations as landlords in low-income neighborhoods.
"The toughest part is the realization of having responsibilities that leave them in a quandary," said Getz Obstfeld, a former director of Banana Kelly who is now a consultant to community housing groups. "They realize that each apartment in that building costs X amount of money to run."
And while the line between good-guy tenants and bad-guy landlords was clearly drawn in their early days, the groups are now finding that life is not as simple when you're the landlord. It may be easy to rally against a landlord who is bleeding a building and neglecting repairs, but it is hard to pull tenants together around the complexities of housing finance or building management.
"The world for them has changed from black and white to very gray," said Mr. Obstfeld. "It's a hard position to be in when the values that created you and the tactics were protest and community mobilization. It's hard to mobilize people around gray issues."
Another concern is that groups will shy away from confronting city agencies on behalf of tenants if they are also relying on those same agencies for buildings and budgets. Some groups, like the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition, have spun off independent housing-development corporations that allow the parent organization to maintain its focus on tenant organizing and advocacy.
In other cases, some groups have had to take elaborate steps to prevent information gathered by workers in the social-service arm of the organizations from being used against tenants in eviction proceedings by the landlord arm.
 
Some Complaints Sound the Same
 But even at its most basic, tenant-landlord relations have their own singular dynamic. Some of those difficulties can be seen at 783 Beck Street, a building renovated and managed by Banana Kelly. While sunken floors, rickety windows and loitering crackheads no longer plague the building, some of its tenants complain that Banana Kelly did a slipshod job and does not respond quickly enough to repair requests.
"They've gotten way over their head," said Rose Davis, part of whose bedroom ceiling collapsed because of water leaking from a faulty radiator upstairs. She said she told the superintendent of the leak before the collapse but was informed the repair would take at least a week.
The repair took three weeks. It was completed the week before Christmas.
"They've got too many buildings now," Ms. Davis said. "Now they're like a corporation, and you have to take a turn."
Ms. Rivera admitted that Banana Kelly had to balance repairs with rental income, but she said she hoped their experiences would point the way to new partnerships. In larger terms, she has been leading her group to re-examine its mission in hopes of getting the community more involved.
Banana Kelly and five other South Bronx groups are hoping to find those answers through their participation in the Comprehensive Community Revitalization Program, a $5.5 million demonstration project financed by the Surdna Foundation, a private philanthropic organization. The project hopes to help propel these groups into the next stage of their development -- coordinated planning for the economic, social and housing needs of the future.
In regular meetings, staff members from the various groups meet with one another as they discuss plans for their communities. They have brought in tenant leaders and made them part of a dialogue about how they see the community's future, zeroing in on needs for education, job training and new businesses, among others.
MBD is hoping to bring health-care centers to the neighborhood and to develop a sprawling tract north of East 174th Street into a large supermarket and other businesses that would employ hundreds from the community. Banana Kelly is also developing health care and day care, but it has taken the opposite approach to economic development, examining ways to help provide loans to residents.
Increasingly, Ms. Rivera of Banana Kelly talks about instilling in residents the skills and encouragement they need to organize themselves and take on a greater role in running their buildings and communities. It is being done partly through training sessions in "values clarification" and self-esteem, which are also a component of the Community Revitalization Program.
"People depend on the system to provide services," said Ms. Rivera. "But you have all the answers inside. You need to know and feel comfortable you can do this. We give them techniques they can use to understand the concept. If you have values, you have to do something about them. Values in a vacuum are irrelevant."
Some observers are skeptical of the training sessions, which are modeled after a successful program in Dade County, Florida, and criticize them for treating poverty as a pathology.
"I've got problems with it," said Chester Hartman, the executive director of the Poverty and Race Research Action Council, a Washington organization that assists community groups. "It puts the onus on the individual and not the system."
 
Sources of Money, Sources of Power
 He added that one reason why community groups are pursuing such classes is that they are in vogue among some foundation officials. His reservation is echoed by others, including some staff members at community organizations, who see the phenomenon as symptomatic of the problems these groups encounter during their growth: As overhead increases and programs expand, they become more responsive to their sources of money than to the immediate needs of the community.
Many directors of community-development corporations say they are keenly aware of these criticisms, but many admit it is a situation they have to make the most of, since there can be precious few resources to handle an ever-expanding workload.
"If we don't get paid, we can't deliver services," said Ralph Porter, the executive director of MBD. "If it wasn't for the needs of the community, we wouldn't be in existence either. Community-development corporations came into being because there is a need. The Hamptons don't have a community development corporation."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 11, 1993, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about community groups' role in the revitalization of the Bronx referred incorrectly to the financing of a program to help the groups plan. The Surdna Foundation did the initial work in developing the program -- the Comprehensive Community Revitalization Program -- but nine other foundations and corporations contributed money.

International A2-9
 
MARINES ATTACK A CLAN CAMP
About 400 U.S. marines attacked a clan leader's camp in the Somali capital, destroying buildings, capturing weapons and killing or wounding many gunmen. It was the sharpest clash involving U.S. troops since they landed in December. A1
GAINS REPORTED IN SOMALI TALKS
After four days of talks in Ethiopia, the leaders of 14 Somali political factions were reported by United Nations officials to be close to an agreement on the first steps toward ending the war in Somalia. A8
IRAQ DEFIES ALLIES ON MISSILES
In an apparent rebuff of the allied demand that Iraq remove newly deployed surface-to-air missiles in southern Iraq, Baghdad said it was entitled to station the weapons anywhere on its territory. A1

Showing some flexibility in the crisis over 415 deported Palestinians, Israel agreed to allow two Red Cross officials, including a doctor, to visit the exiles at their tent camp in southern Lebanon. A2
ECONOMIC WOES FOR ISRAEL
Turning around Israel's state-guided, aid-dependent economy has eluded Prime Minister Rabin. And many Israelis are disappointed that he has not pressed more aggressively for rapid economic change. A3

POLAND ACTS TO CURB ABORTION
The lower house of Poland's Parliament approved a bill that strictly limits access to abortion but falls short of the ban sought by the Roman Catholic Church. The bill, which exempts pregnancies involving rape, incest, genetic abnormalities or threats to the life of the mother, now moves to the Senate, where it is expected to be approved easily. A7

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The nation's chain stores reported strong sales in December and their best holiday period since 1988. A survey of 22 big retailers showed sales rose 8 percent in December. [Page D1.]
The former head of Salomon's government-securities trading agreed to plead guilty to lying at a Treasury auction. [D1.] 
 First-time claims for state unemployment insurance tumbled to the lowest level in more than three years. [D4.]
New York State will pump $100 million into the ailing Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield insurance company. [A1.]
 
Companies
A.T.& T. agreed to acquire 20 percent of Unitel Communications, a Canadian long-distance company. [D2.]
TIAA-CREF, the largest pension fund, named a successor to its chairman, who was nominated as Deputy Secretary of State. [D2.]
A proposal by Air Canada and a group of Dallas businessmen to invest $450 million in Continental Airlines was approved. [D3.]
Motorola's bold plan to create a worldwide mobile telephone network may be too big for investors to embrace. [D3.]

HEADLINE: Dow Off 36.20 for Steepest Loss in 3 Months

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A late selloff in the bond market crumpled the stock market yesterday, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average with its largest one-day loss in three months.
The Dow closed down 36.20 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,268.96, with the broader market off almost as much. Volume, at 304.9 million shares, exceeded 300 million for only the third time in the last year, as the decline accelerated in the last hour of trading. 
 Just as many investors had let their optimism about the new Clinton Administration guide their buying since the election, some analysts said, many gave in to their fears yesterday after the President-elect backed away from his pledge to halve the budget deficit in four years.
With stocks already expensive relative to their dividends and earnings, said Byron R. Wien, a Morgan Stanley strategist, their prices react violently to disappointments. "In a market that's tender anyway," he said, "investors shifted from being complacent to being concerned."
Prices in the bond market fell first, with the yield on the 30-year treasury bond rising 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.44 percent. Heavy borrowing by the Government to cover the budget deficit tends to raise interest rates, and higher rates make the returns available from stocks less attractive relative to bonds.
Philip Smyth, an analyst at Birinyi Associates, said that sell programs accounted for about 25 points of the Dow's decline. Although these programs are used in sophisticated trading strategies, the underlying cause was the rise in interest rates, he said. Other things being equal, yesterday's higher bond yields lowered the relative value of the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks by a good deal more than 1 percent, he said, even more than this average actually declined.
A report that weekly unemployment insurance claims reached their lowest level in four years contributed to the bond market's decline but initially raised investors' hopes for a stronger recovery. Until early afternoon, the stock market was slightly ahead.
Many of the Dow stocks fell a point or more by the close, with Alcoa losing 2, to 70 5/8; Woolworth, 1 7/8, to 30 1/4, and I.B.M., 1, to 47, reaching lows last seen in the mid-1970's.
A big loser in over-the-counter trading was Hunter Environmental Services, which lost 411/16 , to close at 1, after the Texas Water Commission denied its application to build a toxic-waste disposal site outside Houston.
 
Gains in Transportation
 Among the market's few sources of support, some economically sensitive stocks, especially in transportation, finished the day with gains, as the Dow Jones transportation average rose 12.49, or 0.85 percent, to 1480.23.
Airlines and railroads depend on the domestic market for most of their business, so they are more likely to profit from a recovery than manufacturers with heavy sales abroad.
Philip Morris, up 3/4, to 72 5/8, on volume that led the Big Board, arrested its sharp decline with a public relations offensive. A senior executive attacked news reports concerning the health effects of cigarettes and said that 1992 earnings improved about 20 percent.
A continuing rally in Intel, up 1 yesterday, to 99 5/8, on heavy volume, helped the Nasdaq composite average finish with only about half the percentage loss of the Dow. The Nasdaq average fell 3.64, or 0.53 percent, to 678.21.

HEADLINE: Push by U.S. To Cut Tariffs Is Reported

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
In a change of tactics, the Bush Administration is secretly trying to strike a deal by the end of next week to bring about a reduction in tariffs around the world, American and European officials said today.
As the Bush Administration draws to a close, its officials are eager to achieve success in one of the few foreign policy arenas that has consistently frustrated them for four years. But they insist that they will not make unnecessary concessions or sacrifice America's economic interests for the sake of a quick deal. 
 If a deal is made, it will eventually result in lower prices for billions of consumers on a wide range of goods -- from basic clothing to fine crystal -- and remove one of the biggest remaining obstacles to a comprehensive world trade agreement.
A worldwide agreement would, in all likelihood, act as a strong stimulus to the global economy.
 
Vigorous Effort Reported
 Some officials involved in the talks cautioned that many differences remained, and a senior Administration trade official said he doubted the effort would succeed. But others said it was the most vigorous since the United States and the Europeans reached a farm subsidies agreement two months ago, and success could not be ruled out.
The new negotiating began Saturday, when Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, made an unannounced visit to London. She met there with Sir Leon Brittan, a British politician and free-trade enthusiast who is now the European Community's Commissioner for External Affairs, including trade negotiations.
Mrs. Hills and Sir Leon reviewed the stalemate and are said to have concluded that the best way to make progress now was to shift the center of attention to tariffs from free-trade rules, like allowing banks and insurance companies to do business across national frontiers.
As a result, Bush Administration officials are working out proposals to reduce hundreds of specific American import taxes, or tariffs, in exchange for matching cuts in foreign tariffs that hurt overseas sales of American goods. The proposals will be carried to Geneva on Friday by a team of Mrs. Hills's senior aides, said officials who insisted on anonymity.
Mrs. Hills has been personally handling even the most minute details with only a handful of her top aides, excluding many Administration officials normally involved in such talks.
"There are three who know precisely what we're going to do and those are Carla Hills, Jules Katz and Warren Lavorel," one official said. Mr. Katz is senior deputy trade representative; Mr. Lavorel is another top American negotiator.
 
Stress Shifted to Tariffs
 The Americans and Europeans have "had conversations every day this week, some on the telephone and some face to face," the official added. The United States, he said, shifted its emphasis to tariffs in response to renewed European interest.
A trans-Atlantic deal would be tantamount to a worldwide tariff agreement, such is the economic power of the American and European blocs.
The breakthrough sought by the Bush Administration by the end of next week would put pressure on the Clinton Administration to finish the overall talks soon after it takes office, before the negotiating authority from Congress expires on March 2.
But the Bush Administration has told the Clinton transition team almost nothing about the details, one Democrat complained, and Clinton aides have shown little enthusiasm for dealing with the complicated negotiations in their first 100 days in office. Instead, they hope to focus on domestic issues.
Mrs. Hills has pointed out repeatedly that President Bush remains legally in charge until the inauguration of Bill Clinton on Jan. 20, and that Mr. Clinton endorsed the Bush Administration's continued handling of trade matters after he won the election.
Farm subsidies, tariffs and free-trade rules have been the major issues in the talks aimed at broadening the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a series of free-trade pacts. Until now, however, tariffs have been largely ignored. The United States and the European Community have very different sets of these import taxes, and, as a result, different priorities in the negotiations.
The United States has negligible tariffs on most manufactured goods and raw materials but is extremely protective of a few low-skill industries that employ thousands of people, with tariffs of 20 percent or more on imports of products like household glassware and apparel. The European Community has tariffs of 5 or 10 percent on a broad range of manufactured goods and raw materials that the United States produces.
The European Community wants to reduce a few of the highest tariffs on both sides, while the United States seeks the complete elimination of already low tariffs on many goods.

HEADLINE: PEROT TO USE TV TO PROMOTE GROUP

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Texas billionaires don't fade away, it would seem. They just keep coming back on TV.
No matter that the campaign is long over. On Monday, Ross Perot returns to his favorite venues: a news conference in Dallas followed by CNN's "Larry King Live," where it all began. Then ABC's "Good Morning America" Tuesday and NBC's "Today" program on Thursday. 
 Since there is no longer an election to talk about, Mr. Perot will talk up his grass-roots organization, United We Stand, America. For $15 a year, he will tell viewers, they can be part of his group, which says it is promoting issues Mr. Perot emphasized during the campaign, like deficit reduction.
"He'll be making sure that we get more than just promises on the national economy," said Sharon Holman, the spokeswoman for United We Stand.
 
Link to Inauguration Denied
 Ms. Holman said Mr. Perot's plan had nothing to do with President-elect Bill Clinton's imminent inauguration -- that his only motivation was to begin the membership drive.
Although the President-elect has been solicitous of Mr. Perot's supporters, he has apparently felt little compulsion to seek the advice of Mr. Perot, the independent Presidential candidate who got about 19 percent of the vote.
He did not invite Mr. Perot to his economic conference in Little Rock last month. But few would doubt that Mr. Perot will reprise his favorite lines about the deficit, urging the new President (as he urged the old one) to get "under the hood of the car, working on the engine."
Mr. King, who saw his audience shoot up with Mr. Perot's countless appearances last year, has high hopes for Monday night. "In a weird kind of way, people miss him," he said. "It won't be as fervent as in the heat of the campaign, but there will always be interest in Ross Perot. Whatever that potion is that goes into a television screen and beams out to make people attracted to him, Perot has it."
Mr. Perot's plans to return to the cameras suggest that for television viewers, this year may not seem much different from the campaign year. Already, Mr. Clinton has made no secret that he intends to run a permanent campaign out of the White House.
 
'Probably Bored'
 But Edward J. Rollins, who briefly served as Mr. Perot's campaign co-chairman before the two turned on each other, said his former boss may find that he will not get as much attention in the shadows of a new President.
"Obviously, he is probably bored being out of the limelight," Mr. Rollins said. "Usually in a campaign you try to motivate people to do something. What is his motivation here, except to get his ego stroked?"
But he said it would be a mistake for Mr. Perot to attack the incoming President. "In the honeymoon period," Mr. Rollins said, "there wouldn't be many people who would listen to him."
Indeed, Mr. King said, "I don't think you're going to see him come on and blast Clinton. But the public's going to be interested in what he thinks of the Cabinet."
Mr. Perot drew a larger share of the vote than any third-party or independent Presidential candidate since Theodore Roosevelt in 1912. Ms. Holman described United We Stand as a nonpartisan organization that would not endorse candidates or make contributions but might issue report cards on candidates' voting records.
It should come as no surprise that Mr. Perot's return to television next week will not be his last appearance, Ms. Holman said. "He'll be highly visible," Ms. Holman said. Does Mr. Perot miss the attention? "You'd have to ask him," Ms. Holman said.

HEADLINE: Audit of Government Says Billions Are Being Wasted

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The top Federal auditor told President-elect Bill Clinton today that the Government did "an abysmal job of rudimentary bookkeeping" and had tens of billions of dollars in hidden liabilities.
In a series of 45 transition reports, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, the head of the General Accounting Office, painted a grim picture of a Government plagued by mismanagement, unable to collect delinquent taxes and unwilling to acknowledge the full cost of its long-term commitments. 
 He said the State Department, the Transportation Department, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Health Care Financing Administration and the Energy Department were losing billions of dollars a year because they were lax in supervising Federal contractors who build embassies, subways and satellites, pay Medicare claims and run Government laboratories.
"Widespread financial management weaknesses are crippling the ability of our leaders to effectively run the Federal Government," Mr. Bowsher said.
The Comptroller General has historically been a nonpartisan official appointed by the President. Mr. Bowsher was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1981 for a 15-year term.
 
Poor Bookkeeping
 The Government, he said, spends $1.5 trillion a year but does "an abysmal job of rudimentary bookkeeping," using unreliable, ineffective techniques to control the flow of money.
As a flagrant example, Mr. Bowsher cited an Agriculture Department program that lends money to farmers. Under the program, run by the Farmers Home Administration, farmers are delinquent on more than one-third of the $20.5 billion in outstanding loans, and "borrowers who have defaulted on past loans are free to obtain new loans," he said.
Federal officials "seem to believe that keeping farmers on the land is more important than making prudent lending decisions," he said.
In another example, Mr. Bowsher said the Government did not properly supervise private insurance companies that process claims under Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. These contractors "focus more on paying claims quickly than on reviewing the accuracy of payments," he said. In many cases, he said, the Medicare contractors fail to investigate beneficiaries' complaints about fraud by doctors, laboratories and other services.
Likewise, Mr. Bowsher criticized the Energy Department for its supervision of companies that produce nuclear weapons and operate national laboratories for the Government. Under some of these arrangements, he said, the Government must reimburse contractors for money and materials stolen by the contractors' employees and must pay fines incurred by contractors for violating environmental laws.
The Comptroller General's original role, when the General Accounting Office was created in 1921, was to rule on the legality of Government spending. But in recent years the office has spent more and more time analyzing the quality of programs. With a staff of 5,090 employees, the Comptroller General has virtually unlimited power to investigate Government operations.
In the reports, Mr. Bowsher warned Mr. Clinton against relaxing Federal regulation of banks, as the industry and some Clinton advisers have recommended as a way to stimulate the economy by encouraging lending. But Mr. Bowsher said the current inspection of banks by regulators was inadequate to assess "the safety and soundness of bank operations," or to provide early warning of problems.
In fact, Mr. Bowsher recommended new banking regulations. He suggested that Congress should set accounting standards for delinquent loans if the accounting profession did not voluntarily adopt tougher standards.
 
4 Years Since Last Study
 Congress asked Mr. Bowsher in November to analyze the issues facing the new President. In December 1988, Mr. Bowsher gave the President-elect, George Bush, a report that urged him to address domestic problems neglected by the Reagan Administration and said the costs would be staggering.
Now, in the new reports, Mr. Bowsher said the problems and the costs of fixing them had risen sharply.
Mr. Bowsher also warned that the $290 billion Federal deficit in 1992 -- up from $155 billion in 1988 -- understated the fiscal squeeze. He said the shortfall of $386 billion in the Government's operating accounts last year was partly offset by a surplus of $96 billion in trust funds like Social Security.
"This trust fund surplus is a temporary phenomenon that will begin to evaporate within the next 20 years as the baby boom retires," he wrote.
Mr. Bowsher said tax increases were likely to be part of "any credible strategy to reduce the deficit" because "growth in revenues has not kept pace with Federal spending."
The Comptroller General said it would be very difficult for Mr. Clinton to cut the deficit in half in four years, as he promised in the Presidential campaign. "It's more important that he have a plan over a longer period, that he persevere and get the job done," Mr. Bowsher said today in an interview.
He said the experience of the last four years showed that his earlier warnings had been conservative. He noted that recently the inspectors general at several agencies reached similar conclusions after doing their own audits and investigations.
 
Solutions Cost More Now
 In 1988, he said it would cost $100 billion to $130 billion to modernize and clean up the nation's nuclear weapon production plants. In his new report, he puts the cost at $160 billion.
In 1988, Mr. Bowsher said it would cost $50 billion or more for the Government to take over insolvent savings and loan associations, dispose of their assets and pay off depositors. Today he said, "Estimates of the eventual cost to taxpayers of the savings and loan cleanup exceed $300 billion."
In 1988, he said it would cost as much as $14 billion to clean up toxic wastes dumped by Defense Department installations. In his new report, he put the cost at $24.5 billion.
Mr. Bowsher also warned that "current welfare reform efforts may falter or fail." In the late 1980's, Congress, with support from Mr. Clinton, among other Governors, passed several laws to help poor families get job training and jobs. But the laws have not been fully carried out because of rising case loads and state budget constraints," he said.
Finally, the Comptroller General said the savings from military cutbacks would prove elusive. He said: "Our work shows that many of the assumed savings may not materialize. The Defense Department may be faced with additional program reductions of nearly $100 billion."

HEADLINE: Clinton to Meet Today With Mexican Leader

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico will not try to settle their highly complicated differences on North American trade issues when they meet Friday, Democrats and Mexican officials said this week.
George Stephanopoulos, the communications director for Mr. Clinton's transition team, said the meeting in Austin, Tex., would cover immigration and foreign-aid issues as well as the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would eliminate trade barriers among the United States, Canada and Mexico. 
 But Mr. Clinton's Cabinet nominees and Mexico's senior trade negotiators will not attend the session, which both sides described as an opportunity for the two to get to know each other.
 
Mexicans Rooted for Bush
 The meeting is intended partly to mend ties after the American election campaign, when Mexican officials rooted for the re-election of President Bush, Democrats said. Mr. Salinas sat with Mr. Bush in July at the All-Star baseball game in San Diego, which Republicans saw at the time as an opportunity to woo Hispanic voters.
But no details on the free-trade pact will be worked out until officials from all three countries come together, Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
He also said Mr. Clinton had called Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada today and invited him to meet shortly after the inauguration in the first meeting of the Clinton Presidency with any foreign leader.
Mr. Clinton said on Oct. 4 that he would not sign legislation putting the North American pact into law until he had negotiated three supplemental agreements with Mexico and made five changes in American law. The agreements would cover labor and environmental issues and the reimposition of tariffs if imports surge.
 
Language Still Undecided
 The changes would increase spending on workers who lose their jobs because of imports; spend more money on environmental cleanup; help farmers shift away from crops that Mexico grows more efficiently; tighten licensing requirements for Mexican truck drivers who cross the border, and raise barriers to the immigration of strikebreakers.
But the Clinton transition has not yet decided how these broad principles should be translated into legal language, Democrats said.
One important unresolved question is how to raise the money to help people who may lose their jobs because of imports from Mexico or because of the relocation of American factories to Mexico. Economic studies have consistently shown that while the agreement may create more jobs than it destroys, the job losses could nonetheless approach 200,000 over the next few years.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Defense Department;
Aspin Questions Bush Estimates on Arms Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for Defense Secretary, Representative Les Aspin, said today that the Bush Administration's military budget for the next six years may overestimate savings and underestimate weapons costs.
The estimates are significant because Mr. Clinton promised to cut $60 billion out of Mr. Bush's budget of $1.42 trillion for the fiscal years 1992 through 1997. 
 If Mr. Bush's anticipated savings cannot be achieved or if weapons cost more than planned, the Clinton Administration will face the hard choice of cutting more from military spending to make up the difference or scaling back planned cuts to avoid broader troop reductions and layoffs by Pentagon contractors.
 
$60 Million Error?
 Mr. Aspin said that one of his first acts as Defense Secretary would be to sort out the budget figures.
"Are we talking about a realistic number from which the President-elect has pledged to cut $60 billion, or are we talking about something else?" Mr. Aspin asked.
The Bush Administration, for example, contends it can save $71 billion by 1997 through internal cost-cutting steps, like consolidating supply depots and changing accounting procedures. But some Pentagon officials say those measures will save only $10 billion to $20 billion.
Mr. Aspin, a Wisconsin Democrat, began his testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee today by outlining what he sees as the four big dangers facing American security interests in the post-cold war world: weakened control over nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union, regional conflicts, failed reform in the former Soviet republics and sluggish economic growth in the United States.
The 54-year-old chairman of the House Armed Services Committee sailed through today's hearing, easily fielding questions from senators he has dealt with for years and handling subjects as varied as homosexuals in the military and the use of force in Iraq and Bosnia.
But the voluble Mr. Aspin, who typically dispenses his ideas and opinions freely, was under strict orders from the Clinton camp not to say anything controversial. As a result, he declined to comment on several sensitive issues, including women in combat and the possibility of American air strikes against Serbian targets in Bosnia, until the new cabinet could convene.
Today also marked the beginning of a new relationship between Mr. Aspin and Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee. As respective chairmen of the House and Senate panels controlling military programs, the two lawmakers have for years been co-equals, horse trading pet programs and policy compromises. Now, as the Defense Secretary-designate, Mr. Aspin will depend largely on Mr. Nunn and his colleagues for the Pentagon's annual budget.
 
Conciliatory Tone
 Mr. Aspin offered an olive branch to the armed services, whose senior leaders view him suspiciously because he supports a 1.4 million-member military by 1995, which is 200,000 fewer troops than President Bush has proposed. "We will not lose sight of our first duty -- the maintenance of sound, ready, effective forces," Mr. Aspin said in concluding his opening statement.
While refusing to discuss his personal recommendations on military options in Bosnia, Mr. Aspin said the end of the cold war had changed the calculations behind the use of force.
Critics of air strikes against Serbian positions have feared that if aerial bombardment failed to reverse Serbian policies, ground troops would have to be sent in as a natural escalation of force.
"Maybe you use force not to achieve something but to punish people for doing certain things," Mr. Aspin said. "If it doesn't work, the backing off of it doesn't have the same kind of international concerns."
 
Divisive Issues Addressed
 Among social issues affecting the military, Mr. Clinton's promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in the armed services has raised howls of protest from service members and senior officers. Mr. Aspin said as Defense Secretary he would carry out the new policy, but "very carefully and very deliberately."
"From an equity and fairness standpoint, I think there's some real problems with the way the policy is going right now," he said. "We're going to be dealing with this thing in the next four years, no matter what. Either we deal with it forthrightly and well, or backhandedly and bumble it."
Mr. Aspin also defended Mr. Clinton's plan to shrink the military and the Pentagon, and he said pressures to make deeper cuts are coming from lawmakers who do not have military installations or weapons plants in their districts.
"The current situation in Congress right now is not a split between hawks and doves, between liberals and conservatives, between Democrats and Republicans," Mr. Aspin said. "It's between those people that have military bases and facilities in their districts and those who don't."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Deficit and Economic News Batter the Treasury Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury bonds and notes plunged yesterday as traders and investors got a glimpse of a slightly stronger economy. And they may also have begun to peek at the huge deficit in the Federal budget that President Bush proposed on Wednesday and wonder about President-elect Bill Clinton's commitment to reducing it.
Traders said a lot of selling was also prompted by the need to reduce the risk of losses from the billions of dollars in new corporate bonds that dealers issued this week. This was accomplished by selling Treasury securities as a hedge. More than $4.1 billion of new corporate issues were sold yesterday, bringing the total for the week to $10.4 billion. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was off more than a point, and the yield jumped to 7.44 percent, more than wiping out the gains from a rally on Monday. The yield on Wednesday was 7.35 percent. The rally at the beginning of the week pushed the yield down to 7.32 percent from 7.39 percent on Dec. 31.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell more then 3/4 point, and the yield rose to 6.73 percent, from 6.61 percent on Wednesday; the yield on the five-year note jumped to 6.04 percent from 5.92 percent.
The bond selloff also depressed stock prices. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.20 points, its largest one-day loss in three months, to close at 3,268.96. [Page D4.]
The bond market has been behaving abnormally recently, but yesterday's rout seemed to be a return to normal -- for at least a day.
Despite economic data that show the economy growing, prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose recently. Normally, economic growth would worry investors and traders because it would signal rising inflation. But many investors had decided that more growth was positive because it would mean Mr. Clinton could scale back plans to stimulate the economy through spending and tax incentives.
At the same time, investors seemed to become unusually comfortable with the President-elect, a Democrat, and his commitment to reducing the record Federal deficit.
"Those arguments got tired" yesterday, said Jay Goldinger, a government bond trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles.
The day started with a report of a very sharp decline in initial claims for unemployment insurance, reflecting an improvement in the economy that was better than expected. Claims fell by 40,000 in the week ended Dec. 26, to 291,000, the lowest level since April 1989.
To make matters worse, the report came the day before the Labor Department's release of the monthly employment report, which always makes the market nervous.
Some investors and traders were also beginning to look at the projections of a deficit of $300 billion to $400 billion, based on the budget that President Bush sent to Congress on Wednesday. Comments from Mr. Clinton's staff indicating that the President-elect would have to go slower than planned on cutting the deficit also did not help.
John Costas, the managing director of government trading at First Boston, said he was beginning to see a change in the market's thinking. The focus, he said, had been on the slow increase in job growth and the fact that the economy would not accelerate too quickly. This meant no immediate inflationary threat, which would normally push bond prices lower.
But he said some people were talking more about the demand for capital as the economy grows and private capital borrowing demands increase. With the deficit at record levels and moving higher, there could be a scramble for credit that would push interest rates higher.
"Just because you are not having a lot of hiring does not mean there will not be a demand for credit," he said.
The market for new corporate issues was dominated yesterday by the World Bank, Time Warner and RJR Nabisco.
The 30-year World Bank issue was priced to yield 7.669 percent, or about 28 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year benchmark issue. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The 20-year Time Warner bonds were priced to yield 9.125 percent, about 175 basis points more than the 30-year Treasury. The 7-year RJR notes were priced to yield 8.095 percent, about 167.5 basis points more than the when-issued seven-year Treasury note.

HEADLINE: Retailers' Holidays: Happy Indeed

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The nation's chain stores yesterday reported stunningly strong sales in December, their best holiday season since 1988.
Retailers had anticipated moderate gains for the Christmas season, but few had predicted sales as vigorous as they turned out to be. And even the most optimistic were surprised by the results. 
 "Sales were not good -- they were great," said Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service, a publication of Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a New York brokerage firm, that monitors the performance of retail companies. He was one of the few analysts who had predicted outstanding sales growth. "The consumer came out of the closet," he said.
 
 
Lower Sales Ahead?
 Sales are likely to slow in the first quarter of this year, for several reasons. Retailers managed their inventories well during the holidays, so they have relatively few goods left to mark down. Conversely, last year they had so much merchandise to clear out at cut-rate prices that sales soared in January and February. Any gains early this year are likely to pale in comparison.
Behind the surge were many shoppers who had locked their credit cards in the family safe to reduce their debt, but pulled them out for the holidays. "We're wondering whether there won't be some credit card panic this month when people get their bills," Mr. Johnson said.
And many people who ran up bills in December, anticipating their income-tax refunds early this year, may be disappointed to find that their refunds will be smaller than usual. The Bush Administration adjusted the Federal tax-withholding tables to put more money in consumers' pockets last year.
Still, analysts say that retailers have little to fear at the start of the new year, with lean inventories that will protect their profit margins. Retail companies that have languished for the last few years now have reason to celebrate.
"Strong sales coupled with an absence of the price promoting of the last several years and a much more disciplined approach to management made this Christmas a barn-burner," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers.
The Salomon Brothers retail index, which tracks the monthly sales of 22 large retailers and compiles them in a weighted average, rose 8 percent in December. Most analysts and merchants were expecting sales gains of 4 to 6 percent.
 For the five weeks that ended on Saturday, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the country's largest retail chain, posted its best comparable-store sales gains in five years, rising 10 percent above the previous year's level.
Sales at Sears, Roebuck & Company stores open at least a year jumped 8.2 percent, well beyond the company's 5 percent goal. Analysts watch sales in stores open at least a year, known as comparable-store sales, more closely than total sales, because they are a more accurate indicator of a retail chain's performance.
 
 
Big-Ticket Items
 While Sears said sales were strong in all of its departments, home office equipment, video games and furniture were among the goods that led the surge.
After a two-year slump, the Limited, the specialty-store operator that has battled to increase sales this year, had comparable-store sales gains of 9 percent.
 The December reports from some retailers were not so good. The Gap, which routinely earned double-digit sales gains during the recession by making white T-shirts and blue jeans newly fashionable, had a 5 percent sales increase at stores open at least a year, and the company warned that a good portion of those sales came at the expense of profits.
And Kmart discount stores in the United States had a meager 2.3 percent increase in comparable-store sales. At the specialty stores that the Kmart Corporation operates, which include Waldenbooks and the Sports Authority, sales were up 2.2 percent in stores open at least a year. Over all, sales for the corporation were up 2.4 percent.
"While sales in December were at an all-time high, they were slightly under plan, reflecting reduced promotional activity in the U.S. Kmart division," said the chairman and chief executive of the company, Joseph E. Antonini.
He was quick to add that good inventory management, which helped the company match sales to demand, would make Christmas 1992 the most profitable holiday in Kmart's history.
 
Department Stores Surge
 Target, the Dayton Hudson Corporation's discount chain, struggled, like Kmart, until last-minute shoppers lifted its sales just before Christmas. Sales rose 8 percent at Target stores that were open at least a year.
Department store chains, which consumers all but abandoned for discount stores and mass merchants during the recession, celebrated their best monthly sales increases of the year. The Neiman Marcus Group's same-store sales climbed 10.1 percent as shoppers splurged on expensive apparel. Federated Department Stores Inc., which operates Bloomingdale's, Rich's and seven other department store chains, had a 10 percent gain in comparable-store sales.
This was the first holiday season in three years in which stores specializing in trend-setting fashion merchandise, like Neiman Marcus, Bloomingdale's, Express, Ann Taylor and J. C. Penney, outperformed many of the leading discounters.
"With the snapback in consumer spending, spending on apparel snapped back, too," said Wayne Hood, a retailing analyst at Prudential Securities. "It's so noticeable because consumers held off buying apparel for so long."
And gift givers did not neglect retailers specializing in home electronics, computers, furniture and other, longer-lasting merchandise. Circuit City Stores Inc., a consumer electronics retailer, had a 9 percent increase in sales at stores open at least one year. Its chief national competitor, the Best Buys Company, posted a 13 percent sales increase at its comparable stores.

HEADLINE: Weicker's Statewide School Plan Could Resolve Hartford Bias Suit

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s call for a statewide school-integration effort will not end a suit challenging segregation in Hartford's schools, but it could lead to a resolution of the suit that would avoid a court imposing a desegregation plan on the state capital and its suburbs.
The outlines of Mr. Weicker's plan, lawyers for the plaintiffs in the suit said today, meet one of their basic requirements, that integration be approached on a regional basis. 
 But equally important, they said, the Governor, in his address to the General Assembly on Wednesday, acknowledged the state's responsibility to eliminate segregation even if it is unintentional, a result not of laws, but of housing patterns, poverty, or town lines drawn hundreds of years ago.
That acknowledgement, said one of the plaintiffs' lawyers, John C. Brittain, opened a door for the plaintiffs to discuss with state officials the details of an integration bill that is to be submitted to the Legislature in February.
 
A Sticking Point Is Removed
 "One sticking point was liability," Mr. Brittain said today of talks with state officials before the trial opened. "The state can't admit it, and we can't afford to waive it."
The Governor's statement that the state must address the segregation regardless of who or what is responsible for it "largely eliminates that obstacle," Mr. Brittain said.
In the trial in Superior Court, lawyers for the state continue to argue that the state is not responsible for the segregation in Hartford's schools, where 90 percent of the children are from minority groups and half are on welfare.
Now that the Governor has made a major proposal, Mr. Brittain said, "Why not talk?"
"Ideally it would be best to go to the Legislature with a proposal jointly sponsored by the administration and the plaintiffs," he said.
While testimony in the suit is likely to conclude before a bill is introduced, legislation endorsed by the plaintiffs would be similar to a settlement. It would lay out a mutually agreed upon goal, a process and a timetable for integrating the schools.
Since his election campaign in 1990, Mr. Weicker has expressed concern over the growing segregation of schools in Connecticut's cities. His address to legislators, challenging them to uphold the State Constitution's guarantee of an equal public education for everyone, staked out the moral issue of equal opportunity while pointing out the economic benefits of providing all children with a good education.
"There's not enough money in all of Connecticut for the jails that will be," he concluded, after noting that Connecticut is projected to build many more jails than schools this decade.
Mr. Weicker called for dividing Connecticut into six regions, within which towns and cities would develop plans to balance the racial makeup of their schools starting in the 1995-96 school year.
He offered few specifics, other than that the planning process would preserve local control, that towns could consider many options and that the state would help.
 
Statewide Solution Sought
 Mr. Weicker has emphasized that he wants a statewide solution. In a news conference today he did not mention negotiations with lawyers in the Hartford lawsuit. His spokeswoman, Avice Meehan, said he would not comment on the suit.
For many residents, however, the Governor's speech brought to life the issues that have been slowly taking shape in Superior Court in this Hartford suburb, where Judge Harry Hammer has heard three weeks of testimony in the suit known as Sheff v. O'Neill.
The idea that Simsbury, where 95.9 percent of the students are white, or Wethersfield, where 94.4 percent are white, might soon have to strike some balance with Hartford suddenly was made real. Similar racial disparities, along with sharp differences in wealth, exist across the state.
Mr. Weicker's proposals come as no surprise to the state's educators, however, and his call for towns to begin discussing regional integration plans by this fall does not catch them unprepared, especially in the Hartford area, which has been living with the Sheff case for four years.
Part of the case that Mr. Brittain and his colleagues are trying to build rests on reports prepared by the State Department of Education in 1988 and 1989 documenting the growing segregation in the state and describing ways it could be addressed.
The first recommendation of the 1988 report was "that the state, through administrative and legislative means, endorse the concept of 'collective responsibility' for desegregating the public schools."
 
Some Work Undertaken
 The state, witnesses for the plaintiffs have testified, never acted on that or other recommendations. But school superintendents have been studying them carefully, so Mr. Weicker's call for quick action this week did not dismay them, many of them said.
In the Hartford area, superintendents have been meeting for several years to develop programs that bring city and suburban children together. "Small things," said Stephen Tegarden, the Superintendent in Glastonbury, "but certainly in the spirit of cooperation and collaboration. The dialogue has begun."
The superintendents, however, have even undertaken what some describe as war games, in the event of a court desegregation order. "We've taken some time and played out different scenarios," Mr. Tegarden said, " 'what if a judge says do this by such and such a date,' that sort of thing."
The officials, he said, identified half a dozen "critical success factors" in carrying out any such plan, and now Mr. Weicker has led to the start of informational initiatives.
"A lot of them," Mr. Tegarden said, "have to do with getting information out and educating our residents."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 NEW YORK CITY
 
DAILY NEWS BEGINS NEW ERA WITH LAYOFFS
Mortimer B. Zuckerman began a new era at The Daily News with a tense labor confrontation, telling 170 employees, some of whom had worked at The News for decades, that they no longer had jobs. The move by Mr. Zuckerman to cut the membership of the Newspaper Guild by a third signaled a low point for the guild, which represents journalists at several news organizations in New York City. A1. 
DINKINS RECOGNIZES DOMESTIC PARTNERS
 Mayor Dinkins moved to give unmarried heterosexual and homosexual couples in New York City some of the rights enjoyed by married couples. Through an executive order, the Mayor created a city registry in which city residents or nonresident municipal workers who live together could register as unmarried "domestic partners." A1.
SCHOOL OFFICIAL BEING INVESTIGATED DIES
The body of the superintendent of a Bronx school district who was the subject of investigations into allegations of financial misconduct was found in an Albany motel room. B3.
COURT ALLOWS WORK AT AUDUBON THEATER
 New York State's highest court cleared the way for construction to begin on a biomedical-research complex on the site of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom in Manhattan, the building where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965. HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Washington Talk;
'Main St.' Not Stirred By Change In the Wind

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Thomas Caviness isn't going. He isn't in the mood.
Bernadine Carie is curious, but she hasn't quite caught the spirit. 
 Along Georgia Avenue, which is Bill Clinton's designated symbol of the real America in the capital, they might as well be watching the birth of the Clinton Administration from Kalamazoo. To hear the the people along Georgia Avenue discuss it, the inauguration, just four miles and two weeks away, feels like a coming attraction at the cineplex in suburban Silver Spring.
Mr. Clinton's high-energy inaugural machine has been busily pumping up its five-day festival of symbolism, a high-concept political mini-series starring Mr. Clinton and his family, with appearances by Jefferson, Lincoln, the Liberty Bell and the American people. But it just doesn't matter much to Georgia Avenue.
Untouched by the hoopla, they listen to the radio's daily broadcasts on ticket availability (it's slim pickin's). Bill Clinton touched them deeply when he visited their stores shortly after his election, bridging the gap between the marble grandeur of Pennsylvania Avenue and the brick and boards of their own neighborhood. They are happy to see the same spirit in his inauguration. But they aren't exactly excited.
"You have to be in the mood," said Mr. Caviness, 68, owner of Tynisha's Art and Gift shop, as he photocopied some of the press clippings from Mr. Clinton's mid-November visit to his block of black, blue-collar Washington. "Some of this is a quest for publicity, and some of it is an attempt to send a message that he's a down-to-earth President. But I'm not going. I have little use for crowds."
"I haven't really decided if I want to go," said Ms. Carie, a hairdresser, as she spun Justina Cunningham's hair around a curler.
She was pleased, though, that 9-year-old Tiara Dews will be going "to everything," as her grandmother Mary Dews said. Tiara and her mother, Cheri Dews, are going to be part of the Faces of Hope lunch, and Tiara is attending an inaugural ball (one of 11) in a "special designer gown" paid for by the inaugural committee.
A few miles away, Richard Mintz, communications director for the Presidential Inaugural Committee, was describing the process as "like putting together a Fortune 500 Company." His committee should not to be confused with the Armed Forces Inaugural Committee, the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Celebrations or any of the dozens of unofficial events that are using the "inaugural" name.
The official events alone are enough to cause a run on Roman numerals. There's Inaugural I: The Bus Ride, Inaugural II: The Bell-Ringing, and Inaugural III: The Fireworks.
And that's just on Sunday, Jan. 17, well before the Diplomatic Reception, the Reunion on the Mall, the four formal dinners, the concerts at the Capital Center, the Salutes (to Children and Youth) at the Kennedy Center and the actual inauguration at the United States Capitol on Wednesday at 11:30 A.M., with a crowd of 250,000 looking on.
On the unofficial side, the celebration of promise is also a celebration of political and economic pragmatism.
For instance, the Arkansas State Society has arranged a gala event for the home-state folk. The organization rounded up money from nine Fortune 500 companies (mostly telecommunications, energy and timber) and four major trade associations (bankers, insurers and small businesses) to defray the costs.
Washington fax machines, accustomed to spitting out ponderous statements on trade and telecommunications policy, are suddenly producing exclamation-point-filled notices of inaugural events to remember. One group, advertising yet another Elvis-look-alike at yet another party, even put an exclamation point after the word "fax!"
The faxes, of course, are not going up to Georgia Avenue.
"The inauguration's nice," said Elizabeth Neal, 69, who lives above Yong Mo Chong's liquor store, "Hamilton Beverages." "But the most important thing is what's going to happen afterwards. Because we've had a hard time."

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Schools Proposal Strikes a Chord

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to let counties finance schools with income rather than property taxes is a response to an outcry in many communities over property taxes that have continued to rise, sometimes sharply, even during the economic downturn.
"It points up the desperation single-family home owners feel because their property taxes just keep going up," Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said of Mr. Cuomo's proposal. 
 Many details of Mr. Cuomo's program remain sketchy and it is not clear how its impact would vary from taxpayer to taxpayer. But Mr. Cuomo contends his proposal would create a fairer system of school financing because he says income is better than property as a measure of wealth.
The problem of rising property taxes has fueled an emotional debate on Long Island, where officials say high taxes have squeezed elderly residents on fixed incomes and kept young families from buying homes. Concern about property taxes led to the formation of a commission two years ago to study tax relief.
 
'Political Dynamite'
 The New York State Temporary Commission for Tax Relief on Long Island, appointed by the county executives of Nassau and Suffolk counties and partly financed by the state, said that school costs were a major reason for rising property taxes.
In its final report, released late last year, the commission concluded that financing schools with income taxes would be more fair to the poor and middle class, and could stabilize or reduce property taxes.
According to a statistical analysis by the commission, Long Island residents earning over $100,000 per year would pay a larger share of school budgets if schools were financed through income taxes.
The idea had been discussed before, said John V. N. Klein, co-chairman of the commission, but no elected official had proposed it because it was considered "political dynamite."
"People viewed it as yet another tax in addition to existing taxes, and it was politically very treacherous to try to explain some of the nuances," said Mr. Klein, a lawyer in Mineola.
 
Squeeze on Taxpayers
 Mr. Cuomo's proposal, which was introduced in in his State of the State address on Wednesday, may have given the idea new life, Mr. Klein and other officials said.
Though Mr. Cuomo's aides said the Governor had not based his proposal on the Long Island study, they said the Governor did believe that Long Island needed property-tax relief.
"The reality is, property taxes are squeezing people and therefore it's led to this cry for a system that more reflects people's ability to pay," said Andrew J. Zambelli, Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff.
And though he provided only the sketchy outlines of a program, Mr. Cuomo has generated a statewide debate not only over property taxes, but also the financing of education, one of the thorniest subjects in state politics.
 
Unanswered Questions
 In his speech and in interviews afterward, Mr. Cuomo said that each county would be allowed to hold a referendum to determine whether voters would prefer the income-tax or the property-tax system.
If the county decided to switch to the income-tax system, taxes would be levied as a surcharge on the state income tax. The state would collect the money and return it to the county to be distributed among local school districts according to a formula.
But Mr. Cuomo left many details vague, some perhaps purposely for political reasons, some perhaps because his staff has yet to work them out. For instance, it is not clear who could call for a countywide referendum on the school-tax issue. Would it be county legislators, county executives or school boards?
More important, who would establish the formula that would determine how the revenue would be distributed among various school districts in a county? Would it be the state, the county or the school boards? Would those formulas be required to equalize the distribution of money between rich and poor districts?
And what about the 100 or so school districts that cross county lines?
Mr. Cuomo's aides said they intended to answer those questions after consulting with state legislators and local officials.
 
An Uphill Battle
 The answers will determine the type of opposition Mr. Cuomo's proposal will face. School boards, for instance, are likely to fight any plan that reduces their control over raising or spending taxes.
Even in its vague form, Mr. Cuomo's plan faces an uphill battle. The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican from Nassau County, has said he would prefer that the income tax be raised statewide rather than county by county.
Many school administrators say that revenues from property taxes are more stable than income taxes and less likely to drop during a recession. And some have also questioned whether Mr. Cuomo's idea would indeed relieve the tax burden on the poor, the middle class and the elderly.

HEADLINE: 2 Economists See Recovery In New Jersey

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The recession in New Jersey may be over, according to a new report by Rutgers University economists, but even using the most optimistic forecast of job growth, they say, it will be 1999 before employment returns to 1989 levels.
New Jersey lost jobs in every category but services and government employment from 1989 through 1992, the report found. Moreover, the slump eroded white-collar jobs in the usually robust wholesale and retail trades and in financial and real-estate services. Those job categories once seemed recession proof and in fact grew during the brief recession of 1981-82. 
 Getting back to 1989 levels by 1999 would require adding 50,000 jobs annually, which has been the average annual growth since World War II.
"This is a grim look back but it is not a grim look ahead," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics and vice present for academic affairs, who wrote the report with James W. Hughes, professor of public planning. It is part of a series of Rutgers reports on the state's economy.
 
Heady '80's 'Not Returning'
 "My caveat is that the recovery is going to be modest, and the heady times we saw in the mid-80's are not returning, which is perhaps all for the best," Professor Seneca said.
In Trenton today, the state's new director of economic recovery echoed that note of optimism, saying the economic situation was clearly not as bad as it has been.
Robert E. Hughey, named by Gov. Jim Florio last October to a one-year assignment as Chief of Economic Recovery, told a legislative committee that he expected growth in the state's economy "on the order of about 3 percent" over the next year, based on the predictions of economists.
"That's really very fast given where we have been for the past three years" Mr. Hughey said.
In the 1989-92 recession, the only nongovernment service jobs that showed strong growth were in health and social services.
The authors called the 1989-92 recession "a Texas-size debacle," because both Texas in the oil bust of the early 1980's and New Jersey in this recession lost 8.7 percent of their employment total, or about one job in 12.
That is not as bad as Massachusetts, the Rutgers report found. During roughly the same period as the New Jersey recession, Massachusetts lost 11.5 percent of its total employment, or one job out of nine. Connecticut fared about the same as Massachusetts, losing 11.7 percent of its total employment during the recession. Similar figures of New York State were not yet available.
