HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Fall to a 44-Month Low

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
First-time claims for state unemployment insurance tumbled during Christmas week to the lowest level in more than three years, the Labor Department said today.
The unexpected decrease of 40,000 claims, to a seasonally adjusted 291,000 in the week ended Dec. 26, followed a revised drop of 29,000, to 331,000, a week earlier. The previous week's report initially showed a decline of 28,000, to 332,000. 
 The latest weekly level of claims was the lowest since April 22, 1989, when it was also 291,000, a Labor Department spokeswoman said.
Economists generally view the volatile weekly number with some skepticism, however, preferring the four-week moving average. But that average decreased by 8,500 claims, to 332,500, the lowest since September 1989.
"Christmas might have thrown some static, but these numbers have been improving week after week," said Mike Dancey, a trader at the Brokers Resource Corporation in Chicago. "Things are improving."
Although the numbers signal that layoffs continue to taper off as the economy gains strength, a workweek shortened by the Christmas holiday also contributed to the decrease in claims, the government statistics showed.
"If we wash all this through the machinery, I'd say we'd come out with a 5,000 decline in real terms," said Marco Babic, an economist at Evans Economics in Washington. "I think most of it is holiday related."
Twenty-nine states and territories reported decreases in jobless claims in the latest reporting week, led by California and North Carolina. Twenty-four reported increases, led by Wisconsin and Puerto Rico.
The Labor Department also said the number of people receiving benefits in the week ended Dec. 19 decreased 20,000, to 2.75 million, the lowest since October 1990.
The Labor Department also said that 27,430 workers in 50 states and territories filed emergency claims under a separate program providing extended jobless benefits.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Free Agents and the Ratings Pie

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Is free agency in the National Football League NBC's hope for a brighter future? Will an influx of big-name National Conference players to the American Conference tilt the ratings balance from historically dominant CBS to NBC?
It has been 17 seasons since NBC, the A.F.C. network, earned higher Nielsen ratings than CBS, the N.F.C. network. Back in 1975, NBC won the ratings game, 14.2-14.0, after winning, 14.0-13.7, in 1974. Those were the network's only victories. 
 Ever since, the closest NBC has come to CBS was losing, 15.3-15.0, in 1980. (In those days, each rating point represented 685,000 television households. Today, each rating point equals 931,000 TV households.)
Most of CBS's historic ratings dominance has to do with geographic market size. The N.F.C. has teams in larger markets, which help CBS's ratings even when the cities' teams are not Super Bowl contenders.
The N.F.C. has the only teams in Chicago, San Francisco, Washington, Philadelphia and Dallas, plus the only recently competitive team in New York. There is no offsetting balm for NBC in knowing that the A.F.C.'s strength lies in markets with playoff teams like Buffalo, Miami and Pittsburgh.
And when it loses important A.F.C. games such as Buffalo-Houston to ESPN, as it did on the final Sunday night of the season, the peacock network could just plotz.
"In the 1970's at CBS, we used to dream about the days when the Bears, Eagles, Giants and Redskins would all be good at the same time," said Kevin O'Malley, a former CBS official who is now senior vice president of Turner Sports.
The best potential news for NBC came Wednesday when the league and the players agreed on a seven-year labor agreement that gives veteran players true free agency. From March 1 to July 15, more than 250 players -- except for those designated as "franchise players" -- will be eligible to negotiate with any team.
Imagine if the bulk of the elite N.F.C. free agents defected to A.F.C. teams (and A.F.C. teams suffered a lesser corresponding talent drain) bringing in players like Eagles defensive end Reggie White, Packers wide receiver Sterling Sharpe, Giants linebacker Carl Banks, Redskins receivers Art Monk and Gary Clark and Redskins linebacker Wilber Marshall.
"What a wonderful prospect," said Terry O'Neil, executive producer of NBC Sports.
Would such an interconference migration narrow the ratings chasm between CBS and NBC, which finished the regular season at 13.0-11.2? Would watching Reggie White in Jets green or Carl Banks in the Browns' Dog Pound make a difference?
O'Neil isn't certain. The relatively greater success of NBC in the 1970's, he said, was attributed more to the overall appeal of the Steelers, Dolphins and Raiders, not individual player allure.
Any marquee-player movement that favored the A.F.C. would have to be one element in conference-wide improvement that would chip away, not overcome, the N.F.C.'s natural advantage in market size.
"We're waiting for the cycle to reverse, but you need to see it reverse itself on the field," said O'Neil. "One player doesn't make that big a difference."
Until any infusion of N.F.C. talent resuscitates A.F.C. ratings on NBC, O'Neil is content to nurture his network's underdog status and wait for days when strong N.F.C. teams play A.F.C. teams. (NBC televises the games when the visiting team is from the A.F.C.)
"We get to use their strength against them," he said.
The significance of any N.F.C.-to-A.F.C. power shift may pale in importance with the anticipated leap in the cost of signing free agents. That uptick will come at a time when CBS, NBC, ABC, TNT and ESPN, already losing money on their $3.6 billion worth of contracts, want to pay less when the deals expire after next season.
N.F.L. owners made their financial situation less certain last year by rejecting a plan to slash 1993 rights fees by about $238 million and extend the deals at that level through 1995. Instead, the owners decided on a $28 million rollback in 1993 and to roll the dice on an improving economy.
But labor talks put off TV talks. "We haven't visited with the networks for three months," said the Cleveland Browns' owner, Art Modell, a key proponent of the rollback. "We have a new configuration of costs that we have to discuss among ourselves before we go to the networks."
It is possible, a person close to the situation who asked not to be named said, for owners to revisit the $28 million reduction for next year.
Ross Greenburg, the executive producer of HBO Sports, said: "The networks are the banks for the league and their revenues dictate what the owners have to spend. If one owner pays a player $5 million a year, it puts the whole system out of whack. I don't think TV money can support those kinds of salaries. They're all losing money now, without free agency."
Of course, Greenburg wants HBO to join the N.F.L.'s TV/banking fraternity, saying: "I'd hope we're looked on as a legitimate player, to help make up for the network shortfall."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Mass Moca, Round 2
The Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art has been given another chance. Last week, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts agreed to give the museum's Cultural Development Commission a six-month extension to raise $12 million. If it can come up with the money, the Governor said, he will release the $33 million approved by the State Legislature in 1988 to establish the museum in North Adams, Mass. Governor Weld temporarily froze the money after he took office in 1991.
So far, the commission has secured pledges of $4.1 million from individuals, corporations and foundations. The project, popularly known as Mass Moca, is billed as the world's largest museum of contemporary art, concentrating on works from the 1960's, 70's and 80's. The ambitious goal is to fill the abandoned Sprague Technologies plant in North Adams, a complex of 28 buildings on 13.5 acres. 
 "The Governor feels the commission should be able to have more time for fund-raising," said Ann Murphy, a spokeswoman for Mr. Weld. "This fall he visited the site, and although he realizes the potential economic stimulus it could provide to the Berkshires, he believes this has to be a joint public-private venture. Now the private sector has to come up with its end of the bargain."
Former Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis supported the project, authorizing almost $2 million for the master plan. Designed by a team of architects headed by Frank Gehry of Los Angeles, Robert Venturi of Philadelphia and David Childs of Skidmore Owings & Merrill in New York City, the 400,000-square-foot complex would include galleries, a cafe, art-related offices, a hotel and retail space. The commission estimates that the project would cost $70 million, attract 130,000 to 150,000 visitors a year, and provide employment and tourist income for North Adams, an economically depressed city of 17,000.
 
Wanted: A Partner
 "When the Governor took office, he asked the executive planning group of the Mass Moca Commission for three things before he would release the money," said Gary Schiff, the project manager. "The first was the $12 million in private funds; the second, to secure the building permits needed to proceed with the renovations, and the third, to hire an operator, a partner like the Guggenheim Museum, that would bring art to the table."
Mr. Schiff said the commission has obtained the local permits. It has also received statements of interest from three institutions that could run Mass Moca: the Guggenheim in Manhattan, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston and the Art Gallery of Ontario.
Mr. Schiff said the commission's first choice would be the Guggenheim, an obvious partner because Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director, was chairman of the original planning group for Mass Moca in 1985. In those days, Mr. Krens was the director of the Williams College Art Museum in nearby Williamstown, Mass.
A collaboration is also in keeping with the Guggenheim's ambitious plans to run satellite institutions that would use its permanent collection. "Like the Governor, we're watching the state of the economy and the amount of commitment to the project," said Michael Govan, the Guggenheim's deputy director. "We believe that Mass Moca is a valid concept that no museum provides: to properly exhibit the work of the last three decades."
Mr. Govan said the Guggenheim would seriously consider running Mass Moca if the proper resources were found. At this point, however, nothing is definite. The commission is to meet with Governor Weld on July 31 to review the project's progress. "It doesn't make sense to squash this now," Mr. Schiff said. "Not when it's gone this far."
 
Evening Viewings
 About 10 years ago, downtown department stores in various cities began staying open later to attract working customers and compete with shopping malls. Then museums began extending their hours to accommodate young professionals. So perhaps it should come as no surprise that a retail-minded auction house like Sotheby's would be next.
Sotheby's in New York is now offering viewing until 8 P.M. before certain sales. To make the event even more appealing, it will serve wine. The first late evening is scheduled for Monday, when the Old Master paintings and drawings go on view before sales on Wednesday and next Friday.
It would be logical to assume that this was an idea from Sotheby's chairman, the shopping-center magnate A. Alfred Taubman. But Diana D. Brooks, president and chief operating officer of Sotheby's, said the Old Masters department thought up the scheme. Inside every Old Masters sale catalogue is an elegant blue-trimmed card, inviting clients to the evening viewing.
"We're planning to try these later viewing hours for a number of departments and see how they work," Mrs. Brooks said. "The whole point is to try to be more accessible." She added that Sotheby's had many catalogue subscribers its staff didn't know personally and that the invitations were enclosed in the catalogues in the hopes of enticing them into the auction house.
Sotheby's has also been experimenting with Sunday sales. The first was held on Oct. 25, when Sotheby's auctioned American furniture, folk art and paintings in Manhattan. "We're doing another Sunday sale this month, too," Mrs. Brooks said, citing the Jan. 31 sale of American furniture in Manhattan.
Does Christie's plan to follow its rival? "Not at this point," a spokeswoman said.
Bets are, however, that it, too, will start burning the candle at both ends.
 
Freud and Acquavella
 The 70-year-old English realist painter Lucian Freud has switched galleries, leaving James Kirkman of London, who had been Mr. Freud's dealer for 20 years, for the William Acquavella Gallery in New York. It is an unusual choice, since the gallery does not usually represent living artists.
"He's the only artist I've taken on," said William Acquavella, the owner of the Manhattan gallery. "I've really never represented anyone, except years ago when I briefly took on some younger artists. But I like Freud as a painter, so I've committed to him. But he'll probably be the only one."
While Mr. Acquavella declined to discuss the details of the arrangement, he did confirm that he had purchased a large body of work from Mr. Freud's studio. "Right now he's working on large-scale pieces, which I think are the best he's ever done," Mr. Acquavella said. The gallery already has three.
Mr. Acquavella's timing is certainly right. A traveling exhibition of paintings, drawings and etchings done since 1980 is to open at the Whitechapel Art Gallery in London in September, then travel to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in December and to the Reina Sofia in Madrid in 1994.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Restraint and Ebullience In Cuban and Colleagues

BYLINE: BY ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
"Wifredo Lam and His Contemporaries, 1938-1952" is like a play whose two acts couldn't be more different. The first is slow and quiet, the second fast and loud; but together they form a dense, thought-provoking unit.
Downstairs at the Studio Museum in Harlem, restraint rules. Proceeding at an almost stately pace, the show focuses on the unfolding of Wifredo Lam's moody but gentlemanly art in the years just before, during and after World War II. Lam, who was born in Cuba of a Chinese father and a mulatto mother, went to Spain to study art in 1923, when he was 21, and to Paris in 1938, where he was befriended by Picasso and Andre Breton. He spent most of the years covered by this exhibition back in Cuba, driven there by the war in 1941, and during this time he integrated Cubist and Surrealist innovations with symbols and motifs of his own Afro-Cuban culture. 
 The works on display -- the best of which are on paper and date from the first half of the 1940's -- are often pale and light of touch. They feature Picassoid figures whose violently rearranged bodies and faces blend aspects of horse and human with hints of mysterious rites and rituals. Although Lam did not visit New York until 1948, he had one-man shows at the Pierre Matisse Gallery in 1942, '44 and '45. His efforts from these years are very much in step with, if not a little in advance of, the totemic images and mythical subjects of a number of North American artists whose style would soon be called Abstract Expressionist.
The high point here is the verdant blue-green "Jungle" from 1943, an enormous crowded painting on paper that groups five of Lam's hybrid beings against dense tropical foliage. Its proudly glaring figures look back to Picasso's "Demoiselles d'Avignon," while its shallow space and tightly rhythmic composition seem to presage Pollock's all-over drip paintings.
Upstairs, Lam's friends, acquaintances and contemporaries from Europe, the United States and Cuba hold forth. Here, the scene is charged, at times ebullient and almost raucously diverse, as an array of sensibilities both legendary and nearly unknown, respond to different strains of European modernism. Various Abstract Expressionists are on hand, including Pollock, Adolph Gottlieb, Robert Motherwell and Richard Pousette-Dart, as are Europe-based painters like Matta and Andre Masson, who waited out the war in the United States, and Victor Brauner and Oscar Dominguez, a Spanish Surrealist. Many of them are represented by fascinating paintings not often seen in New York.
The expressionist figuration of the Cobra group, which was formed in Belgium in 1948, and which shared Lam's belief in national styles, is briefly glimpsed in small paintings and watercolors by Asger Jorn, Constant and Karl Appel. And more than half the upstairs space here is devoted to the work of Lam's Cuban contemporaries, who abandoned academic training (often with the help of travel to Paris) for Cubism and Surrealism, sometimes adding heavy flavorings of folk art.
This section, which is spotty but in some ways the liveliest part of the show, is full of relatively unknown names and unfamiliar paintings. (Many of them belong to the Museum of Modern Art, which actively collected Latin American art in the 1940's and 50's.) Especially noteworthy are the bright, brashly confident Cubist works of Amelia Pelaez del Casals; "The Tornado," by Mario Carreno, which has a suave, faux-naivete similar to that of Raoul Dufy's work; "The Giadrunama and the Bird," by Luis Martinez-Pedro, an artist of dazzling graphic skills, and Rene Portocarrero's "Cerro Interior," which translates stained glass and tiled floors into a vibrant visual mosaic.
This is the second big Lam exhibition of the season, and it is better than the first, a retrospective of the artist's works on paper at the Americas Society in Manhattan last fall. In the earlier show, Lam's often wan images seemed overshadowed by inflationary wall texts. These touted him as a "decolonizer" who transcended and disrupted European modernism by infusing his art with a more authentic primitivism derived from his own cultural roots. But the visual evidence spoke of his debt to a range of artists, from Picasso to Matta.
The Studio Museum show takes a different tack, assembling stronger works and also removing Lam's art from the vacuum of theory. Specializing in wall texts that concentrate on identifying the Afro-Cuban sources of some of Lam's motifs, it demonstrates that the return to Cuba precipitated Lam's most original work. In addition, it simply places Lam's work in the diverse company of the art of his time, allowing viewers to compare and contrast and draw their own conclusions.
The chance to compare Lam's work with that of his Abstract Expressionist and Cuban contemporaries, in particular, sharpens one's appreciation of his achievement and his personality. Although his early 40's works seem especially prescient, in the second half of the decade, when Abstract Expressionism came into its own, Lam's art fell more heavily than ever under the spell of Picasso, in particular the tortured animal-human forms of "Guernica." The oddly arid, attenuated images from these years, which, tellingly, are on canvas not paper, forsake the lush plant forms of the Cuban landscape that inspired the artist when he first returned to his homeland. They seem adrift, as if the end of the war had refocused Lam's attention on Europe. In fact, he returned to Paris to live in 1952, dying there is 1982.
Compared to his Cuban contemporaries, Lam seems extraordinarily ambitious, determined to achieve an art of international stature. But he also comes across as inhibited, as if constricted or weighed down by this ambition, or by some intrinsic personality trait. Apart from a few images -- most notably "The Jungle," his small drawings and a tiny softly colored painting from 1948 titled "I Am Leaving" -- Lam seemed to keep all the different cultures he moved through at arm's length. His work is dignified and aloof, entirely consistent with the way this tall, rather priestly artist himself appears in photographs. But in the end it is also more admirable than satisfying, which is why you may find yourself enjoying this exhibition's second act a bit more than its first.
"Wifredo Lam and His Contemporaries, 1938-1952" remains at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, through April 11.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail from Wifredo Lam's "Jungle," at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

HEADLINE: The First, Faltering Steps Toward A Free Market

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Russia for Sale: The Rough Road to Capitalism" covers two turbulent years of Russia's staggerings toward a market economy, from 1990, when aspiring entrepreneurs were running into entrenched obstructionists, through the attempted coup by hard-liners in August 1991, up to the shaky ascendance of President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Sasha, a St. Petersburg steelworker and the central figure of a timely documentary on Sunday, is an enthusiastic supporter of Mr. Yeltsin. You can see him at work at two jobs and then giving blood to earn a few more rubles, at home in the unspacious but subsidized apartment where he lives with his wife and two sons, and on long lines with other shoppers. Sasha tells of his disillusionment with Communist Party promises -- "We've simply been cheated" -- and his faith in the democratic movement, with its goal of a free market. 
 The theme of the evening is the clash between the Yeltsin-style innovators and the party bosses who still run things. One wishful businessman focused on here, Volodya, spent nine months in prison for his efforts to become a capitalist. Whether he actually violated the law is not clear, in part because the laws, made for a wholly state-controlled economic system, are themselves far from clear when it comes to dealing with anything resembling an unfettered economy.
Many Russians, still faced with bare shelves in Government stores and out-of-reach prices in private markets, are not entranced by the new businessmen, whom they dismiss as shady operators with little concern for the general well-being. But prospects of profit seem to be dancing in many heads. By the end of this pro-Yeltsin hour, the police officer who arrested Volodya has set up his own private security business, staffed with those, like himself, who learned their job by cracking down on the emerging Volodyas and Sashas.
'Elvis, U.S.A.'
 TBS, tonight at 8:05
Tonight you can join Paul Provenza, a low-key comedian who looks a little like Robert De Niro, on an intermittently droll journey around the United States in a 1956 Cadillac convertible in search of the spirit of Elvis Presley. He finds it in forms like the Elvis Potato (Mr. Provenza is not able to attract much interest in a pumpkin that he says looks like Ed Asner); a piece of a carpet that Elvis may have stood on ("On, boy," Mr. Provenza says, "if only those stains could talk"); a roll of toilet paper said to have been stolen from Graceland, Elvis's home in Memphis, and other intimate artifacts like a wart that may once have been attached to Elvis and a promising toenail.
Mr. Provenza's bemused view of the phenomenon seems rational in the circumstances. He asks one of the innumerable Elvis imitators he encounters, "Why do you think this never happened to Robert Goulet?"
'Pole to Pole'
 A&E, Sunday at 8 P.M
On the subjects of journeys and Russia, the former Soviet Union is the destination in the opening hour of Michael Palin's eight-hour account of his travels from the North Pole to the South Pole without the help of the scheduled airlines. You can follow the good-humored, enthusiastic British actor and writer, last seen on A&E in "Around the World in 80 Days," from the top of the world down through Scandinavia by small plane, motorized sledge, icebreaker, fishing trawler, speedboat and other means of locomotion.
En route he discusses vegetarianism with a trapper in the middle of a snowy nowhere, swings from one ship to another on a hook, pans for gold, chats with Santa Claus and goes skinny-dipping after enduring an authentic Finnish sauna. The second hour, also on Sunday, at 9, finds him hastening to catch a ferry to Turkey. Next week he goes on to Egypt, and most of the rest of his journey will be through Africa. It's a vigorous and colorful trip, and Mr. Palin makes agreeable company if you can keep up with him.
'Families Divided'
 'A Day in Court'
 Court TV, Sunday at 8 P.M.
Carrying on its expanding mission of exploring legal issues through significant trials, Court TV offers an hourlong review of the case of a 12-year-old from Florida who sued to end his relationship with his biological parents. The trial, which received considerable attention, including gavel-to-gavel coverage by Court TV, in September, led to a shift in legal assumptions about the rights and duties of parents and children.

HEADLINE: Hockey;
Rangers' Plight Falls On Captain Dad Now

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Captain Dad knows best. He is stern but merry, kindly and brave, leads by example playing hard and hurt; you would follow him through fire on ice because he's always right or, even better, because he relieves you of the responsibility to think for yourself.
But when Captain Dad fails to deliver, he takes all the blame; his shame is worse than his honor. 
 There have been two games since Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, became Dad on Monday. The tie with the New Jersey Devils, a good team struggling, and the rout of the Ottawa Senators, a poor team dying, offered no sure clues to the outcome of Messier's gamble: in its twilight, he has put the image of his career on the line.
It was no compulsive gesture; the scenario and his personality dictated it. He had been brought to New York as the frozen chosen, a man with four Stanley Cup rings who knew how to win. He skated like a winner, chilly-eyed, confident; off the ice, the cant of his body and the controlled tension of his voice were reminiscent of generals' at press briefings.
The struggle for control of the team between Messier and Coach Roger Neilson did not become critical until the Rangers collapsed in the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Even a winning hockey team is not really the family you wish you had, but a losing team or a team that has lost its way is a nightmare family from hell, a jittery jumble of blamethrowers.
There's blame enough for all. Neilson, reserved, cerebral, was a stereotypical football coach -- videotape-head, chess-player, control freak -- for a team that needed a basketball coach -- a creative consultant, a manipulative salesperson who made each player feel significant and stretched. Neilson was sure to have problems with Messier, an aging, battered warrior-prince who had played in the shadow of the Great Gretzky and wanted to be the hero of a team of his own.
And Messier, for all his superstar aura -- typically, Eric Lindros as a junior player made his locker a grotto of Messier photos -- did not necessarily feed the potential of others. He centered a line that included his personal bodyguard, Adam Graves, and an emerging marksman, Tony Amonte, and because of his infirmities rarely pulled his weight on defense.
There are players on the Rangers, Brian Leetch, Mike Gartner, James Patrick, now the Russians, who in their ways are as interesting performers as Messier. They have done well, but perhaps not flowered as much as they might under a system that made Messier the hub of the wheel. He is, after all, the essential Canadian hard-core gunner (Gordie Howe was another), cold, mean, efficient, constantly hooking, pushing tripping, brilliantly alert to opportunity.
But it is Messier as team leader, party host, moral beacon, big brother, that makes the muckers and grinders moist. Perhaps more than any other major sports team members, hockey players revel in their brotherhood of hard men -- like hunters and firefighters and soldiers on the line -- whose talk of macho and single-minded discipline often borders on authoritarianism.
That traditional hockey esthetic may be changing now as the game seems poised to follow the National Basketball Association into a new world of marketing, expansion, internationalism, television. The waves of gifted, flashy American, Russian and European players are making the game more exciting and accessible to people who didn't skate to school. The new franchises representing Blockbuster Video and Disney World may vote differently from the old boy Canadians.
Paramount's current desperation for a winning Ranger team is not a response to their ever-loyal fans but to the coming new order in hockey. New York teams can no longer assume they will be their leagues' flagship franchises. There are too many truly major league cities in North America now. The Rangers cannot afford to be a failure when it's morning in The Rink.
Even though Messier represents the old order, it made far more immediate strategic, economic and public-relations sense to dump Neilson; after all, Madonna had never considered Roger a boy-toy. But the fans are waiting to be shown; they booed Messier at the Garden the other night.
Maybe the booing was just a casual sympathy vote for Neilson, who was heading home to Canada with his best friend, the cancer-riddled 14-year-old Labrador, Mike. Roger wanted to get home before Mike died, so he could be put down and buried in his native soil.
Or maybe the booing was really for Mess, a man clutching and grabbing at his time, a man who doesn't hit people much anymore, and when he does they don't always notice.
The rest of the season will be Messier's failure or triumph. In 10 days, Messier will turn 32, old for a hockey player, not necessarily old for the lead in the continuing Ranger sitcom, which will be called either Captain Dad or Father Knew Worst.

HEADLINE: Boating;
This Year at Javits Center, Industry Stages Variety Show

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
It is considered a marine trade exhibition, but the New York National Boat Show this year is offering enough sideshows to fill a circus tent.
The event, in its 83d year, is scheduled to open officially tomorrow at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 11th Avenue between 34th and 39th Streets. It is open for a sneak preview today for anyone willing to pay $20 for a ticket, compared with the regular $8 admission price for an adult. 
 With as many as 1,000 recreational boats filling an area the size of six football fields, the show, designed as a kind of marketing barometer on anticipated sales for the upcoming boating season, has plenty of browsing potential. But added to the marine lineup, which includes thousands of boating accessories, will be many other exhibits designed to educate and entertain showgoers.
For instance, there will be an indoor pond, measuring 25 feet by 50 feet, for radio-controlled model boats, which visitors will be able to operate. Several world-class fishing experts will offer seminars on fresh-water and saltwater techniques. And instructors will conduct a water-ski clinic. An exhibit of antique boats will include a 1939 hydroplane once raced by Guy Lombardo.
Ninety percent of the new boats on display will be powerboats. While the New York show usually emphasizes power rather than sail, the concentration this year is heavier than usual. Many sailboat manufacturers have chosen to show their wares instead at Sail Expo, a new exhibition scheduled for Feb. 4-7 in Atlantic City.
In an effort to woo sailing enthusiasts to the New York show, organizers have set up Sail Pier 34, an indoor floor area where sailboats will be tied up at a waterfront dock.
The boating industry has been hit hard by the recession. Since 1988, the last lucrative year in the marine industry, when sales totaled $18 billion, sales have declined by 45 percent. Nevertheless, people in the marine industry appear to be taking a more optimistic view this year.
"With the economy coming back, I'm looking for increased attendance at the show," said Michael Duffy, the New York show's manager. He noted that ticket sales in recent years, which he declined to reveal, have been off as much as 20 percent from the boom years of the late 1980's.
Exhibit space at the New York show, which extends through Sunday, Jan. 17, is sold out this year, Duffy said.
For information on the show, telephone (212) 216-3616.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Confirmation Roundup;
Reich Charts a Path to Return the Labor Dept. to Center Stage

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

 BODY:

Federico F. Pena
Secretary of Transportation
WASHINGTON (Special to The New York Times) -- Federico F. Pena, the Transportation Secretary-designate, put himself at odds with budget cutters in the Clinton Administration when he said that money now used to keep the deficit down should be spent on public works. 
 Mr. Pena told the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation that the Aviation Trust Fund, which is financed by a tax on airline tickets, has a $7.5 billion surplus and said the money should be used to build and renovate airports and to modernize air traffic-control systems. That is the original purpose of the trust fund, but for more than a decade its surpluses have gone unspent to avoid increasing the deficit. Mr. Clinton's top budget officials have repeatedly described budget reduction as their top priority.
Anticipating Mr. Pena's battles with Mr. Clinton's budget cutters, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the committee, told Mr. Pena to leave immediately for Little Rock. "They're picking your pockets right now," Mr. Hollings said.
Mr. Hollings predicted that his committee would approve Mr. Pena's nomination next week and send it to the floor for swift approval.
Mr. Pena described his goal as a public-private "partnership." Jim Landry, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the airline industry, said that although he welcomed this approach, "U.S. airlines also need some immediate tax and regulatory relief that must be addressed if we are to put a stop to the layoff notices for airline employees."
Mr. Pena said that re-regulation of the airline industry was "not on my radar." He endorsed a proposal by Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of United Air Lines, who on Wednesday called for a national commission to study the beleaguered airline industry, which has lost $8 billion since 1990. United announced on Wednesday that it would eliminate 2,800 jobs in an economy effort.
"We need to bring the best minds that we can to look at this, and come up with some solution," Mr. Pena said.
On other issues, Mr. Pena endorsed tougher fuel-economy standards, high-speed trains and the use of public pension funds to build and modernize parts of the transportation system. "If you structure a program carefully, so that it's a sound investment, I think there's a way to make that work," he said.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
At Wits' End: Algonquinites in Hollywood

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
BY 1935, Dorothy Parker had abandoned the life of a New York sophisticate for that of a Hollywood screenwriter, but the sunshine did nothing to mellow her caustic outlook. As she wrote in a letter back east to Alexander Woollcott, her friend from the old days of the Algonquin Round Table, "Aside from the work which I hate like holy water, I love it here." It was the kindest thing she ever said about writing for the movies.
About the same time, George S. Kaufman, the quintessential Broadway playwright, wrote to a friend, "I'm going to Hollywood, God damn it, this Saturday, but only for a few weeks." He was true to his word, which went a long way toward saving his self-respect. 
 For while Parker, Kaufman, Woollcott and Robert Benchley -- the core group of writers who gathered daily for lunch at the Algonquin Hotel in the 1920's -- were not big on matters of faith, there were a few things they deeply believed in: wit, fame and the fundamental truth expressed in a telegram from their pal Herman Mankiewicz. Soon after arriving in Hollywood as a screenwriter, Mankiewicz cabled Ben Hecht: "There are millions to be grabbed out here and your only competition is idiots. Don't let this get around."
The Algonquinites hated Hollywood, but that doesn't mean they weren't good at it. The proof is in "Tales of the Algonquin Round Table," a deliciously entertaining, extravagant series running at the Film Forum in the South Village from today through Feb. 18. The series includes about 50 features connected (sometimes in a glancing way) to the Algonquinites: great Hollywood valentines like "Dinner at Eight"; arty eccentricities like "The Scoundrel," with Noel Coward as the supercilious title character; the early screwball comedy "Laughter," and several programs of classic Benchley shorts, comic lectures like "How to Sleep" and "The Sex Life of the Polyp." All demonstrate that the Algonquin writers contributed richly to the movies in spite of themselves.
"The Ten-Year Lunch," Aviva Slesin's 1987 documentary (shown at matinees this weekend), offers a vivid introduction to the pre-Hollywood Round Table. They were journalists when they started out: Woollcott, the most influential drama critic of his day; Kaufman, the drama editor of The New York Times; Robert Sherwood, a film critic whose work pre-dated talkies; Benchley and Parker and Donald Ogden Stewart, essayists and critics for various magazines. They ate together, worked together and, most important, quoted each other's remarks in print, and so became famous for being famously witty.
In "The Ten-Year Lunch," you can find the Round Table's best and best-known lines. Playing one of the word games the group loved, Parker was asked to use "horticulture" in a sentence and said, "You can lead a whore to culture but you can't make her think."
By 1929, the Round Table had disbanded, partly because so many had become successful on Broadway or, more frequently, in Hollywood.
Some, like Kaufman, took the movie money and ran. Though he worked on some film scripts -- notably, "A Night at the Opera," having co-written "The Cocoanuts" and "Animal Crackers" for the Marx Brothers on Broadway -- most of Kaufman's contributions to Hollywood came from the constant stream of hit plays he co-wrote, then surrendered to Hollywood studios and writers.
Several films based on his plays -- "Dinner at Eight," "The Royal Family of Broadway," "The Man Who Came to Dinner" -- are social satires that cozy up to the rich, only to discover that they are as wonderfully foolish as poor folk. (That, basically, is what the Algonquinites did in life, too.) But there is a refreshing current of cynicism in everything Kaufman touched. It was he, after all, who suggested that Irving Berlin change the line "I'll be loving you always" to "I'll be loving you Thursday."
"The Man Who Came to Dinner" (to be shown this weekend) was written by Kaufman and Moss Hart because they had promised Woollcott a play for him to star in. They created Sheriden Whiteside, a Woollcott clone and self-important curmudgeon, who breaks a hip while on a lecture tour and takes over the house and lives of his nouveau riche host. As it happened, on stage and screen Monty Wooley played Whiteside with a great deal more heart than the insufferable Woollcott might have.
At least that's the conclusion to be drawn from seeing Woollcott on screen in the 1934 short "Mr. W.'s Little Game" (on a later program with "The Man With Two Faces," based on a Kaufman-Woollcott play). It isn't much of a film, but it is a fascinating biographical footnote. Playing himself, Woollcott sits in a restaurant and instigates a word game that he is certain, with his superior intellect, to win. His competitor is a blonde he calls Little Miss Birdbrain. Whatever charms Woollcott had in life -- and he was said to be generous as well as insulting and vicious -- they fail to come through on screen. His writing seems dated and shallow today, and the petty personality behind "Mr. W.'s Little Game" suggests why.
Woollcott usually stayed far away from the movies, but Hollywood has its revenge on the cautious Kaufman. When the actress Mary Astor was embroiled in an ugly custody suit, her ex-husband leaked parts of her diary to the press. There in print was the evidence of her love affair with Kaufman, including the detail that she considered him a "perfect" lover. Kaufman was in Hollywood when he was summoned to court in the case, but he escaped by hiding out in Moss Hart's house, then on Irving Thalberg's yacht, and then by sneaking onto a train back East, still on the lam.
The Astor diary was a tabloid scandal for weeks, and Kaufman was mortified. So you have to wonder why the only film Kaufman ever directed, a dozen years later, was a comedy about tabloids competing to get their hands on a scandalous diary. In "The Senator Was Indiscreet" (1947), William Powell plays a genially corrupt Senator. "There's an old saying in my state," the Senator says. "If you can't beat 'em, bribe 'em." When he misplaces the dairy that recorded those bribes, tabloids scramble to find it, much the way they competed to publish the Astor diaries. Kaufman directs this without a wink at the audience.
As a film, "The Senator Was Indiscreet" is stiffly theatrical, with conspicuous painted backdrops. But as a satire (written by Charles MacArthur), it seems fresher than ever. Note the Senator's campaign banner that says: "Against inflation. Against deflation. For flation."
Kaufman obviously forgave Hollywood. Other Algonquinites like Parker and Benchley hated themselves for selling out their talent, and basically drank themselves to death.
Parker, who usually worked on scripts with her on-and-off husband, Alan Campbell, contributed little to movies that can be attributed to her with any certainty. Parker and Campbell wrote the screenplay for the 1937 version of "A Star Is Born," still a scathing look at Hollywood's destructive shallowness. But much of her work was additional dialogue and script doctoring. Much of the time, she wasn't sober. There is a story of Parker in Hollywood, weeping into her drink, "I used to be a poet."
Benchley was just as tortured. All his life he intended to write a historical book about Queen Anne, meaning to become a "serious" writer. He never knew that his contribution to the movies would remain enduring and wildly comic.
The dozens of shorts he began making in 1928 are parodies of lectures, with the ever-inept Benchley character explaining some banal experience. His discussion of "How to Start the Day" or "How to Behave" (when you're a houseguest, it doesn't pay to sleep till noon) are examples of deadpan wit at its best. In "Important Business," Benchley plays a businessman who tells his family and colleagues he is going to Washington on top-secret business. He actually goes to Washington, though he never gets beyond the train station. Self-importance was never so genially or sympathetically mocked.
The immense range and wealth of the Film Forum series comes with a catch: a broad definition of what the Round Table was, extending the group's reach to include peripheral members like Mankiewicz, Hecht and MacArthur. But Bruce Goldstein, the Film Forum's repertory programmer, has created this series with his usual savvy sense. His generous definition reveals that the wry, sophisticated Algonquin spirit was often best expressed on film by artists who were not charter members of the Round Table.
Hecht and MacArthur and Mankiewicz contributed far more to the movies than any of the true Algonquinites. Not coincidentally (and despite Mankiewicz's telegram), they were not so snobbishly hostile to Hollywood. Their lesser-known films offer some of the best surprises in this series.
Mankiewicz's script for "Ladies' Man" (1931), with William Powell as an unabashed gigolo involved with Carole Lombard and her mother, is a sharp, uncompromising period piece. The audience has no misconceptions about why the wealthy older woman allows Powell to sell her jewels and keep the cash. As in many films of the day, there is too much melodrama here; someone is always threatening suicide or pulling a gun to resolve romantic differences. But Mankiewicz's steely dialogue remains effective.
"If you're not going to marry me, I'll kill myself," Lombard tells Powell. "Are you going to marry me?"
Calmly, urbanely, Powell answers, "I don't think so."
Two little-known Hecht-MacArthur films are the most intriguing and cinematic in the series. In the mid-1930's, the team wrote, produced and directed several films, including "Crime Without Passion," in which Claude Rains plays a caddish lawyer who thinks he commits a murder out of jealousy. The film's editor, Slavko Vorkapitch, created a spectacular, surreal opening montage in which women representing the Furies fly up against New York skyscrapers while shattering glass falls around them. Later, as Rains tries to cover up his crime, he walks the streets mentally talking to himself in voice-over. There is an affection for the camera and the possibilities of film here that the true Algonquinites never possessed.
And the 1936 Hecht-MacArthur film, "The Scoundrel," may exemplify the Algonquin spirit best of all. Noel Coward, as a heartless, womanizing book publisher named Anthony Mallare, is the soul of cynical sophistication. Stepping out of the shower next to his office, Mallare tells his colleagues why he will not publish a sure best-seller. "It reeks of morality," he says contemptuously. "It's a vulgar way to swindle the public, selling them the things they least need -- virtue and dullness."
Mallare comes to reject -- through a laughable return from the dead -- his own cold-hearted life. "The Scoundrel" ends bizarrely, as if "It's a Wonderful Life" were grafted onto an Oscar Wilde play. But until then, it offers glimpses of the Algonquin Round Table at its worst and best. The worst is personified by Alexander Woollcott in a cameo role. As an author-friend of Mallare, Woollcott suggests all the chic, empty cynicism of his set.
But you can say this for the multi-talented Algonquinites: They were never virtuous and never dull. They might have taken that as a great compliment.

Who's Who at the Round Table
 Not every member (regular or occasional) of the Algonquin Round Table went to Hollywood. But here is a glimpse of those who did and are included in the Film Forum series:
ROBERT BENCHLEY: A humorist, critic and magazine writer. Benchley left New York behind for a lucrative career, starring in an immensely popular series of movie shorts. "How to Sleep" (1935) won an Academy Award.
MARC CONNELLY: A theater reporter turned playwright. Connelly was a true Algonquinite and George S. Kaufman's earliest collaborator.
EDNA FERBER: A Round Table regular. Ferber was one of Kaufman's best collaborators ("The Royal Family," "Dinner at Eight") and a novelist on her own ("Giant").
GEORGE S. KAUFMAN: He wrote only one play on his own, but with various collaborators Kaufman became one of the most successful playwrights and directors in Broadway history. He directed the original "Guys and Dolls," and some say he wrote Groucho Marx's best lines.
BEN HECHT: A peripheral Algonquinite. Hecht was a Chicago newspaperman turned playwright and an immensely talented screenwriter. With Charles MacArthur he wrote such Broadway and Hollywood classics as "The Front Page" (directed on stage by Kaufman) and "Twentieth Century."
RING LARDNER: A sportswriter and short-story writer on friendly terms with the Round Table.
CHARLES MACARTHUR: Like his partner Ben Hecht, MacArthur was a newspaperman turned playwright and screenwriter. He and his wife, Helen Hayes, sometimes dropped by the Round Table.
HERMAN J. MANKIEWICZ: Once Kaufman's assistant in The New York Times's drama department, in Hollywood Mankiewicz became a prolific screenwriter and producer. He co-wrote "Citizen Kane" (how much was his and how much Orson Welles's is a subject of endless dispute).
ALICE DUER MILLER: A sometime Algonquinite. She wrote the poem "The White Cliffs of Dover."
DOROTHY PARKER:Famous as a poet, short-story writer and wit ("Men seldom make passes/At girls who wear glasses" is hers). Parker published several books before heading to Hollywood. By the 1930's she was already in a steep decline, though she lived until 1967.
ROBERT E. SHERWOOD: An original Algonquinite, and a great friend and colleague of Parker and Benchley at Vanity Fair. Sherwood began writing plays seriously ("The Petrified Forest" and "Waterloo Bridge") only after he walked away from the Round Table.
DONALD OGDEN STEWART: A humorist and essayist. Stewart was a Round Table member who became one of Hollywood's sharpest screenwriters (including "Holiday" and "The Philadelphia Story," both based on Philip Barry's plays, and the early screwball comedy "Laughter.") His Hollywood career ended when he was blacklisted.
JAMES THURBER: The great New Yorker writer, cartoonist and all-around satirist. His path crossed that of the Round Table.
ALEXANDER WOOLLCOTT: The Algonquin Round Table started at a lunch in Woollcott's honor in 1919, and he was always at the group's center. His drama criticism (first for The New York Times, then for The New York Herald and The World) made him a Broadway power. He went on to do radio shows and commercial endorsements, and actually appeared on tour in "The Man Who Came to Dinner," whose lead character was based on him. CARYN JAMES

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Weekend on Friday, with an article about the Algonquin literary crowd and Hollywood, misidentified the actress shown with Claude Rains in a scene from "Crime Without Passion." She was Margo; Carmen Brown was the name of the character she played.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Hoving's Adventures At the Met

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
Making the Mummies Dance By Thomas Hoving Illustrated. 448 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25. 
In "Making the Mummies Dance," his bizarre, nasty and ultimately disheartening account of his stormy 10-year reign as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Thomas Hoving gloats about a bit of heads-up detective work. He writes that as a candidate in 1966 for the directorship, he discovered, unbeknownst to museum officials, that "the relentless State Commissioner for Human Rights, Eleanor Holmes Norton, was preparing to hit the museum with a series of legal charges alleging massive abuses in the hiring practices and promotions of women employees." His "shocker," he recalls, stunned the trustees, and he implies that it helped him to win the job.
 This anecdote is vintage Hoving for its combination of skulduggery, one-upmanship, bravado and unreliability. In 1966, Ms. Norton was working for the American Civil Liberties Union and had no dealings with the museum; she never served as State Commissioner, although in 1971 she became chairwoman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights. Furthermore, according to the museum, no such investigation of hiring practices took place until 1971, during Mr. Hoving's own tenure; and then it involved the office of the New York State Attorney General, not Ms. Norton, who this week confirmed the inaccuracies of Mr. Hoving's story.
 Details, details. Mr. Hoving does not let them get in the way of this docudrama of a memoir, which, like the incident with Eleanor Holmes Norton, has little to do, in the end, with art, and sheds too little light on the running of a great museum.
 The author makes embarrassing art-historical blunders: he refers to frescoes by Verrocchio, although none exist by the artist; twice Mr. Hoving attributes a portrait by David to Ingres; he calls the artist Bramante, who was born near Urbino, a Florentine. And he packs his book with extensive and spicy quotations, many now at least 20 years old, by dozens of people, some of whom have since died, lots of whom sound suspiciously like Mr. Hoving: this, from someone who admits in his book that as director he "embellished the truth."
 Moreover, in skewering one enemy after another, Mr. Hoving comes across as having a chip on his shoulder the size of the Euphronius krater, that imposing ancient Greek pot of questionable provenance whose purchase by the Metropolitan caused one of the bigger brouhahas of his tenure. He calls one curator "something of a dunce" and accuses another of "a pattern of sloth and manipulation"; a trustee is written off as "a bumbling lightweight," while Charles and Jayne Wrightsman, consistent and remarkably generous supporters of the museum, although inconsistent supporters of Mr. Hoving, are described as "cardboard-thin, moving through life by rote."
 Yet the real problem with "Making the Mummies Dance" has to do not with its petty slipups, its spasms of revenge and its incredible anecdotes, but with the fact that the author has chosen to make such trivial matters the substance of his work.
 Mr. Hoving obviously knows the impact of his directorship was not trivial. With typical egotism, but in this case with some justification, he takes credit for "the most sweeping revolution in the history of art museums." Indeed, he is probably the most influential and innovative museum official of the postwar period, and the issues of his tenure from 1967 to 1977 are indeed sweeping and very much still alive.
 He by no means invented the idea of the blockbuster show, nor the notion of opening up art museums, partly through educational programs, to a wide public: the Museum of Modern Art, for one, was working along those lines decades before Mr. Hoving came along, and Frances Henry Taylor, as director of the Metropolitan during the 1940's and early 50's, strove to make the museum more accessible.
 But Mr. Hoving carried those ideas forward with extraordinary zeal, and from the bully pulpit of his position as director of the country's premier art museum he spread with extraordinary success the gospels of expansion and populism. The vast building programs, the stream of lavish loan exhibitions smartly designed like department store displays to broaden their appeal, the ambitious accompanying catalogues, the whole notion of the art museum as public spectacle -- which all came to characterize the museum world of the 1970's and 80's, but which in their way were outgrowths of 1960's thinking -- can be partly traced to Mr. Hoving and the groundbreaking Metropolitan Centennial celebrations organized by George Trescher under Mr. Hoving between 1969 and 1971.
 His legacy is immensely complicated, all the more so because his increasing fixation as director on banalities like museum shops and attendance figures tends to obscure the more idealistic and substantive aspects of his era. One thinks of his longtime rival, J. Carter Brown, who as head of the National Gallery of Art in Washington charted a much steadier course in masterminding grand, popular shows and a physical expansion program, but whose record of acquisitions -- the most enduring legacy a director leaves behind -- cannot compare.
 One also thinks of Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim Museum's current director and Mr. Hoving's heir as museum innovator and art-world lightning rod. Like Mr. Hoving, Mr. Krens gives the impression that he conceives of museums in terms of money and power and of artworks as commodities and prizes. But unlike Mr. Hoving, he has not also demonstrated (at least not yet) any eye, or genuine feel, for art.
 Mr. Hoving is an easy scapegoat for every excess of the museum world -- for the commercialism and overexpansion that followed in his wake -- and he makes himself all the more so by this once-over-lightly, tattletale memoir. But in fairness, he oversaw the organization of exhibitions of historic importance that combined widespread popularity with seriousness of purpose, like "19th-Century America," "Masterpieces of Tapestry" and "The Year 1200," as well as calamitous events like "Harlem on My Mind" (whose anti-Semitic catalogue introduction Mr. Hoving defends interestingly, although unpersuasively, in "Making the Mummies Dance").
 It's obvious, in retrospect, that the sale of art, or deaccessioning, that took place at the museum under Mr. Hoving was as disastrous and ill-managed as his critics at the time thought. But he also oversaw a renovation and expansion of the Metropolitan that transformed the institution from what was widely regarded as a dingy, sleepy place into a glittering palace, more coherently organized, with new wings for the Temple of Dendur, for Nelson Rockefeller's African, Oceanic and Mesoamerican art collection, for Robert Lehman's outstanding collection of Old Master and 19th-century paintings and drawings and decorative arts, and for all the other treasures that came into the museum's possession under Mr. Hoving.
 How curious, in retrospect, was the turmoil that the Metropolitan's expansion plan caused. Conservationists, alarmed about encroachment on Central Park, railed against it and especially against Mr. Hoving, a former Parks Commissioner whom they considered a turncoat. Politicians argued that the museum should, instead, disperse its holdings among the city's boroughs, an attempt to trump the populist director at his own game.
 Today, the idea of dispersal is widely discredited. And Central Park is undiminished. The downside of the expansion plan has to do with other matters, with the banality and pomposity of the architecture, with the mediocrity of Dendur, with the dubious deals that were cut, like the one allowing the Lehman collection to become a museum within the museum. When Mr. Hoving gets around in his book to analyzing the impact of expansion, after dozens of pages chronicling the wheeling and dealing that brought it about, he writes all of three paragraphs, acknowledging the drawbacks of the Lehman bequest, briefly noting the complaints of critics and asserting that the Grand Staircase should have been demolished, more escalators and elevators installed and a bigger garage built. He sums it up in a macho sound-bite: "If the master plan possesses one failing, it is not, as these critics suggest, that it is too big, but that it is too little and too cowardly."
So it goes throughout "Making the Mummies Dance." About deaccessioning, Mr. Hoving accepts blame for public-relations gaffes that included lying; but he does not debate the merits of the works that were sold, like a van Gogh whose value rose far beyond what the Metropolitan got for it, or like three Max Beckmanns whose sale drastically diminished the museum's German Expressionist collection. Nor does he debate the wisdom of having almost sold such works as a grisaille Odalisque by Ingres, which under Mr. Hoving was in storage but which lately has been revalued and put prominently on view. Had he engaged fairly in such debates, it would have been much harder for him to defend his actions. He eschews serious reflection as if fearful of boring readers whom he has enticed by juicy gossip. In this respect, the book is a fitting analog for the failures of his populist agenda, with its confusion of style for substance and of mass appeal for mass edification.
 Just how appealing the book will be, however, for the masses unfamiliar with Mr. Hoving's cast of characters and unconcerned with the minutiae, say, of his battle to construct a parking garage beneath the museum, is an open question. To insiders, on the other hand, it can be riveting, but in a morbid sort of way, as one waits for the next water balloon to drop on the head of one or another of Mr. Hoving's enemies.
 "Making the Mummies Dance" is in the end most revealing as a romp through Mr. Hoving's quirky mind. Just when one is thinking that the author is a cold, driven man given to dangerous extremes, he confesses that he's "a very hard, driving and cold man" who goes "overboard, which I tended to do more and more as the years went on." He admits that he has "never had close friends," he refers to himself as a toady, hypocrite and shark, and he quotes without rebuttal a colleague's criticism of him that he has a "craving for admiration and tendency to lapse into self-pity." He is disarmingly, almost touchingly, self-critical, and at times even tougher on himself than he deserves. He is as eager to trumpet his faults as his triumphs, because it is the trumpeting that seems to count, the need -- as it was when he was director, and even at the risk of self-sacrifice -- to "always be in the news."
His book provides, especially in its stories about organizing blockbusters, a number of timely parables about the pitfalls of glitz. But it mostly holds up a distorted lens through which everything in the museum world seems to depend on the director. Mr. Hoving, as he would clearly be the first to say, is a clever and complex man and there is a great and substantive book to be written about his years at the Metropolitan. "Making the Mummies Dance" is not it.

HEADLINE: Shannon McCune, 79, Educator, Geographer and Asia Expert, Dies

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Shannon McCune, an educator, geographer and specialist in Asian studies, died Monday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 79.
 His family said he died of congestive heart failure. 
Dr. McCune, a former president of the University of Vermont and provost of the University of Massachusetts, was an expert on the geography of the Far East. Besides his academic positions he was director of Unesco's education department in Paris and held several United States Government positions as an Asian expert.
 He served as the first civil administrator of Japan's Ryukyu Islands from 1962 to 1964, when the islands were under American military control. He returned to Okinawa, the main island, in 1970 with a research grant from the National Science Foundation.
 
Began Teaching in 1939
 He was born in Sonchon, Korea, the son of Presbyterian missionaries. He received a bachelor's degree from the College of Wooster, in Ohio, a master's degree from Syracuse University and a Ph.D. in geography from Clark University in Worcester, Mass., in 1939.
 Dr. McCune began his teaching career in 1939 at Ohio State University. In 1947 he went to Colgate University as chairman of the geography department, where he remained until 1955.
 He was provost of the University of Massachusetts from 1955 to 1961. In 1965 he was named president of the University of Vermont, but resigned in 1966 to do research for the university in the Far East.
 Dr. McCune was director of the American Geographical Society of New York from 1967 to 1969. He then went to the University of Florida in Gainesville as a professor and chairman of the geography department, retiring in 1979.
 
Won Medal of Freedom
 He served with the Foreign Economic Administration in India, Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) and in China, for which he won the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1946, and was educational consultant to a United Nations development mission in the Indonesian province of West Irian in 1967.
 In addition to scores of articles and monographs on Asian geography, Dr. McCune was the author of several books, including "Korea's Heritage, a Regional and Social Geography," published in 1956 by the Charles E. Tuttle Company in Rutland, Vt.; "Korea: Land of Broken Calm," published in 1966 by the Van Nostrand Company in Princeton, N.J., and "The Ryuku Islands," published in 1975 in England.
 He is survived by his wife, the former Edith Blair; two daughters, Antoinette Bement of Jamaica, Vt., and Shannon Wagner of Pittsburgh; a son, George Blair McCune of Anchorage, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Taking the Big Plunge Into the Sea of Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Call them the investments of the 90's.
Millions of people have discovered that mutual funds are a simple, low-cost way to own stocks and bonds. The funds allow investors to minimize their risks by spreading their money among many securities. They are easy to buy and sell and, perhaps most important, they give buyers an investment edge because the money they put into funds is managed by professionals. 
 With those advantages, it is not surprising that one in four Americans now owns shares in mutual funds, and their number is growing as people abandon certificates of deposit and other forms of insured savings that now offer low interest rates.
In 1992 some investors struck gold in funds. The top-performing fund, Fidelity Select Savings and Loan, soared 57.8 percent in value. Second- place Oakmark gained 48.5 percent, and third-place Fidelity Select Regional Banks, 48.6 percent. But there was bad news, too. Lexington Strategic Investments, 1992's worst performer, plummeted a dizzying 60.7 percent.
To help investors pick winners, The New York Times is publishing a table today showing the 1992 performance of more than 3,000 stock and bond funds. The table, which begins on Page 37, identifies funds by the kinds of securities they invest in and also gives their performance over the last five years. A second table lists average returns for more than 80 different kinds of funds, so you can compare a fund's performance with how well its peers are doing.
These tables provide the information you need to get started in funds. If you are new to the game, and apprehensive, relax -- you are not alone. More than half of the new customers calling Fidelity Investments about mutual funds described themselves as investment beginners, Fidelity found in a recent survey. So did a quarter of their existing investors. Lack of confidence about making investment decisions isn't confined to novices or young people. While they are older than 50, on average, only 24 percent of Fidelity's customers described themselves as experienced.
So let's start from the beginning. Behind the hype is this reality: a mutual fund is simply a way to let a small investor behave like a big investor. Funds, called investment companies, pool your money with other people's and use it to buy stocks, bonds and other securities. Investors own shares in the fund proportionate to the amount they invest. Each share represents ownership of part of the fund's underlying securities, and share prices are based on the current value of the fund's holdings. If the value increases (or drops), the fund's share price rises (or falls).
Fund investing is convenient. You can do business by mail or by telephone. Most funds let you automatically reinvest dividends, a good way to save systematically. (A system called dollar cost averaging, investing the same amount of money regularly, can reduce the average cost of your shares over time.) Because fund shares are priced daily, you always know what your investments are worth, and you can sell out at any time, just as you can with stocks. Many funds belong to families of stock, bond and money market funds, so you can build a balanced group of funds with one company.
Of course, funds are not without their own set of problems. Gains may be shaved by high expenses and up-front charges, or loads. Not all the professional managers of the funds are prudent and prescient, and some have lost money for their investors. Moreover, members of investment clubs for many years have been reaping rich rewards by taking the risk of putting money into individual stocks and bonds. And late last year, in a rather startling opinion, Peter Lynch, former manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund and arguably the best mutual fund manager ever, suggested that investors might be better off picking their own stocks.
So with those caveats in mind, people who want to begin picking funds should first get a grasp of the concept of investment risk. The goal is to match the fund's risk level to your own.
There are three basic types of risk. Market risk is the risk that the value of your investment will decline. Credit risk is the risk that a bond issuer will not pay the interest owed or the principal amount at maturity. Inflation risk is the risk that when you sell, the dollar you get back may be worth less than the dollar you invested. And remember that no fund is insured like a bank deposit.
One basic rule applies to all investments: the greater the risk, the greater the potential reward. Conversely the less risk you take, the smaller your potential return. No investments are risk-free -- even federally insured bank accounts are vulnerable to inflation risk.
Investors were spoiled during the 80's, an unusual time when low-risk investments like bank accounts and certificates of deposit paid hefty yields. Today those yields have evaporated, forcing investors into higher-risk alternatives.
How much risk should you take? That depends largely on how long your money will be invested. The more time you have, the more risks you can afford because historically the stock market has risen in spite of temporary declines.
Before moving onto the where's and how's of buying funds, you should learn about asset allocation, a fancy word for dividing your money among a variety of investments to reduce risk. Think about splitting your holdings among several types of stock and bond funds and also consider investing overseas as well as in the United States.
Investors who enjoy researching the market can save money by buying shares in no-load funds directly from the company. You pay no sales charge but still pay fund administrative expenses, of course.
Start by finding funds with good five-year records in the tables. Consistent performance from year to year is important; it's risky to buy a fund based on one good year's performance because it may not be repeated. Funds are ranked by "total return," which measures changes in share price plus income.
 
For Further Information
 You can get more information in reference works like Morningstar Mutual Fund Sourcebook or Standard & Poor's/Lipper Mutual Fund Profiles, which your local library may own.
Most fund companies have toll-free telephone numbers (call the toll- free directory at 1 800 555-1212). Trained telephone representatives can answer questions from whether the fund manager who built the track record is still there (always ask!) to how to fill out forms to open the account.
Otherwise, you can buy funds through stock brokers or financial planners, who are compensated by the load, or sales charge, levied by about two-thirds of all funds. Low-loads charge from 1 to 3 percent, mid-loads, 4 to 6 percent of the amount invested. Paying a load reduces your return because less of the money you invest buys fund shares. Loads are not included in the returns listed in the table.
Every fund has an investment objective that the fund manager works toward. These are designated by the abbreviations used in the tables.
 
Riskiest of Funds
 The riskiest of the five major types of stock funds are capital appreciation funds. Next are small-company funds, this year's winner with a gain of 12.5 percent. Then come growth funds, which invest in stocks of more established companies.
Growth-and-income funds aim for capital appreciation plus income by owning high dividend-paying stocks plus some bonds. So do equity-income funds, which focus more on yield.
Specialty funds invest in narrow sectors like health care or gold stocks. Because of that, they shine when the markets favor their sector and sink when it doesn't. In 1992, financial services funds gained 35.3 percent, for example, while gold funds fell 14.6 percent. But top performers over longer periods usually are the more diversified growth funds.
Hybrid funds combine stocks and bonds in varying proportions. Balanced funds usually own 60 percent stocks, 40 percent bonds while flexible funds shift the proportions.
Bond funds are staples for investors who want income. Along the spectrum of credit risk, government bond funds are least risky. Next come high-quality corporate bond funds and then junk bond funds.
Because rising interest rates push down bond prices, short-term bond funds carry the least amount of market risk, followed by intermediate- and long-term bond funds. The usual rule applies: the greater the risk, the higher the yield.
Expenses are critical in bond funds because returns move in narrower ranges than stock funds. Make sure your fund's expenses are in line.
Tax-free bond funds probably will soar in popularity if President-elect Clinton raises tax rates because the interest they pay is free of Federal taxes, and also may be free of state and local taxes. Remember, however, that capital gains are taxable.
