HEADLINE: TOP BOSNIAN AIDE IS SLAIN BY SERB

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Serbian nationalist troops besieging Sarajevo shot and killed a top official of the Bosnian Government today after halting a United Nations armored vehicle that was carrying him from Sarajevo airport into the city.
Members of a hard-line faction in the Government immediately announced that they would not return to peace talks with their Serbian nationalist opponents until they were given convincing assurances that the Serbs were genuinely seeking peace. 
 [ Alija Izetbegovic, the President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, said in New York that his Government was discussing whether "to withdraw the Bosnian delegation from the negotiations" in Geneva, The Associated Press reported. Speaking at Kennedy Airport, where he met with Vice President-elect Al Gore before returning to Bosnia, he said he didn't know whether a decision had been made.]
 
Appeal for Restraint
 The slain official, Hakija Turajlic, was one of three Deputy Prime Ministers of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, which has been struggling to survive a war with a secessionist army of Serbian nationalists. Mr. Turajlic was in charge of economic policy.
Gen. Philippe Morillon of France, the United Nations commander for Bosnia and Herzegovina, called the killing "one of the most detestable violations in this conflict."
General Morillon, fearing that the incident could provide the spark for a major Bosnian counteroffensive, appealed to both sides for restraint.
"It's a catastrophe," he said after an emergency meeting with the top officers of the 7,500-man United Nations military force. "I will try to convince everybody that it is perhaps not the reason to start the war again, but perhaps on the contrary a reason for everybody to understand that this tragedy has to stop as soon as possible."
The killing took place as Mr. Turajlic, 47 years old, was inside an armored personnel carrier belonging to the French marine battalion assigned to the United Nations forces. The vehicle, painted white and bearing the blue United Nations flag and insignia, was halted about 500 yards from the airport exit gate by two Serbian tanks and what General Morillon described as a force of 30 to 40 Serbian soldiers.
General Morillon said the Serbian troops demanded that the three French soldiers operating the vehicle hand over Mr. Turajlic. The soldiers radioed for help and were joined by the French officer who commands the airport, Col. Patrice Sartre. A confrontation lasting one hour and 45 minutes ensued, which ended with a Serbian soldier thrusting his automatic weapon over Colonel Sartre's shoulder and firing at Mr. Turajlic through the vehicle's open rear door.
The general said that Mr. Turajlic, who joined the Bosnian Government last year after serving as managing director of an industrial conglomerate in the former Yugoslavia, was struck by seven bullets, three in the chest, and died instantly.
General Morillon said that the Serbian soldiers withdrew from the scene immediately, and that Colonel Sartre, acting under United Nations rules of engagement that allow soldiers to open fire only to save lives, decided not to fire back.
General Morillon said Mr. Turajlic had requested a United Nations armored vehicle to take him to the airport, along a notoriously dangerous route that runs between Serbian and Bosnian front lines, when the United Nations headquarters was unable to make arrangements for a Turkish Government delegation to enter the city. The general said that the Turkish officials had arrived at the airport aboard a Turkish aircraft at lunchtime, with virtually no advance notice, and that United Nations officers had agreed to take Mr. Turajlic to meet the Turkish officials at the airport.
The Serbian troops rushed onto the road ahead of the United Nations vehicle as it returned to Sarajevo at 4:30 P.M., dusk in the Balkans at this time of year. General Morillon said the Serbian soldiers had told the French soldiers that they had seen the Turkish aircraft and knew that it had carried 150 Turkish troops to join the Bosnian forces in the defense of Sarajevo. General Morillon said the Turkish aircraft had carried relief supplies..
The general said that he had ordered an inquiry to establish several key points, including why the French marines, outnumbered 10 to 1, had not been reinforced during the protracted standoff by other soldiers from the French battalion that has its headquarters at an airport garrison that is within sight of the spot where the killing occurred. The general also said he wanted to know why the rear door of the armored vehicle had been opened, against normal procedures here. "I think it was because the Serbian soldiers wanted to inspect the vehicle for weapons," he said.
 
Following U.N. Guidelines
 The general said Colonel Sartre's decison not to call in more French marines followed established United Nations practice here. He said Serbian nationalist forces had repeatedly halted United Nations armored vehicles at gunpoint, ordered their doors opened and searched the vehicles, usually on the pretext that they were carrying arms for the Bosnian forces. Normally, the general said, such incidents are resolved without resort to force. "We are not prepared for such madness," he said.
"I have asked the Serbian side not only to arrest the author of this assassination, and they say he is under arrest, but also to arrest the commanding officer responsible for the decision that had these results."
For the United Nations force, the killing was the second major embarrassment in four days. On Tuesday, the operators of a home for the elderly that is only 750 yards from the United Nations headquarters on the embattled western edge of Sarajevo announced that 10 residents had died in 36 hours of the zero-degree cold that has settled over the Bosnian capital. Their deaths brought to 190 out of 302 residents at the home who have died since the Bosnian war began last April.
Employees at the home had appealed to United Nations commanders for help in evacuating the residents from the battle zone for at least four months, and, if evacuation was impossible, for wood-burning heaters to stave off the bitter Balkan winter. But because of what United Nations officials described as a failure of communications, nothing was done for the residents of the home apart from weekly deliveries of food supplies, even after all electricity in Sarajevo failed and cut off the home's only heating.
Even before the setbacks this week, the United Nations force here appeared to be in serious trouble. It has operated under a mandate that limits it to negotiation with the warring sides, and the rival factions have repeatedly taken advantage of this lack of military authority.
 
Blow for U.N. Commander
 General Morillon, 57, who took command of the force in September, appeared to take today's killing as a personal blow. The United Nations force has had 17 of its own men killed, many of them by mortar and sniper fire from Serbian or Bosnian troops around Sarajevo.
But General Morillon, like his predecessor, Maj. Gen. Lewis W. Mackenzie of Canada, has consistently spoken out against the alternative to the United Nations peacekeeping force, which many believe should include Western military intervention.
General Morillon named the officer commanding the Serbian troops who carried out the killing as Gen. Stanislav Galic, a top commander of the Serbian fighters in Bosnia and Herzegovina, most of whom belonged to the Yugoslav Army garrison stationed in Sarajevo before Bosnia declared its independence. General Galic's tanks, artillery and antiaircraft guns have inflicted most of the heaviest damage on Sarajevo, where an estimated 55,000 people have been killed or wounded during the siege.
The leaders of the Serbian nationalist cause in Bosnia were reported to be attending a meeting in the eastern Bosnian town of Zvornik. General Morillon said he had been told that the session was to decide policy for the resumption of the Geneva peace talks, where both Serbian and Bosnian Government leaders have balked at a joint United Nations-European Community plan to divide Bosnia into semiautonomous regions under a weak central government.
 
Peace Talks in Doubt
 Ejup Ganic, a Bosnian vice president, said that the decision not to resume negotiations in Geneva had been made "here, in Sarajevo, by those running the Government" in the absence of President Izetbegovic.
"It's a great tragedy," Mr. Ganic said. "Hakija Turajlic was absolutely the most efficient, competent minister in this Government."
"I think we shouldn't go to continue talks in Geneva unless the aggressors show that they are for peace," Mr. Ganic said. "If we continue like this, they will kill each of us, one by one, until there is no Government left."
The killing appeared likely to strengthen hard-liners in the Bosnian Government, including Mr. Ganic, who have differed with Mr. Izetbegovic in the past over his decision to continue negotiations with the Serbian nationalists. Mr. Ganic and the Bosnian military commander, Maj. Sefer Halilovic, have taken the position that any negotiated settlement with the Serbian nationalists, who now occupy about two-thirds of the republic, would amount to a surrender, and that the Bosnia Muslims should resolve to fight on, regardless of the costs.
At the United Nations, in New York, the Security Council said in a statement that it was "profoundly shocked" to learn of the killing of Mr. Turajlic "while he was under the protection of the United Nations Protection Force." The Council called his death an "outrageous act of terrorism," a "grave violation of international humanitarian law" and "a flagrant challange to the authority of the United Nations force.
The Council also asked Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to investigate in the killing and report back "without delay."

HEADLINE: Issues of Survival for Declining Union

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
The latest painful labor battle at The Daily News is a sign of the decline of the power of unions in the New York City newspaper industry, highlighting deep and, some say, permanent divisions between New York unions that once derived their power from unity.
It showed how weak newspaper unions have become in an age when technology has made it possible for publishers to put out newspapers without union members, and thus is a watershed in the labor movement and in the news industry. 
 The New York Newspaper Guild, which represents news, advertising and circulation employees, is fighting for its life as a credible union after a third of its members at The Daily News became unemployed this week because of the actions of Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the new Daily News owner.
 
Another Struggle Exposed
 The struggle of the guild, the largest of the city's newspaper unions, exposed a little mentioned debate in newsrooms over whether unions have a place there. A number of reporters and editors, the beneficiaries of better pay and greater prestige won over several generations, see themselves as professionals who have moved beyond the need for labor alliances forged by their predecessors.
And, perhaps most important, this week's events raised questions about whether a union can be called a union at all if it must stand by without a strike, a job action or a picket line, while an employer demands that union members apply for their own jobs. After The Daily News's bankruptcy, and the guild's failure to reach an accord with Mr. Zuckerman, the new publisher took advantage of his legal right to view the newspaper as a newly created business and the 540 guild employees as job applicants.
"This is yet another sign of how feeble labor unions are generally and particularly in the news industry in New York," said Mitchell Stephens, chairman of New York University's department of journalism and the author of a book on the history of the news business.
"It is a very sad day," Mr. Stephens said yesterday, "for people who know the accomplishments of labor in the development of the New York City press."
The guild is now relying on a call for a readers' boycott and a planned "corporate campaign" to have supporters stop doing business with Mr. Zuckerman's real-estate and publishing enterprises. It is also pressing for continued negotiations with Mr. Zuckerman.
That the union has fallen back on the boycott tool, often used in battles that do not involve unions at all, is a symbol itself of the defensive posture forced upon the guild. Nearly half its members eventually crossed the picket lines of the five-month Daily News strike two years ago. Even many of those who supported that strike knew, as the crisis was building with Mr. Zuckerman in recent weeks, that another strike would never win the support of the guild rank-and-file.
 
Methodical Approach
 A strike would almost certainly have failed. Mr. Zuckerman methodically won contracts with the only unions that can still stop newspaper production and delivery, the unions representing pressmen and drivers, and with the other trade unions. As the guild headed toward what Mr. Zuckerman said was an inevitable winnowing of its ranks, he had 9 of The News's 10 unions on his side.
Together, those unions, their joint umbrella group, the Allied Printing Trades Council, and the council's influential president, George E. McDonald, repeatedly signaled the guild that they had the deal they wanted. It was clear that the other unions would have broken a guild strike.
Even if the union manages to stage what would now be viewed as a comeback at The Daily News, the guild has lost enormous ground. This week's events come after signs of growing dissension in the union citywide. The guild represents employees at The New York Times and The New York Post and other major New York news organizations. For several years, dissidents have openly criticized the union's leadership for what they say is passiveness with publishers and undemocratic union management.
Barry F. Lipton, the guild president, acknowledged yesterday that this week's events were a serious blow. He said the union was made vulnerable partly because Federal labor law allowed what he called Mr. Zuckerman's effort to break the union. He also said the union was on the defensive because the new publisher was able to isolate the guild from the other Daily News unions.
Some guild members who are critics of the citywide leadership acknowledge that the weakness of the guild is due in large measure to declining loyalty of members. At The New York Post, Mr. Lipton was criticized for negotiating a take-it-or-see-the-newspaper-die deal in 1990 with Peter S. Kalikow, the publisher.
Mr. Lipton has been under fire at The Post ever since by a group of dissidents who say he gave away too much. He has repeatedly said the deal was the only option. It cut employee work weeks, and pay, by 20 percent and generally reduced the ranks and morale of guild members.
Karen Phillips, the secretary of the guild local at The Post, is one of Mr. Lipton's critics. But this week, she acknowledged that the problems of the guild are more fundamental than internal politics.
"Most of the people in newspapers," she said, "don't understand unions. They think they're for auto workers."
In most industries, a union's weakness is best measured by the reaction of management when a union gets into difficulty at one company. Competitors see that as an opportunity.
It is the same in the news business. In response to a question yesterday, Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for The New York Times, said that Mr. Zuckerman's actions would not necessarily require changes at The Times.
But, she said, The News labor situation "is bound to have some effect; we don't live in a vacuum." The Times's current contract with the guild expires in March.
At The Post, even before Mr. Zuckerman had completed his staff reduction, Mr. Kalikow saw an opportunity. "Assuming he tries to assassinate the guild, which is what he seems to be doing," Mr. Kalikow said this week, "I'm sure we will be able to negotiate a deal which improves our position."
Yesterday, Tonice Sgrignoli, a copy editor who has been one of the most vocal guild members at The Daily News, said this week's events suggested that the guild, after telling its members to follow management instructions to apply for jobs with Mr. Zuckerman, may be so weak now that it cannot rightly be called a union.
"When I was told to reappy for my job, I said: 'Why don't we just admit it: We don't have a union.' "
Ms. Sgrignoli did what the union recommended and applied for the job. In the envelope she received on Thursday, there was a form letter telling her that her application had been rejected.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE SHOWS NO CHANGE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Employers' payrolls grew by a modest 64,000 jobs in December as the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7.3 percent, the Labor Department said today in a report that underscores how slowly the job market is reacting to economic expansion.
The figures were somewhat disappointing in light of recent drops in first-time claims for jobless benefits and other indications that the economy is slowly recovering from the recession. 
 The employment report appeared to increase the chances that President-elect Bill Clinton, who has been meeting with his economic advisers this week in Little Rock, Ark., would undertake an aggressive program of fiscal stimulus. The current unemployment rate is half a percentage point higher than the 6.8 percent that prevailed in March 1991, the month recently designated as the bottom of the recession.
 
Deficit Outlook Worsens
 The latest lackluster job data came two days after President Bush, in his final budget, projected deficits over the next several years far deeper than the Administration had estimated as recently as July. This would tend to deter Mr. Clinton from trying to buoy the economy by extra spending on highways and other public works projects. Despite nearly two years of expansion in the national output, sluggish though it has been, American employers have added no more workers than absolutely necessary. The strategy has been to use existing workers for extra hours and to work them harder and to make greater use of temporary employees.
"Companies are just reluctant to hire in this period of increased global competition," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company. Instead, he said, the emphasis is still on improving efficiency, a boon for the economy in the long run but in the short run a many-faceted problem, often involving hardships for individuals.
Today's report, the first broad appraisal of the economy's performance for December, included numerous revisions, aberrations and adjustments that combined to reinforce the recent pattern of a weak pickup in demand for workers.
"In general, we can say that the trend of recent months has been one of slow improvement," William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
The gain of 64,000 in nonfarm payrolls was toward the lower end of expectations, analysts said, but the increase would have been fairly respectable had it not been for the absence of poll watchers and other temporary election workers who, the Labor Department estimated, swelled November payrolls by 45,000.
 
Weather Played a Role
 Similarly, the length of the average workweek in private industry declined 18 minutes, to 34.3 hours, but much of the drop was attributed to severe storms that hit the Northeast in mid-December. The workweek at factories, meanwhile, rose for the third straight week to what the department called a "very high" reading of 41.3 hours.
Factory jobs, however, edged up just 3,000 after growing 25,000 in November and employment in construction fell another 5,000 to remain below levels a year earlier.
This meant all the growth was in services, mainly business and health services, as slower-than-normal seasonal hiring in department and clothing stores was offset by increases at auto dealers, restaurants and bars.
The Government survey of households showed more job growth, 247,000 in December, than did employers' payrolls. But because the labor force grew by 226,000, there was no change in the unemployment rate.
 
Plenty of Revisions
 The jobless rate had initially been reported at 7.2 percent for November but was moved up today to 7.3 percent after the annual applications of updated seasonal adjustment factors. The jobless rate for April was also revised one-tenth of a point higher for April but was lowered by that amount for May, June and July.
The number of so-called discouraged workers -- those who have stopped looking for jobs because they think it futile -- declined 42,000 in the tabulation for the fourth quarter, but the rounded total remained 1.1 million, the same level that has prevailed since the third quarter of 1991.
Regionally, the Midwest continued to post the lowest jobless rate even though it showed a rise last month to 6.1 percent from 5.9. In the Northeast, the rate rose to 8.1 percent from 8, but the South and West both had declines, to 6.7 percent and 8.5 percent, respectively.
The number of Americans working part time because of economic reasons -- the so-called partially unemployed -- eased by about 150,000 during December to 6,349,000, a number that has shown little trend over the last year.
The average spell of unemployment lasted 19.2 weeks, up from 18.4 weeks in November and returning to the October level. Those out of work more than 15 weeks climbed 159,000 while the newly unemployed -- jobless for less than five weeks -- fell 78,000.
Reflecting the shorter workweek, average weekly earnings slumped 1 percent last month, prompting fresh doubts among some analysts about the ability of consumers to sustain their vigorous spending pace of recent months.
Today's report also showed that the department's index of aggregate weekly hours -- a proxy for industrial production -- fell to 121.1 last month from 122 in November. On the other hand, 52.9 percent of industries added to their payrolls in December, up from 50.6 percent and the fourth straight increase.
Over all, said Joan D. Schneider, economist for Continental Bank in Chicago, "It's heartening that things are getting better, but the improvement is pretty anemic relative to what we were doing before the recession."

HEADLINE: New York City Is Star Of Showbiz Expo East

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Despite its brassy name and exuberant commercialism, the Showbiz Expo East, which ends tonight, is more than just a trade show. The high-decibel, high-tech convention that has commandeered the New York Hilton for the last two days has become a continuing referendum on the viability of New York's film-, theater- and television-production industries.
Many of the 6,000 entertainment-industry managers, production workers and technical apparatchiks attending the event expressed delight simply that the Expo, a Los Angeles institution for the last nine years, had actually come to New York for the first time. This is, after all, a winter in which the city's entertainment industry finds itself still mired deeply in a recession, even though economists tell us the nation is on the rebound. According to a new study unveiled at the Expo, there are also lingering effects of the talent drain caused by the nine-month Hollywood film boycott that ended in 1991. 
 The main preoccupation of conventiongoers, in fact, whether they were schmoozing in corridors, seated in panel sessions or navigating through a three-floor circus of 200 exhibitors' booths, was a trio of recurring questions: How bad is the city's entertainment economy? Will more jobs leave for the South, the West and the Canadian North? Will the work come back if the economy improves under a new President?
The answers varied widely, from unvarnished gloom to irrepressible optimism.
Barry J. Shapiro, a producer and director of commercials, said that a lot of New York film companies had gone out of business "and didn't pay their bills, and there are a lot of horror stories out there about that."
Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of Actors Equity, said that "actors have been fleeing the city and the East Coast because they can't make a living." For those who have stayed, he added, there has been a reduction not only in the number of weeks worked each year, but also in salary levels.
Alison Johns, the editor of Millimeter, the motion-picture-industry magazine, said, "Things pretty much hit bottom when 'Lost in Yonkers' was filmed in Cincinnati."
A somewhat rosier assessment was offered by Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project. "Going to the cold shower of the 90's from the Jacuzzi of the 80's has been good for all of us," she said. "It's good, facing reality. New York City is not going to drop off a cliff, and we want to be ready when the good times come again."
Thomas F. Leahy, president of the Theater Development Fund, agreed. "I'm an Irish Catholic," he said, "and I believe that all growth comes out of pain."
 
Creating 'Buzz and Momentum'
 The Expo offered more than 20 panel discussions, on theater financing and video breakthroughs as well as one that promised to show "how you can use film festivals to create the necessary buzz and momentum for your next film." There was also a session officially dubbed "Safe Sets," a discussion of liability issues on movie sets.
Or participants could simply mill around and rub shoulders with theater, film and television managers, government officials, union executives, directors, cinematographers, designers, make-up artists and prop people. Those attending the Expo paid from $25 to $195, depending upon the number of days and panels chosen.
If the convention's Showbiz name conjures images of lounge thrushes crooning in smoky nightclubs or deal-making weasels in agent suits, the reality of the Expo was an electronic bedlam of exhibitors' booths. People hawked their up-to-the-minute wares, which included underwater cameras, satellite phones, film-to-video transfer systems and theatrical fogging machines using liquid-nitrogen smoke generators, which are replacing the traditional dry-ice machines.
The cost of space ran from $1,900 to $10,000 for exhibitors, who included a film-location weathercasting company ("24 hours, 7 days, always a live meteorologist, never a recording!" a sign said) as well as an abundance of salesmen flogging 10 competing script-writing software packages, and representatives of 42 local, state and national film offices (among them Canadian, British and Portuguese), all trying to attract production companies.
Standing staunchly against this invading army was Richard Brick, the new director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, who characterized New York as "the premiere urban landscape in the world, a tremendous investment value for any film."
Alluding to the fact that the city has never rebounded from the effects of the Hollywood boycott, Mr. Brick added, "Right now, New York could not be more user-friendly, because people are hungry now here."
Mr. Brick announced that the budget for his office had been doubled, from $500,000 to about $1 million, and insisted that the increase in funds was accompanied by a new sense of urgency to win back the movie business. Part of the extra money will be used to raise New York's visibility in Los Angeles and at the major international film festivals, he said.
The Broadway Alliance, which for the past two years has tried to fight the recession by bringing lower-cost productions to Broadway -- through cost concessions from producers, theater owners and theatrical unions -- also announced plans to expand: from 3 theaters to 10 or more. The plays thus far produced by the alliance have been critical and commercial disappointments, and some people have said that the location of the three theaters currently used has limited the interest of producers in future alliance presentations. The three -- the Belasco, Nederlander and Walter Kerr -- are some distance from Broadway's theatrical core.
 
Proposed Additions
 David S. Rosenak, the chairman of the alliance, announced that theater owners and most of the seven participating theatrical unions had agreed to add the Brooks Atkinson, the Ambassador, the Cort, the Golden, the Longacre and the Neil Simon to the current list of alliance houses.
The plan is still under negotiation, however, since Actors Equity has not yet approved the proposal to add the Eugene O'Neill and the Royale to the alliance roster. Mr. Eisenberg of Actors Equity said the union was looking favorably toward the O'Neill but not the Royale.
Perhaps the best thing the Expo provided was the chance to just hang out. "In this business, a lot of us work alone, and this is a great way to get together and realize we're all part of one family," said Bob Gerardi, an actor and composer who also produces music for film and commercials.
Richard Cohn, a gaffer, or film-crew head electrician, who lives in Brooklyn, said, "It's really great to see just how many people are alive and well and still working here."

HEADLINE: Taking Reins, Zuckerman Faces Union Challenge

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Mortimer B. Zuckerman assumed control of The Daily News yesterday with an olive branch for the news staff he had decimated in an economy measure and a firm pledge to restore his new, $36.3 million property to its glory days as New York's sassy-but-serious hometown tabloid.
"It should be, and has been, a popular and populist paper -- a street smart, sassy, serious journal for the average New York family," the new owner and co-publisher said in an interview, echoing a vision sketched earlier in a meeting with a somber, occasionally defiant news staff. 
 But even as he took over the ailing paper, Mr. Zuckerman was hit with a new challenge. The Newspaper Guild of New York -- whose ranks he had slashed by about 170 jobs Thursday night, out of 540 -- moved to start a reader and advertiser boycott of The News and a broader campaign against other Zuckerman properties in a bid to win back curtailed jobs, salaries and benefits.
 
Little Support for Guild
 Guild leaders announced that Ray Rogers, a controversial labor consultant known for organizing boycotts and other pressure tactics against J. P. Stevens, Hormel, American Airlines, International Paper and other companies since the 1970's, had been hired to run the union's fight against Mr. Zuckerman.
A spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Rex Hardesty, said the national labor organization had not yet heard about the call for a boycott by the Newspaper Guild, and he could not comment on whether it would support a boycott.
But the guild, which represents news, advertising and circulation employees, had no support among other unions and many guild members, who had lost careers overnight, expressed skepticism about the tactic. Some also were critical of their union, saying it had not protected their jobs.
On his first whirlwind day as owner, Mr. Zuckerman, 55, a real-estate and publishing entrepreneur, took a midnight tour of The New's decrepit Brooklyn printing plant, gave newspaper and television interviews and met with a news staff whose somber faces and angry remarks reflected bitterness over the fate of scores of colleagues who had been let go, many after decades of service.
 
Portrays Self as Savior
 At The News's main office at 220 East 42d Street, Mr. Zuckerman walked through the seventh-floor newsroom lined with famous front pages and the ghosts of 73 years of fast, flashy journalism. He settled himself on a desk amid jumbles of paper and bleating phones and was soon surrounded by editors, reporters and photographers, some of the survivors of a staff cut by a third.
Calm and articulate, his tone earnest but at times more forceful in response to belligerent comments in a one-hour meeting, Mr. Zuckerman portrayed himself as the savior of The News, sketched his vision of its future and repeatedly expressed regret over layoffs he portrayed as necessary for survival of a bankrupt paper that had lost $100 million over the last decade.
He said mistakes might have been made in what some called the brutal way the layoffs were handled. He also said mistakes might have been made in what he portrayed as swift decisions by subordinates on which staff members to cut. He promised to review the cuts and "rectify our mistakes if we've made them."
He wavered between apology and sympathy. "No one likes to be associated with something like this," Mr. Zuckerman said. He said that he expected to hire new employees to bring back the newsroom staffing, which he said he had reduced for reasons of quality, to its pre-layoff level, and he noted that other unions at The News had also suffered sharp staff cuts.
But Don Singleton, a reporter, contradicted him, saying the drivers and pressmen had not lost as many jobs as it seemed, but rather had a cutback of working shifts that had been filled by overtime and casual workers.
Mr. Zuckerman said that was a fair point. But he said he had sincerely tried to reach an agreement with the guild.
Tom Robbins, a reporter who had been on the guild negotiating committee, disputed him. "You never put a final offer on the table," he said.
The voice of Juan Gonzalez, the columnist, shook with anger as he spoke of his shock over the way the layoffs had been handled and demanded to know what management deadwood Mr. Zuckerman might cut. Mr. Zuckerman, his face flushed, said there would probably be a "merit adjustment" for management workers and repeated forcefully his desire to have a productive work force at all levels.
Larry Sutton, another reporter, asked if staff assignments would be shuffled. Mr. Zuckerman said his attention had been so focused on the details of buying The News that he had had little time for editorial direction beyond hiring a new metro editor, Richard Esposito, from New York Newsday.
He underscored his commitment to building a new $150 million color printing plant for The News in the next 18 months.
After the meeting, many staff members streamed out to a meeting at Guild headquarters on West 44th Street.
At Guild headquarters, about 200 members gathered in the afternoon and spoke of their plight. Some who were let go said they were eligible for a buyout equal to two and a half weeks' pay for every year of service, paid weekly over a long time, or two weeks pay for every year paid in a lump sum. They said they were also entitled to 18 months of health benefits at a favorable group rate.
Some who were still on the staff said they had been offered lower-paying jobs, with salary cuts ranging from $50 to $400 a week. Those offered jobs said they had been offered the options of taking buyouts or staying on at current seniority, waiving rights to severance benefits.
Those who stay will be given a new health insurance policy. Under the new policy, they said, they will have to pay 25 percent of their health care costs.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Employers' payrolls grew by a modest 64,000 jobs in December as the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7.3 percent. The Labor Department report underscores how slowly the job market is reacting to economic expansion. [Page 1.]
New York and New Jersey employment increased in December, offering further evidence that the economic downturn in the states is bottoming out. [52.] 
 Consumers increased their borrowing by 2 percent in November. The third consecutive increase was the longest string of advances in two years. [50.]
Economists confess that the recession that was recently declared over is still defying traditional analysis. [52.]
The labor battle at The Daily News is a sign of the decline of the power of unions in the New York City newspaper industry. [1.]
Governor Cuomo proposed changing the way New York State structures its long-term borrowing. [28.]
 
 Companies
Carl C. Icahn admits he bought Trans World Airlines cheap but lost the chance to sell before Persian Gulf hostilities began. [41.]
Many reasons for restricting foreign ownership in United States airlines are no longer valid, a Government report says. [41.]
A co-founder of Next resigned, increasing speculation that the computer company is moving to become a software publisher. [41.]
Shares in Apple moved up after an executive was quoted as saying that revenue and unit sales grew significantly. [43.]
Bank of Boston will double, to $6 billion, the amount of new loans it will make in New England by the end of next year. [43.]
 
 International
Japanese auto executives say the Government extended its car export quota to head off U.S. demands for trade concessions. [41.]
Japan's Pioneer Electronic violated a cherished policy of lifetime employment in dismissing 35 middle managers. [1.]
A onetime banker and native East German was nominated as Germany's next Economics Minister. [5.]
President-elect Clinton told the Mexican President he would act quickly on the North American Free Trade Agreement. [8.]
 
 Markets
The Dow industrials lost 17.29 in heavy trading. It gave the average a 50-point loss for the first week of the year. [41.]
Treasury prices ended mixed on fears that President-elect Clinton would aggressively stimulate the economy. [50.]
The dollar and gold closed mostly higher. [51.] Oil prices finished moderately lower on tensions in the Middle East. [51.]
 
 Your Money
Millions of people have discovered that mutual funds are a simple, low-cost way to own stocks and bonds. [35.]
Wall Street firms with bad regulatory histories are spinning off executives to start new firms with clean rap sheets. [35.]
Small-claims court has grown popular, discovered by part-timers, small businesses and others without lawyers. [36.]

HEADLINE: Word of Bosnian's Killing Cuts Clinton Briefing Short

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The President of Bosnia, Alija Izetbegovic, was briefing Clinton aides on the negotiations in Geneva to end the killing in his country when the news arrived of his Deputy Prime Minister's assassination by Serbian gunmen.
Though Mr. Izetbegovic struggled to contain his emotions in the face of the news and the open weeping of some of his aides, the meeting broke up about 15 minutes later. It was a turn of events that vividly illustrated for members of the Clinton transition team the volatile nature of the Balkan crisis they will be responsible for handling in less than two weeks. 
 "It was a moment that I will never forget," said a transition official who was in the room when the news arrived of the assassination of Hakija Turalic, Bosnia's Deputy Prime Minister for Economics.
Earlier Mr. Izetbegovic, who traveled to the United States this week to drum up support for his country, met with Bush Administration officials who urged him to "remain engaged" in the Geneva peace talks.
 
Boycott Is Possible
 Janet Amon, an official with the Bosnian Mission to the United Nations, said tonight that Mr. Izetbegovic was considering boycotting the Geneva talks because of the killing.
Ms. Amon said the Bosnian President was considering taking part in a meeting of the Organization of Islamic Countries in Dakar, Senegal, next week, instead of traveling to Geneva.
Mr. Izetbegovic later said that his Government was discussing whether "to withdraw the Bosnian delegation from the negotiations" in Geneva, The Associated Press reported. Speaking after a meeting in New York with President-elect Al Gore, the Bosnian President said he did not know whether a decision had been made.
Administration officials had originally declined to meet Mr. Izetbegovic for fear that it could be seen as an opening for him to pull out of the talks.
"We discussed the Geneva process and our side expressed the belief that it is the best hope for peace," said an Administration official who insisted on not being identified. The official said the Administration was not taking a position on any of the specific proposals that have been put forward, including a plan to devide Bosnia into 10 semi-autonomous regions. The plan has been criticized as legitimizing aggression by Serbs who now control the majority of Bosnian territory.
 
News of Killing
 Immediately after the meeting with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and Arnold Kanter, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, at the White House, Mr. Izetbegovic told reporters that the slaying was "not only an attack on our Government, but at the same time it is an attack upon the United Nations."
Mr. Turajlic was riding in a United Nations convoy traveling from Sarajevo Airport when the armored vehicle he was in was stopped by Serbian gunmen, the general commanding the United Nations force in Bosnia and Herzegovina said. After an hour and a half the confrontation ended when a Serbian soldier shot the minister, firing over the shoulder of the United Nations commander on the scene.
Clinton aides said their meeting with Mr. Izetbegovic took place this afternoon in a hotel room in the Georgetown section of Washington. An official with Mr. Clinton's transition team said the Bosnian leader had pulled out a map and was explaining how the country would be divided under a plan that had been put forward by Cyrus R. Vance, the former United States Secretary of State, and Lord Owen of Britain, co-chairmen of the Geneva talks.
As Mr. Izetbegovic began his explanation, one of his aides burst into the room and informed him in his native language that Mr. Turajlic had been killed. Hearing the news, several of Mr. Izetbegovic's aides began sobbing.
 
Pressure to Join Talks
 Leon Fuerth, a transition official who works in the foreign policy area, reportedly asked Mr. Izetbegovic if he wanted to recess the meeting to regain his composure. But the Bosnia leader chose to continue.
But after about 15 minutes, it was decided that the discussion should resume later.
In recent days, the Bush Administration and the Clinton transition team have vacillated over whether they should meet with him. Mr. Vance expressed concern that meetings with Mr. Izetbegovic would upset the delicate negotiations.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Izetbegovic said he had been pressed into entering into the Geneva negotiations by Mr. Vance and Mr. Owen. The Bosnian leader said the two men told him that he risked responsibility for the failure of peace efforts if he declined to take part in the talks.
At a breakfast sponsored by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Mr. Izetbegovic said that Bosnians consider it "to be a humiliation" for him to be negotiating with Serbian leaders whom he considers war criminals.

HEADLINE: Region Adds Jobs but Data Remain Mixed

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in December rose a bit in New York State and dropped in New Jersey, but employment among residents of both states increased, offering further evidence that their recession-ravaged economies are bottoming out.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in New York increased to 8.4 percent, from 8 percent in November, while New Jersey's rate fell to 8 percent from 8.7 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. Data on Connecticut were not released yesterday. 
 "The negatives are losing force and the positives are strengthening," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner. "We're seeing the tide of the decline receding. The improvement is agonizingly slow. It is coming in fits and starts but it's there."
The number of employed New Yorkers rose by a scant 31,000, to 7,872,000, in December from 7,841,000 in November. But there was also an increase in the active labor force, or those seeking or available for jobs. That increase accounts for the rise in the unemployment rate.
New York City's unadjusted unemployment rate rose to 11 percent in December from 10.5 percent in November. The number of city residents with jobs rose by 45,000. Seasonally adjusted data for the city were not available. Seasonal adjustment is an attempt by the bureau to help make comparisons more meaningful by compensating for temporary factors like increased retail hiring during the Christmas season.
"Manufacturing job losses in New York State have slowed to a trickle, jobs in business services are showing some gains for the first time in several years and retail trade has picked up slightly," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "Among the major industries, only construction is still cutting back substantially."
The preliminary average unemployment rate in New York State for all of 1992 was the highest in nine years at 8.5 percent, up from the 7.2 percent average in 1991.
 
New Jersey Job Picture Improves
 New Jersey's unemployment rate last month was the lowest since April. December was the third consecutive month that the rate has been below 9 percent. The number of New Jersey residents with jobs increased in December by 69,000, or more than twice the number in New York State, to 3,697,000.
"In New Jersey, there have been no further declines in manufacturing jobs for several months, construction is stabilizing and employment in services has been moving up for several months," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
New Jersey's preliminary average unemployment rate for 1992 was 8.4 percent, the highest in a decade. The 1991 average was 6.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Iraq's War of Nerves

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The latest showdown between Washington and Baghdad demonstrates once again, two years after the fact, how sharply the denouement of the war in the Persian Gulf differed from what the victorious allies expected at the time.
By defeating Saddam Hussein's armies in the field, President Bush and other Western leaders concluded, they had weakened him to the point that he would either be toppled in a coup or find it impossible to resist the enforcement of the United Nations resolutions designed to curb his powers. 
 But the Iraqi President remains in charge, and he has retained enough power to tweak the nose of the United States and the United Nations again and again. He hindered the inspection teams trying to prevent Iraq from rebuilding a nuclear capacity. He cut the routes used by convoys carrying relief supplies to the Kurds in the north. And then he moved surface-to-air missiles into position to threaten allied plans patrolling the no-flight zone in the south.
 
No Quick Solutions
 With only 10 days left in his Presidency, Mr. Bush took to the phones again, lining up support for air strikes against the Iraqis if the missiles were not moved. But whether they are moved far enough fast enough to suit the Americans, the President is in no position in the gulf -- any more than he is in Somalia or Bosnia -- to wrap up the trouble neatly before Jan. 20 and present Bill Clinton with a relatively clean foreign-policy slate.
If Mr. Hussein complied with the allied demands, which he would almost certainly do only while proclaiming to the world and to his own people that he had no intention of doing so, or if he dismantled the missiles, as appeared possible tonight, little would be resolved. He would retain the capacity to move them into a hostile position once more, or to test the allies in other ways.
A number of Middle East analysts, for instance, fear that the Iraqi leader may try to further suppress resistance among the Iraqi Kurds, who live along the border with Turkey. Between 1988 and 1989, Iraqi troops are believed to have killed more than 150,000 Kurds, perhaps as many as 200,000, and Pentagon officials said Baghdad retains ample military capacity to carry out another such slaughter.
If the missiles are not moved, and air strikes are carried out, a possibility that seemed to be receding as the deadline passed, it is difficult to see how the strikes could have more than a transitory effect. Iraq might lose some anti-aircraft missiles or some other aging military equipment if Mr. Bush decided to strike at the missiles themselves. He might lose more if the raids hit established bases rather than the mobile missiles, but nothing that he could not quickly replace.
According to American intelligence reports, the Iraqis have kept their best missile batteries, equipped with Soviet-built SA-11's and SA-13's, well north of the no-flight zone imposed to protect Shiite Muslim rebels. The missiles that were moved there, touching off the present crisis, are older, obsolescent models considered expendable.
 
Former Allies Unallied
 But the resistance of nations like Egypt, Syria and Turkey, which were crucial allies in the 1991 conflict, will make it very difficult to strike at Baghdad itself, European diplomats said. Nor is there much support for attacks on the resources that keep Mr. Hussein in power, from the rebuilt munitions factories to the barracks of the elite troops based in the Baghdad region.
The high-tech weapons of which American commanders were so proud during the war, and which constitute one of the main Western advantages in the continuing conflict with Mr. Hussein, are of very limited use in this situation.
From Mr. Hussein's point of view, the war of nerves is very useful. It gives him a chance to posture as the defender of Iraqi sovereignty, as the man who takes the West right to the brink. To the degree that that prompts feelings of patriotism and diverts attention from the raging inflation and the epidemic of shortages caused by economic sanctions, he is clearly the beneficiary.
Laurie Mylroie, a scholar at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, thinks the Iraqi President and his circle are convinced that they won the war, in the sense that they clung to power in the face of overwhelming firepower and diplomatic strength. They "stood up to the Americans."
"Watching him on Iraqi television when I was there in November," Ms. Mylroie said, "it was stunning to see his self-confidence and his arrogance, and his evident pleasure in public adulation, however obviously coerced. Bombing isn't going to change that much. It has very limited utility."
Mr. Clinton, she suggested, will have to decide for himself whether to reformulate American goals to include the elimination of Mr. Hussein or accept the fact that the Security Council resolutions cannot be fully enforced until he loses power.
 
An Uncertain Policy
 In a speech in October, Mr. Clinton, who rather reluctantly supported the use of force in the gulf two years ago, hinted that he might adopt a tougher policy in the region if elected. It was a mistake, he said then, to urge the Kurds and the Shiites to resist and then do little to support them.
But the President-elect has never suggested that he would be willing to contemplate allied military incursions to help the rebels. At any rate, such an intervention would almost certainly be resisted by the Pentagon on the ground that it constituted an open-ended commitment in an unstable region.
Today, Mr. Clinton remained the foreign-policy team player he has been since November. Mr. Bush had consulted him "about the action that the President proposed to take," he said, "and I agree with the action."

HEADLINE: Visiting U.S. General Warns Haiti's Military Chiefs

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 8

 BODY:
As part of intensive joint efforts by the Bush Administration and aides of President-elect Bill Clinton to settle Haiti's political crisis and avert a renewed flood of refugees, a United States Marine Corps general, in a visit here, has warned Haitian military leaders that they must quickly recognize the country's exiled President.
The officer, Maj. Gen. John Sheehan, told the Haitian High Command that any solution of the crisis must include their recognition of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was overthrown in a military coup on September 1991, Haitians and Americans close to the discussions said today. 
 In a tense meeting at Haitian Army headquarters, they said, General Sheehan, who was dressed in formal uniform, warned the military leaders that if the country's crisis was allowed to fester they would not "be able to look to their American counterparts for any kind of sustenance."
 
A 'Window of Opportunity'
 Later, General Sheehan told the military leaders that if they quickly ended their opposition to a return of democratic government the United States was prepared to resume nonlethal aid to the Haitian military as part of a program to professionalize a ragtag and undisciplined army. In the second of two long meetings on Thursday night, General Sheehan began preliminary explorations of what shape such aid might take.
The general ended a 72-hour visit here this morning. Commenting on his visit, the first by a high-level American officer since the coup against Father Aristide, a senior Bush Administration official said that for the first time in months there was now a "window of opportunity" for settling Haiti's crisis.
The official pinned his cautious optimism on what he described as the "unprecedented cooperation" between incoming and outgoing Administrations in sending a clear message to all parties to the Haitian crisis, the recent decision by the United Nations to become involved, and "fear in Haiti of harsher measures to come as well as simple exhaustion."
Other than the warning by General Sheehan that the United States would not help extricate members of Haiti's High Command if the crisis was allowed to deteriorate, officials said no direct threats of punitive action had been made.
 
Pressure on President, Too
 Although the United States Embassy said General Sheehan's visit was part of a long-planned swing through the region, diplomats and Haitians involved in discussions toward a political solution here said that the military exchange represented part of an aggressive and concerted push by the Bush Administration, aides to Mr. Clinton and the United Nations.
While talks were under way here, a participant said, Father Aristide, who has lived in exile in Washington since his overthrow, was being told by these same parties that his cooperation was also expected and that concessions must be made by his side as well.
In 15 months of on-again, off-again efforts to settle Haiti's crisis, diplomats say, the country's army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, has steadfastly sought refuge behind a series of civilian governments backed by the military, blocking progress by refusing to become directly involved in political discussions.
At the same time, when settlements have appeared close, Father Aristide has balked at the last moment, the diplomats say. At other times, they say, he has simply refused to engage in the negotiating efforts.
The prospect of a resurgence of Haiti's refugee crisis has brought high-level attention to the country's problems in Washington. This attention, coming on top of the recent decision by the United Nations to supplement an ineffective Organization of American States as a broker here, appears to have brought a level of urgency to the situation that for the first time in months has raised hopes for an early solution.
 
'An Offer You Can't Refuse'
 "The U.N. and the U.S. are all together banging home the same message to both the generals and to Aristide saying this is an offer you can't refuse," said a participant in the discussions who declined to be further identified. "And there have been enough communications back and forth so that each side knows what kind of lumps the other is taking."
Asked for an assessment of how General Sheehan's message was received by General Cedras, another person with knowledge of the talks said of the Haitian High Command, "Even though nobody exactly told them the wrath of God was about to come down on their heads, they were pretty shaken up."
But despite the coordinated international efforts to resolve the crisis, an official warned, "There are still many things which could come unraveled here by the work of any number of actors, from refugee groups to Father Aristide's supporters to elements of the military to human rights people to the Haitian Parliament."
Among the many questions that remain unresolved are the selection of a new Prime Minister who would be acceptable across Haiti's deep divides between left and right and rich and poor. Even thornier, diplomats say, is the fate of General Cedras, whose punishment or exile has been demanded by Father Aristide for his role in the coup.
In recent diplomatic discussions, General Cedras has sought to justify the coup by saying that it was an attempt to block Father Aristide's threatened use of political violence.
In his talks with Haitians officers, General Sheehan told them that "a professional military is one that is subservient to civilian authority and your explanations are not sufficient," a person close to the discussions said.
But in recent weeks, senior American officials have said that in addition to the troubling remarks of the populist President during his seven-month tenure, they are now convinced, bolstered by an F.B.I. investigation of the matter, that Father Aristide personally ordered the killing in prison of one of his most bitter opponents, Roger Lafontant, while the coup was under way. Father Aristide's supporters deny this.
Also undetermined is the timing for Father Aristide's return once a settlement is reached. In the past, diplomats have said the Haitian President could return only after a substantial interim period during which the country's economy was revived and all its institutions, from the army itself to the judiciary to health care and education, were stabilized. Father Aristide and many of his supporters have held out for a quick return.
Another potential stumbling block are plans by the provisional Prime Minister, Marc L. Bazin, to hold legislative elections on Jan. 18, which diplomats say are intended to pack the Parliament with Mr. Bazin's supporters, hence blocking Father Aristide's return or sharply curtailing his powers. Despite a seeming willingness to cooperate, elements of the armed forces were most likely backing these efforts behind the scenes, several diplomats said.
"Perhaps we'll have an agreement before then," one said. "I know that is what we are pushing for. Then Marc Bazin will not be a factor and we can avoid a whole other layer of complication."

 UNIONS' DECLINE HIGHLIGHTED IN FIGHT
The latest labor battle at The Daily News is a sign of the decline of the power of unions in the New York City newspaper industry, highlighting deep and, some say, permanent divisions between unions that once derived their power from unity. News analysis, Page 1.
 
 NEW OWNER'S TOUR OF INSPECTION

The new owner assumed control of The Daily News with an olive branch for the news staff he had decimated in an economy measure and a firm pledge to restore his new, $36.3 million property to its glory days. Page 26.

Four of Mayor Dinkins's chief social policy advisers, including Andrew M. Cuomo, who headed his commission on homelessness, are in the running for high-ranking jobs in the Clinton Administration, officials said. Page 27.

In the month before his body was found in an Albany motel room, a beleaguered Bronx school district superintendent filled a notebook with complaints about educational policies in the city, law-enforcement officials said. Page 27.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 17.29 in 4th Fall in Row

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Queasy investors sent stocks zigging and zagging yesterday, leaving the Dow with its fourth straight drop in heavy trading and a loss of almost 50 points for the first week of the year.
The Dow finished with a decline of 17.29, about half a percent, to 3,251.67 yesterday after sagging by as much as 37 points earlier in the session. 
 Still, the Dow's decline overstated the broader market's retreat only somewhat, as Big Board losers decisively outnumbered gainers.
Many itches in many places seemed to account for all the scratching and selling yesterday and this week. The greatest irritant, perhaps, was the outlook for the coming Clinton Administration, with growing doubts about whether President-elect Bill Clinton can fulfill his pledges to cut the Federal budget deficit and stimulate the economy at the same time.
 
Pause to Reap Profits
 Some traders said investors were merely pausing to take profits they have rolled up since fall. Others said they wanted to reduce their risks in view of a possible showdown between the United States and Iraq.
The bond market also had a rough week, with the 30-year Treasury bond sliding again yesterday, raising the yield to 7.46 percent. [Page 50.]
Yesterday's report that unemployment remained at 7.3 percent in December convinced some investors that Mr. Clinton would have to spend vigorously for the economy to generate more jobs.
Yet analysts and traders were more inclined to treat the week as a post-election, post-holiday letdown than an ominous start to the new year.
"You had your Clinton honeymoon and everyone felt good," spending heavily for Christmas, said Edward M. Kerschner, chief strategist at Paine Webber. "Now people sit down and say, 'What's he actually going to do?' But there hasn't been any change in fundamentals."
 
Buyers Find Bargains
 Those fundamentals -- low interest rates, a gradual recovery and strong investor enthusiasm -- assure some money managers that stocks can remain at levels that by most measures are high.
Indeed, the Dow came more than halfway back from its lows in mid-afternoon yesterday once investors saw some favorite stocks at tempting levels.
Among the prominent winners yesterday were stocks that had done the worst earlier in the week. Philip Morris, beaten down earlier by the threat of increased tobacco taxes and regulation, gained 1 3/8, to 74, yesterday in heavy trading. Medical stocks also recovered, with Baxter, Merck, Lilly and Johnson & Johnson each gaining at least a point.
Airlines and railroads continued to advance, propelling the Dow Jones transportation average up 8.06 points, to 1,488.29, for a 39-point 2.7 percent gain during the week. Analysts say that transportation stocks will benefit from the recovery in the United States without suffering from slowdowns abroad.
Smaller stocks, which advanced twice this week on days the Dow industrials fell, continued to fare somewhat better than larger issues yesterday. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks slipped just a point, to 677.21. Among those falling was Intel, which broke a string of strong advances by falling 7/8, to 98 3/4, yesterday as Nasdaq's most active stock.
 
Buy Recommendations
 Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Sachs & Company is among the analysts still saying that those companies likely to prosper in the early phases of a domestic recovery -- retail, transportation, media and some technology -- are now the ones to buy.
While some of these issues resisted the market's decline for much of the week, yesterday's selling was widespread. Procter & Gamble, Woolworth, Boeing and Exxon were among widely held stocks losing a point or more.
National Medical Enterprises, the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, fell 1 3/4, to 9 7/8, after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday on the ramifications of complaints of malpractice and fraud at the company's psychiatric hospitals.
I.B.M. fell 1/2 point, to 46 1/2, in heavy trading, down 3 7/8 for the week to levels last seen in the computer punchcard era of the 1970's. A few brave analysts predicted a rebound, saying that year-end selling for tax and reporting reasons had pushed I.B.M. below its real worth.
Some investors seeking havens apparently left the stock market altogether for short-term Treasury issues, the traditional parking place for timid money.
 
'Flight to Quality'
 "It's a flight to quality from equities," said Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody. "People don't want to hold stock too heavily over the weekend. They don't know what's going to happen in Iraq."
He attributed last week's high volume to outright confusion, in a churning market that has made money managers shift investments from sector to sector as they wonder about what to do next.
Few analysts are still counting on a January rally like the ones they used to know. Rao Chalasani, the chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities, told investors to cut back their stock holdings by 10 percentage points, to 50 percent for the conservative or 60 percent for the aggressive.
"The January effect was in October," he said.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
The next two weeks may determine whether the incoming Clinton Administration and the nation's Roman Catholic bishops lock themselves into a moral and political cold war. When the head of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops wrote President-elect Bill Clinton a month ago, offering prayers for his success, the good wishes masked some serious difficulties the bishops are having in settling on a stance toward the new Administration.
One sign of this groping is the very date of the letter -- more than a month after Mr. Clinton's election. The delay reflects a fundamental disagreement between the church and the new Administration over an issue that has generated more than its share of discord over the years: abortion. Already there are signs that this disagreement could shape their whole relationship. 
 At a meeting at the bishops' conference in mid-November, James Cardinal Hickey, the Archibishop of Washington, even asked whether it would be appropriate for a Catholic prelate to share a public platform with the incoming President. And in the Vatican there are reports of intense discussions about the United States, quite possibly echoes of the consternation felt by some of the American hierarchy.
It would be wrong to dismiss this edginess as something without consequences for the new Administration. Mr. Clinton is too savvy not to recognize the damage that a cold war with the bishops could do to his plans. The church has significant influence on issues like health care, welfare reform and child care -- issues on which Mr. Clinton is placing his highest hopes.
There is also great potential for an alliance. In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton contended that his agenda and the Democratic Party's "historic commitments" to social-welfare issues were much closer to the Catholic Church's social vision than Republican ideas were.
Many bishops would agree, up to a point. Fighting poverty and helping new immigrants with housing and health care are not abstract concerns for the bishops; they have seen the church's charitable resources often stretched to serve four times as many people as they did 10 years ago.
At a more philosophical level, Mr. Clinton's notion that the Government has a responsibility to redress economic and social inequities certainly comes closer to the Catholic tradition than Reaganism did.
But for the bishops, abortion has a special place on their moral and political horizon, much as Israel's security has for leaders of Jewish groups. To opponents of abortion it is a life-and-death matter, generating the kind of passionate repudiations of compromises or half measures that AIDS has generated among gay rights groups.
To have a Presidential campaign so unambiguously identify itself with abortion rights, as the Democratic Party did at its convention in New York last July, was deeply disturbing to the bishops. All the more so because it proved to be far from similarly disturbing to the electorate, which did not let its mixed views on abortion overshadow its clear-cut desire for new leadership.
In this sense, even if Mr. Clinton's victory was not a statement about abortion, it was a statement about the politics of abortion -- and a stinging loss for the anti-abortion movement. While that may eventually compel the movement to reassess its strategy, its first public response has been to appeal to the troops to demonstrate greater dedication than ever.
So the Catholic bishops, despite their tendencies toward caution and pragmatism, are feeling both political and moral pressures to take an adversarial stance toward the new Administration.
That would mean renouncing the chance to influence important proposals on issues where the church and the White House might share common ground. But it could also mean reducing the chance to influence their own parishioners, who may not welcome a manifestly uncooperative attitude toward a Presidency in which they, along with many other Americans, have invested their hopes.
So far, the bishops and Mr. Clinton appear determined to avoid this kind of cold war, working together when possible and disagreeing when it is inevitable. The most significant of Mr. Clinton's positions on abortion, his support of abortion-rights legislation, may not become a live issue while the new President and Congress concentrate on the economy.
But the annual anti-abortion march in Washington on the anniversary of Roe v. Wade will take place on Jan. 22, two days after Mr. Clinton's inauguration. At least one Cardinal will address marchers at a service on Jan. 21.
Mr. Clinton has promised to remove Federal restrictions on research using tissue from aborted fetuses, on abortion-related procedures in military hospitals overseas and on the information about abortion that can be provided by federally financed clinics.
If he honors those pledges swiftly, issuing the necessary executive orders immediately after his inauguration -- and on the eve of the anti-abortion march -- a quick conflict can be expected. The church will be publicly represented by Cardinals who need not check their statements with other members of the hierarchy. They will be speaking to a fervent audience eager for words of uncompromising condemnation.
Right then and there, the pattern may be set.

HEADLINE: Japan Takes a Pre-emptive Step on Auto Exports

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Japanese auto executives said the Government's decision today that it would extend for another year its current ceiling on automobile exports to the United States was an effort to head off expected demands from the new Administration in Washington for more trade concessions.
But the continuation of the voluntary export restraints at 1.65 million cars for the fiscal year that begins in April is not expected to please United States auto makers, some of whose executives have been seeking tighter limits. Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has said Japan should cut the ceiling to 1.3 million cars or less. He said in Detroit today that Japan's decision to maintain export quotas at the current level would not help ease trade problems.
 
Ministry Denial
 Auto executives here say they suspect Japan's Government announced the export cap before President-elect Bill Clinton takes office later this month to pre-empt possible demands for a lower ceiling by the new Administration, which has promised to be more aggressive in helping American industries. 
 But an official in Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry denied this, saying the decision on export restraints is disclosed at this time almost every year. He said the export cap was extended in recognition of the problems the Big Three auto makers, particularly the General Motors Corporation, are facing.
Auto executives here say Japan's trade ministry considered lowering the ceiling but feared it would hurt Japan's own auto companies, which are in a severe slump because of falling sales in their home markets and weak economies abroad.
In Washington today, Kathleen Lydon, press secretary for the United States trade representative, declined to comment on Japan's decision on export quotas, citing a policy of not discussing voluntary Japanese trade arrangements that are not bilateral deals.
In recent years, exports to the United States have been below the ceiling because Japanese auto makers have been shifting production to their United States factories. For that reason, the restraints have been derided as meaningless.
Last year, the limit was cut to 1.65 million vehicles from 2.3 million, but exports are expected to be slightly below even this lower ceiling for the current fiscal year, ending in March.
But Japanese Government officials and auto industry analysts say that if the automobile sales in the United States grow in the coming year, as expected as the American economy recovers, Japanese companies might want to increase their exports. In that case, the restrictions could begin to bite, though not in a major way.
"The Japanese won't be able to expand their sales as fast as the market might improve, which means that the Japanese market share comes down," said Benjamin Moyer, analyst for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo.
He said, however, that such supply problems will not arise in the next year or so because the Japanese companies still have room to increase production at their American plants to make up for a shortfall in exports.
The Japanese automobile companies seem willing to live with the quota system, which has caused them little pain while helping to mollify a major trading partner.
Yoshifumi Tsuji, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said in a statement today that the Government's decision "takes into account the overall Japan-U.S. relations and is a realistic measure."
But American auto makers take a different view. The heads of the Big Three auto makers and of the United Automobile Workers union met with Mr. Clinton in Little Rock, Ark., earlier this week and at least some of the officials were believed to have sought a lower ceiling on Japanese exports. It is not known what Mr. Clinton's reply was, but the auto executives and Owen Bieber, the union chief, said they were pleased with the meeting.
Rather than focusing on Japanese auto exports, the Big Three American auto makers have agreed to focus on Japan's overall trade deficit, which is affected in the automotive sector by the export of engines and other parts. The auto makers have said they wish the new Administration to take a tough stand on pushing Japan to reduce that deficit any way it can.
In Detroit today, Mr. Poling of Ford told the Economic Club of Detroit that the decision by Japan not to lower its export quotas would worsen the country's trade deficit with the United States. He said the decision by the Japanese "shows they are not very concerned about it."
He said the automotive portion of the trade imbalance had remained at about $33 billion a year since 1986.
John F. Smith Jr., president of G.M., and Robert J. Eaton, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, reiterated at the Detroit meeting statements they made to President-elect Clinton earlier in the week seeking help for the domestic auto industry.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The heads of Big Three auto makers, from left, Robert J. Eaton of Chrysler, Harold Poling of Ford and John F. Smith Jr. of General Motors, spoke about trade problems with Japan at a luncheon in Detroit yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boston Bank To Double Loan Funds

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 8

 BODY:
Officials of the Bank of Boston said today that they would double, to $6 billion, the amount of new loans they had pledged to make in New England by the end of next year.
The nation's 21st-largest bank holding company said it was increasing the amount because of greater-than-expected demand under a loan-marketing program it announced in May to lend $3 billion to consumers and small businesses in New England. 
 Officials said the bank had lent $2 billion of the $3 billion in only seven months without lowering its credit standards. They said the bank logged 7,800 calls to a toll-free telephone number since May.
 
Suggests New Demand
 "That suggests to us that there are a lot more people out there who can use loans and who are creditworthy," Ira Stepanian, the Bank of Boston's chairman and chief executive, said today at a forum the bank held here.
Thomas Theurkauf, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment bank specializing in bank stocks, said the lending program appeared to be successful, but that it was not unique to the region. "The other major banks, and for that matter the smaller banks, are also in the process of reinvigorating their marketing programs," he added.
Mr. Theurkauf said that while demand under the Bank of Boston program appeared strong, it was difficult to determine how much was from existing customers of the bank. "It's a marketing program and a useful one, but I don't think anyone can say it's caused $2 billion in activity," he said.
Mr. Stepanian acknowledged that his bank and others, under fire from regulators for making bad real estate loans in the 1980's, had slowed New England's recovery by reacting with "undue caution" to recent loan requests. But he said the Bank of Boston was now "seeking to dispel the notion that banks are unwilling or unable to make loans."
The bank can make $6 billion available because it has had five profitable quarters, raising $558 million in the last year from stock sales and earnings.
The Bank of Boston is seeking new borrowers mainly among creditworthy small businesses, Mr. Stepanian said. Of the 1,200 businesses that have been promised loans so far, 1,000 are small businesses that requested loans of less than $1 million, and 38 are businesses in inner cities.
But small-business owners said they had seen no signs that other large area banks were changing their conservative lending policies.
Kerry C. Stackpole, executive director of the 1,400-member Small Business Association of New England, said a survey in November showed that 45 percent of his association's members were still having trouble getting loans despite the perception that the New England economy may be turning around.
