HEADLINE: Economists Meet, and Puzzle Over a Slump

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 8

 BODY:
The recession has been pronounced over, but a panel of economists at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association this week said traditional economic theory failed to explain why it ever happened.
"My overall assessment is that you cannot explain this one," said Robert E. Hall, the Stanford University economist who heads the committee that formally sets dates for the beginnings and ends of recessions. In a paper, he rejected the eight or so standard causes of recession -- things like high interest rates or declining government outlays -- as having caused this one. 
 Two panelists and many of the 200 or more experts in the audience seemed to agree that an unusual event had occurred in mid-1990, one that someday might enter history as a consumer spending version of a stock market crash.
People suddenly stopped buying. The trigger was clearly the Persian Gulf crisis and the danger of higher oil prices, which did not occur. The Persian Gulf shock should have worn off in a few months, and consumers should have returned to more robust buying, without bringing on a recession. After all, people had the income to buy more and the room to take on more debt, but they did not do either. And their reluctance, their loss of confidence, cascaded through the economy.
"In 1990, for some reason, consumers got scared and stayed scared," said Olivier Blanchard, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist. "They have spent much less than we would have predicted from past experience and income." Mr. Blanchard, who has studied the phenomenon, labeled it "negative animal spirits."
While acknowledging the phenomenon, Mr. Hall said the fall in consumer buying seemed insufficient to have resulted in the free fall in the economy that occurred in 1990 and 1991.
Nevertheless, no one at the session, including Mr. Hall and Mr. Blanchard, offered assurances of good times ahead, despite the pickup in retail sales over the holiday.

HEADLINE: Rutgers Feels Cuts, but President Won't Cry

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Dr. Francis L. Lawrence's desk in the president's office at Rutgers University is clean and tidy, but his agenda for the state's flagship campus is cluttered with fallout from New Jersey's slumping economy.
State financing for the 48,000-student network of undergraduate and graduate schools has declined outright since the economy went into recession in 1989. As Dr. Lawrence begins his third year on the job, Rutgers is scrambling to make up $121 million in salary increases to which it is already committed and to postpone needed maintenance, including work on the balky elevator at the law school that stranded a Federal judge between floors last year. 
 Faculty members who greeted Dr. Lawrence's installation as a relief from what they perceived as the imperious administration of his predecessor, Edward J. Bloustein, now complain that they find Dr. Lawrence aloof, particularly on budget questions.
"I was as high as the sky on him when he came here," said Stanley Hall, a chemistry professor on the university's Newark campus. "Now I'm kind of at a low ebb."
Meanwhile, the faculty union, whose contract expired in June, is talking about a "job action" after students return from winter break on Jan. 19 if the administration does not agree to such requests as higher pay for teachers with long tenure and more liberal family leave policies.
At the same time, the faculty union is supporting members of student government who have disrupted meetings of the university's governing board and staged sit-ins at university buildings to protest tuition increases and demand funds for a statewide student lobbying group. Amid these challenges, Dr. Lawrence maintains an air of managerial aplomb that might seem more attuned to his former role as provost of Tulane University, the private university in New Orleans that he left in 1990, than to the hurly-burly of a public institution with four times the enrollment.
He is moving ahead with his own agenda, confident that the faculty will settle, that the State House will open its purse and that disruptive students will behave. His focus is on strengthening undergraduate instruction that suffered over the last decade as administrators focused on new construction and on scientific research. He is requiring more thorough examination of the academic achievements of prospective faculty members, has created refresher courses in teaching for faculty members who want to improve their skills and is attacking the organizational red tape that he thinks contributes to frazzled tempers in hard economic times.
 
What Chaos?
 He scoffed at reports of despair and chaos at the university.
"Do you see chaos around here? No," he said. "Am I backed into a corner by the funding cuts? No. Am I convinced that the state is not doing enough for us? Yes."
Dr. Lawrence's "top, highest priority" is to restore the ranks of full-time faculty members at Rutgers, which has hired an increasing number of less expensive part-timers over the last four years. The university's New Brunswick campus employed just 10 part-time instructors in 1989, and has 113 today.
The president also wants to attack the $110 million backlog of needed maintenance and repairs that has accumulated since the mid-1980's, when the backlog was just $10 million.
Besides creating a vice presidency for undergraduate education and a faculty and student committee on reforming undergraduate education, Dr. Lawrence opened centers for tutoring and special workshops in students' fields. In their first term last fall, 1,700 students went to the evening learning centers, and the biggest complaint seems to be that they are not open late enough.
In addition, he created training centers for undergraduate teachers, where faculty members sit down with "master teachers" for ideas on improving their work.
Dr. Lawrence ticks off these initiatives in a brisk, boardroom style with more of the M.B.A. about it than the 16th-century Romance languages and culture that are his academic specialities. He crackles with virile corporate neologisms -- "I'll ball park the figures," "We have to prioritize" and "That's my M.O."
"I'm a humanist, but I'm also a T.Q.M. type," he said in reply to a question about his style. "Total quality management. I believe in discipline, sound management and accountability."
Dr. Wells Keddie, the president of the faculty union, the campus chapter of the American Association of University Professors, credits Dr. Lawrence with improving undergraduate education. "In the last 15 years it was clear to anyone with a willing eye to see that undergraduate education was playing second fiddle to research, and Dr. Lawrence is trying for better balance."
But Dr. Keddie accused the present administration of being negative toward union negotiators. "I have decided that there are people in power in the central administration that have decide to demonize this union and its leadership."
To some students, the issue should be money today, to stabilize or even to reduce tuition, not long-range changes handed down from the president's suite of offices in Old Queens.
 
'There Is a Crisis'
 "Our position is that there is a crisis in higher education," said Rob Hill, a 1992 graduate and now head of United Students of New Jersey, whose supporters have disrupted administration meetings to press demands for funds for their lobbying group. "Most people except Lawrence seem to recognize that students are the main people who can solve this crisis, who can go to Trenton and fight for the students."
But Rebecca Rolnick, assignment editor of the student newspaper, The Daily Targum, said the depth of students' support for the undergraduate colleges' student government groups was hard to gauge.
"There is some support for the student governing associations on this, but I have no idea how much or how little, she said. "I would say that this is not something that has got people tearing down our door or writing a lot of letters to us about."
Meanwhile, Dr. Lawrence angered many faculty members by having his deans, without consulting with department members, draw up contingency plans for cutting department budgets by 5, 10 or 15 percent if the need should arise.
"My real concern is that this was done to the exclusion of the faculty," said Dr. Hall, the professor of chemistry, who is also a member of the University Senate. "They never brought this in to us and said: 'This is what might have to be done. What can you do to help?' Instead we have a lot of rumors going around about the weak departments that are going to get it."
Dr. Lawrence is not inclined to pause for the ritual bewailing of budget cuts and the grim vows to squeeze help from Trenton that the faculty union and some students want to hear.
"We have to be realistic," he said. "We have to be accountable and we have to address the problems that exist today."

HEADLINE: Shock in a Land of Lifetime Jobs: 35 Managers Dismissed in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The unthinkable has happened in Japan, and it has touched a nerve in the ranks of the nation's middle managers.
A well-known maker of audio and video equipment, Pioneer Electronic, conceded today that it was essentially firing 35 middle managers, a candid admission that Japanese companies have begun to violate their long-cherished policies of lifetime employment. 
 Such a move would barely attract notice in the United States, where thousands of employees are sometimes given pink slips in a day. But in Japan, the commitment to keeping people employed through good times and bad is a pillar of a management system in which Japanese workers remain highly dedicated to their companies. And the move, in the midst of a severe economic slump, portends significant changes in the Japanese corporate culture.
 
 
'It Has Come to This'
 "My first reaction, honestly, was, 'My God, it has come to this,' " an automobile executive said. But he quickly added, "If the current slump continues for another year or two, a lot of companies will be doing the same thing."
Pioneer, a Tokyo-based maker of car stereos, laser-disk players and other other electronics gear, did not actually fire the employees outright, a spokesman said. Rather, it told the managers in late December that they would have until the end of January to retire.
If the managers, all in their 50's, did retire, they would receive a hefty bonus. If they didn't, they would eventually be dismissed. "This is actually, practically, a dismissal," the spokesman, Yojiro Orita, said.
Takeo Naruse, deputy general manager of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, a lobbying group, called the Pioneer move "shock therapy." He said most other companies would not resort to such drastic actions, which could hurt company morale. Still, he said, "Gradually, Japanese employment practices are changing."
To be sure, lifetime employment has never been universal. Small and medium-sized companies, which often supply components to large companies, frequently lay off workers and act as a buffer to help the big companies maintain full employment. And even at large corporations, the job guarantee does not apply to legions of part-time or temporary workers. But in the case of Pioneer, a leading electronics company, the affected managers are full-time employees.
Some experts said Pioneer's approach was a slightly stricter version of what was now happening quietly in many businesses, with managers being asked to retire for the good of the companies. The procedure is called "kata tataki," or a tap on the shoulder. Most employees accept the offer, although they usually have the option of declining if they are willing to accept lower pay or a lesser job.
Many employers insist that they are not dismissing workers, but the boundary between forced resignations and voluntary departures is becoming very narrow. "Most companies have been terminating middle managers already for a long time," said Kazunori Morishita, president of Bright Career, a firm that helps workers find new jobs. "But they don't say, 'If you don't agree, you will be fired.' "
Many economists have questioned how much longer Japanese companies can continue their practice of lifetime employment in the face of the severe economic slump. During the speculative "bubble economy" of the late 1980's, companies actively hired, believing the economy would keep expanding. Now that the economy has slowed, many employees are no longer necessary.
 
Redundant Workers
 Some economic research organizations estimate that about 1 million employees in Japanese companies, out of the nation's total employment of about 65 million, are redundant. This underemployment, which drags down corporate earnings, is in some sense a bigger problem than unemployment, which is still a low 2.3 percent.
So far, many companies have announced plans to cut thousands of employees in the next few years. But they insist they will do that by reducing hiring, offering voluntary retirements or transferring employees to other divisions or to subsidiaries.
Many companies bend over backward to avoid layoffs -- by paying people to stay home, for example. Or a steel company with excess employees might lend them to an auto company with a shortage of workers.
 
Fears of Worker Shortage
 Part of the resolve to hang on to employees stems from fear that because of Japan's low birth rates, the severe worker shortage that plagued the nation until recently will reoccur when the economy recovers.
Another aspect of Japanese management that is changing is the seniority system, in which promotions and salaries tend to rise with the length of service. That has weighed down companies with many middle-aged managers with high salaries but little opportunity to advance. Now, some leading companies like Honda and Fujitsu are moving toward a system in which pay is based on merit, at least for top managers.
"In the old, traditional system, you work long and are eventually promoted to manager," said Mr. Orita, the Pioneer spokesman. "That system can no longer work because we're moving into a severe economic situation. So we're forced to look at each manager's achievements."
Mr. Orita said the 35 employees, whose identities were being kept secret even in the company, were chosen because they were not performing up to par. Because of their seniority, many have the rank and salary of a section chief but have no one reporting to them.
 
Morale May Suffer
 Some outsiders questioned the move, saying that eliminating 35 employees out of more than 1,000 managers saves Pioneer barely any money and will hurt morale. While its profits are dropping, Pioneer is still making money, unlike many other consumer electronics companies.
A few months ago, the president of TDK, a manufacturer of magnetic tapes, proposed paying about 50 older managers 90 percent of their salaries if they would stay home until they reached retirement age. But the employees revolted, forcing the president to rescind the plan.
Mr. Orita said that when Pioneer employees learned about the forced retirements from newspapers or television -- the company did not announce them internally -- some managers were shocked and feared they would be the next to get the tap on the shoulder. But, he said, the move could raise the morale of younger executives who resent having promotions blocked by older managers who do not work as hard.
As he emerged from work today at the company's headquarters, one manager in his 30's said the action was "drastic" and would hurt morale. Another merely shrugged. "It's strict," he said, "but it's unavoidable."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Proposes to End 'Back-Door Financing'

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
It has become a familiar ritual. Every year, New York State faces another yawning budget gap. And every year, it comes up with another creative financing maneuver to balance its books and borrow money for things like prisons and roads.
The schemes have given New York State a reputation for off-budget financial legerdemain and saddled the state with one of the lowest credit ratings in the country. But on Wednesday, to the cautious praise of fiscal watchdogs who have long criticized his borrowing practices, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed changing the way the state does its long-term borrowing.
 
No More Sleight of Hand
 Under the proposal, quasi-governmental authorities like the Urban Development Corporation would no longer be able to float bonds to build things they were never intended to build, like prisons. Nor would the state be able to sell things it already owns -- prisons, or sections of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway -- to its own authorities to raise money to balance its budget. 
 The goal of Mr. Cuomo's plan, he said in his State of the State speech, is to "give the people more say in how much debt we create and to stop back-door financing altogether." The State Budget Director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, said that it would eventually put an end to much of the borrowing by authorities, borrowing that costs the state far more in annual interest payments than borrowing by the state itself.
 
They Want Details
 Legislative leaders said that they would have to see more details before they could comment fully on the plan. But it may have a better than usual chance in the Legislature this year, because it has the support of State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, a Republican who has repeatedly charged that the budgetary remedies favored by Governor Cuomo, a Democrat, were no better than dressed-up money-laundering schemes.
"This is really a turning of the corner," Mr. Regan said in an interview. "You can't go back after this and say, 'How about a little money here, how about a little money there.' This is just a reversal of 30 years of horseplay."
New York State now owes about $24.3 billion, which eventually must be paid back by the taxpayers. In the current fiscal year, the state is paying $2.1 billion in interest alone.
 
More Scrutiny
 Under Mr. Cuomo's proposal, the state would probably not borrow any less than it does now. But its borrowing would be more subject to voter scrutiny, and would also result in more favorable interest rates and lower interest costs, Mr. Bulgaro said.
Currently the state is allowed to put only one bond issue before the voters at a time. This forces officials either to pile a lot of borrowing into a single large package and hope the voters will approve, or to resort to backdoor borrowing without voter approval. The last two bond issues -- a $1.98 billion environmental bond act in 1990 and an $800 million jobs bond act in November -- were defeated amid deep public disillusionment over state finances.
Mr. Cuomo's plan calls for amendments to the State Constitution that would allow the state to put more than one bond issue before the voters at a time, presumably in smaller amounts, so that the voters might be more willing to accept them.
The new bonds would also be backed by specific revenue sources, like the state income tax. Currently, money borrowed by quasi-governmental authorities is paid back through annual appropriations from the State Legislature, a practice disdained as unreliable by rating agencies, which therefore results in lower bond ratings and higher interest rates.
The difficulty is that the plan would require amendments to the Constitution, a long and difficult process that means the measures would not be enacted until 1996 at the earliest. In the interim, the Governor has left some legislators leery by proposing to create a new authority that could centralize state borrowing, with tighter voter controls, until the Constitution could be amended.
"The sum total of all the reforms will raise the state's credit rating, and once the voters understand the package they will approve it," Mr. Bulgaro said. "You will get a central review of the state's capacity to incur and afford debt, and we will not borrow to eliminate budget deficits. Debt would be used for capital purposes."
Budget watchdogs and officials at rating agencies reacted to the plan with a positive but wait-and-see attitude.
Cynthia Green, the senior research analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that monitors the state's finances, said that she welcomed efforts to change but that nothing short of a complete overhaul, including a full-scale study of the state's long-term borrowing needs, would be enough.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Borrowing Up 3d Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Consumers increased their borrowing in November for the third consecutive month, the longest string of advances in two years, the Government said today.
The outstanding consumer installment credit rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2 percent, to $723.9 billion, the Federal Reserve said. It rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in October and 2.4 percent in September. 
 The last time outstanding credit increased three months in a row was September through November in 1990. Before the latest gains, outstanding credit had shrunk for seven consecutive months.
The November report fits with other economic indicators, including surveys showing a jump in consumer confidence after the Presidential election and chain-store reports showing the best Christmas sales in four years.
But, economists warn that the spending will not continue unless businesses pick up the pace of their hiring.
"Ultimately, for the upturn in consumer spending to be sustained, job growth has to be better because job growth affects income growth," said Allen Sinai, an economist at the Boston Company Inc., a unit of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Sinai said the most recent job gain reported by the Labor Department, 64,000 in December, "might not sustain the optimism of the household sector that we've seen develop since the election."
Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of all economic activity, is crucial to the recovery. During and after the recession, loans outstanding shrank as cautious consumers reduced the debt they had incurred during the go-go years of the 1980's.
In November, revolving loans outstanding edged up at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, to $250.6 billion, the fourth consecutive increase.
Automobile loans jumped at a 3.3 percent annual rate, to $257.8 billion, after a 1.3 percent decline in October.
Other consumer loans advanced at a 2.3 percent annual rate, to $215.5 billion. This category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations.
The various changes left total consumer debt not secured by real estate at the highest total since March.

HEADLINE: Pausing to See Poverty, and to Remember Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Sure, they're New Yorkers -- pushing and shoving and scrapping their way through the day. But these people belie the popular image of the jaded and grumbling Gothamite. They do not scorn the homeless men who wander past them on the subway. They are moved by stories of middle-aged women thrown out of work for the first time in their lives by the recession.
And for them, giving to charity is a cathartic experience. They send donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund because they feel they must try to rid their city of some of its suffering.
 
'Maybe Next Year'
 "How fortunate we are to have the possibility of feeding our hungry as individuals," Jacqueline Simon of Manhattan wrote in a note that she enclosed with her donation of $1,000. "We do not need the marines, just our personal humanity and your fine services. How shameful it is that there are people in our generous country in the sad and dramatic straits you describe each day." 
 Other contributors also expressed frustration with poverty in New York City.
"Every year I hope the need will be smaller -- or at least no greater," wrote Lauren W. Field of Manhattan, who also gave $1,000. "Once again, I am disappointed. Maybe next year I won't be."
Added Peggy Straus of Manhattan, who sent $ 10: "I wish it were possible to say that I've noticed any kind of improvement in meeting the needs of the poor and the helpless. But if anything, their needs continue to go largely unmet, as government turns its attention elsewhere."
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped tens of thousands of people whose lives seemed devoid of hope. The New York Times pays the expenses of the Neediest Cases campaign, so all contributions are given directly to seven charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
In her letter to the fund that she enclosed with a $300 check, Joan Skurnik of Manhattan posed a question: "Dare we hope things will be better next year?"
"I wish I could do more -- New York has been good to me and you have been good to New Yorkers," she wrote. "However, as this century closes, more people than ever are in need. Something has gone terribly wrong with our social contract."
And Harriette A. Simons of Manhattan sent $100, explaining that she was giving to the Neediest Cases for the first time because she was upset by the growing misery in the United States and around the world.
"Perhaps the pictures and stories from Somalia and Bosnia sharpened and prodded my conscience," she wrote. "Suddenly I feel personally involved."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Fears of Conflict Lift Dollar; Gold Prices Also Move Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher yesterday in busy currency trading as political instability heated up around the world.
Gold prices also settled mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.20 an ounce, up 50 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 35 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $329.25. 
 The dollar advanced overnight in Europe, setting the stage for a strong opening when trading shifted to domestic markets. Analysts said the dollar was in demand again as a "safe haven" currency, as it often is in times of world turmoil.
Iraq rejected a Western ultimatum that it remove missiles from southern Iraq and said any allied attack would provoke a counterattack.
And in Yugoslavia, Serbian gunmen killed the Deputy Prime Minister of Bosnia and Herzegovina at a roadblock in Sarajevo.
"There are not a lot of reasons to sell the dollar," said Frank Pusateri, a vice president of the Bank of Boston. "There is still concern over Iraq and the Bosnian minister."
 
 
A Brief Selloff
 The dollar sold off briefly after a report on December unemployment. The Labor Department said the jobless rate held at 7.3 percent last month. Currency traders focused on the gain of 64,000 jobs, which was well below analysts' expectations of gains ranging from 100,000 to 120,000.
Still, Mr. Pusateri noted that most other world economies were perceived as being "in worse shape than we are," and the dollar recovered to close at its highs for the day.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 125.42 Japanese yen, from 125.09 yen at the Thursday close. Later in London, it fell to 124.25 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.35 yen, up from 125.15 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5407, from $1.5345 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.5320 to buy 1, more expensive than $1.5315 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Thursday rates, included: 1.6465 German marks, up from 1.6365; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4945; 5.6020 French francs, up from 5.5635; 1,508.25 Italian lire, down from 1.510.00, and 1.2825 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2801.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with the late Thursday rates, included: 1.6375 German marks, unchanged; 1.4940 Swiss francs, down from 1.4947; 5.5715 French francs, up from 5.5630; 1.8405 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8390; 1,497 Italian lire, down from 1,513, and 1.2820 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2795.

HEADLINE: Opening Up Japanese Politics

 BODY:
After 36 years of one-party dominance, Japan appears headed toward competitive politics. The leading faction of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has shattered, pointing the way to a realignment that could eventually bring an American-style two-party system. For a time, political infighting could make it harder for Tokyo to deliver on diplomatic deals. In the longer run, democratic competition would be good for Japan, and the U.S.
Ichiro Ozawa, Japan's most formidable younger politician and its most fiercely ambitious, forced the split. After building his career as the protege of Shin Kanemaru, the disgraced "godfather" of Japanese factional politics, Mr. Ozawa has now cleverly, if cynically, reinvented himself as the champion of political reform. 
 That new image should help him in the wake of the big political corruption scandals that have sparked anger in a usually complacent electorate. But it should also help the reform cause; major changes rarely happen in Japan without powerful sponsors.
Mr. Ozawa is still working out the details of his reform agenda. The most effective steps would be strictly enforced limits on political contributions, comprehensive disclosure requirements and a long-overdue reapportionment of parliamentary seats to reflect urbanization.
At present, large secret contributions are made with an eye to steering government business toward the contributors, often at the expense of foreign competitors. The rural bias in Parliament gives extra weight to protectionist rice growers and other farmers. This comes at the expense of urban consumers, who prefer more competitive retail prices and more government spending on social services. They also tend to be Japan's most internationally minded citizens.
The rise of a more competitive politics is likely to give ordinary Japanese greater influence in public affairs. By making himself their champion, Mr. Ozawa can accelerate this process.
One-party rule has guided Japan through decades of economic success. But that success has now pushed a new international and social agenda to the fore, an agenda that would benefit mightily from political competition and anti-corruption reforms.
As different as the U.S. and Japanese political systems are, Americans in 1993 can readily empathize with the disgust ordinary Japanese feel toward "money politics" and their desire for constructive change.

HEADLINE: In Bad Times, U.S. Should Assist States More

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Tax That Rides the Tides" (Op-Ed, Dec. 22), Ralph Bradburd's proposal for a permanent Federal income tax surcharge that automatically varies inversely with the unemployment rate is a sensible way to attack the deficit problem and the need for short-term economic stimulus. It is one of those long-term structural reforms that, once enacted, would make most people wonder why it had not been done years earlier. 
 A complement to this surcharge would be a permanent program of Federal countercyclical aid to state and local governments, similar to one we had in the late 1970's. As in that program, the total the Federal Government provides each year would depend on how bad economic conditions are nationally, with the program winding down as the economy recovers. Like the earlier program, the per capita amount each state received should depend on its unemployment rate, with a threshold rate below which a state receives nothing.
Unlike the Federal Government, state governments respond strongly to recession, but in ways that make it worse: they cut back spending and increase taxes, to balance budgets thrown into deep deficit by recession. Federal assistance not tied to any specific type of spending would be immediately effective in stopping such recession-deepening actions by the states. After all, cutting programs and raising taxes are not popular things to do. Governors and legislators would love to stop doing them.
Like the income tax surcharge, this program combines short-term stimulus and a long-term deficit reduction strategy. Both need to be permanent and automatic to realize their promise.
 
DICK NETZER
Prof. of Economics and Public Administration, New York University
New York, Dec. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: German Law Won't End Immigration Problems

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Germany Closes the Gate" (editorial, Dec. 9) you criticize the accord reached by Germany's major parties severely to limit entry of foreigners seeking to escape persecution or economic hardships in their countries. Unfortunately, this policy, once enacted into law in 1993, will not solve the problems of illegal immigration, which will increase sharply, and of right-wing backlash. 
 True, Germany cannot absorb all who want to better their economic conditions, but an immigration policy based on a quota system, as stipulated in bills introduced in the Parliament this year by the Alternative '90 and Greens deputies, would be a partial solution. Those bills would integrate foreigners into German society, granting them more civil rights after five years of residence and German citizenship for children of foreign parents born on German soil.
Unfortunately, most Government deputies are opposed to a quota system based on the concept that Germany should be a country of immigration; thus it is unlikely this proposal will be implemented soon.
There is hope, however, that citizenship will be granted to foreigners more easily. You are not correct in saying that German citizenship is denied to a Turkish guest worker who has lived in Germany for 30 years. Any foreigner who has resided in Germany for 15 years (and spouse and children for less time) can apply for citizenship before January 1996, but may not have dual citizenship. Any foreigner younger than 23 is entitled to apply for citizenship after eight years' residence, including six years' attendance at a German school. The procedure, however, is complex, time-consuming and costly.
Critics of limited immigration say convincingly that national solutions to migration problems will not work without international efforts to remove the causes of large-scale movement of poor people to wealthier countries. For the German Government and other West European governments to try to buttress a Fortress Europe policy will fail as long as the gap widens between the first world (United States, Canada, Western Europe) on one side and the second world (former Communist bloc states) and third world (most African, Asian and Latin American states) on the other.
First world states must share more of their wealth with poorer states in order to slow down the exodus of people. An international social charter is needed that would provide minimum protection for workers and families in their home countries on a global scale. Finally, wealthy states must adopt foreign policies that would assist, rather than harm, third world states.
 
GERARD BRAUNTHAL
Amherst, Mass., Dec. 21, 1992
 
The writer retired as a professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts.

HEADLINE: Shock in a Land of Lifetime Jobs: 35 Managers Dismissed in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The unthinkable has happened in Japan, and it has touched a nerve in the ranks of the nation's middle managers.
A well-known maker of audio and video equipment, Pioneer Electronic, conceded today that it was essentially firing 35 middle managers, a candid admission that Japanese companies have begun to violate their long-cherished policies of lifetime employment. 
 Such a move would barely attract notice in the United States, where thousands of employees are sometimes given pink slips in a day. But in Japan, the commitment to keeping people employed through good times and bad is a pillar of a management system in which Japanese workers remain highly dedicated to their companies. And the move, in the midst of a severe economic slump, portends significant changes in the Japanese corporate culture.
 
 
'It Has Come to This'
 "My first reaction, honestly, was, 'My God, it has come to this,' " an automobile executive said. But he quickly added, "If the current slump continues for another year or two, a lot of companies will be doing the same thing."
Pioneer, a Tokyo-based maker of car stereos, laser-disk players and other other electronics gear, did not actually fire the employees outright, a spokesman said. Rather, it told the managers in late December that they would have until the end of January to retire.
If the managers, all in their 50's, did retire, they would receive a hefty bonus. If they didn't, they would eventually be dismissed. "This is actually, practically, a dismissal," the spokesman, Yojiro Orita, said.
Takeo Naruse, deputy general manager of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, a lobbying group, called the Pioneer move "shock therapy." He said most other companies would not resort to such drastic actions, which could hurt company morale. Still, he said, "Gradually, Japanese employment practices are changing."
To be sure, lifetime employment has never been universal. Small and medium-sized companies, which often supply components to large companies, frequently lay off workers and act as a buffer to help the big companies maintain full employment. And even at large corporations, the job guarantee does not apply to legions of part-time or temporary workers. But in the case of Pioneer, a leading electronics company, the affected managers are full-time employees.
Some experts said Pioneer's approach was a slightly stricter version of what was now happening quietly in many businesses, with managers being asked to retire for the good of the companies. The procedure is called "kata tataki," or a tap on the shoulder. Most employees accept the offer, although they usually have the option of declining if they are willing to accept lower pay or a lesser job.
Many employers insist that they are not dismissing workers, but the boundary between forced resignations and voluntary departures is becoming very narrow. "Most companies have been terminating middle managers already for a long time," said Kazunori Morishita, president of Bright Career, a firm that helps workers find new jobs. "But they don't say, 'If you don't agree, you will be fired.' "
Many economists have questioned how much longer Japanese companies can continue their practice of lifetime employment in the face of the severe economic slump. During the speculative "bubble economy" of the late 1980's, companies actively hired, believing the economy would keep expanding. Now that the economy has slowed, many employees are no longer necessary.
 
Redundant Workers
 Some economic research organizations estimate that about 1 million employees in Japanese companies, out of the nation's total employment of about 65 million, are redundant. This underemployment, which drags down corporate earnings, is in some sense a bigger problem than unemployment, which is still a low 2.3 percent.
So far, many companies have announced plans to cut thousands of employees in the next few years. But they insist they will do that by reducing hiring, offering voluntary retirements or transferring employees to other divisions or to subsidiaries.
Many companies bend over backward to avoid layoffs -- by paying people to stay home, for example. Or a steel company with excess employees might lend them to an auto company with a shortage of workers.
 
Fears of Worker Shortage
 Part of the resolve to hang on to employees stems from fear that because of Japan's low birth rates, the severe worker shortage that plagued the nation until recently will reoccur when the economy recovers.
Another aspect of Japanese management that is changing is the seniority system, in which promotions and salaries tend to rise with the length of service. That has weighed down companies with many middle-aged managers with high salaries but little opportunity to advance. Now, some leading companies like Honda and Fujitsu are moving toward a system in which pay is based on merit, at least for top managers.
"In the old, traditional system, you work long and are eventually promoted to manager," said Mr. Orita, the Pioneer spokesman. "That system can no longer work because we're moving into a severe economic situation. So we're forced to look at each manager's achievements."
Mr. Orita said the 35 employees, whose identities were being kept secret even in the company, were chosen because they were not performing up to par. Because of their seniority, many have the rank and salary of a section chief but have no one reporting to them.
 
Morale May Suffer
 Some outsiders questioned the move, saying that eliminating 35 employees out of more than 1,000 managers saves Pioneer barely any money and will hurt morale. While its profits are dropping, Pioneer is still making money, unlike many other consumer electronics companies.
A few months ago, the president of TDK, a manufacturer of magnetic tapes, proposed paying about 50 older managers 90 percent of their salaries if they would stay home until they reached retirement age. But the employees revolted, forcing the president to rescind the plan.
Mr. Orita said that when Pioneer employees learned about the forced retirements from newspapers or television -- the company did not announce them internally -- some managers were shocked and feared they would be the next to get the tap on the shoulder. But, he said, the move could raise the morale of younger executives who resent having promotions blocked by older managers who do not work as hard.
As he emerged from work today at the company's headquarters, one manager in his 30's said the action was "drastic" and would hurt morale. Another merely shrugged. "It's strict," he said, "but it's unavoidable."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 16; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

HEADLINE: College Curriculums Shaken to the Core

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3D

 BODY:
EVER SINCE Stanford University overhauled its curriculum in 1988 from a rigid core of courses dealing with Western civilization to one that includes few required courses and a larger, more varied menu of subjects on women and minorities from which students can choose, life hasn't been the same at the nation's colleges and universities.
College core curriculums, those courses that supposedly represent the core of learning that each institution wants to instill in its graduates, are undergoing a reformation. The process is leaving the intellectual underpinnings of some institutions teetering and others firmly set upon a new educational path. 
 The major battle in this revolution pits those who believe the core should be based on the Western canon against those who support a broader, multicultural base rich in the voices of women, minorities and foreign cultures. But an examination of curriculum revisions nationwide indicates that while this struggle draws the passion and attention, it is a lesser issue whose heat masks the main question: whether a particular American college or university needs a core curriculum, and if so, what purpose it should serve.
It is a challenge that few institutions are consciously undertaking. But whether by design or default, a clear trend in core curriculums is emerging: American colleges and universities are moving away from an emphasis on content -- requiring all students to take specific courses in which they will study the same texts -- and toward an emphasis on intellectual processes: requiring students to sample certain subjects, within which they can take any courses as long as they are taught to think critically and analytically.
According to a survey by the American Council on Education, an association of 1,700 public and private colleges and universities, the percentage of its members that maintained core curriculums in the spring of 1992 was 80 percent, down from 82 percent in 1987. But Clifton Conrad, a professor of higher education at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, said the slight drop over the last five years masks great turmoil among colleges. "Literally hundreds of them are revising their curriculums," Professor Conrad said.
O. T. Hargrave, associate dean for student academic affairs at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, which revised its curriculum this academic year, agrees that "There is across the country a lot of revision going on." At S.M.U., Mr. Hargrave said, curriculum revisions "focus more on teaching critical analysis rather than making sure we have covered all the basic contents."
However, according to Professor Conrad, who has been following the core curriculum debate closely: "People think it's just an issue about whose voices we hear, but it's much more profound. There are some essential questions we should be asking."
Students of higher education reform say many institutions are avoiding the task. Most, they say, are distracted by the debate over Western versus multicultural curriculums because it is an emotional one, defined by issues of race and gender. Among faculty members, too, there is some resistance to change because "the university is the most conservative of all our social institutions," said Professor Conrad.
"And, frankly," he added, "anytime anyone has certain control or privileges they are unwilling to give up their power."
There are questions of cost, too: New materials often must be purchased and new professors hired to teach the new courses.
As a result, revised curriculums often are politicized by the fights over Western versus non-Western thought and the relative importance of each department or subject, and without any obvious educational focus, critics say. Indeed, many students earn bachelor's degrees without knowledge of "basic landmarks of history and thought," wrote Lynne V. Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, in a 1989 report, "50 Hours." The report urged institutions of higher learning to revise curriculums so that undergraduates study a more cohesive, focused curriculum, including Western thought, math, science and social science.
The endowment backed its complaints with evidence: 25 percent of 700 college seniors surveyed in 1989, for example, did not know that Columbus landed in the Western Hemisphere before 1500, according to a Gallup poll released with the endowment's study. And most students surveyed could not identify Magna Carta. "Many American colleges and universities fail to provide enough structure in curriculums," the Endowment report concluded.
SOME STUDENTS concur, saying they feel as if they are in a supermarket making disparate selections that find them at the checkout counter without the makings of a complete, intellectually nutritious meal and graduating without a sense of what they know. Other students have avoided institutions with cafeteria-style curriculums.
When Jeff A. Zanarini graduated from high school in Omaha, Neb., three years ago, for example, he visited Stanford. He was turned off, he said, by the smorgasbord approach to curriculum. "Universities like Stanford have really gone too far," said Mr. Zanarini, now a junior with a double major in economics and French at Southern Methodist University, whose curriculum is largely based on the Western canon and requires students to take one multicultural course. "Every student expects some non-Western course; I feel I'm getting the right dose at S.M.U."
For administrators and faculty who may feel less sure, the Association of American Colleges last month released a 127-page book, "Core Curriculum and Cultural Pluralism: A Guide for Campus Planners," by Betty Schmitz, director of the Curriculum Transformation Project at the University of Washington.
Meanwhile, to fill the vacuum that has resulted from the battle over core curriculums, individual schools and departments in which students major are producing increasingly structured curriculum requirements of their own. The purpose of these requirements -- to equip graduates for the job market -- stands in marked contrast to the purpose of their progenitors.
Columbia University instituted the grandfather of core curriculums in 1919, a year after the end of World War I. Columbia took war issues as a model for an innovative course called "Contemporary Civilization." The idea won faculty support by promising to provide students with a common background of ideas and by spanning compartmentalized disciplines. But the course also had an ideological mission: "Contemporary Civilization" would inoculate young people against Bolshevism and other subversive doctrines. One dean said it would produce students "who shall be safe for democracy."
That purpose rarely obtains on today's college campuses. Rather, new core curriculums, where instituted, must be geared to a world that has experienced an information explosion, the globalization of national economies and a radically changing job market.
There are many ways to design core curriculums that will achieve these new ends. At some institutions, the debate comes down to using the Western canon or a multicultural curriculum as stepping stones to critical thinking. Western core advocates and universities that embrace the "Great Books" -- disparagingly referred to by some as works by Dead White European Males, or DWEM -- argue that certain universal truths speak to all generations of students. This is a Western culture, they say, and all students should understand its underpinnings.
Supporters of multicultural curriculums say they recognize that knowledge is neither finite nor static. This nation, they maintain, is a multicultural society whose constituents bring strength and vigor to college studies. Core curriculums should include these new voices, proponents say, and new ways to teach students how to approach learning and thinking.
At other institutions the debate seems to be between structuralists, who advocate a rigid set of courses required of all students, and advocates of choice, who see little merit in all students studying the same materials. At St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., for instance, the curriculum is based on the Western core, with no apologies. "We are supplying students with the common and the universal root of their present conditions," said Eva T. H. Brann, dean of the college. And works by Asian or African-American women writers are "not central to the tradition."
"They say everyone should read the same thing," said Henry Rosovsky, the architect of Harvard University's core curriculum, disparaging the structuralists as politically motivated. "Our curriculum offers choice."
Harvard's core was revamped in 1978, well before Stanford triggered the current debate, but because of Harvard's stature it remains a lightning rod in the curriculum wars. The Harvard core, say critics, is too broad and poorly focused. "It is not a core," said William J. Bennett, the United States Secretary of Education from 1985 to 1988 and now a fellow at the Hudson Institute, a conservative research institution. Mr. Bennett derisively called Harvard's curriculum "core light," and added: "The Harvard core is essentially a group of professorial idiosyncrasies elevated to the status of a seeming coherent core."
Not so, responds Mr. Rosovsky, who chronicled some of the debate in his book "The University: An Owner's Manual" (Norton, 1990). Harvard students must take 16 courses across a spectrum of 10 academic areas including historical studies, literature and arts, social analysis, science and moral reasoning.
Within these areas, students are offered so many choices that they could graduate without ever taking a course in Western civilization. "Can one -- as has often been asked -- graduate from Harvard without reading Shakespeare?" Mr. Rosovsky writes. "Yes, but one cannot get a degree without reading literary classics in a critical and analytical way under the guidance of a specialist."
 
'At Harvard, We Have Chosen One Way'
 "There is no one way to define an educated person," Mr. Rosovsky added in an interview. "The requirements are aimed at broadening someone's intellectual perspective. At Harvard, we have chosen one way. I am not saying it is the only way."
Scholars at the University of California at Berkeley agree. "Knowledge comes in a lot of different ways, and the strength of a larger university is its ability to offer intellectual diversity," said Arnold L. Lieman, chairman of the psychology department.
At Berkeley, for instance, the 14 colleges and schools that constitute the university design their own curriculums and maintain their own requirements. Two courses are required of all students: "American Cultures" and basic English. Besides those, students fill their plates with a dizzying array of requirements for their majors.
There have been few cries of protest from students on campus, many of whom say they welcome the choice. "U.C. Berkeley offers enough in terms of selection," said Nick Perlmuter, a junior from Huntington Beach, Calif., majoring in environmental science. Mr. Perlmuter said he didn't feel cheated by the lack of other required courses because "what they are training us to do is go out and find the information, because it's already there, and analyze it."
Unlike many other universities, Boise State University in Idaho is asking hard questions about curriculum. The faculty is considering revisions that take a more measured approach, one that balances the Western canon with non-Western courses and that teaches all courses in a way that helps students think and analyze information in different ways. "A core curriculum should reflect certain common experiences or knowledge that most undergraduates should be exposed to," said Daryl E. Jones, interim executive vice president. "It is one of the things that binds us all together."
Currently Boise State maintains a 51-credit core curriculum, which requires students to take six credits of English composition and pass a writing exam, and 12 credits each of required courses in three areas: arts and humanities, social sciences, and natural science and mathematics. They are also required to take nine more elective credits in those three areas.
But as Boise State ponders revisions, "the key issue is how that relates to other cultures and other experiences and fits in the overall education of a student," Mr. Jones said. "We haven't resolved all the issues ourselves."
