SECTION: Section 6; Page 23; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4323 words

HEADLINE: A Nation of Readers Dumps Its Writers

BYLINE: By Katie Hafner; Katie Hafner is at work on a book about the consequences of German reunification.

 BODY:
In the Summer of 1990, barely six months after the Berlin wall fell, residents of Kommlitz, a small village near Leipzig in southeastern Germany, made a bizarre discovery. Their local garbage dump had been turned into a mountain of books. It looked as if a city library had been turned upside down and had its contents shaken out. It was a curiously arbitrary collection. Communist tracts were discarded along with German classics; Lenin's "State and Revolution" lay next to the works of Tolstoy. But most of the books were by East Germany's most celebrated fiction writers: Christa Wolf, Stefan Heym, Hermann Kant and Anna Seghers.
As it turned out, the main East German book distributor had simply dumped some 10 million volumes, emptying its warehouse to make way for a soft-drink repository. After people had picked through the books, taking what they wanted, the rest were buried in a huge pit. 
 East Germans threw away a lot of things after the wall came down. They abandoned their plastic two-stroke Trabants in favor of sturdy, speedy Volkswagen Golfs. They discarded their ill-cut blue jeans made of synthetic fiber and bought Levi's instead. When kiwis, avocados and tomatoes arrived in the stores, they stopped buying the tiresome native-grown apples and cabbage they had suffered for 40 years. And why not?
But the rejection of their own authors' books was the rejection of a collective soul. The collapse of Communist East Germany has taken its writers with it. Once among that nation's most elite and privileged citizens, they have suffered a summary fall from grace. Once heroes, they are now being accused of timidity and are falling into discredit. Once looked to for the truth, they are now mistrusted and, still worse, ignored.
East Germany was called the Nation of Readers. Its citizens adored their authors. Writers were the Oprah Winfreys and Phil Donahues of the nation, the ones to whom people turned for what the Germans call Lebenshilfe, or life help, the ones designated to answer the question: How do you get by in an authoritarian regime? It was in the pages of East German novels that such topics as alcoholism, homosexuality and abortion were first broached. Public readings were always standing room only, and often they turned into mass public confessionals. It was at readings, says Therese Hornigk, a literary historian in Eastern Berlin, that people realized they weren't alone. "People went to readings to experience solidarity and build up self-confidence," she says.
Christa Wolf, in particular, East Germany's most famous writer, was a kind of Mother Confessor. Wolf's cathartic, intensely personal and multilayered prose inspired thousands of people to write to her about their own lives. She employed a secretary just to help her answer the dozens of letters she received every day.
Prominent writers enjoyed commensurately privileged lives. They were free to travel to Western countries for lectures and readings. They lived in large apartments and houses in exclusive neighborhoods in East Berlin, and drove Western cars. Many of them had country homes as well. Some even kept bank accounts in Switzerland. When Wolf traveled, she was a diplomat-celebrity.
Even writers with mediocre talent could find a publisher and make a good living -- if they espoused the party line. As a rule, books in East Germany enjoyed enormous first printings by Western standards -- and still there was a shortage. East Germans waited for new works from Christa Wolf, Christoph Hein and Stefan Heym the way they waited for the oranges that were fleetingly available around Christmas. A first printing of 500,000 wasn't unusual for those writers, and their books would sell out within days. A volume of poetry would typically have a first print run of 20,000 copies, while in the West a first printing of 2,000 for a book of poetry is considered large. And, curiously enough, books were hoarded the way sugar and coffee were, just in the event of lean times. The central distributor in Leipzig hoarded millions of books, which is how it ended up with so many after the wall fell.
When East Germany became a nation in 1949, its writers were idealistic Socialists. Many of them moved there from the West because they believed that they were taking part in building the better of the two postwar Germanys. Christa Wolf and others participated in a writer-worker movement in the late 50's and early 60's, in which writers were encouraged to work in factories and then describe their experiences. With few exceptions, East German literature was characterized by its intensity and earnestness, by a culture of sacrifice and suffering -- one of Christa Wolf's favorite settings is a hospital. It was Socialist realism mixed with utopian dreaming. Protagonists might have flirted with the idea of going West, but the real heroes rejected emigration in the end.
Hermann Kant's 1965 novel, "The Auditorium," is a classic example. It is the story of an East German journalist's visit to his hometown in a frightening and disquieting West Germany. The journalist's brief trip turns into a personal confrontation with a divided Germany, and the lesson Kant imparts is a common one in East German fiction: the reactionary Western state is to be rejected in favor of the "new" Socialist one. "The Auditorium" was required reading in East German schools and there were one million copies in print.
In return for the adulation they bestowed, readers got a kind of intellectual balm. The books they took refuge in might have occasionally ruffled the state, but they seldom questioned the legitimacy of one-party rule. East German literature served to reinforce the idea of Communism, if not exactly the reality of it. And in return for its largess, the Communist state got a body of literature that inadvertently sustained rather than exposed the hard-edged, brutal reality of a dictatorship.
Morally, writers in East Germany lived a kind of double life. Their brand of dissidence was far more cautious than the radical dissidence of Vaclav Havel in Czechoslovakia and Gyorgy Konrad in Hungary. East German writers engaged in a constant balancing act, at once adherents to the "Project" of Socialism and purveyors of a truth that couldn't be found in East German newspapers. In her 1987 novel, "Accident/A Day's News," for example, Wolf wrote critically of the Chernobyl nuclear accident, after official East German press reports had minimized the event.
As in other East Bloc countries, in East Germany there was a culture of artistic allusion and linguistic evasion. Censors worked full-time to catch double- and triple-entendres. When the East German Government refused to print a book, authors occasionally published the book in West Germany. The Communist regime didn't discourage the practice, because it pocketed the hard currency. Writers who went too far in the eyes of the regime, like Gunter Kunert and Rainer Kunze, were simply exported to West Germany.
But a true literature of dissent like the Samizdat underground literature in the Soviet Union never appeared in East Germany. Writers drew much of their sustenance from the rejection of their other half, West Germany, as a land of crass consumerism still run by fascists. This bred a peculiarly weak tradition of defiance. "Much more than in other East Bloc countries, writers were very involved in the Project of Socialism," says Peter Schneider, a writer from Western Berlin. "This created a mental block, a fixation not to become West Germany. In thousands of pages of literature in East Germany, you never find the simple demand for democracy. In Czechoslovakia, on the other hand, you wouldn't meet a single serious writer after 1968 who would say, 'I'm still a Communist.' "
Although they could have left for the West, writers like Christa Wolf felt obligated to stay, especially during the period of mass emigration in 1961 just before the wall went up. Wolf received hundreds of letters from readers imploring her not to leave. "People needed me," she says. "People needed something to give them strength." Besides, Wolf says: "I couldn't have written the books I wrote anywhere else. There was nothing that interested me more than the country, its people and the conflict situation there."
Even after the wall fell in November 1989 and the nation was crumbling around them, East German intellectuals who had stayed held fast to the idea of a Third Way: Socialism with a human face. Deaf to their fellow citizens' demands for Western goods and hard currency, intellectuals instead issued declarations and manifestoes imploring East Germans to stay and help reform Socialism.
There were some who didn't stay. Through the years, East Germany lost many of its most talented and popular stars to the West. Some, like the dissident poet and songwriter Wolf Biermann, were forced to leave. After holding a concert in Cologne in late 1976, during which he sang songs with particularly pointed antigovernment lyrics, Biermann, a cross between Bob Dylan and Andrei Sakharov, was told by the East German authorities not to return. Biermann's expulsion set off a protest among his fellow writers, several of whom eventually followed him to West Germany.
For their part, West German writers were well aware of the effect their country's presence had on East German writers. The two groups shared a history and a language, but they had little in common as writers. Martin Walser, one of West Germany's most prolific novelists, says he felt more comfortable talking with writers from England and France than from East Germany. Encounters with Eastern colleagues were awkward because the writers all had a whiff of collusion about them. "It always made conversations very artificially polite," Walser recalls. "Hermann Kant was always very nice but I was never sure about his background."
Writers from the two halves of Germany still maintain separate branches of PEN, the writers' organization, and the question of whether they should merge is a topic of heavy debate. Writers from the former West Germany are reluctant to sit in the same room with writers from the former East Germany, and the Western PEN group is insisting that certain Communist members of the Eastern branch leave the organization before the two branches unite. Those who left East Germany before late 1989 are even more self-righteous. Monika Maron, an outspoken writer who has embraced the West wholeheartedly since leaving East Germany five years ago, says she can't imagine that the two PEN's will someday merge. "We're just waiting for them all to die out," she says of those in the Eastern branch.
Today, the question of who stayed and who left is a topic discussed with a lingering moral defensiveness. Maron left East Germany after she was unable to publish her first novel, "Flight of Ashes," there. "Flight of Ashes" is the story of an East German journalist and the unpleasant consequences she faces after writing the truth about the environmental conditions in and around the town of Bitterfeld. For years, East Germany's chemical industries had saturated the Bitterfeld surround with hazardous wastes, making it one of the most polluted spots in Europe. For anyone who traveled to within a few miles of the area, the filthy air and blackened rivers were impossible to overlook. After the East German authorities refused to print the book, Maron had it published in West Germany in 1981, then finally left seven years later.
Maron has taken on the style and biting humor that still distinguish many self-assured Western Germans from their Eastern counterparts. Her most recent novel appeared in 1991 to excellent reviews, and she has the air of someone satisfied to know that she was right after all, that the Christa Wolfs of the world were wrong. She moved to Hamburg nearly five years ago but keeps an apartment in Pankow, a quiet tree-lined neighborhood in Eastern Berlin where Wolf and other members of the East German literary set still live. But Maron is uncomfortable there; chance encounters with the writers who stayed are always awkward, and she is looking for an apartment in Western Berlin. "It's unbelievable to me that people who think for a living didn't see what a pile of filth and muck the entire country was," Maron says.
A FORM OF LITERARY AMNESIA HAS struck citizens in the erstwhile Nation of Readers. Ask people in Eastern Germany whether they read certain authors from the German Democratic Republic and they'll give a look of puzzlement mixed with guilt and shake their heads, as if the names are vaguely familiar, but they can't recall having read the books. If they did read them, they can't recall having liked them.
One of the most poignant scenes illustrating the precipitous fall of East German writers came at the annual Frankfurt Book Fair in October. While thousands of publishers and book agents from around the world were in deal-signing overdrive and dozens of authors read from their works, Hermann Kant read from his recently published memoir.
Four years ago, a public reading by Kant would have drawn hundreds. But his Frankfurt appearance was relegated to a local youth hostel on the fringes of the book fair's main action. The audience was composed of a group of fellow travelers. In an embarrassing development for Kant, it had just been disclosed that for all the years he presided over the powerful East German writers' union he had been an informant for the Stasi, the East German secret police.
"It was really very sad," says Frank Schirrmacher, the literary editor of the influential Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Germany's largest national daily newspaper, who attended Kant's reading. "This is where the whole story of East German literature ended, in the basement of a youth hostel in Frankfurt." As a bitter footnote, Schirrmacher adds that the very movement that started in that city in the 1920's with the founding of the Marxist-oriented Frankfurt Institute has been reduced to a roomful of depressed and broken old men with heart ailments. "Kant's reading was a kind of symbolic last encounter with the whole idea of Communist cultural understanding," says Schirrmacher.
Writers don't quite belong in the gallery of villains alongside Erich Honecker, the former East German leader who is now on trial in Berlin, or Erich Mielke, the former head of the Stasi, who is on trial for murder. But their ambiguous role has caused readers in the former East Germany to recoil from the literature that once helped them through the day; it sparked attacks from a generation of brash young critics and brought about a silence among the writers themselves.
After an initial flurry of essays once the wall came down, and a handful of memoirs, writers from the former East Germany stopped producing. The fall of Communism should have liberated writers -- instead it crippled them and exposed them to the world of harsh criticism. It pointed up the difference between writers in the West, who write because they believe they have something to say, and writers in the East, who wrote because their readers needed them to say something.
Schirrmacher started the onslaught in 1990, with an unprecedented attack on Christa Wolf. For years rumored to be on the short list for the Nobel Prize, Wolf had gained a worldwide reputation. Her subtly critical fiction and her readiness to take on contemporary German history made her a hero both to East German readers and West German critics. Through the years, the 63-year-old novelist's writing, translated into 27 languages, has engendered a voluminous body of secondary literature. She has a particularly large following among American feminists.
Shortly after the Berlin wall fell, Wolf published a 100-page book titled "What Remains," a novella she had written a decade earlier and kept in a desk drawer. The book is based on a period she spent under Stasi surveillance in the late 1970's after she protested the expulsion of Wolf Biermann.
As soon as Christa Wolf's book appeared in the spring of 1990, Schirrmacher did the unthinkable. With brazen disrespect, Schirrmacher, then 33, attacked older critics for having perpetuated the myth of an East German literature of dissent, and he attacked Wolf herself for having lacked the courage to publish the book 10 years earlier. If she had done so, Schirrmacher argued, she could have forced into public a discussion of the Stasi -- a topic conspicuously absent from East German literature -- much earlier. She claimed to be complaining about the Stasi, but she waited until it was safe to do it. She claimed to be a victim but was in fact a tacit collaborator.
Sensitive and unaccustomed to such harsh treatment, Wolf largely withdrew from public view. For the next two years, she declined invitations to appear at conferences and colloquia. Last September she went to Santa Monica, Calif., to begin a nine-month stay as a visiting scholar at the Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities. One of her conditions in accepting the invitation was that she be shielded from the press.
German literary critics have described Wolf's decision to leave Germany as a form of self-imposed exile, but she says she was simply looking for a way to get some work done. Life on the California shoreline appears to have had its effect on the intense Wolf. She's living close to the beach and has seen an acupuncturist for pain in her hip. More significantly, she is re-emerging as an intellectual voice. Last year, she gave two readings in New York, and two of her books are coming out this spring in English translation. In a recent telephone interview, she sounded positively mellow.
Wolf's California sojourn has also given her the time and distance she needs to reflect on her once and future role in German literature. She dismisses Schirrmacher's attack on her intellectual integrity as "arrogant nonsense." But in a way he was right. Wolf's exalted position as a virtual State Poet would have protected her from ugly consequences. If the East German authorities had refused to print her novella, she could have done what many of her colleagues and even she had done in the past -- published it in West Germany. "There could have been a real explosion," says Schirrmacher. Then he went a step further. While he was at it, he decided to pose some larger questions that no West German critic had yet dared ask. Were East Germany's biggest talents independent thinkers or panderers to the Communist regime? Were they the conscience of their nation or cowardly collaborators in the failed experiment of East Germany?
Sadly, they were a little bit of all these things. But what Schirrmacher and others have ignored is that they were also the most reliable chroniclers of a corner of history that the world is all too eager to forget.
EAST GERMAN WRITERS WHO counted on a built-in audience must grapple now with the vagaries of a fickle reading public; they must compete, in essence, with Stephen King. Many publishing houses in the former East Germany have folded or been bought out by Western firms and sharply reduced their lists, leaving hundreds of writers without a publisher at all. Many are now demanding unemployment benefits from the German Government.
People in Eastern Germany need a new kind of "life help" now. In the Literature Store halfway down a busy pedestrian mall in Potsdam near Berlin, customers pass by the shelf of serious literature at the door; barely stop to leaf through any number of tomes analyzing the fall of East Germany; ignore translations of Charles Bukowski and Richard Ford, and head for a table near the cash register. It is stacked with books offering tax advice, insurance primers, travel guides and language texts. When Eastern Germans do spend money on books, these are the books they buy.
Part of the reason people have stopped buying books is that they are no longer so affordable. The average price of a hard-cover book in East Germany was $4. Today it is $30, or the equivalent of a month's rent in the former East Germany. One influential German publisher says that although former East Germans account for one-fifth of the overall population in Germany today, they buy less than 2 percent of all books sold.
It's depressing to be irrelevant all of a sudden. Since the wall fell, fewer than a dozen copies of Kant's "Auditorium" have been sold. Kant's rambling house next to a lake on the outskirts of Berlin is being reclaimed by its Western owners and, given the recent news of his Stasi connections, he is uncertain of his future.
The chasm between writers and their public in the former East Germany has also taken some grotesque turns. The life of 79-year-old Stefan Heym was known to every East German schoolchild. Heym, a Jew, fled Hitler and fought in the United States Army during World War II, then moved to East Germany in 1952 out of a commitment to Socialism. He went on to become one of East Germany's most prolific and privileged writers. When he wrote books that weren't to the East German Government's liking, he simply had them published in the West.
A prickly personality, Heym has the air of someone who's seen it all. But even Heym was rattled by what happened to him last summer. He was sitting in a restaurant when a stranger, smiling politely, approached his table, then punched him in the face. "He came up to me and I thought I knew him. I thought he'd read my books," Heym recalls. "Instead he wanted to smash my skull." Heym's assailant turned out to be a former East German who had long since emigrated to the United States and was apparently intent on blaming Heym personally for the East Germans' 40 years of suffering under Communism. A few weeks later he got a note from another stranger calling him a "Commie Jewish swine."
ONCE THE Eastern Germans have learned how to file their taxes and buy their car insurance, once they have seen Miami and read a few airport novels, they might be ready to start reading serious literature again.
And what they find might surprise them.
Since the wall fell, a new generation of writers has emerged, and it is getting a lot of attention. These writers are twenty- and thirtysomething, and they are far more taken with Hemingway and Faulkner and Austrian Surrealists than they ever were with Christa Wolf or Stefan Heym. Theirs is a generation saved, perhaps, by its lack of investment in East-West politics. In the same way that it took someone of Schirrmacher's youth to attack a writer twice his age, it could take a new generation of writers to produce the next burst of literature in the former East Germany.
Durs Grunbein, outgoing and self-possessed, smokes a long slender cigar of Brazilian tobacco and sips Glenlivet whisky in the Cafe Einstein, a Viennese-style coffeehouse in Berlin that Berliners might describe as shicki-micki, a bit too chic for comfort. The 30-year-old poet is a rising star. His powerfully graphic poems have made him a darling among the Western critics, particularly Frank Schirrmacher. The Frankfurt paper publishes his poetry regularly. There's something frightening about the imagery in Grunbein's verse, and German critics welcome its anarchistic, occasionally criminal elements.
A Grunbein sample: " 'Still any bomb splinters?!' Good for spiked gums,/Installed in violet baby skulls./Tell me, which nurse pressed her thumb/unfeelingly into our soft fontanel?"
Grunbein, who considers Ezra Pound one of his biggest influences, explains that he wrote this after reading a poem by another young poet who lives in Cologne. He has much more of an affinity with this young peer in the West, to whom the poem is dedicated, than with writers like Christa Wolf.
These young writers see themselves less as East Germans than as writers who live in Germany. And they certainly have no hang-ups about parlaying the past three years into fiction. As the older writers hold back, the younger set is already getting attention.
Johannes Jansen, 26, and Holger Teschke, 34, are two good examples. Jansen, who writes abstract, experimental prose, has a contract with Suhrkamp Verlag, one of Germany's largest publishers, and has finished a trilogy. He is moving now toward "real stories," and is at work on a book-length parable whose protagonist is a blend of the hero of a Grimms Fairy Tale and Job. Teschke works as a producer at the famous Berliner Ensemble theater and he's on his way to the United States for a five-month stay at Amherst College, where he plans to write a novel about German reunification, possibly through the lens of the Thirty Years' War.
Still, the most likely source of a great and lasting literary work that tackles the fall of the Berlin wall and the collapse of Communism will be someone with the pure gift and historical reach of Christa Wolf. The wrenching period of the last three years is going to have to emerge in fictional form from someone of Wolf's stature -- perhaps from Wolf herself. No one has doubted her talent; it's her politics they question. Wolf says it is "laughable" for critics to expect a big literary work any time soon. She points out that it can take decades before a historic event is ready to be retold as fiction. Tolstoy wrote "War and Peace" 50 years after the Napoleonic wars; Hemingway wrote "A Farewell to Arms" 11 years after the Armistice.
Wolf's stay in Los Angeles, where such writers as Bertolt Brecht and Thomas Mann spent years in exile, may be just the prescription. "I think we'll see astonishing sentences from her," says the German writer Martin Walser. "A little California always does good," he adds, without a trace of humor. "Especially for the East German writers. They should all get stipends to go to California." That's not because they need a rest cure, but because they need some distance. Real distance, Walser adds, "from this terribly confining place. Germany."

HEADLINE: PROFILE;
At Milton, a Headmaster With a Difference

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD

 BODY:
SOON AFTER Edwin P. Fredie assumed duties as Milton Academy's new headmaster in the fall of 1991, he surprised the campus at the season's first assembly by standing outside the hall and personally greeting each student. His friendliness went against the stereotype of the aloof headmaster of a venerable, prestigious New England boarding school.
Then, having established a reputation for accessibility at the school, in Milton, Mass., Mr. Fredie also demonstrated his authority. At an assembly in the spring where candidates running for student-body president gave campaign talks, one junior laced his speech with expletives. Mr. Fredie promptly stood up to object, saying that such language was inappropriate in a public assembly. 
"It stunned people," said Leopolvo Maza, a teacher of Spanish. "Milton is known for its individualism. But people also realized he was bringing important ethical standards."
Mr. Fredie's actions have been under particular scrutiny because he is the first black to be named headmaster of one of the major American private schools, which are often seen as protectors of privilege.
Moreover, while his name rhymes with "tweedy," the 47-year-old Mr. Fredie is decidedly not preppy. He is a product of public school education, albeit Boston's best -- the Boston Latin School -- and his career has been spent as a public school teacher and principal. That background made him an unusual choice for a private ivy-covered institution that was founded in 1798 and includes among its graduates the poet T. S. Eliot, the architect R. Buckminster Fuller and Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Edward M. Kennedy. With 972 students on its red-brick campus 10 miles south of Boston, Milton is generally considered one of the most sought-after schools in the nation.
But Milton's teachers, administrators and alumni are virtually unanimous in praising the performance of Mr. Fredie, a round-faced man with a quiet, low-key manner and a reputation as a skilled administrator. "It is too early for a definitive judgment, but all the signs are very positive," said Carol Surkin, a 1955 Milton graduate, a trustee and a co-chairwoman of the search committee that picked Mr. Fredie.
William Moore, a teacher of French, said, "He has established a new tone, a very direct, human, tolerant tone." And, Mr. Moore said, Mr. Fredie "represents multiple perspectives on class and race, so he is ideal for an institution like Milton that is committed to diversity."
 
Lives on Campus
 Mr. Fredie lives on campus in Milton's headmaster's house, a comfortable New England-style clapboard dwelling, with his wife, Marcia. After he became headmaster, she quit her job as a merchandise coordinator at The Talbot's, a women's clothing-store chain. Two of the Fredies' children are students at Milton, while a son, Michael, is studying at the Coast Guard Academy and a daughter, Kenya, is entering the Ph.D. anthropology program at the University of Arizona this month.
Although Mrs. Surkin and other members of the search committee deny that race was a factor in Mr. Fredie's selection, a number of people familiar with Milton say that, like other leading prep schools, it has been making a determined effort to be more democratic, trying to transform itself into a more culturally diverse school reflecting the realities of contemporary America.
Mr. Fredie's name was suggested not by the consultant the school hired, but by the parents of a student who lived in Needham, another Boston suburb, where Mr. Fredie was the high school principal.
There Mr. Fredie, whose father was a home builder and whose mother was a lawyer, had developed a stellar reputation. He had introduced a tough core curriculum that helped raise students' test scores.
He had also coped with sharply falling enrollment and consequent devastating cutbacks in state and local financing for public education as Massachusetts towns were hit by the effects of a new law that restricted their ability to raise property taxes. Under Mr. Fredie, Needham High School went from 1,800 students in three grades to 1,000 students in four grades. Mr. Fredie had to reduce the number of teachers to 100, from 150.
Mr. Fredie acknowledged that when the search committee invited him for a job interview, he was reluctant. "I had this image of private schools in England, uniforms and Mr. Chips," he said in an interview.
But he went, and wowed the committee. "I was sitting next to him and I was amazed," said George E. Ayers, a vice president of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, based in Washington, D.C. "He was so warm, he had a glow of caring about students."
As Mrs. Surkin remembers it, that Mr. Fredie would be the first black headmaster of a prep school "was a subject that really didn't come up -- none of us cared."
 
A Warning on Donors
 But Mr. Ayers, who is also black, said he reminded the committee that some alumni, and potential donors, might be concerned. "I've spent 90 percent of my life being the only black dealing with a white world," he said. "I said, 'You'll definitely have some people with that concern.' "
There was a sense of shock that Mr. Fredie, who became interested in education while registering black voters in rural Georgia in 1965 and had since devoted himself wholeheartedly to the public education system, would want to move to a private school. After graduating from Boston University and receiving a master's degree from the Harvard School of Education, he taught at Harlem's Public School 129 in New York City and in the Needham public school system.
Mr. Fredie's answer is direct. He had become "frustrated and disappointed with public education," he said, and was planning to retire soon anyway, to seek a job in another field.
In his view, "public education is going in the wrong direction." For one thing, schools are burdened by an increasingly centralized bureaucracy, with more and more state mandates requiring reams of paperwork. "Less and less time is devoted to actually finding out what makes good students and teachers," he said.
In public schools, he said, "Everyone is on an assembly line. The structure of the school is based on economics, not educational excellence." Teachers, through their unions, "have become consumed by how much money they can make. They have become focused on what is good for them, not what is good for students."
"I know my colleagues will say that the problem is that kids from single-parent families are not prepared to learn," he said. "But any kid can succeed. What you need is a teacher who can challenge you."
The proof, Mr. Fredie said, can be found at Milton. "We have kids from very privileged backgrounds. And we have some from very dysfunctional families. But you can't tell the difference. The reason is that our classes are small and our teachers are dedicated."
At Milton, he said, "We have teachers who are not afraid to tell kids, 'I'll see you on Monday afternoon at 3, and you're going to be here till you get it right.' "
 
48 Percent Are Girls
 Milton starts with kindergarten, though the largest bulge of students is in the 9th through 12th grades; it has always been coeducational and today 48 percent of the enrollees are girls. Tuition for boarders is $19,000 a year. Some 25 percent of the students receive financial aid, and 10 percent are black, some of them from neighboring Mattapan, a heavily black and low-income section of Boston.
Milton's proximity to a large black community presents both an opportunity and source of concern. Last September, several black students from Milton High School showed up at Milton Academy for what was supposed to be a closed dance. A security guard, following orders, turned them away. But some students from the academy who knew the visitors came out and argued that the guard was discriminating based on their color.
Mr. Fredie moved swiftly to defuse the incident. He spoke about it in an assembly, and brought together the students and security guard to discuss the issue. The academy's security staff has also been directed to join special sessions devoted to multicultural awareness being run at the school by a private Boston company.
Deval Patrick, class of 1974, a member of Milton's board of trustees and a lawyer in Boston, said Mr. Fredie's actions showed one of his strengths -- he sees everything as an educational opportunity. "When there is a minor crisis," Mr. Patrick said, "he uses it to help kids mature."

HEADLINE: The Middle Class Goes Public

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
DURING the last generation, the idea of middle-class people enrolling their children in urban public schools has become something akin to letting the youngsters play in traffic: too dangerous for any sensible parent to even consider.
So when people move to a new city, they are often greeted with the kind of advice that Susan Krinsky, who lives in New Orleans, heard time and again: "You cannot, of course, send your kids to the public schools. Here is a list of the acceptable private schools." 
 But growing numbers of middle-class parents are organizing in defense of public schools. They contend that the horror stories about public schools have been exaggerated and tinted by racial stereotypes. And they say private schools present their own set of perils by creating a sheltered, homogeneous world for children who will graduate unprepared for a diverse society. Others say they simply cannot afford the high-priced tuition of private academies, and will fight to improve the public schools, for which they pay taxes anyway.
Whatever the reasons, public schools have lately been holding their own on enrollment, a generation after middle-class people began leaving in droves. Nationally, the number of children in private schools has leveled off in recent years at about 10.5 percent.
 
Nationwide Growth
 The successes of a group in Jackson, Miss., to restore racial and economic balance to public schools has inspired the creation of chapters nationwide called Parents for Public Schools. In Jackson, a racial integration plan in the 1980's fueled "white flight" that changed public school enrollment from 60 percent white to 80 percent black. The departure of middle-class families, along with their loss of faith in the schools, led to the failure of bond issues that threatened to eviscerate school programs.
In 1989, 26 parents joined in trying to persuade middle-class people to reconsider public schools. They targeted four elementary schools that had become virtually all black. In four years, they have succeeded in building an enrollment that reflects the racial makeup of those neighborhoods; the schools are now 60 to 65 percent white.
"We told people, 'Let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater,' " said Sandra Murley, executive director of the Jackson group, which has 3,500 members nationally. "The public schools can be what we want them to be if we just hang in there." She added: "We've got a lot of children growing up in settings that don't reflect the community. People today don't have a lot of empathy for those unlike themselves. And I think that's because they don't know much about them."
Scholars who have followed school enrollments say middle-class parents are hardly rushing back to public schools in great numbers. But they express optimism that more parents appear to be open to the idea. Many public schools, meanwhile, have aggressively courted the middle class, designing special programs that smaller private schools cannot afford to offer.
 
Is the Tide Turning?
 "We still see a lot of movement away from the public schools," said Amy Stuart Wells, an assistant professor of educational policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. "But it could be that the tide is turning back. We've spent the last 10 years beating up on the public schools. Maybe the next stage will be concentrating on ways to fix them. The fundamental question is: Do we still want public education in this country?"
Ms. Krinsky, who is the associate dean at Tulane University's law school, said she would hear people at parties criticize public schools. When she would ask, "Have you ever been in one of the schools?" she said the answer was usually, "Well, no."
Before their children reached school age, Ms. Krinsky said that she and her family assumed they would choose private schools. But while voting at a nearby school, she was struck by its vibrancy and by the creative drawings on the walls. So she talked with a principal, who allowed her to sit in on classes.
"I didn't see anything go on that doesn't go on in a private school," Ms. Krinsky said. "And I saw a lot happening that doesn't go on in a private school -- like racial integration."
To be sure, even their most enthusiastic defenders acknowledge that many public schools, especially in big cities, are riven with serious problems. The debate over "school choice" and tax vouchers for private schools illustrates the widespread discontent with public schools.
Even in affluent suburban districts, some parents have become frustrated with what they consider an insensitive bureaucracy. "When parents do get involved, the administrators patronize you, then they ignore you, then they confront you, then they threaten you," said Phil Burgess, the head of a research organization.
When classes opened last fall, Mr. Burgess said, his second-grade daughter brought home a teacher's note to parents. "It said essentially, 'Our job is the three "r's" -- reading, writing and arithmetic. And your job is respect, responsibility and rectitude.' The implication was: you stay out of our business and we'll stay out of yours."
For years, the notion of the superiority of private schools and upper-middle-class suburban schools has gone virtually unchallenged. But some parents have found those schools wanting. After sending her daughter to private school for a year, Allyson Shuldberg Eccles, who lives in Denver, said, "I felt like we had tossed away $6,000."
In choosing a private school, the Eccleses had "followed the old adage -- you get what you pay for," said Milton Eccles, an investment consultant. "But it didn't work out that way." Their daughter received no more attention than she had in public school.
Then Ms. Eccles discovered a magnet public school called Denver School of the Arts, which opened last year. There her daughter takes two drama classes a day and a music class, in addition to her regular academic load. Ms. Eccles was also struck with the diversity of children on the public school playgrounds. "You didn't just see white kids and black kids," she said. "There were Hispanic kids, Asian kids. There were kids from Russia."
Like many big-city districts, Denver lost huge numbers of middle-class whites after a Federal judge in 1969 ordered its schools to become racially integrated. Twenty years later, schools that had been two-thirds "Anglo," or non-Hispanic white, were now only one-third.
But in the last four years the white population has leveled off, and the district's enrollment has stabilized. Denver schools are now about 42 percent Hispanic, 31.5 percent white, 21.6 percent black, 3.7 percent Asian and 1.2 percent American Indian, according to the city's Board of Education.
The public schools have learned that they must market themselves to win back middle-class students, said Dorothy Gotlieb, the president of the Denver Board of Education.
So the Denver schools recently ran television advertisements. They were produced for free by a local agency. Air time was paid by the television station and local businesses.
In one ad, a narrator intones: "You will always find those who excel in school and are successful after leaving it. But you don't usually find so many, who do so well, from the same place. Ladies and gentlemen, graduates of the Denver public schools." The ad then displays a long list of former students who have gained prominence.
Denver has also dropped the tuition requirement for nonresident students. This year, 1,200 students from the suburbs are attending Denver schools.
 
Notions of Status
 In some places, the choice of a school is bound up with notions of status. Ms. Krinsky said an acquaintance had fretted that his business contacts would look askance when they learned his children attended public schools. "He was worried that sending his kids to public school would hurt him professionally," she said.
Paul Reams, an executive at the International Business Machines Corporation in Macon, Ga., said that on learning that his children attend public school, some members of his church "pretty much say: 'What's wrong with you? You can afford a private school.' "
In many cases, Mr. Reams said, people draw conclusions about city schools based on the buildings, which tend to be in need of repair, and the neighborhoods, which have comparatively high crime rates. "I went into a public school and looked around," he said. "What I found was teachers who really cared and kids who were bright and hopeful. We're very happy with our decision."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Milton and Allyson Shuldberg Eccles returned their daughter to public school in Denver after a year of private school. Above they helped their children, Melissa, 14, and Matthew, 9, with homework. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
What's New At the U.N.? Ask Drew U.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK

 BODY:
THE WORTH of the United Nations may be debated at least as long as Saddam Hussein survives, but its popularity could be measured by Drew University's Semester on the United Nations.
For 30 years, Drew, in Madison, N.J., has offered a semester of formal study at United Nations headquarters in Manhattan; the semester is also open to non-Drew students. Most of that time Drew has had the only regular on-site campus program there, with its own office across First Avenue from the General Assembly building and a veteran United Nations officer as assistant director. 
 "The dead period, so to speak, was the mid-1970's to the mid-1980's," said Richard S. Rhone, a political science professor who has directed the semester for much of the last 20 years. Once the cold war paralyzed the Security Council and the agency turned to patrolling neutral zones and promoting economic development and humanitarian aid, interest fell. Those tasks were "quite frankly, not as sexy and exciting" as the original image of enforcing collective security, he said.
"Since the mid-1980's it's a whole new world out there," Professor Rhone said. With the end of the cold war and the Persian Gulf fighting, more students have shown interest in the security apparatus of the United Nations, he said. Enrollment, however, is limited to 30.
Students are currently being briefed on the United Nations' role in supplying aid to Somalia, a role the professor called somewhere between the armed force of the gulf war and typical peacekeeping. "The program emphasis changes as the emphasis of the U.N. changes," he said.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Programs In a Meltdown

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
NUCLEAR power has grabbed headlines lately because of the premature retirement of several reactors, but something else in the industry is quietly withering away: its educational infrastructure.
Nationwide, only about 1,000 college juniors and seniors are enrolled in nuclear engineering degree programs, down from a peak of about 2,100 in the late 1970's, according to Energy Department surveys. Enrollment in master's programs stands at about 800, down from 1,400 in the mid-70's. 
 At first glance the department's surveys suggest that doctoral students are bucking the trend: their numbers have risen slightly since the mid-70's, to about 700. But half the students are from abroad. And while foreigners constitute a large proportion of most doctoral engineering programs in the United States, foreign graduates in other fields tend to stay here, university professors report; in the nuclear field they go home, because their countries are building more plants than this country is.
 
Undergraduates Drop
 Still, at least the doctoral programs can survive on foreign students until a time when more American students might apply. Energy Department figures show the number of undergraduate programs dropping from 80 in 1975 to 53 in the last academic year.
More precipitous is the decline in the number of research reactors, the tools near the heart of the graduate programs. About 27 survive, down from 76 in the mid-70's. Some succumbed to student losses; others to increasing maintenance and security costs.
The demise of nuclear engineering programs mimics the industry's slump. Until the mid-1970's, experts were predicting that there would be 1,000 power-generating reactors in this country by the turn of the century, and by 1978 utilities nationwide had placed orders for 250 reactors. But half those orders were canceled, and the reactor population now stands at 111 and falling.
Most were done in by unfavorable economics; compared with other sources of electricity, reactors were too expensive to build and operate. The 1979 accident at Three Mile Island did not improve the industry's image. But professors say that students do not mention this.
It's all bad news for engineering schools, said Kenneth C. Rogers, who was president of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., until President Reagan appointed him to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission five years ago. "The problem is that it hasn't been perceived as an expanding, exciting field to go into," Mr. Rogers said.
The drop in the number of nuclear engineering students would not be an issue if it paralleled the job market. But nuclear engineers, along with other specialists like radiation protection technicians, are likely to be in high demand as the Federal Government begins to clean up its complex for producing nuclear weapons. As a legacy of 40 years of nuclear weapons production, the Energy Department has polluted vast areas and has thousands of buildings to decontaminate.
The department says that the project is the largest environmental restoration project in history. It will require tearing down old structures and putting up factories to process wastes into safer forms and other "engineered structures," from bunkers to fabricated caves, to store wastes. The project will also require constant attention to radiation exposure and to the potential for concentrating scraps of bomb fuel. If too much fuel is brought together, a chain reaction will result, creating a lethal shower of radiation and spreading the wastes.
 
Licenses Expiring
 At Pennsylvania State University, Edward H. Klevans, head of the nuclear program and an associate dean in the college of engineering, sees other reasons the nuclear industry may need more engineers. In the next few years some plants will approach the expiration of their 40-year operating licenses and will apply for extensions, Professor Klevans said. Recertifying them would require extensive engineering work.
But even plant retirements will create jobs, he said, since the fuel must be carefully removed; then contaminated parts must be cleaned or painstakingly cut up with remote-controlled equipment for disposal, and worker exposure to radiation must be minimized.
And new plants could be built. The energy bill that Congress passed last year simplifies the rules for licensing a new generation of power reactors, and smoothes the way for disposal of nuclear waste, in hopes of eventually spawning a rebirth of the technology.
Indeed, by some projections there could be more jobs than people to fill them. A 1990 report by the National Academy of Sciences said that if orders for nuclear plants resume, the demand for nuclear engineers could double or triple. "This demand would greatly exceed the output of current nuclear engineering programs even if they were to expand to full capacity," the study found.
In case of shortage, the industry is likely to rely more heavily on other kinds of engineers, who would be specially trained for nuclear work. Already, nuclear engineering professors say, utilities are following this path. But people trained as nuclear engineers are better suited, experts in the field say, because they have a particularly broad background in physics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and other areas.
The civilian nuclear industry had hoped that its fortunes, and its recruits, would be strengthened by the public's recent focus on the environment. From acid rain to global warming, electric utilities are beset with problems that nuclear power would seem to sidestep.
But that has not lured more students, said Kent F. Hansen, a professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a faculty member for 30 years. In discussions with students entering the field, Professor Hansen said, "Only a few said they were concerned about nuclear being environmentally more benign than the alternatives."
The reasons they did give, he said, were varied and pedestrian: Some had lived near nuclear plants; others had friends and neighbors who were nuclear engineers; still others were interested in an engineering field they consider more exotic than others.
The industry is trying to shore up this educational base. The Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, a utility group formed after the Three Mile Island accident to increase communication among utilities and bring peer pressure to bear on those with operating problems, last year sponsored 275 undergraduate scholarships and 40 graduate-level fellowships. One goal, said Angelina Howard, a spokeswoman, is to keep talented people "going into the educational pipeline and coming out into the industry."
But the key, Professor Hansen said, will be the new plant orders. "I don't see how it can carry on without that happening," he said.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Can Botstein Convince The Young?

BYLINE: By Alex Ross

 BODY:
With typical irony, the composer Hector Berlioz wrote that "for all the obvious shortcomings of a performance the conductor is not blamed." Except, perhaps, when the conductor is also a college president, whirlwind polymath and minor celebrity. Leon Botstein, in his first three concerts as music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, fashioned programs on interdisciplinary themes, largely devoid of familiar music; his musicianship did not quite live up to the richness of his aims, and blame naturally fell on him.
Shortcomings were easily found in the first half of the season. The American Symphony does not have a sumptuous tone, and the conductor is no virtuoso. Performances sometimes lost momentum, and power was restored in crude climaxes. Mr. Botstein distracted himself and the audience with breathless, overstated pronouncements between works: "There's really something very dangerous about this piece," he said several times. He offered too many ideas at once. The great German conductor Hans von Bulow, who advised colleagues to keep the score in the head, not the head in the score, might have made an exception here. 
 But Mr. Botstein's slow progress as a conductor does not diminish the overriding importance of his goals. With financial crises in the wings, orchestras must take strenuous action to save themselves; Mr. Botstein has shown one possible path, more or less discarding the traditional repertory in programs arranged around distinct, often extramusical topics. The first concert, in September, gathered music of Europeans who lived in America during World War II (Martinu, Korngold, Hindemith, Weill); the second, in November, examined the influence of surrealism on composers (Poulenc, Cage, Varese, Koechlin); the third, late last month, linked American modernist painters with compositional contemporaries (Cowell, Copland, Feldman, Sessions and others).
This approach addresses, first, the widening rift between concerts and recordings. With the explosion of novelties on records, collectors have been inventing their own alternative repertory, their own musical subculture. A solitary rendition of a work by Martinu or Feldman can assume greater importance than all 69 current CD's of Mozart's "Kleine Nachtmusik." Many of these listeners, unwilling to let the aloof machinations of big-league programming dictate what they hear, have been avoiding concert halls. They may find solace in Mr. Botstein's off-center programming.
So may some others. Everyone murmurs religiously these days that classical music must find new, young listeners. Influenced, perhaps, by the 20-something generation's reputation for superficiality, some recommend a glossy repackaging of tradition, a make-over. They are wrong. This coveted young audience resists classical music precisely because it seems remote, shrouded, wrapped up in itself. They find musical sophistication elsewhere -- for instance, in the brand of alternative rock that links individuality with social skepticism. A devotee of Pere Ubu's "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo" may not see the need for Penderecki's "Threnody to the Victims of Hiroshima."
Mr. Botstein's concept has potential to convince younger listeners that classical music is not some cobwebbed ghost ship, lost in time. The ultimate task remains the rejuvenation of new music. (In contrast to the American Symphony of the Stokowski era, 1962-72, when premieres came fast and furious, Mr. Botstein's orchestra has so far avoided works written after 1975.) But without some sense of what went on earlier in the century, premieres will continue to be greeted either by dull incomprehension or by a fleeting, circuslike excitement. What must be cultivated is a nontraditional vision of the musical past that emphasizes links between music and society, between music and other cultural disciplines in which the younger generation is better schooled.
This vision will be difficult to achieve. Simply publicizing the American Symphony venture is a Sisyphean task. Eugene Carr, the orchestra's executive director, says that subscriptions are up 20 percent, and that new ticket buyers have been drawn in by offbeat advertising techniques and low ticket prices. The audience for the one Friday-night concert did look a bit younger, but the somewhat sparse crowd on Sunday afternoons resembled the norm (the Mumbler, the Dozer, the Unwrapper and other familiar characters).
Mr. Botstein, for his part, faces the challenge of ensemble precision; crucial elements of his audience, the connoisseurs and record collectors, expect sharper performances. He also needs to adopt a less professorial tone. Lectures should be confined to the beginning of each half to avoid the deadly appearance of "tagging" each work as an academic find. And the programming should have more balance. "This is a program Leopold Stokowski would have been proud of," Mr. Botstein boasted at one concert; but Stokowski would have linked the obscurities to a better-known work, which the audience could use as a point of reference (as when he paired Ives's Fourth Symphony with Beethoven's Fifth).
Most of the performances have been acceptable; a few have been inspired. Given time, Mr. Botstein should be able to produce polished performances of serious intent, as his Richard Strauss festival at Bard College showed last summer. If in the end he falls short, younger audiences may indeed be out of reach, and larger failures will follow.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Pop Can Survive Almost Anything. But Respect?!

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
A President who plays saxophone, admires Elvis Presley and came of age in the late 1960's is bound to affect the course of popular music. Bill Clinton doubtless has memories of a time when popular music helped shake America loose from white-bread 50's illusions, and he clearly likes the stuff; Aretha Franklin sang at his convention. During the campaign, Al Gore was so up to date he cited R.E.M. albums when facing a young audience in Georgia.
The question for the next four years is whether R-E-S-P-E-C-T from the top will make popular music more innovative, or more complacent. Under a pluralistic administration, new musical coalitions could be built, but genres that have been screaming in the wilderness may find themselves with less to complain about. 
 For more than a decade, popular music has been greeted with negligence, incomprehension and suspicion. The Reagan years brought the first Senate hearings about popular music since the 1950's (convened by a subcommittee that Mr. Gore headed after his wife, Tipper, fanned parental anxieties). The Senate's jaw-boning led to warning labels on potentially offensive albums. Although George Bush posed with an electric guitar at his inaugural, the two Republican Administrations clearly came from the pre-rock generation.
President Bush's vaunted love of country music seemed mostly a marketing tactic. Even so, during his Administration, country made huge commercial gains. But Nashville's rise, as personified by Garth Brooks, actually parallels the Clinton campaign: acknowledging but not emphasizing Southern roots, using modern showmanship, and making a direct pitch for suburban and baby-boomer audiences.
If the mainstream follows the President's public example, there are some obvious predictions for the Clinton years. The upswing in Elvis imagery may start a 50's revival that makes "Grease" look authentic. And baby boomers are bound to try to reclaim the high ground of rock from the grunge, hip-hop and thrash noise makers who make boomers feel old. Will Wynonna Judd and the Red Hot Chili Peppers sing vintage Motown songs?
As a saxophonist, the President-elect is rhythmically challenged and sounds anemic, yet his example should boost interest in jazz and blues. And while the Smithsonian is already committed to American vernacular music, a Presidential imprimatur can only help confirm the legitimacy of honkers and shouters. But Mr. Clinton is a centrist; he won't kick the National Symphony Orchestra out of the Kennedy Center.
The resurgent feminism that helped elect Mr. Clinton is already giving women a stronger voice across pop and is battling the misogyny that mars hard-rock and hip-hop. The Clinton campaign's emphasis on tolerance could also lessen homophobia. With luck, the nastiest voices will begin to sound dated and unhip.
Since family values issues failed to sway most voters, the moral panic around popular music (and other cultural forms) may recede. The result could be a renewal of free-speech guarantees, from the National Endowment for the Arts to major entertainment conglomerates.
At the same time, performers who depend largely on shock value and sensationalism are likely to miss the inevitable publicity. Tolerance may do more to blunt the Andrew Dice Clays and 2 Live Crews of the world than all the outrage and litigation of the last decade. It would be an appropriate moment for Tipper Gore, who is still affiliated with the Parents Music Resource Center (which led the movement for warning labels on albums), to resign from the group, and to admit that much of the center's so-called educational materials reflected the influence of the religious right.
Democratic Administrations presided over one of rock's most fertile periods, from 1961-68, and one of its most contradictory ones, 1977-80, during Jimmy Carter's Presidency. In the 60's, under Kennedy and Johnson, an expanding economy and the friction over civil rights and Vietnam convinced rockers that they represented a vanguard community, that they could experiment yet stay popular. The Carter years were another story, with domesticity in the foreground and economic turbulence lurking. A recession bred the comfortable, introspective corporate pop of groups like the Eagles or Fleetwood Mac (who provided the Clinton campaign's theme song), the boom and bust of disco, and the radical mutations of punk-rock and hip-hop, which were influential but commercially marginal.
The Reagan-Bush years made a whole generation feel marginal. People in their teens and 20's faced indifferent elders, the affluent yuppies. People in power grabbed consumer goodies, sliced spending for education and infrastructure, and shunted young workers toward jobs as hamburger flippers and keypunch operators. Young folks couldn't distract themselves with unrestrained sexual license or drug-induced pleasures, either.
In response, the growth areas of late-80's and early-90's popular music offered mechanical dance-beat escapism and tidings of anger and death. Rock grew even more contrary. Black separatist hip-hop counterbalanced racially divisive Willie Horton campaign advertisements; after the Reagan defense buildup and backpedaling on the environment sustained countless songs about nuclear war, dying on the battlefield and toxic terror. Instead of the implicit optimism of protest songs, apocalyptic thrash bands and rappers offered a chance to vent.
The priorities of the new Administration are likely to ricochet, directly and contrarily, through the popular music of the mid-90's. Clinton likes high technology; dancers already like techno music. Hillary Clinton's interest in children's issues may bring more songs about child abuse, troubled families and growing up ignored or uneducated.
Those concerns, in turn, may be part of a general shift away from global affairs to private ones. As everyone knows by now, Chelsea Clinton's name was suggested by a late 60's Joni Mitchell song; the Clinton years may bring a new crop of confessional songwriters, though they'll probably use drum machines along with finger-picking.
By raising expectations, the Clinton Administration is bound to sidetrack some musical extremists. With the cold war over, thrashers are already backing away from the H-bomb repertory; the new Administation's environmental initiatives could make pollution seem less threatening. If the politicians address such broad issues, rock's most vociferous pessimists might turn to personal miseries.
Hip-hop may not be so easily mollified. The Presidential campaign avoided virtually all discussion of urban issues, and one of Clinton's cheapest shots was a swipe at the little-known but divisive rapper Sister Souljah and, through her, at the Rev. Jesse Jackson. (Rappers, among the most self-conscious of community spokespeople, are likely to shout even louder if they feel no one is listening.)
Yet with that conspicuous exception, the Clinton Administration arrives on a promising mandate. The electorate voted not for some imagined good old days or to "stay the course," but to make changes, perhaps even to experiment. It wants something new, and that -- not revivals or reactions -- is what stimulates the best popular music.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Hold the Hunk Stuff, The Man's an Actor First

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
Liam Neeson was letting a bit of his subliminated Irishness show, worrying like Yeats about his stony epitaph. "Is this what's going to be on my tombstone? 'He dated Julia Roberts and Barbra Streisand.' "
The actor, for all his careful study of Hollywood and its narcissistic folkways, was railing pleasantly at how his social and personal life gets misrepresented in what for the last five years has been his hometown, the Hollywood Hills, an ocean and a culture away from Ballymena, County Antrim, the small rural town where he was born in Northern Ireland. 
 His point is well taken, of course. How can the gossips of Tinseltown imply he's just a 6-foot-4 Celtic hunk on the evidence of a few celebrity dates and friendships, when Mr. Neeson is in the midst of a more than average run of acting, recharging himself in what he talks of as his ancient craft of itinerant pretenders and vagabond make-believers. Just his sort of people, he says thankfully, while his limousine waits outside a hotel on Central Park South in Manhattan to get him back to rehearsal.
Fresh from gimping about in the title role of the forthcoming film version of Edith Wharton's "Ethan Frome," a job of work that presents no assault on the Schwarzenegger school of thespian arts, Mr. Neeson is taking a 10-week break from Hollywood to appear on Broadway in the Roundabout Theater Company production of "Anna Christie." This is Eugene O'Neill's ever-dark evergreen about failed life and love on the seafaring fringe. It opens on Thursday at the Criterion Center with Mr. Neeson playing the drunken, lyrical suitor to Natasha Richardson's fallen Anna, and Rip Torn as her sad, sodden father.
With this, his first stage role in eight years, the 40-year-old actor is consciously trying to have it both ways, doing some heavy lifting for the vagabond craft to sharpen his edge for returning to the Hollywood Hills for another crack at the crass art of becoming box office. He speaks of it that bluntly, invoking Gary Cooper and James Cagney as ghostly role models for his goal of seeing if he can master the right mix of the acting and money arts.
"They don't give a damn out there if you did the greatest Hamlet of the decade or whatever," he says. "But if you're in a hit film -- doesn't matter if you're an average actor, a competent actor or not -- then you'll be the flavor. They'll send you scripts and they'll evolve films around you," he says, with a mix of envy and loathing.
"Nowadays, if you've got a ponytail and a nice Armani suit and the gift of the gab you can make it in Hollywood," he says, mourning the old days he imagines when there was at least a studio craft system. "But I'd love to be in a hit film," he has to admit. "And then I'll decide the life after that."
Thus far, Mr. Neeson carefully measures his journeyman's strivings in 15 films across five years, incidentally describing a Hollywood that is strange and ingrown enough to seem just over the rise from Ballymena, particularly when his mother, Kitty, pays a visit. She goes walking the Hollywood Hills and cadges a cup of tea and a life story from some of her son's mystery neighbors in the cinema jungle.
"I'd say, 'Mommy, you've been gone hours. Where were you?' " says Mr. Neeson, slipping into the Irish narrative gift at life's small events. "And she'd say, 'Well, I was on a walk and met this nice man who brought me in and made me tea.' And then she'd give me another life story of someone."
Mr. Neeson, his voice low and sardonic, makes the Hollywood thicket seem at least as real and foggy as O'Neill's waterfront. "It will be interesting after this play to see how long I can take it back there," says the actor, whose experience is grounded in the Irish and English stage.
"I mean, Hollywood is the center of the English-speaking cinema. That's where the work is. It's not in London and it's certainly not in Ireland," says Mr. Neeson, who took a flier from those workplaces in 1987 and gambled on cracking the movies, arriving in Los Angeles, he recalls, with just five weeks' rent and a resolve not to be narrowly typecast as a boy-o off the boat.
"I told these guys: 'Please don't say I'm an Irish actor,' " he recalls of the agents he hired. "I'm an actor. An actor who wants to audition for parts for an actor my age."
Mr. Neeson is also a big handsome man with a memorable look of self-doubt on his broad face. This is a casting quality that, as he moves safely beyond his five-week gamble, seems to pass as easily for urban angst, as in one of the confused-lover roles that he played in Woody Allen's "Husbands and Wives," as for self-tragedy in O'Neill's Mat Burke and Wharton's Ethan Frome, or even self-comedy, as in his part as a Kansas sheriff in Steve Martin's new film, "Leap of Faith."
About the film "Ethan Frome," to be released on Feb. 26, and his role of almost inarticulate pathos demanding the twisted-body acting of a Lon Chaney, he says he is pleased -- as much for the movie's lean economics as its artistic goals. "I'm very proud of that -- made for $2.4 million when the average Hollywood film costs $25 million," he stresses. Less certainly, he adds, about the film directed by John Madden: "I'm scared to say it's my best work, but I feel the role suits me and I suit the role."
Mr. Neeson says O'Neill reminds him of some of the O'Casey and other Irish masterworks he did at the Abbey Theater in Dublin. "A poetic construction," he says. "You can really go for this stuff. It's not like Stoppard, where you play with words or everybody hides emotions through wonderfully odd sentences. This guy O'Neill goes straight for it.
"The play is unbelievably passionate and everybody bares their soul," he says about the rehearsals, pleased at the chance to work with Natasha Richardson, who talked him into playing Mat Burke, the broken-hearted coal stoker. "David Leveaux, the director, gave us a great talk and said we have to go for this: 'Trust me as I'm trusting you. Let's take this as far as we can, and don't be afraid, because whatever pain or misery or happiness you're feeling on stage, just imagine O'Neill felt 10 times that to inspire him to write this.' "
So the O'Neill sounds as though it will do as a breather, even if it may not be the real-life struggle of Hollywood. "In the early days of rehearsing, I was seeing how far I could go. I was far too theatrical. But the play holds you up," he explains. "Twelve hours of rehearsals a day and you'll still do two more at the pub later talking about it."
In speaking like so many before him of getting back to his roots on stage, Mr. Neeson says he has had to dust off three different sorts of Irish accents to play Mat Burke. "At times, O'Neill makes my character passionate, like he's from the west of Ireland, and I'll pronounce 'slap' as givin' ya a great 'shlap'! Other times, he's Dublin gutteral: 'A hard whorulld -- world -- it is.' Or flat Belfast: 'You'll be wishin' you were married to a FAIR-mur' -- a farmer." A big smile at this, the actor so dedicated to full-craft acting resorting, like the latest rap-star Hollywood transport, to playing bits of himself.
"I'm doing this play in part because I'm always lambasting young actors out there who wouldn't know a theater if they passed it on the street. They arrive there by the truckload every day, these young beautiful girls and boys hoping to be soap opera stars. No craft at all, looking for the easy life," he says, Nathanael West-angry, not O'Neill-despairing, about his life.
"I'm here for my sanity," he summarizes, sipping tea by the hotel bar, minutes from escaping by limo back into O'Neill's bleak lyricism. "I'd hate to be in Hollywood at age 18 or 19 and believe all that blather."
Mr. Neeson is proud he has been coming on steadily out there, being remembered occasionally, by casting specialists at least, for playing Diane Keaton's thoughtful boyfriend in "The Good Mother" or the deaf mute helped by Cher in "Suspect."
"I've avoided being pigeonholed so far, knock on wood. But I'm not going to flog myself stupid if it doesn't happen," he takes care to contend, the "it" being box-office brute force.
"I'm paying the bills and my next role is up for grabs," says the actor, sounding like O'Neill's stoker retreating to the sea, shipping out in a limo. "But that's what I like about acting. You know, I'm a single guy and I love being able to pack a suitcase at a moment's notice and head off somewhere. I like being from that."
He stops for a kind of epitaph worthy of a tombstone in Hollywood, not Ballymena. "Sometimes I'm sitting out there in L.A. by my pool and it's 85 degrees and I suddenly think, 'I'm lonesome.' And then I take a fresh look about me, and I say, 'Stuff it, I'm doing all right here -- I could be digging ditches back in Ireland.' "
