HEADLINE: Packages Unwrapped: A Sampling

BYLINE: By SUZANNE MacNEILLE; SUZANNE MacNEILLE is a journalist who specializes in travel.

 BODY:
IF the thought of traveling to London during the most off of the off-season months has never crossed your mind, tour operators with package deals to Britain will be happy to supply reasons why you might consider switching your July vacation to January or February. You won't have to stand on line to see the Crown Jewels; the theater season is in full swing; Harrods winter sale is on. They will also assert that a week in London can be surprisingly inexpensive, even for the traditionally slow off-season.
How is it possible that six nights in London, including air fare, can cost as little as $449? The dollar's new-found strength -- at the end of December the pound was worth only about $1.55, compared with $1.93 a year earlier -- is the major reason. 
 The stronger dollar, says Neil Johnson, marketing director of Travel Bound, which is offering the $449 deal, has "made London a truly affordable place to consider."
Christopher Ford, president of Europe Express, which has a $469 six-night air-land London package, said the downward trend in tour prices had also come about because London hotels were offering lower rates. "In real terms, London is as cheap as it's been in many years," Mr. Ford said.
Aside from these factors, of course, tour packagers can usually offer lower prices than the independent traveler pays because they reserve blocks of rooms -- and airline seats -- and get them at special rates.
Some of the current London packages, including the Europe Express program, which started at $569 last winter, cost even less than in the 1991-92 season. At that time airlines and tour companies, eager to persuade Americans to cross the Atlantic during the height of the recession, kept prices almost as low as they did the year before -- when the Gulf war was hurting travel to Europe. The recession and the Gulf war were blamed for reducing the number of American visitors to Britain from more than 3 million in 1990 to 2.25 million in 1991. In a sense they have also set the pricing standards for 1993.
For instance, in its current brochure, British Airways, which maintains it is the largest wholesaler of British packages in the United States, lists hotel rates comparable to last year's, in some cases lower.
Air fares are also staying at levels similar to last year's. As of Dec. 30 American Airlines was publishing a round-trip midweek fare from New York of $379, which must be purchased two weeks in advance for travel through March 31. That fare is the same as last winter. British Airways also offers a $379 ticket with similar restrictions. USAir has a round-trip weekday fare of $306, which must be purchased within 48 hours of booking. USAir's New York-London flight involves connections through Baltimore, Pittsburgh or other cities.
This year most operators are promoting packages that focus mainly on the essentials: air fare coupled with hotels, or selling hotel space separately, on a per-night basis.
"There used to be a philosophy of including everything in a single program," said Patrick Henry, manager of international product development for American Airlines' Fly AAway Vacations, which offers six-night London hotel stays starting at $191 a person, sharing a double room.
"In the past few years we've been going more and more for a bare-bones structure to which you can add on." This, he says, keeps prices down.
But even with the strong dollar, and the bare-bones argument, some of these deals seem too good to be true. Are they just attempts to persuade you to trade up to higher-priced lodgings? Is the hotel some dump on the outskirts of London? Would it be cheaper to fashion your own package, utilizing a low air fare and booking the hotels yourself?
Calling as an ordinary tourist -- in mid-December -- to book a selection of packages offered by tour companies proved to be a straightforward process. There were no attempts to bait and switch to a higher-priced hotel. Rooms in all categories were readily available (though reservations at least two weeks ahead are suggested). In some cases, the operator offered a savings of 50 percent or more over the hotel's regular rates.
As for the hotels themselves, an inspection of eight budget and medium-priced hotels used in package tours -- and listed in the accompanying article -- suggested that, while most involve some sort of trade-off, they generally offer clean bedrooms with private bathrooms, television and radio, and direct-dial telephone. All have at least one restaurant and one bar.
THE programs highlighted below, all of the bare-bones variety, are only a sampling of the many packages available; most airlines flying to London, and many tour companies, offer them. All prices, including the hotel's listed rates, which are given for comparative purposes, are per person, double occupancy. Taxes and service charges are included. (The totals are calculated at the rate of about $1.55 to the pound.) Extra nights can usually be added.
The prices of packages that include air fare are based on weekday, round-trip economy fares from New York, Newark and other Northeastern cities. The $379 round-trip fares recently quoted by British Airways and American are used for comparison, although fares may drop $20 or more as the season progresses. The cost of air transfers is based on the approximately $15 one would spend on bus fare to and from Heathrow and central London. (Gatwick is slightly more expensive.)
The prices quoted are for the winter season -- but keep in mind that March, traditionally the last month of the off-season, is often more expensive, sometimes by as much as 30 percent, than January and February. Some of the more expensive hotels have additional periods when higher rates apply.
All of the tour companies have complicated refund policies, described in detail in the brochures. When a traveler cancels, most companies will charge a fee and-or a percentage of the package price, based on how many days in advance the trip is canceled. All operators strongly suggest purchasing trip-cancellation insurance.
British Airways, (800) 247-9297, offers its passengers London packages with few or many frills. Among the most minimal of its programs is the London Six Night Special, a land-only program that includes airport transfers and Continental breakfast. It starts at $190 for accommodations at the President Hotel in Russell Square; for $367, you can stay at the statelier Grosvenor Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road. (The Grosvenor, near Victoria Station, is not to be confused with Grosvenor House, the deluxe hotel on Park Lane.) If you were to book these hotels yourself, without buying a package, six nights at the President with breakfast and airport transfers would cost about $300 a person, based on two in a room; at the Grosvenor Hotel, $630.
The Historic London package, which combines air fare with accommodations, starts at $629 for six nights at the Tavistock near Russell Square, and includes Continental breakfast, transfers and entertainment vouchers. Accommodations at the St. Giles Hotel near the British Museum, cost $727; a stay at the Grosvenor near Victoria Station is $823. Using British Airways' $379 fare, an independently designed package would cost about $685 with accommodations at the Tavistock, $860 for the St. Giles and $1,035 for the Grosvenor.
The airline will also book rooms at about 60 centrally situated London hotels on a per-night basis. The Strand Palace near Covent Garden costs $58 a person, including English breakfast (compared with $94 a person if purchased independently); the most expensive listing, the luxurious Grosvenor House near Hyde Park, is $138 (compared with $200) with full English breakfast.
American Airlines, (800) 832-8383), has a London a La Carte program, a six-night land package that includes transfers, Continental breakfast, a London bus tour and a cruise on the River Thames. The program starts at $191 for accommodations in the Harewood in Marylebone (compared with $418, including the cost of tours, transfers and the hotel's listed rates for room and breakfast). Rooms at the White House near Regent's Park are $259 (compared with $633, including the cost of all features); $285 at the Drury Lane Moat House near Covent Garden (compared with $630 for four weekday and two weekend nights), and $403 at the Strand Palace near Covent Garden (compared with $585). Travelers should note the conditions attached to these bookings. They must reserve their hotel at the same time as the flight, or there is a $99 surcharge. There's also a $15 surcharge unless one books a room more than 31 days before departure.
Europe Express, (212) 334-0836, a two-and-a-half-year-old company based in New York, is offering a $469 air and land package, using USAir as the carrier. While this package may eventually change if USAir raises its trans-Atlantic fares, Mr. Ford, the company's president, says another, virtually identical program with British Airways, costing $499, will not change. The lowest rates for both packages are for accommodations in less expensive hotels that include the Norfolk Towers near Paddington Station. (Booking the components independently, using the hotel's listed rates and USAir's $306 connecting flight and British Airways' $379 fare, the price would be, respectively, $702 and $775.)
Six nights at the Norfolk in South Kensington costs $569 with USAir and $599 with British Airways. (The comparison cost is $964 for two weekend nights and four weekdays at the Norfolk, using USAir; $1,037 when using British Airways.)
Europe Express also offers a la carte prices at 28 London hotels, with Continental breakfast. While the company will not guarantee the quality of the room, Mr. Ford says that Travco, the London company that helps make land arrangements for his packages, will find clients more suitable accommodations if they are not satisfied.
Travel Bound, (212) 334-1350 or (800) 456-8656, which is based in New York and has been in operation since 1982, uses Virgin Atlantic Airways for its Royal Londoner package. The package includes a cream tea at Self ridge's department store, and Continental breakfast, and starts at $449 for six nights at the Barkston Hotel off Earl's Court Road; $549 will put you in the Forte Crest near Regent's Park. (Booked independently and using Virgin Atlantic, the trip would cost $765 at the Barkston and $894 at the Forte Crest Regents Park.) A similar package, using Continental Air Lines, is slightly more expensive, starting at $499.
These rates, according to Mr. Johnson of Travel Bound, will not be affected by any further currency fluctuations or change in air fares.
Travel Bound also has a selection of 25 hotels that can be booked on a nightly basis. The Drury Lane Moat House is $69 a night, with breakfast, compared with $107 if paying the hotel's weekday rate for room and breakfast. No minimum stay is required.

HEADLINE: PROBLEMS WE THOUGHT WE SOLVED

 BODY:
The first paragraph of Perri Klass's article "Tackling Problems We Thought We Solved" (Dec. 13), where she describes the unnecessary death of a 9-month-old baby from dehydrating diarrhea for lack of a $6 bottle of rehydrating solution, captures just about everything that ails our health-care system: the lack of basic primary care for mothers and children; the high cost of simple remedies that put them out of reach of poor families; the lack of outreach, education and community support; the underlying poverty. For those of us who work on health issues in the developing world, it is a reminder of how important our work is and how relevant to the needs of American children.
Worldwide, more than three million children die every year from diarrhea, most of them in countries where the annual per capita spending on all health care is less than the price of that one prescription for Pedialyte. 
 Despite such grim financial realities, enormous progress has been made in the developing world. In her home country of El Salvador, the mother of that infant might very well have been instructed to make a mixture of household sugar, salt and water that would have prevented her infant's death. It is time to apply at home some of the lessons learned internationally.
 
PAMELA R. JOHNSON
U.S. Agency for International Development
Washington

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Architects Now On Board;
Huge L.I. Federal Court Complex

 BODY:
With the choice of Richard Meier and Michael Harris Spector as architects of the $195 million Federal Building and United States Courthouse planned in Islip, L.I., the Government has shown that it is not looking for a neo-classical temple with fluted columns and pediments. Mr. Meier, in particular, is widely known for the spare serenity of his designs: crisp, cool, bright and uncluttered.
"This will be a contemporary, modern court complex," Mr. Spector declared. "That's what we presented as our philosophy and what's been accepted by the General Services Administration and the judiciary." 
 William J. Diamond, the regional administrator of the General Services Administration, said the project would be the first major Federal complex ever built on Long Island and a "fantastic shot in the arm" for the local economy.
The 450,000-square-foot office and courthouse project is to rise on a 24.7-acre site at North Spur Drive and Carleton Avenue, beginning in 1995. It is expected to take three years to build. There will be 21 courtrooms in the new building.
Two weeks ago, the Government chose the Spector Group of North Hills, L.I., as architects, working in association with Richard Meier & Partners of Manhattan.
"The whole idea," Mr. Diamond said, "is to build something there that will be of architectural high quality."
Mr. Meier said the project would be his first important civic building for a public client in the United States. "There was a point when Federal buildings were considered in this country to be among the most important, prestigious works of architecture," Mr. Meier said. "I believe there are people in the Government who feel that very strongly again."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1479 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The New York Gains Tax;
An Added Weight on a Struggling Market

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE tax collectors of New York State sat happily in the 80's in a cart pulled by a frisky horse, the active market in real-estate sales. They collected hundreds of millions of dollars from a tax that no other jurisdiction decided to levy -- 10 percent of the gain on sales of more than $1 million.
But the horse has staggered. And as the gains tax enters its second decade, it has become an element in retarding recovery, inarguably so in the case of workouts of troubled properties. 
 The long-term effect is likely to be the inhibition of the development of new co-ops and condominiums and the sale of commercial real estate, often a prelude to investment in property improvements. At present the tax is primarily interfering with workouts of troubled property. It also routinely complicates corporate sales when real estate is a major asset. That these consequences would follow a turn in the cycle was widely predicted even before the tax was adopted as a budgetary expedient in 1983. But upward momentum in the market made it an irresistible revenue-raiser for state government.
In an interview last month, James W. Wetzler, the state's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, said that no consideration was being given to repealing the tax. He said that it was "never designed for a period when real estate is depressed" and was "creating notable problems." But it will raise about $110 million this fiscal year, ending March 31, based on current transaction levels, he said. It will be the sixth year of declining revenue since the $792 million peak of fiscal 1987.
The focus now is on making the tax liability conform more closely to real economic gain, Mr. Wetzler said. A good case has been made for changing the way the tax applies in workouts, he said. It has complicated workouts because would-be sellers find themselves liable for tax on properties on which they lost money.
Conversion sponsors seeking to rid themselves of co-op apartments are a notable case in point. Another concerns developers of newly built office buildings, or developers who in the 80's purchased existing buildings planning major renovations and re-leasing.
There have been some reforms. Co-op corporations don't have to pay the tax when sponsor-owned shares are seized because of defaults in maintenance payments. And under a one-year "targeted penalty abatement program," interest-payment penalties for late payers or underpayers have been waived. In foreclosures, lenders taking back property don't have to pay the tax to record a deed. But the former owner is still liable for the tax.
There are many reasons beyond the gains tax -- nicknamed the Cuomo tax in the real-estate world -- for the drop in real-estate sales activity in the state. But if owners are discouraged from selling because of tax consequences, if buyers start to discount possible future taxes from what they are willing to pay and if developers are discouraged from risk-taking, the economy of the state will suffer, property owners and lenders say.
"The tax has definitely had a negative impact on real estate in New York," said Joseph A. DeLuca, executive vice president of the real estate group of Chemical Bank.
"It's just one more good reason for keeping away from New York," said William Zeckendorf Jr., a major condominium builder in the 80's. He said he considers the tax a gross sales tax rather than a gains tax, because builders and converters are not allowed to consider many of the key soft costs of development as part of the cost basis used for calculating the gain.
These costs include interest on site-acquisition loans; the cost of carrying unsold space after construction; marketing and advertising expenses; the expense, in Manhattan, of buying Section 421a tax abatement certificates to enhance affordability to buyers; leasing-up expenses; brokerage commissions for leasing; tenant relocation expenses and marketing and advertising costs.
"THE tax is a significant hardship," said Jan Nicholson, vice president of Citicorp Real Estate. "Because of the problems, we will be much more cautious about making real estate loans in New York." In default situations it inhibits borrowers from working with their lender, she said, and it has been a major problem for condominium development as well.
The problem for lenders is that the tax has impeded their ability to negotiate expeditious takeovers of real estate from defaulting condominium and office builders, conversion sponsors and owners of commercial property generally. Technically, the tax is based on the difference between what the state determines is the "consideration" (what the seller derives from the sale) and what it considers to be the "original purchase price," the basis from which the gain is calculated.
In a transfer in lieu of foreclosure, the consideration has been taken to reflect what is owed rather than what a property is currently worth in the marketplace. This can produce a large tax liability for a borrower already facing an economic loss, leaving defaulting borrowers unwilling to transfer deeds back to lenders. Lenders are obliged to go through long and costly foreclosure procedures, while the debt mounts and buildings cannot compete effectively for tenants.
Some lawyers and accountants think that the Department of Taxation and Finance may have pointed a way out of this situation in an advisory opinion issued late last month. It says the state will accept fair-market value, rather than debt owed, as the consideration when there is a transfer of a controlling interest in an entity in which real estate is one of the assets.
The opinion was issued to accountants at Deloitte & Touche. The firm's senior tax manager, William H. Korman, said it opens the door to partnership or stock acquisitions by lenders, rather than asset acquisitions, as a way of avoiding the gains tax in transfers to a lender after default.
Tax lawyers representing owners contend the statute itself is explicit that the measure of the gains tax in a controlling-interest transfer is the real estate's fair-market value. But there had been no explicit confirmation until the new advisory opinion.
As much as the gains tax has been a problem in workouts, its long-term effect is greatest on real-estate activity generally -- decisions on whether to buy or sell and the availability of mortgage loans.
Existing commercial properties that need new capital and new leadership will find it harder to come by them, real estate professionals say. Long-term owners, facing extraordinary gains taxes because of the law's failure to provide for updating basis to account for inflation, are less likely to sell.
Risk-taking buyers who need to borrow new capital, improve buildings and look for new tenants are likely to lower their expectations of what the property will be worth if their efforts succeed. They will therefore be willing to pay less to buy.
"The state does not respect bottom-fisher costs," said Carolyn Lee Ichel, a lawyer at Roberts & Holland.
Nor does it respect the economic losses of risk-takers. Jeffrey R. Gural, president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, a management company whose principals bought Class B Manhattan buildings in the 80's, told of paying a tax of $1 million on a downtown building that was purchased half empty for $50 million, improved, rented up and sold two years later for $70 million.
"Our total cost was $70 million," he said, "but the state said we made a $10 million profit." Among other things, $5 million in interest on the acquisition loan was not allowed as part of the basis for calculating gain.
In Albany, some of the most contentious issues have been adjudicated by the state's three-member Tax Appeals Tribunal, an independent division of the Department of Taxation and Finance. Its president, John P. Dugan, said that the tribunal's decision that the "cost of carry in a soft market doesn't reduce the amount of consideration subject to gain" had been confirmed by the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court.
"It's a tough law," Mr. Dugan said, noting that the state Legislature passed it in 1983 as the "budget closer" expecting it to produce $85 million in taxes. In fact, it far exceeded those expectations.
However, some of the activities that produced those revenues are now extinct, and under current Federal tax law are unlikely to revive even in an improvement in the sales market. Conversions of rentals to co-ops and condominiums are one. In 1990 the state assessed $46 million on sponsors of co-op conversions, for example. There were $37 million of assessments on newly built condominiums, for which taxes are due as aggregate sales reach $1 million.
Such development activity -- especially in New York City, where multifamily property is involved -- seems far less likely in the future. The gains tax is a significant reason.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Manhattan Office Leasing;
A Glow at the End of the Tunnel?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
IT'S not exactly a rebound. And if it's a light at the end of the tunnel, it's no more than a 40-watt bulb. But it looks like maybe, just maybe, the end of 1992 will be remembered as the cheer-up point for the depressed midtown market.
Vacancy rates were down and rents slowed their precipitous slide. 
 Tenants started exercising options to expand and some brokers report that concession packages -- free rent, build-out money and the like -- were getting smaller, too.
"I'm not saying landlords aren't hurting, or that rents are going up at more than a creep, or that New York should expect huge increases in tax revenues from commercial buildings any time soon,"said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "But the fact is, midtown leasing activity is way, way up."
December numbers aren't all compiled yet, but the data that emerged through November show reasons for cheer.
The Edward S. Gordon Company, for example, reported that in the first 11 months of 1992 nearly 2 million square feet of midtown space were absorbed; in the same period last year, more than 3 million were added to an already glutted market. That absorption brought the midtown vacancy rate, Gordon says, down to 16.8 percent (or 31.9 million feet), from 17.6 percent (33.3 million feet) for the same time last year.
But such statistics, while plentiful -- many large brokerages issue quarterly market reports -- are not definitive. Most are based on anecodotal evidence or surveys of landlords and buildings deemed, often arbitrarily, to be representative.
Space absorption figures are particularly problematic. They rarely take into account space that, while officially occupied, is available for sublease. And, if a tenant signs a lease for, say, 100,000 feet effective in 1994, that space is immediately subtracted from the market availability list. But the space the tenant currently occupies often is not added to the market figures until the tenant moves. So while the future space and current space should cancel each other out statistically, in fact the space shuffling often shows up as another 100,000 feet of space absorbed.
If brokers don't agree on the numbers, they certainly agree on the direction those numbers are pointing: Up.
"The first part of 1992 was all about tenants dragging their feet in negotiations," said Bruce Mosler, vice chairman of the Galbreath Riverbank brokerage. "But the end of 1992 was about making real commitments."
Brokers cite many factors behind the new buoyancy. High on most lists is pent-up demand for space. In the last few years, many tenants held off looking for new space, waiting to see if rents would drop even further. Finally, many could hold out no longer; their existing leases were too close to expiration.
Other tenants, with less time pressure, jumped in when they felt that no stronger deals could be found.
"For two years no one wanted to commit to space," said Barry Gosin, president of Newmark Real Estate Services. "Now corporate chairmen have decided the market has hit bottom and it's time to negotiate."
And many tenants finally felt more secure about their own businesses and their ability to expand. Big accounting concerns like Price Waterhouse and Ernst & Young took extra space scarcely months after the ink on their new leases had dried. And many tenants signed long-term leases, in part to lock in bargains, but also in part because they had decided to tough it out in New York.
"Long leases don't have an immediate impact on vacancies, but they send the right signal about New York," said William M. Korchak, director of leasing for Compass Management & Leasing, part of Equitable Real Estate Investment Management.
For large tenants, in fact, there was a sense of impending scarcity amidst the glut, a belief that they had better grab large blocks of space now, lest they not be available later.
"NO ONE expects any speculative building any time soon," said James S. Vanderslice, managing director of Cushman & Wakefield.
Mergers, particularly among banks, will release space, of course. Bank of America, which merged with Security Pacific, will probably move to Security Pacific Plaza at 40 East 52d Street, vacating some 300,000 feet at 355 Madison Avenue, near 45th. And brokers expect Chemical Bank to free 900,000 feet of space at 277 Park Avenue, near 48th Street, in 1994, and consolidate with its merger partner, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, across the street at 270 Park Avenue.
"The space is being quietly shopped around, but there's a 50-50 chance that it will hit the market empty," said Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate.
Still, most brokers expect a net shrinkage in marketable blocks of large space. Americas Towers, the city's newest and highest-profile building, is rapidly being leased. Smith Barney will probably buy 1585 Broadway and use much of it itself, taking that building off the market.
Paramount is looking for several hundred thousand feet somewhere in midtown. Metropolitan Life, which bought the Pan Am building at 200 Park Avenue, will occupy at least 210,000 feet itself, even though other tenants showed definite interest in the space.
"We had a live tenant looking for more than 100,000 feet of space, that we simply couldn't get in there," said Steven B. Siegel, Gordon's chief executive.
For landlords, it has meant a new sense of empowerment. Brokers report that while large tenants can still pretty well get whatever they want, smaller tenants no longer can count on an automatic year's free rent or $45 a foot in work. They may get them, but they have to bargain much harder for them.
"It's still a tenant's market, but the footing is a bit more equal now," said Mr. Spinola.
Of course, there have been losers.
THERE'S been a flight to quality as tenants find they can rent luxury space in Class A buildings for what, barely three years ago, would have put them in cramped, Class B quarters. Cushman & Wakefield notes that in the third quarter of 1992 vacancy rates in Class A buildings had dropped to 16 percent, from 16.7 percent in the second quarter. But vacancies in Class B buildings held stubbornly at 19.9 percent.
Moreover, some brokers predict more foreclosures. Once free rent, build-out work and other costs are factored in, top-of-the-line midtown space seems to have bottomed out at about $35 a foot.
"That's just not enough to support a lot of the debt that these buildings took on in the 80's," warned Mr. Cohen of Williams.
And much of midtown's gain was at downtown's expense.
"There's a real tale of two cities here," said Randal Fuchs, director of marketing and research for Joseph Hilton & Associates. "We're seeing tenants moving uptown, simply shuffling space."
One example: Bank of Tokyo moved out of about 150,000 feet at 100 Broadway, in the Wall Street area, to similar space at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street.
Still, even downtown may have reason for some cheer. As midtown tightens up, some tenants will have to look downtown. Mr. Siegel reports that one publishing company that is now in prime midtown space is looking downtown. And there is talk that the city may provide incentives for converting more than 5 million feet of antiquated downtown office space to residential use, which would automatically tighten up the market.
No one is suggesting that midtown's problems are over. Midtown is a headquarters area, and even if the economy recovers, corporations are unlikely to restore the layers of executive jobs they cut in the 1980's. Moreover, most of the leasing activity in 1992 was from companies that already had space.
"The city still has to find a way to provide incentives for new tenants to walk in here," warned Mr. Mosler of Galbraith Riverbank.
All in all, though, most brokers entered 1993 with buoyant spirits.
"As everything seemed to be recovering in 1992, my main question was, 'Would this last through 1993?' " said Gordon's Mr. Siegel. "Now, I think it will."
Even those who think that talk of recovery is premature express a certain optimism.
"Large corporations are still downsizing, Wall Street isn't hiring, but small businesses are picking up the slack," said Newmark's Mr. Gosin. "The next couple years won't be a bed of roses, but nothing will get worse."

HEADLINE: New L.I. Faces In Congress Mean a Loss Of Influence

BYLINE: By States News Service

 BODY:
TWO years ago, Long Island's representatives in Congress had worked their way up in the seniority system to gain a fair amount of influence in the House.
Representatives Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of West Islip, and Raymond J. McGrath, Republican of Valley Stream, sat on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. Representative Robert J. Mrazek, Democrat of Huntington, helped dispense money as a member of the Appropriations Committee. Norman F. Lent, Republican of Baldwin with 22 years in the House, helped influence issues important to Long Island, like fishing and other water-related problems, with his seat on the Merchant Marines and Fisheries Committee. Mr. Lent also sat on the investigative Energy and Commerce Committee. 
 But redistricting and the election in November changed the face of the delegation. Mr. Lent and Mr. McGrath announced early on that they were retiring. Mr. Mrazek bowed out after an abortive primary bid for the Senate, and redistricting shaved a seat from the Island's representation. A tight election felled nine-term Mr. Downey, and redistricting moved Representative Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of Forest Hills, solidly into Nassau County.
As a result the five-member delegation now includes three first-year members and one new member to the Island in addition to Representative George Hochbrueckner, Democrat of Centereach.
Long Island lawmakers say there is no question that the changes leave the group less influential.
"I don't think anybody can deny we've lost an awful lot of years in seniority," said Representative David Levy, Republican of Baldwin. Mr. Levy represents the redrawn 4th District, previously in Mr. McGrath and Mr. Lent's territory.
"You take Norm out and Ray, a high-ranking Republican for 18 years, and Tom Downey, who was in the majority on Ways and Means -- clearly, that's a tremendous loss of clout which cannot be made up for many years to come," said Mr. Hochbrueckner, who will be returning for his fourth term.
 
'The Landscape Has Changed'
 "Those bridges of trust take some time to develop," said Rick Lazio, Republican of Brightwaters, who defeated Mr. Downey. "I know I'm not going to get everything done in the first six months or first year or even the first term."
Further hampering the effectiveness is the party affiliation of the first-year members. All three are Republicans in a Democratically controlled House as a Democratic President prepares to take office.
"I am acutely aware of the fact that the landscape has changed," Mr. Lazio said. "Speaking for myself, I need to be a little bit quicker and smarter. It means I need to develop good personal relationships with Democrats as well as Republicans."
Representative Peter King, Republican of Seaford, said the votes of his party colleagues' would have meant much more if President Bush were returning for a second term. "With a Democratic President, there's no question that that takes away a lot of leverage," he said. "Sure, I'm going to miss that."
But new and old members alike maintain that Island voters are not doomed to years of lost projects and less money. Although the delegation is rife with neophyte lawmakers, the sheer size of the Class of '92 in Congress -- 110 new members, nearly a quarter of the House -- means that the first-year members are not starting from the same back benches that most current members did.
"I think it makes it easier to get in the game quickly," Mr. Hochbrueckner said. "The organization and the institution that you have to cozy up to is smaller. When I came in there were something like 35 new members and 400 old ones This year there is less there to work on in terms of cracking the system."
He and Mr. King said the proportions of the class would allow the group to be somewhat of a voting bloc. "I don't expect to be able to walk in right away and be Norman Lent," Mr. King said. "But with so many new members we become almost a swing vote. I think it's up to me and the other new members to exercise that swing vote."
"As a class they have a lot of clout," Mr. Hochbrueckner said. "I think you'll find a lot of senior types will be more willing to work with the freshmen."
Other longtime members like Mr. Ackerman were less enthusiastic. "There's a little bit of naivete there," he said. "In order to get things done you have to get coalitions. The power structure is based on seniority, and there's going to be coalitions built within all levels of the pyramid. If they're counting on functioning as a cohesive freshman group, that's not going to work. It's going to break down into regions and committees."
 
Can the Bacon Still Be Harvested?
 Many politicians agree that the success of the first-year members from Long Island will largely depend on how far the White House and the Democratic leadership in Congress extends a hand to the minority.
"It depends on the partisan shift," said Herbert Rosenbaum, a professor of political science at Hofstra University. "The Long Island constituents have been very carefully taught that their representatives are the ambassadors to bring home the bacon. Whether they can do that depends on the leadership in the White House and how much leeway the new President gives the Republicans."
Nevertheless, the Long Island lawmakers said the delegation planned to work together to push projects for the region. The group, with a full schedule of plans, met a few times between Election Day and the official swearing-in, on Jan. 5.
"We're going to try to get up to speed for the people of Long Island," Mr. Ackerman said. "Regardless of political affiliation, that's the only way to go. We've talked about the economy and the loss of jobs on Long Island. We met jointly with Grumman to discuss the problems there."
 
Important Committee Assignments
 Mr. Hochbrueckner said the conversion of military industries and other programs to help displaced workers topped his agenda. Mr. King said that as a member of the Merchant Marine and Fisheries panel he would work to find money to combat beach erosion and other destruction caused by major storms.
Helping the group are the committee assignments. Mr. King, Mr. Lazio and Mr. Levy did not receive their first choices, Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce. But their assignments were among their top requests.
Mr. Levy was assigned to the Foreign Affairs and Public Works Committees. He said that he did not have a specific agenda, but that he was pleased that the Foreign Affairs panel would let him to address issues dealing with Israel. "I have a large constituency in my district that is interested in matters involving Israel," he said. "I'll be dealing with that."
 
To Fight 'Regulatory Morass'
 Mr. Lazio, who received seats on the Banking and Budget committees, said he hoped to review the "regulatory morass" that he says is keeping banks from lending money and stifling the recovery from the recession. "I think if we can carefully scrutinize regulations that have been or about to be implemented and eliminate some of those that are ill advised," Mr. Lazio said. "We can pump billions of dollars into the economy without raising taxes or increasing the deficit."
He will be joined on the Banking committee by Mr. King, who replaces Mr. Lent on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee. "That committee serves in a watchdog role," Mr. King said. "My district includes all of the South Shore and some of the North Shore. So of course while there, I'll work to protect the fishing industry" in addition to finding money to repair storm damage.

HEADLINE: New College Loan Rules Take Effect

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS a senior at John Jay High School in Katonah, Amanda Arpino had her heart set on Ripon College in Wisconsin. But her mother, Carol, could not afford the $18,000 yearly cost, and she knew her $70,000 income and $240,000 condominium would keep her daughter from qualifying for Federal aid. They didn't even bother filling out the loan forms. Ripon offered a scholarship, but it wasn't enough.
Amanda settled for the State University of New York at Binghamton, a much larger college that fit into Carol's $6,000 yearly school budget. 
 Now the Federal Government is loosening its loan rules to make it easier for middle-class students to pay for college. That is good news for some families, but educators worry that the relaxed rules will encourage students and parents to take on more debt than they can afford.
The Arpinos aren't giving into the temptation. Although the new rules would put Ripon's expensive education within Amanda Arpino's reach, she and her mother decided that the debt -- $12,000 a year -- would be more than they could handle.
 
Three Major Loan Programs
 Although many people think of grants when they think of student aid, for years most of the help from the Federal Government came in the form of federally guaranteed low-interest bank loans available through three major programs. The largest is the subsidized Stafford loan program, which allows low-income students to borrow for college or graduate school.
There is also the Supplemental Loans for Students program, which lets any student, regardless of income, take out a small Government-guaranteed bank loan, and the Plus Loan, which lets parents get low-interest loans to pay for their child's college education. Unlike the other two, Stafford is a subsidized loan, which means the Government makes the student's interest payments so long as he or she stays in school.
The revised Higher Education Act, signed into law last summer, makes dozens of changes to existing grant and loan programs. Four changes, in particular, are expected to increase student borrowing in Westchester.
 
Borrowing Becomes Easier
 First, the act creates a new non-need-based Stafford loan. Every student in America is eligible for the loans, which are now available to pay for the semester starting this month. The loans offer low-interest rates but are considered unsubsidized because the Government doesn't cover the initial interest payments. Banks will continue lending money to low-income students through the regular subsidized Stafford program.
Second, the law loosens the Federal formula that decides who gets student aid and how much. Specifically, the Government will stop counting home equity when it determines how much families can borrow under need-based programs like the regular Stafford.
Third, it removes lending limits from the Plus program, letting parents borrow up to the full cost of a child's education. Under the old law, parents were able to borrow only $4,000 a year.
Fourth, the law increases the size of most Stafford loans, increasing lifetime limits for undergraduates to $23,000 from $17,250. It also raises the limits for graduate school Stafford borrowing, to $8,500 a year from $7,500. The limits for upperclassmen on Supplemental Loans for Students will also increase.
 
Embracing the Middle Class
 One of the goals of the changes was to "embrace the middle class in student-aid programs," said John Curtice, director of financial services at the State University's central administration office in Albany. The new law helps families that can "stomach the loans" to pay for college, he said.
When students hear the words "financial aid" they tend to imagine grants and scholarships, not loans, said Kathleen Payea, associate director of financial services at College Scholarship Service, the Manhattan-based student-aid arm of the nonprofit organization called the College Board, which is best known for administering standardized tests. Ms. Payea said the new law has raised expectations that won't be met.
One has a choice between having a loan and not being able to pay for college at all, countered Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Harrison, a member of the House Education and Labor Committee and a supporter of the law. "The role of the Government is to provide access and opportunity for all youngsters, but the individual decision to take on that debt has to be the individual's."
The Arpinos are better off financially than the typical Westchester family, but their home is worth less than the average home in the county. As a supervisor of guidance and business education at Woodlands High School, Carol Arpino makes $70,000 a year, above the 1990 county median of $58,862 for a family. Her Cross River town house, which she bought for $240,000 five years ago, cost less than the median of $283,500. But as a divorced mother working off a nearly new mortgage and paying for her daughter's education on her own, her finances are tighter than most family's. She can only afford to spend $6,000 a year on her daughter's college education.
Still, they are among the middle- class people that the rule changes were designed to help, and a look at the way the new rules could help pay for Amanda Arpino's education could offer some guidance for other Westchester families.
 
Below-Market Interest Rate
 With the new non-need-based Stafford Loans becoming available this month, Amanda Arpino, a sophomore in college, will be able to borrow $2,625. As with a regular need-based Stafford, her money will be lent by banks at a below-market interest rate, and the Government will guarantee that the bank is paid back. Because her loan won't come from the old subsidized program, Amanda Arpino won't get Government help with the early interest payments.
Amanda Arpino's new $2,625 loan will bring her closer to a semester at Ripon but won't get her to the school, which costs about $9,000 a term.
Having already spent about $2,000 on college for this school year, Carol Arpino could contribute about $4,000 for Ripon. That would still leave Amanda Arpino $2,000 short of Ripon's single semester cost.
In Westchester, the unsubsidized program could generate close to 10,000 new loans, giving area students $24 million in new funds, said Charles Treadwell, director of research policy at the New York State Higher Education Services Corporation, the company that will insure most of those loans. Mr. Treadwell couldn't say exactly who will borrow the unsubsidized funds, but a similar Pennsylvania program gives out most of its loans to families who make $30,000 to $54,000 a year, according to the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, which insures that state's student loans.
 
Home Equity to Be Removed
 Next fall Amanda Arpino's loan package could improve again, when the Government relaxes the eligibility rules for need-based aid, raises the Stafford loan limits and removes the limits on how much Carol Arpino can borrow under the Plus program.
Under the relaxed Stafford borrowing rules, the Government won't count home equity or other assets when it decides how much a family should contribute to its child's education. The Government figures out how much aid to give each student by subtracting the family's share from the cost of the school. The Government covers its share, ranging from $2,625 for freshmen to $8,500 for graduate students, through loan programs, and most schools try to pick up the rest of the tab.
Nationwide, the new rules will reduce the amount families put in by an average of about $700, said Ms. Payea of the College Scholarship Service. Homeowners will benefit the most. Their share will drop an average of $1,500 while most renters will see their tuition share increase, she said.
Together, the new Stafford and Plus rules would make it possible for Amanda Arpino to spend her junior and senior years at Ripon.
 
To Go Into Debt or Not?
 Under the new formula, the Government will require Carol Arpino to put about $15,000 (in cash or loans) toward her daughter's education, according to rough calculations made by Ms. Payea. Subtract that $15,000 from Ripon's $18,000 annual cost, and that leaves Amanda Arpino eligible for $3,000 in need-based aid. The Government would probably offer Amanda Arpino a $3,000 subsidized Stafford to cover the Government's share.
But Carol Arpino can only afford to contribute $6,000 a year, so that will leave the family with a $9,000 annual gap. Amanda Arpino can fill part of that gap by borrowing another $2,500 from the new unsubsidized Stafford program in each of her last two years of college. That will still leave the Arpinos $6,500 short each year. Carol Arpino can take up that slack with a $6,500 Plus loan or Amanda Arpino can borrow $5,000 under the Supplemental Loans for Students program while her mother borrows $1,500 from Plus. Amanda Arpino works part time and contributes something to the cost of her education.
But for the Arpinos, the total debt for two years at Ripon would still be about $24,000. The question for them and other Westchester families is whether the exclusive private school education is worth the debt.
The answer for the Arpinos is no. After college, Armanda Arpino said, she plans to earn both business and law degrees. She expects her graduate education to put her $100,000 in debt and she says that any undergraduate loans are out of the question. For other families the answer may be different.
 
 
 
COLLEGES DOUBT THEY CAN GIVE MORE HELP

 
 NEXT fall, new Federal lending rules will reduce the amount that middle-class families must put toward college and increase Government contributions. The new rules will also leave a larger financial gap for colleges to cover. Financial-aid officers at several colleges say they can't afford to fill that new gap. Instead, they are coming up with their own formulas. Here is how several are coping:
Sarah Lawrence in Yonkers can't afford to use the new Federal formula, said Robert M. Kinnally, the school's director of financial aid. Instead, the school is using an aid formula developed by the College Scholarship Service, the student-aid arm of the nonprofit College Board, the group that administers standardized admissions tests.
Mr. Kinnally described the College Scholarship formula as an affordable compromise between the new and old Federal formulas that will "keep our budget intact and keep our families as happy as possible."
Under the old Federal formula, the Government included the full value of a family's home when it determined how much that family would have tocontribute to college costs -- and how much was left over for the Federal Government to contribute. Under the new Federal formula, the Government doesn't consider home value at all. Using the College Scholarship formula, Sarah Lawrence will look at part of a family's home value -- up to three times the family's income -- when it decides how to distribute its funds. In other ways the College Scholarship formula follows the new Federal formula, Mr. Kinnally said.
Though Sarah Lawrence is changing its aid formula in an effort to keep up with the Federal changes, Mr. Kinnally said he expects the college's new formula to yield just about the same dollar amounts as the old one. "We think it's going to be some kind of a wash," he said. "It has to be."
Sarah Lawrence now gives out about $5 million of its grant money every year. That figure can't go up much, Mr. Kinnally said, because the extra money isn't there. If using the new College Scholarship formula results in higher costs than using the old method, Sarah Lawrence will have to rethink the way it disburses funds, Mr. Kinnally said.
Vassar College in Poughkeepsie would have to spend $1.5 million to $2 million of its own money this fall to finance all the middle-class students the Federal Government now says are eligible. The college just doesn't have the extra cash, said Michael Fraher, the director of financial aid.
"Basically, we're going to continue to use the old formula" to distribute Vassar funds, Mr. Fraher said. Students who are already getting aid from Vassar will get the same package in the 1993-94 school year. And students who are not eligible for Vassar money now won't qualify for it in the future.
At Pace University, using the new formula would also cost millions of dollars, said Leo Kornfeld, vice president of enrollment management. But the university, which already puts 15 percent of its tuition income into grants and scholarships, will not be able to increase its grant budget by millions, he said.
"We have never, nor can we ever meet the needs of all the students who come to Pace," he said. Pace will continue to allocate its limited scholarship dollars by helping the best students first, he said.
The new Federal rules are not going to change the financial-aid picture at Mercy College, said Marion Dale, the school's director of financial aid. The school offers some merit-based scholarships, but its largest aid program offers grants to students whose family income is less than $15,000 a year, Miss Dale said. The Dobbs Ferry college can't afford to expand its program to include the middle class, she said.
Similarly, Iona College will not offer new grants. "There's no way a school with our endowment can meet all the need," said Monica Simotas, Iona's director of financial aid. "My budget for financial aid is not going to be increased."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Bright Forecasts for the Far East

BYLINE: By Sheryl WuDunn

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
The Hong Kong stock market's stellar performance last year might have stunned and dazzled overseas investors, but local investors are grumbling.
They are distressed that nearly half the gains they scored when the Hang Seng index hit a record in mid-November were erased in December. From a high of 6,570.83, the index tumbled by year's end to 5,512.39. Still, that was up 28.3 percent for the entire year, the highest growth of all the world's markets. 
 Volatility is a way of life in the Hong Kong market, where fortunes and failures are intricately linked to the political winds of mainland China, particularly to the activities of a small group of octogenarians who with a single grunt or a smile on television can send ripples through the market. Last year, economic optimism in Hong Kong surged because China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, visited the country's southern region to dramatize the need for faster economic growth and more capitalist-style changes.
Business executives and traders scurry back and forth between the territory and the mainland, agonizing over risky opportunities that boast of doubling their capital in a couple of years.
Once dismissed as a far-away market that ignored fundamentals, Hong Kong is now attracting growing numbers of overseas investors -- Americans, in particular. With the Hong Kong dollar pegged to the American dollar at a rate of 7.8 to 1, Americans face little currency risk.
Hong Kong's link with China -- once viewed as negative by investors who feared the territory would be swallowed up by China in 1997 -- increasingly is seen as an advantage. Investors eager to cash in on China's economic boom see the Hong Kong market as a China play offering a more orderly environment than Chinese stocks themselves.
Indeed, the pendulum has swung so far that many brokers have criticized Hong Kong's new governor, Christopher Patten, for introducing democracy proposals that offended China. A bitter denunciation by Chinese authorities caused Hong Kong stocks to plunge in the last six weeks of 1992.
"Can you believe it?" asked a Chinese business executive with interests in Hong Kong. "The Communists and the capitalists are on the same side against democracy?"
This year Hong Kong's economy is expected to remain buoyant as it prepares to enter the Year of the Rooster, mostly on the coattails of China's economic boom, and some analysts expect the market to set records again. Price/earnings ratios for Hang Seng index stocks in 1992 were about 11-to-1, and some analysts project that based on prospects for high corporate earnings for this year, that even with higher prices the ratio will drop to 9-to-1.
Still, the contretemps over Mr. Patten's pro-democracy proposals overshadows the market. China reiterated a few days ago that it would not accept the proposals, nor would it compromise. Mr. Patten submits his proposals next month to the Legislative Council, and talks could drag on for weeks and even months.
A secondary concern is Washington. Some fear that President-elect Bill Clinton and the Democrat-controlled Congress will attach conditions to United States trade benefits to China. Such worries could damp the usual optimism and flurry of investment that precedes the Chinese New Year on Jan. 23.
The market closed Friday at 5,529.56, down 17.76 points from Thursday's close.
Other Asian markets, notably Malaysia and Thailand, also showed handsome gains last year. Only three years after spinning off from a partnership with Singapore, the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 643.96, up 15.8 percent last year, compared with a 4.2 percent rise for the Dow Jones industrial average.
Prospects for this year are also somewhat rosy. Malaysia's economy, with real growth last year of 8.5 percent over 1991, is Asia's fastest growing next to China. This year, after several years of impressive growth, economists predict a lower but still healthy growth rate of about 7 to 8 percent.
"There has to be some sort of consolidation if nothing else just to cope with the slow economy we are seeing in Western countries and the domestic bottlenecks," said Paul S. B. Chan, head of research at OCBC Securities (Melaka) Sdn Berhad, in Kuala Lumpur. "All these are converging around this time, so I think it will lead to a slower rate of growth for equity prices as well."
Analysts say the index could rise to 700 or 750 by the end of the year, and that prices could be 15 to 20 times 1993 earnings.
Thailand's stock market surprised investors by pulling itself out of a deep slump brought on by an attempted coup. The SET index ended the year at 893.42, up 25.6 percent. The economy grew 7.5 percent and is expected to do even better this year.
With $55 billion in market capitalization, or about half that of Malaysia's market, and more than three times its turnover, Thailand may be a somewhat risky but potentially profitable option for overseas investors.
"Thailand is one of the better picks, and I expect it will hit new highs," said Timothy H. Moe, head of regional research at Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd. "If politics are resolved in Hong Kong, then Hong Kong has the potential to go up higher than Thailand."
"But Thailand right now is not laboring under the same political cloud as Hong Kong," he added, "and it's a better bet than Malaysia, because the overall valuations are cheaper in Thailand."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
High Hopes for Public Bonds

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
For the municipal bond market, Christmas came in November with the election of Bill Clinton as President. After 12 years of Republican efforts to shrink Government at all levels, states and cities, along with the Wall Street firms that underwrite their bonds, now feel that they've got a friend in the White House.
Wall Street, while trying to contain its optimism, expects politically fascinating and financially lucrative days ahead. What is unclear, however, is precisely what the Clinton Administration, however committed to greater public-works spending, will actually do. Equally unknown is what these new policies will mean for municipal issuers and underwriters. 
 Part of this good feeling stems from the fact that 1992 was a record year for municipal bonds, even with a Republican Administration. The volume of long-term municipal securities issued -- bonds to build prisons, bridges, roads and other bits of the infrastructure -- rose 36 percent, to a record $233 billion. Much of the volume came about because low interest rates enabled state and local governments to redeem old high-coupon bonds with lower-coupon, lower-cost, ones. A record $95 billion in municipal bonds were redeemed in 1992, twice 1991's level.
If interest rates stay low, refundings will continue in 1993, although at a slower pace, since most issuers that could refund have already done so. Instead, the action is shifting to Washington, where President-elect Clinton has promised to spend $20 billion a year in what he calls "hard Federal dollars" on infrastructure projects. And while details are fuzzy, Mr. Clinton has outlined a plan of matching Federal funds with municipal borrowings and private dollars.
Those in the municipal bond market are heartened by the perception that Mr. Clinton is one of them: a former bond issuer who has sat on numerous industry commissions. "He is someone who really understands this market and what it can do," said Michael McCarthy, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Co. "The question is whether this will translate into legislation that allows projects to happen that aren't already happening."
This is a far cry from the dark days for the industry that began with the far-reaching 1986 tax act. That measure made it harder for municipalities to issue many types of tax-exempt bonds and knocked some big buyers, mainly banks, out of the market. Since then, the cry for more public projects has increased as urban areas continue to decay and social, and environmental, problems rise. And at the same time, new funding for these projects has limped along.
So, at a time of pent-up demand for public-works financing comes a President ready to embrace it -- and raise taxes on the wealthy to increase the audience for tax-free bonds. But, many ask, how might this all happen? Former Representative Beryl Anthony of Arkansas, head of the influential Anthony Commission, has put forth a legislative package to roll back many of the 1986 changes -- including making it easier for banks to buy tax-free bonds, permitting more public-private ventures and lifting restrictions capping the amount of bonds municipalities can issue.
Mr. Anthony said he expects "broad support" for this package. And with plenty of reason: Mr. Clinton, as Arkansas Governor, was a founding member of the Anthony Commission and helped kick around some of these ideas. Besides, a similar package passed Congress last year only to be vetoed by President Bush. "As long as Bush was in the White House, no one wanted to work hard and get vetoed," said Mr. Anthony. "Now our work has a chance of getting enacted."
A more controversial proposal being floated by Mr. Anthony is the creation of a new type of tax-exempt bond, called a "public activity" bond. This bond would allow private investors to use tax-free bonds to build or buy a public-use business, like a wastewater treatment plant, and run it at a profit. This proposal raises the specter of past abuses where municipal bond proceeds were used solely for private ventures. But many years have passed since those abuses occurred, and public-private ventures are squarely in keeping with Mr. Clinton's stated philosophy.
Another notion being aired is the concept of federally guaranteed taxable infrastructure bonds, similar to Ginnie Mae bonds. These would be designed to lure some of the $3 trillion in pension dollars to infrastructure projects. Since pensions are not taxed, they rarely buy tax-free securities. But they would buy a federally-guaranteed taxable municipal bond -- if it existed. In Washington, however, some worry that this new guarantee will only create another contingent liability on the Federal budget. And they say there are already enough potential municipal bond investors out there, without having to turn to pensions. "I'm not sure it's understood how much our existing marketplace, with some minor changes, could be used without creating another government guarantee," said Micah S. Greene, executive vice president of the Public Securities Association. Lobbyists are scurrying around the transition team, and one another, to fine-tune this concept.
Oddly enough, however, some suggest that Mr. Clinton might just bypass the municipal bond market entirely and make direct Federal grants for projects. "Some people have seen past Democratic Administrations and think they can get the government to give them some money," said R. Fenn Putman, a managing director at Lehman Brothers. "And free money is better than low-cost money." Yet a close reading of Mr. Clinton's statements indicates that he will use Federal funds as seed money for state revolving funds, which then borrow in the marketplace. This "leveraging" creates more money for projects, even if some is borrowed.
Still, hardheaded Wall Street financiers are not ready to declare that happy days are here again. "Over the last 10 years, everything that could go wrong for the municipal market did," said Daniel Keating, head of municipal finance at Bear Stearns. "So if all this happens, it will work out well for us. But these days, no one is overly optimistic."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Did Wall Street Vigilantes Take a Snooze?

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
They're known as Wall Street's vigilantes, the professional skeptics who buy and sell bonds for a living and who can reputedly see inflation threats visible to no one else. Their hypersensitive reactions to shifting Federal budget prospects are now studied by politicians as well as investors.
But the vigilantes, at least until the past few days, seem to have gone to sleep. How else do you explain a yield of less than 7 1/2 percent on 30-year Treasury bonds, a quarter percentage point less than when Bill Clinton was elected President, in the face of a hemorrhaging Federal budget? Perhaps the Street is reassured by the prominence in the new Administration of two of its own -- Robert E. Rubin of Goldman Sachs as chairman of the National Economic Council and Roger Altman of Blackstone Group as No. 2 at Treasury. 
 Perhaps Wall Street thinks global recession will keep interest rates in check. Oddly, recent statistics showing American growth picking up have tended to push interest rates down, not up, in the belief that Mr. Clinton will need a less ambitious stimulation package.
More likely, however, the vigilantes have forgotten -- or never learned -- budget history and still don't recognize the deficit's structural nature. Jimmy Carter with his "zero based" methodology projected a balanced budget, and he left office with record red ink. The same, writ large, for Ronald Reagan. And four years ago, the O.M.B. chief, Richard G. Darman, said: "We will succeed at deficit reduction," only to watch the deficit more than double, to $327.3 billion for the current year.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation failed to contain, much less reduce, the deficit. Nor has the ballyhooed but evadable Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990. The Government, which last posted a surplus in 1969, can no longer envision budgetary balance in distant years. And last week's annual projections by the Bush Administration brought a replay of political arguments about phony numbers, allowing the Clinton camp to start backing away from campaign pledges to halve the deficit over four years.
"There is a honeymoon going on," said one market operator when asked about the apparent suspension of critical faculties during the Clinton transition.
You don't have to buy the whole deficit-disaster scenario of Harry E. Figgie Jr.'s "Bankruptcy 1995" to lose sleep. Consider the fact that recent deficits do not yet reflect the exploding cost of health care and other entitlements, which accounted for the same 11 percent of national output in 1991 as they did in 1976.
Of course, Mr. Clinton and the Congressional Democrats, realizing that there's no longer anyone else to blame, may perform the fiscal equivalent of Richard Nixon's going to China and slash spening. But this doesn't seem the smart way to bet, particularly since Mr. Clinton's rhetoric is at odds with the evidence of him as a guy who finds it hard to say no.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Stock Twists and Turns of '92

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Playing the stock market so far in the 90's has been like taking a ride on Coney Island's famous Cyclone roller-coaster. Stock funds in 1990 suffered a 7.3 percent loss on average, only to attain a return of 30.7 percent in '91 and then skid last year to a gain of just 6 percent.
But even that small return didn't come until the end of the year. The stock market was flat most of 1992, nervously waiting to learn who would next occupy the White House, and only bounded up in November and December on post-election euphoria. 
 In another abrupt turn, the market finally began favoring undervalued stocks over growth companies and funds that invest in smaller companies bested their blue-chip cousins for the second year in a row.
Funds that invest in shares of small companies, by far the riskiest group of major stock funds, led that pack with a 12.5 percent return, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. Next in line were equity-income funds, with a 9.4 percent return, and growth-and-income funds, 8.6 percent, both of which own high-dividend stocks or bonds that lift their returns.
Among specialty funds, the 14 financial services funds, which invest in banks, brokerages, insurance companies and the like, continued their strong run, landing first place in that category with a remarkable 35.3 percent return. Other winners were science and technology, 13.5 percent, and real estate, 12.8 percent. Stodgy utilities funds also shone, at 9.1 percent.
Starring among hybrid funds were the convertible securities funds, boasting a 13.6 percent return. Other funds that own a mix of stocks and bonds performed about the same as all-stock ones. Balanced funds showed a return of 7.2 percent and asset-allocation funds had a 7.5 percent return.
Despite the European currency crisis last fall and other instability abroad, funds that invest in gold, which is fast losing its reputation as a refuge from international turmoil, showed a 14.6 percent loss. Other losers were the health-and-biotechnology funds -- 1991's biggest gainers -- with an 8.3 percent loss, and environmental funds, a 6.2 percent loss.
For the fourth consecutive year, America was the best place to invest, with major stock funds returning 8.9 percent. The international funds as a group lost 5.1 percent. Because of a stock market scandal and continuing political and economic problems in Japan, funds that invest there were the year's biggest losers, plunging 21.3 percent. European issues did not fare too well either, losing 8 percent. Funds in Latin America and the Pacific region were basically flat.
This middle-of-the-road year for the investor looks much rosier from the perspective of the fund industry. Record-low yields in taxable money markets -- the funds yielded 3.39 percent on average for the year, according to IBC/Donoghue in Ashland, Mass. -- pushed investors into higher-risk alternatives.
As a result, the industry will wind up with twelve-month net sales of roughly $185 billion, up $40 billion from the previous record set in 1986 and $66.5 billion higher than in 1991, said Dean P. Eberling, an asset management and brokerage analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers.
The explosive growth probably will continue if significant household money now in money market funds, certificates of deposit and bank accounts continues to flow into stock and bond funds. Any type of pro-savings legislation coming from the new Democratic administration "would be an additional positive," Mr. Eberling said.
Just as hordes of first-time investors moved into mutual funds, one large recipient of their money, the short-term multi-market funds, collapsed. These funds, intended to capture high yields on government securities abroad, fell victim to the European currency crisis. When funds move into such sophisticated trading strategies or derivative securities, the results have been mainly disastrous and last year was no exception.
As the fixed-income market gets more and more esoteric, "I worry that we will have more problems," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group in Chicago.
Trouble ahead could come in the form of a spike in interest rates. Most investors and fund managers haven't seen interest rates rise in years. While investors may be aware of default risk, many do not understand that prices of long-term securities, like most municipal bonds, would fall if rates rose.
One portent of trouble may be that 1992 was the year of the deal in the fund industry. Recalling that the sales of Smith Barney and Kidder Peabody came just before the 1987 stock market crash, some have suggested that such transactions are a warning of market peaks.
This year, two of the biggest players in municipal bond funds changed hands: John Nuveen & Company sold shares to the public and Van Kampen Merritt, a Xerox division, was sold to its management.
The biggest deal of all was the acquisition of John Templeton's international mutual fund empire by Franklin Resources Inc. for $913 million.
Franklin has a strong domestic fixed-income business, and its new bet on international equities, especially those culled using a value approach, may be as shrewd, some analysts say, as its original bet on bonds in the early 80's.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Where Giants Tread: A New Biography of Microsoft's Chief

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
William H. Gates is one of the busiest executives in the world, people who work for him say, yet he still finds time to read books. If he can do it, so can anyone. An appropriate one to start with is "Gates: How Microsoft's Mogul Reinvented an Industry and Made Himself the Richest Man in America," by Stephen Manes and Paul Andrews ($25, Doubleday).
It is not the first biography of Mr. Gates, co-founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation and, as everyone seems compelled to add, the richest man in America. Given that Mr. Gates is but 37 years old, there will surely be many other attempts. But this book, written by a veteran computer industry columnist and a reporter for The Seattle Times, is to date the definitive work. 
 The most complete and thoroughly documented history of the Microsoft Corporation and its role in the emergence of the personal computer industry, the book provides many surprises. Contrary to what one would expect from a company that so thoroughly dominates the software industry, Microsoft's success arises from a steady procession of failures and missteps. The key is that each spurred Mr. Gates all the more to succeed.
"Gates," the book, gets beyond the cliche of Gates the billionaire nerd. It reveals, instead, a very smart guy with a passion not just to succeed but to win . . . no, to dominate. In his early 20's, he rebuffed a lucrative buyout offer from H. Ross Perot. He works 72 hours a week with occasional bursts of up to 90, and even when he is not working he devours information the way a black hole sucks up light.
But there are lots of very smart and competitive men and women at the helms of businesses, and "Gates" is particularly good at providing insights into what sets Mr. Gates apart. To use a computer analogy, the book tries to peer at his source code, at the basic instructions that define his essence. The field of biotechnology is his second passion, and logic and rationale replace spirituality and faith in Mr. Gates's cosmology.
His management style is heavier on the stick than on the carrot, but the carrot is golden. A single $1 share of Microsoft stock held since 1981, before the company went public, is worth approximately $1,500 today. At one point, new programmers were given 2,500 shares with a promise that they would someday be a "downpayment on a house." Mr. Gates's worth is estimated at more than $7 billion; literally hundreds of his employees have stock holdings worth more than $1 million, and Mr. Gates's chief lieutenant, Steve Ballmer, is a billionaire. So is Paul Allen, a high school pal of Mr. Gates and a co-founder of Microsoft who now owns the Seattle Supersonics basketball team.
Mr. Gates appears to shrug off the current Federal Trade Commission investigation into whether Microsoft's business practices are monopolistic and impassive when the stock market buffets his Microsoft holdings ("I have an infinite amount of money"). But he is truly outraged when he reads that a competitor, Philippe Kahn of Borland International Inc., referred to him as "not a technical guy."
When Mr. Gates prefaces a response to reporter's question by saying "I don't know how technical you are," he might as well be questioning the writer's character. Although he has not personally coded any Microsoft software in years, he still appears to take greater pride in his technical savvy than in his substantial business skills.
The nontechnical side of Mr. Gates is illuminated to some degree -- not enough, but far more than in previous accounts of Mr. Gates's life: his well-to-do family in Seattle, with whom he remains very close; his occasional escapades, from marathon poker games to undergraduate pranks at Harvard, before he dropped out; his collections of exotic cars and speeding tickets.
Whether this approach reflects Mr. Gates's obsession with business or the writers' inability to tap into the other parts of his personality is unclear. Mr. Gates did consent to be interviewed and opened the Microsoft archives to the writers, but most detail from those interviews appears to focus on business matters.
Mr. Manes said in a telephone interview that after Mr. Gates obtained a bootlegged copy of the book's galley proofs, the Microsoft chief spent seven hours on the phone from Hawaii, where he was vacationing, arguing with the writers "in excruciating detail" about various points.
Mr. Gates's main concern, Mr. Manes said, appeared to be that he felt he did not get enough credit for his achievements as a programmer and that Microsoft did not get enough credit for outsmarting its rivals, as opposed to simply being lucky or aggressive or persistent.
In the end, readers may still not feel that they know Mr. Gates, but they certainly will understand him better. And because Mr. Gates is, for all practical purposes, the embodiment of the personal computer industry, readers will also have a better understanding of the issues that affect the industry.
 
'The Virtual Corporation'
 Another thoughtful book for the new year is "The Virtual Corporation: Structuring and Revitalizing the Corporation for the 21st Century," by William H. Davidow and Michael S. Malone ($23, Harper Collins).
Virtual is a buzzword in the industry today -- with virtual machines, virtual memory and virtual reality. It means, essentially, something that acts as if it is something else. A virtual corporation, then, is a business organization that can be many things to many people, quite apart from the rigid, hierarchical corporations of today. In this vision, the corporation's structure is determined by its customers, rather than its executives.
Using examples taken from successful businesses, the authors attempt to outline the requisites for business success in the coming century, when they expect "virtual companies" to compete on a global scale to deliver "virtual products" -- mainly information -- instantly to customers.
The authors are occasionally given to breathless forecasting: "By the year 2015, the United States will either be a leader in this new business revolution or it will be a postindustrial version of a developing country. Either a nation of independent knowledge workers or a colony of economic serfs." If such binary thinking is a bit hard to take, the book does present a compelling vision of how businesses are evolving. The challenges are already clear: education of the workforce as learning becomes more important than manual labor; increased global competition, and the changing role of management in an information-based company.
