HEADLINE: Father Earth

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: TAOS, N.M.

 BODY:
About 15 miles west of Taos, a road with no name tapers off into the flat tableland beneath the Tres Orejas, three small volcanic peaks. Soon the road disappears entirely. All that remains is a thick carpet of snow and a set of coyote tracks pitching toward infinity.
But if you can envision an Alternative Republic here, you don't need a road. Thus, a frigid winter morning recently found Michael Reynolds, a one-man Monkey Wrench gang of architecture, barreling through the snowdrifts, his Dodge pickup swerving every which way, destined for an unsightly pile of tires and dirt, his new Atlantis: downtown Star. 
 And so, as the New Year begins, changing the world has come down to this: a Taos morning blue with cold, a 47-year-old man with fly-away hair and a pickax pounding frozen dirt into used tires -- the detritus of 20th-century civilization and building blocks of a new utopia.
Star is an acronym for the Social Transformation Alternative Republic, a 1,100-acre self-sufficient community for around 300 people that Mr. Reynolds, a renegade pioneer in the alternative-housing movement, is building on a sage- and pinon-flecked periphery of town.
The houses at Star will be what Mr. Reynolds has christened "earth ships," dwellings made of rammed earth and tires that the architect has been perfecting in and around Taos for the last 20 years. His goal -- already realized at another project nearby -- is to be independent of the conventional power grid. Instead of being heated by electricity, the earth ships will use sculpted earth, tire walls and the sun, which also powers the photovoltaic cells that provide electricity. Rather than conventional plumbing, there will be catch-water roof systems to harvest and filter runoff from snow and rain. Used water from bathtubs and sinks will be piped into jungly planters where flowers and vegetables grow. There will be no sewers -- only solar toilets, an invention of Mr. Reynolds that reduces human waste to dust, dust that "may even be good for something," he said.
Mr. Reynolds called Star a republic, rather than a housing development, and half jokingly threatened secession from the United States if Government authorities try to intervene. He talks fast and thinks globally. His main objective at Star, according to the community's articles of association, will be to "evolve humanity into an earthen harmony." The earthen harmony, he said, will be "half dictatorship, half democracy."
Mr. Reynolds doesn't think of himself as a guru, though ardent disciples read his books and watch his videos. He doesn't particularly look like one, either, padding around his offices in kneepads and wool socks with toes poking through, or being engaged in his seemingly futile midwinter tire-pounding rituals, proof "you can build these things even in the dead of winter with bozos," as he called his crew. He sees himself as a scout, a "scout on a wagon train going west."
Alternative building styles, from his steel-belted radicalism to houses constructed of straw bales, have experienced something of a resurgence recently in New Mexico, a home of adobe construction. Though the material has a poverty stigma in the third world, where it is a staple, in places like Santa Fe, it is as much an accouterment of the good life as are Range Rovers and Jacuzzis.
A movement within the growing green architecture movement, which focuses on energy efficiency and nontoxic building materials, the current bubble of alternative activity is "a somewhat logical extension of the 60's," said Stuart Brand, the founder of the Whole Earth Catalog. It combines a concern for home and family with affordable housing and environmentalism. Mr. Reynolds's grand experiment is anti-industrial in the way it uses technology to bypass utilities and other outside life-support systems but is more sophisticated and replicable than early back-to-the-land efforts.
Viewed collectively, Mr. Brand said, mini-movements like Mr. Reynolds's suggest that "hippie premises haven't been entirely undone, and people now have the time and money to act on them." Mr. Reynolds believes that earth ships contrast with the now-fabled communes, which betrayed a "naive trust in human nature." "The thing is," he said, "people don't want to live together. These people also froze to death. They didn't have the right vessel."
The right vessel -- the low-budget model -- is a two-bedroom, 1,000-square-foot house with horseshoe-shaped rooms tucked into the earth. Its walls are made from stacked tire casings, indestructible building blocks packed solidly with dirt. The rammed dirt functions like a battery, storing and releasing the earth's own warmth as well as heat from the sun. It takes about 800 or 900 automobile tires (and a matrix of innumerable aluminum cans and cement) to build one house. A basic earth ship can cost anywhere from $30,000 to $40,000 if the owner is his own contractor and does much of the work himself. And it can cost as little as $60,000 for a custom-designed original by his company, Solar Survival Architecture.
On a treacherously steep mountainside outside of town, Mr. Reynolds's latest ideas have already taken root at Reach (or Rural Earthship Alternative Community Habitat), a cluster of 15 earth ships, two of which have been completed, slinking up the cliffside like a new-age Mesa Verde.
Among the Reach homeowners are the actor Dennis Weaver and his wife, Gerry, who have also built a $1 million, 10,000-square-foot earth ship in Ridgway, Colo., a mammoth pad that Mr. Reynolds wryly referred to as the Earth Yacht. Keith Carradine is another client. Mr. Weaver called Mr. Reynolds "an absolute dedicated risk-taking visionary genius." The actor is promulgating the earth-ship concept through lectures and his own mail-order video. (Mr. Weaver's come-on on the package has a more show-biz feeling: "As seen on 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.' Mr. Reynolds's pitch in promotional literature -- "Good for getting permits" -- is more basic.)
For Mr. Reynolds, earth ships are a social mission that transcends architecture. "A lunar module allows you to go to the moon and function," he is fond of saying, vaguely echoing Buckminster Fuller, whose geodesic domes were considered radical concepts for spaceship earth. "This vessel enables you to live on the earth and function."
Mr. Reynolds's inspiration is not Buckminster Fuller. It is Noah. "Noah was building an ark to survive the coming storm," he said, pounding tires one afternoon on the mesa, the red dirt flinging from his pickax and adhering to the sweat on his nose. "We're building vessels for the storm we're already in."
Underlying the world's problems is stress, or so Mr. Reynolds thinks -- the terrible stress that comes from having to "work at a job seven days a week" to pay the mortgage. Give people a cheap, energy-efficient house that they can build themselves, and you liberate them from the "rip-off" of mortgages and bank loans. They are then free to pursue whatever makes them happy. It's the fluffy bunny-rabbit theory: "Put it into a corner, and it'll claw you," he said. "But take the stress out of its life, put it in a house with solar heat and banana leaves, and it will blossom. It's no fun to be around cornered rabbits who are uptight and weirded out."
So far, Mr. Reynolds has signed up 29 weirded-out rabbit couples for Star, where construction will begin in earnest in late March, and he expects nearly 200 more. Earth-ship owners have the option of buying a generic set of drawings for $1,200 from Mr. Reynolds and building the house with a knowledgeable crew, or hiring Solar Survival Architecture to do the work (at a minimum of $65 a square foot), as Mr. Weaver did. Or they can combine the two. Solar Survival offers weekend how-to seminars seven times a year, costing $600 a couple or $350 a person. Mr. Reynolds has published the two-volume "Earthship: How to Build Your Own," which has sold 20,000 copies and become something of a cult classic. Thanks in part to Mr. Weaver's video, word has spread. Pat Habicht, a soft-spoken Englishwoman who lives in an early-model earth ship, charges $15 for earth-ship tours to the curious pilgrims seeking enlightment on earth ships.
One recent morning, two 40-ish women from San Francisco -- one a massage therapist, the other a nutritionist -- met with Mr. Reynolds at his headquarters, in a place he calls the Castle, a bizarre-looking sparkly structure of cement and beer cans that tends to exude an unearthly glow. They were talking about what he called their tool scene and finalizing the generic earth ship that they plan to build with a crew at Star this spring for $50 a square foot. Their home will include fish and waterlilies. "It's like being a pioneer," one of them said. "You're taking responsibility for your own beingness."
MR. REYNOLDS forsees a time when people might be liberated by their earth ships, in which he said most food "except bacon and Cheetos." could be grown. He also predicts the money economy will be replaced by a barter economy as the drudgery of earning a living slips away. Eventually, the dams, landfills, nuclear power plants and other scourges of humankind could disappear.
"The ramifications are pretty intense," Mr. Reynolds said. "I turned a rock over in my imagination and saw a pearl."
Mr. Reynolds, who grew up in and around Louisville, Ky., moved to northern New Mexico in the 1960's after studying architecture at the University of Cincinnati with the goal of "racing motorcycles, getting hurt and avoiding the draft." His mother was a homemaker. His father, a milkman, used to hoard materials like oatmeal cartons. "That planted the seed," he recalled. "I learned that this was not waste. It was material."
He got a teaching job at a vocational school outside Taos, resulting in a draft deferment. After watching news reports of housing and garbage crises, he started tinkering with beer cans. In 1971, he built his first beer-can house in Taos. "It was in The Denver Post right under Nixon's picture, in color," he recalled nostalgically.
He began experimenting with bunkerlike rammed-earth dwellings, and wilder structures topped with wind turbines that had an esthetic not unlike that of a cement mixer. But it wasn't until he discovered pyramids that he had an epiphany -- a drugless one, he hastens to point out.
As he wrote in his book "A Coming of Wizards: A Manual of Human Potential" (High Mesa Press, 1988), sleeping in a pyramid connected him with the energy patterns of the universe. The room started tilting and spinning, and there were swirling purples and a red misty haze. The wizards spoke. "Whether it was my mind or the cosmos talking, I don't know," he says today. He was one weirded-out rabbit.
Abandoning pyramids because 75 percent of the people wouldn't understand them, he pursued the less telepathic earth ship. He was determined to find a housing solution that, "like a radio frequency," could hook people up with their "energy band."
His penchant for test-piloting his own houses has taken a toll. "The typical wife," he said, doesn't want to move every three years to another "psychic proving ground." He's had five weddings (three to the same person); his wife, Chris Simpson, is an astrologer. His energy band includes a sense of humor. "At least they always get a house out of it," he said of his exes.
Despite his cosmic observances, the two completed earth ships at Reach -- custom-built by his company -- are down-to-earth and quite lovely. The houses, one of them Mr. Weaver's, have thick curved walls, echoing the bend in the tires, and exposed rugged cliff faces that contrast with the smooth earthen/ stucco finishes. Rooms are designed in U-shapes, instead of at right angles, and they open onto a bright hallway lined with solar windows that face south. The slanting glass is angled to fully capture the winter sun's reflection. An interior wetlands runs the full length of the house, a lush welter of tomato plants, peas, flowers and herbs.
It's too soon to tell how the Reach houses -- the first ones to go cold turkey off the conventional power grid -- will work day in and day out (one wonders how a compost toilet and photovoltaic-powered washer-dryer work during extended family gatherings). But many of the ideas are rooted in common sense, and that is why New Mexico building officials seem willing to work with him.
Although Reach and Star are located outside the Taos city limits, they are still subject to New Mexico state building codes, which have responded to statewide interest in alternative building by granting experimental permits to people like Mr. Reynolds. Homeowner must also sign waivers saying they are aware of their houses' experimental nature and absolving the state of liability.
Of the fledgling earth ships built by Solar Survival in and around Taos, some of them 18 years old, none have suffered building failure, said Bob Koss, the state's regional building inspector. But questions remain about what will happen when novices with tires in their eyes build earth ships on a large scale. At Star, Mr. Koss noted, Mr. Reynolds "is getting close to the point where he's not going to have the control that he did." Mr. Reynolds will inspect the earth ships, for a sliding fee, four times during the construction process.
ONE of Mr. Reynolds's major premises is that earth ships can be built by anybody, anywhere. Although Noah survived 40 days and 40 nights of rain, some people doubt that earth ships would. The Austin, Tex., architect Pliny Fisk 3d, an expert on alternative building technologies, worries that "people are getting mesmerized." In damper climates, he said, there is a concern that walls one day may collapse. Others wonder about invading pristine places with "vacation houses for environmental dilettantes," as one Taos resident put it.
Though Mr. Reynolds said his do-it-yourself earth-ship formula is "hard to mess up," the idea that any committed person can build one is certainly debatable. Marsha Campbell, a 49-year-old social worker, moved to Taos from Ohio to build an earth ship in 1991. Her tales are reminiscent of Great Plains pioneer women in sod houses -- living in an unfinished dirt house, hauling 40-pound containers of water, dashing to the outhouse in the dead of night. Eventually she reached the end of her $20,000, unable to complete the project. Along the way, she and her lover broke up.
"I think Michael Reynolds is a genius," she now says, "and the idea works if you can hire him to build the house. But if you can't, you suffer. In my life, I've been pretty much able to do everything I set out to do. But I certainly couldn't build that stupid house."
Mr. Reynolds's personal supervision costs money -- $65 an hour, to be exact. He acknowledges that the popularity of the books and videos may have lead to some false expectations. "They somehow get the impression that I'm on call anytime to take them to nirvana," he said. There is a potential scenario at Star not unlike one involving 200 fifth graders who all need Daddy to help them with their homework.
Still, out on the Taos mesas, where the soul feels limitless and it seems possible to see forever, some have clearly found, if not exactly nirvana, a reasonable facsimile. There is something elemental about living in a house that requires its occupants to watch the weather, as if they were hawks or beavers, sensing what the wind and clouds will do instead of setting a thermostat.
"You have to be partners with the house," said Mr. Weaver, who has become the Bob Vila of earth ships. If it's cloudy three days in a row, you can't use the washing machine. Speaking by telephone, Mr. Weaver sounded genuinely happy. Indoors, there were bananas. Outside, it was blizzarding.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Linda Baron and Christopher Lloyd

 BODY:
Linda M. Baron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Baron of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Christopher Lloyd, the son of Joshua Lloyd of London and the late Anne Lloyd. Rabbi Albert Sturmer officiated at the Great Hall at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.
Ms. Baron, who is keeping her name, is a freelance photographer and picture editor in New York. She graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. Her father, now retired, was an associate at Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, a law firm in New York. Her mother, Toby Baron, is a partner in Window Designs, a window-design firm in Scarsdale. 
 Mr. Lloyd is a senior corporate trainer with Pacific Bell Directory, a telecommunications company in San Francisco. He graduated from the London School of Economics. His father, now retired, was an assistant headmaster of the Iron Mill Lane School in Crayford, Kent, England. The bridegroom is the stepson of Muriel Lloyd of London.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 909 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Congress And Clinton: A Handshake If Not a Kiss

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALL over the Capitol, moonstruck Democrats are pledging allegiance to Bill Clinton and the legislation for which he stands. Whatever that is.
For example, Senate aides say campaign finance legislation, a subject of more than casual interest to the lawmakers, simply awaits Mr. Clinton's improvements. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, told a subcommittee chairman last week that the committee would do what Mr. Clinton wanted on health care. The new chairman of the House Budget Committee, Representative Martin O. Sabo, said the committee would delay work on deficit reduction legislation until it hears from him. 
 The amiable mood has even been taken up by Senate Republicans, who are playing patty-cake with Mr. Clinton's Cabinet selections. But that seems more like a tactical approach -- lying low until a target is spotted.
But what is the basis of this lovesick behavior by the Democrats? And how long can it last?
 
Too Few Accomplishments
 First of all, it is not a longstanding romance. Mr. Clinton became the choice of Congressional Democrats, whom he occasionally slighted, only after they concluded he had a good chance to be President. While they admire him, at root this is a marriage of political convenience.
There are two main reasons this marriage seems advantageous to the Congressional Democrats. The first is that they think the country looks down on Congress because it couldn't accomplish much fighting with President Bush, and that their fate is therefore linked to Mr. Clinton's. Only if he succeeds can they succeed. Second, many important lawmakers want to make laws, not just be here.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley is not striking a political pose when he says, "There is a tremendous desire here to work with the new Administration and to produce a legislative result and to move forward on the deficit, economic growth and health care reform." It's not just those big issues, either. Committee chairmen are already at work translating some of his campaign promises into bills they hope he will support, in areas from job apprenticeship to childhood immunizations.
They already have his support on some bills Mr. Bush vetoed last year, especially family leave and voter registration, so they can pass them soon.
But this relationship faces problems when it starts confronting money. The Government doesn't have nearly enough to do all that Mr. Clinton or the Congressional Democrats would like to do, and someone has to be denied. As Prof. Charles Jones of the University of Wisconsin put it, in some ways the issues "don't change very much from what Bush and the Congress were facing last year. And those issues go to the core of how are you going to do more with less. How are you going to solve these problems within the constraint of the great Reagan debt?"
That issue has to be faced first sometime in March, when the national debt bumps up against its statutory ceiling and the House confronts the need to cast painful if meaningless votes to raise the ceiling. And if that issue is combined with deficit reduction measures, as House leaders expect, some interests in the party are going to feel shortchanged.
The test for Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders is to frame those questions in ways that give members "political cover for disappointing their constituents," as Representative Vic Fazio put it.
Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, who is more inclined than many Washingtonians to expect the good mood to last, said: "To help Clinton, they will have to incur the wrath of someone. The challenge to Clinton is to frame the choices and the issues in a way that gets members to recalculate -- to think through anew those costs and benefits."
Or, as Mr. Fazio said, to explain that you were voting for something that wasn't perfect in order to support the President "for the good of the country." He added: "A lot of people are inclined to do that for Clinton."
It is not clear just what the Republicans can do to affect this process. In the Senate, they can filibuster. They say they want to see what Mr. Clinton will actually propose. "The game hasn't begun yet," said Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader. "We're in the warm-up period. Everyone's shooting free throws."
 
Mindless Obstructionism
 In the House, Republicans expect to obstruct and delay. Their quarrel is not so much with Mr. Clinton as with House Democrats. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, their second-ranking leader, said this week that Republicans would routinely force every roll call they can as a way to show displeasure at Democratic bullying on rules. But to the country it might just look like mindless obstructionism, and there is nothing like Mr. Gingrich and such tactics to unify the Democrats.
In the long run, Mr. Foley observed, "it's unrealistic to assume that there will never be disagreement and all will be perfect consensus." So Mr. Clinton's reaction will matter when Congress amends a proposal and passes it. Will he be like Lyndon B. Johnson, who used to claim victory if he got more or less what he asked, or like Jimmy Carter, who used to grumble when he didn't get absolutely everything?
The future of this relationship depends most of all on Mr. Clinton, and how he handles his Presidency generally. "Presidents who are perceived to be powerful and popular get their way," Mr. Fazio said.

PUB-DATE: January 10, 1993

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1132 words

HEADLINE: SO MUCH FOR THEORY;
Clinton's Bright Ideas Get to Meet the Ugly Facts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN campaigning for President, Abraham Lincoln promised not to abolish slavery. Franklin D. Roosevelt vowed to balance the budget. Lyndon B. Johnson said he was not "about to send American boys 9,000 or 10,000 miles away from home to do what Asian boys ought to be doing for themselves." Richard M. Nixon had a secret plan to end the war in Vietnam. Jimmy Carter said he would remove price controls on natural gas. Ronald Reagan said he would never negotiate for the release of hostages. And, of course, George Bush promised not to raise taxes.
So when Bill Clinton seemed to back off last week from his campaign pledge to cut the Federal budget deficit in half over the next four years, hardly anyone was surprised. As Mr. Bush said in 1990 when he announced he had changed his mind about taxes, "That's the American system." 
 It is not so much that candidates mean to lie. Most of the time, they honestly think they can keep their campaign promises. But the problems of government turn out to be more intractable as one gets closer to being responsible for solving them.
Presidential candidates can make the world stand still. They are free to develop promises and proposals at the outset and stick with them through Election Day. For a President, the world spins round and round, and what seemed like wise policy yesterday is often overtaken by events by tomorrow.
Peter B. Teeley, the United States Ambassador to Canada, who is a friend and political adviser of Mr. Bush's, put the matter this way: "You get into office and you get very hard information for the first time. It can be economic figures or it can be intelligence on foreign policy or defense problems, and it becomes a very cold shower that wakes you up from the campaign."
That is what has happened to Mr. Clinton. Last January, the Bush Administration's Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office, the Government's two main economic forecasters, both reported that a strong economy and the completion of the savings and loan bailout would allow the deficit in 1996 to be about half what it was in 1992, even if no tax and spending policies were changed. So Mr. Clinton's promise was somewhat empty. All it meant was that if somewhere he cut taxes or increased spending, elsewhere he would have to raise taxes or reduce spending.
By July, circumstances had changed. The economy was growing more slowly than expected. Medical costs were rising faster. Some expenditures for the savings and loan bailout had been put off for another fiscal year. Budget officials reported in their midyear review that the 1992 deficit would be slightly lower than had been forecast in January but that in 1996 it would be quite a bit higher.
But while his advisers cautioned him during the summer that his promise to cut the deficit in half over four years would be much harder to keep, Mr. Clinton, at least publicly, paid them no heed. "A candidate can't afford to keep changing positions," said an aide who regularly traveled on the campaign plane. "He would have been accused of flip-flopping, and no candidate can stand that in the middle of a campaign."
Last week, Mr. Bush's budget office released its official economic forecasts, and they painted a picture that was worse than ever. The deficit in fiscal year 1992, which ended in September, was $290 billion, and without any changes in policy, the Administration reported, the deficit will be $266 billion in 1996 and $305 billion in 1997.
In Little Rock, Mr. Clinton called the new figures an "unsettling revelation." His assistants accused the Bush Administration of cooking the books in a way that actually understated the probable deficit for 1996 and 1997 by as much as $60 billion each year, an assertion that Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, denied.
 
Off Balance
 Mr. Clinton's surprise was surely exaggerated, and Mr. Darman's figures were probably unrealistic. But they agreed on one basic point: Mr. Clinton cannot cut the deficit in half and still fulfill his promises to increase spending for public works, education and job training, to allow college students to work off loans by joining a national service corps, to overhaul the welfare system, to cut taxes for middle-income families and businesses that invest in new equipment and to raise taxes on no one but families with annual incomes above $200,000.
"The math does not work," said Mr. Darman.
In a way, Mr. Clinton seemed to relish the news. It gave him a trap door to escape some campaign promises, and it helped prepare political ground for unpopular tax and spending measures.
There was other bad news last week as well. The Commerce Department reported that spending on health care rose to 14 percent of the nation's total economic output in 1992, the highest ever, and that medical spending would continue to go up 12 percent to 15 percent a year "unless significant changes in the health-care system occur."
The chief Federal auditor, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, a Reagan appointee, warned the new Administration that the Government's books had been seriously mismanaged in recent years and that it had tens of billions of dollars of hidden liabilities for such matters as cleaning up toxic waste and paying off depositors of failed banks and savings and loan associations.
Overseas, tensions worsened in Iraq and Somalia. The war and human tragedy in Bosnia continued with the Clinton team seemingly undecided about what course to follow. Mr. Clinton and his advisers have worried aloud since the election that international problems, basically ignored during the campaign, might be so demanding that Mr. Clinton would not be able to pay full attention to economic issues at home.
 
Tax and Charge
 So far, the economy is still topic A. No one divulged exactly what was discussed at Mr. Clinton's meeting Thursday with his economic advisers. But a good bet is that they talked about how the only way to limit the deficit is to increase the taxes of middle-income Americans, cut popular programs or both, and how the only way to get a handle on medical costs is to change the system under which most people get whatever treatment they want wherever they want, at little or no out-of-pocket cost.
Mr. Clinton clearly understands this. During his two-day economic conference in Little Rock last month, he displayed a dazzling grasp of economic and social policy issues. But not once during the campaign and not since has Mr. Clinton let on that ordinary Americans might have to sacrifice anything they now enjoy.
In other words, he has still not addressed the fundamental questions he ducked during the campaign but will have to face squarely as President: Who will have to give up what, and when will he tell them so?

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Coming Soon: Fingerprints at Many Fingertips

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
SAY the word "fingerprint" and scenes out of Dragnet begin to flicker: A burly cop rolling a suspect's fingers in messy black ink. Detectives with magnifying glasses poring over smudged file cards.
But think again. 
 A fingerprint, thanks to recent technological advances, can now be captured in a flash by an optical scanner tethered to a personal computer. No ink involved. And that new ease in taking prints -- which some say removes the air of being arrested -- means that the demand for fingerprints may rise the same way that demand for Social Security numbers has risen over the last 50 years. This cheers some police departments and worries some civil libertarians.
Someday, fingerprints may be imbedded -- as a numerical code, not as an actual print -- in credit cards so a cashier with a finger scanner can tell whether the person presenting the card is the person who owns it. Eventually, a fingerprint registered at the front desk may replace hotel room keys, and a touch on a mini-scanner will open the door to the room.
"It's the only true form of identification," said Archie Yew, marketing manager of Cogent Systems of Alhambra, Calif., which writes software for fingerprint systems. "And you carry it with you wherever you go."
The new fingerprint technology has been slowly developed over the last 20 years for its obvious first customer, law enforcement agencies.
Already, more than half the states and several major cities have set up their own data bases that, sometimes within hours, can electronically identify fingerprints lifted at a crime scene. Once, a detective's only options were to send in a list of suspects with the prints, or request a print-by-print search that might take weeks or months by hand.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has converted the prints of about 24 million criminals into mathematical formulas. It has the prints of another 4 million criminals, plus the prints of 38 million other Americans, most of them military veterans or Federal employees, on file cards.
Right now, despite what television has led people to think, the police rarely dust for fingerprints except in murders and other serious crimes. It is expensive and time-consuming to collect prints at the scene -- and then fingerprint other people to sort out the ones that belong to the victim or anyone else there legitimately. But if having fingerprints might instantly produce a list of suspects from old arrest records, the police might begin dusting for prints more often.
Some spectacular breakthroughs have already been made. In October, a 37-year-old ex-burglar was convicted of murdering a widow in the Bronx in 1974. Fingerprints had been found on a brandy glass and a window, but had lain in police files for 17 years until a detective decided to try cross-checking them in the new data bases of the F.B.I. and several states. They matched those of Herman Myers, a former Bronx resident who was living in South Carolina and had been arrested on an incest charge there.
Other law-enforcement uses are in the offing. In about two years, the F.B.I. says, fingerprint scanners tied to a national computer network will be in some police cruisers, letting officers know, for example, whether a speeder is a wanted fugitive.
The new technology is already being used by other agencies to prevent things like welfare fraud.
Social services officials in California's Los Angeles County and in two upstate New York State counties are fingerprinting welfare applicants to prevent them from collecting duplicate benefits by registering at several offices under different names. In the California program's first 16 months, officials said, it saved $7.8 million because 314 applicants were caught filing duplicate applications and another 3,010 were dropped from the rolls after refusing to be fingerprinted.
The new technology converts the unique pattern of a fingerprint's ridges, bifurcations and endings, called minutiae, into a mathematical formula. A computer data base can quickly compare a print's formula with others.
With better software and the recent development of "live" scanners -- which read the print directly from the finger, rather than from a card -- the technology can be installed almost anywhere.
 
ExpensiveAt a Cost
 But it's expensive. A minimal system, like that used by one county, costs over $2 million. A large one like that used by California's Department of Justice costs over $30 million.
A single scanner can cost $1,000, said Oscar Pieper, president of Identicator Corp. in California. But hardware should get cheaper. "As time goes on, it will become less expensive, like calculators and microwaves and VCR's," said Julie Watts, marketing director for National Registry, a St. Petersburg, Fla., company that markets the devices.
Lawrence Sherman, professor of criminology at the University of Maryland, said he is skeptical that there will be any revolution in police work. Even cities that can afford scanners in cruisers may worry about their adverse effects.
It may be "better policing not to be so intrusive on the street," Professor Sherman said. "In a racially tense or economically tense area, if the police are stopping people a lot and checking ID's, it can precipitate disturbances or maybe even riots."
 
Cross-Referencing
 Civil libertarians fear that the confidentiality of fingerprint data gathered to fight crime will quickly be breached. What, some ask, would stop immigration authorities from retrieving the fingerprints of welfare recipients, or even of credit-card holders, to ferret out illegal aliens?
"Because the largest fingerprint file is maintained by law enforcement," said Janlori Goldman, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's privacy and technology project, "my concern is the sort of cross-referencing of fingerprints between the F.B.I., the Department of Motor Vehicles, the immigration office and the welfare office."
To guard against such pooling of data, the New York state legislature, for one, has barred state welfare officials from sharing the prints of welfare applicants with the criminal justice system. And private manufacturers assure that their data bases will be impenetrable by the government.
Even with scanners that make getting fingerprinted more like photocopying one's hand than like Dragnet, many people still associate the process with crime. That bothers many advocates for the poor, who say it may frighten away the people who need help most.
It "really is a criminalization of poverty," said Rachel Leon, an advocate for the poor in Albany. "To people who do not understand, there may be a real fear that in the future it will be used against them."
Lisa Nunez, an official in Los Angeles County's Department of Social Services, disagreed.
"The system is very user-friendly," she said. "Having your picture taken has to be a lot more intimidating than having your print scanned."

HEADLINE: U.S. SAYS BAGHDAD REMOVED MISSILES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The White House said today that it was satisfied that Baghdad had "backed down" in the face of an allied ultimatum by removing surface-to-air missiles that were threatening allied planes patrolling the skies of southern Iraq.
American officials said it did not appear that Iraq had fully met the allies' original demands that the missiles, which set off a new confrontation over Iraqi military movements, be returned to their "original sites or configurations" within 48 hours. 
 But the officials said that the Iraqis had removed the immediate threat to allied air patrols by dismantling and dispersing the missile batteries, and that some of them seemed to be headed to their original locations.
 
Preliminary View Confirmed
 There were indications Friday night that the White House believed Baghdad had responded in a way that would make military action unnecessary. But it was not until today, when additional reconnaissance was conducted in the Persian Gulf, that Administration officials issued a statement saying Iraq had acceded to their demands.
"All available evidence indicates that Iraq is acceding to the requirements of the coalition's Jan. 6 demarche," the White House statement said.
"No Iraqi aircraft have entered the no-fly zone south of the 32d parallel and the Iraqi surface-to-air missiles have been dispersed and are no longer threatening coalition flight operations."
Iraq had deployed about half a dozen SA-3 missile batteries and a smaller number of SA-2 missile batteries near the town of Al Amarah, where they were used to cover jets flying in the no-flight zone. Most of the missile batteries were drawn from north of the 32d parallel, which marks the northern boundary of the air exclusion zone. At least one SAM missile battery was also moved from Basra, where it was stationed when the air exclusion zone went into effect.
 
Concerned About New Missiles
 The United States was particularly concerned about the deployment of the new missiles. Some officials said they believed that the missile batteries had been deployed as a trap while other officials said they believed that the weapons were intended to inhibit the United States and allies from enforcing the no-flight zone. By packing up and dispersing the missiles, Iraq has removed that immediate threat.
Administration officials said the White House statement, asserting that the Iraqi leader had "backed down" in the face of allied demands, was intended to humiliate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by portraying him as compliant and weak.
 
Situation Called Complex
 But some American officials, who asked not to be named, said the actual situation was more complex. The ultimatum delivered to the Iraqis on Wednesday demanded that all of the Iraqi missiles that were recently moved into new positions in the south "be returned to their original sites or configurations within 48 hours."
One American official who insisted on anonymity said that not all of the surface to air missiles had been located by American intelligence and that it was not clear if all of them were being returned to their original locations. The White House statement implied as much by warning that the United States would keep Iraq's military activities under close scrutiny and strike without warning if it deemed the missiles posed a future threat.
Thus the defusing of the showdown over the missiles does not mean that the confrontation between Baghdad and Washington is over.
Even as it moved the missiles, Baghdad set off a new confrontation with the West by banning all flights by United Nations weapons inspectors on United Nations aircraft inside Iraq. The United Nations Security Council has declared the Iraqi ban a "material breach" of its obligations under the resolutions that ended the Persian Gulf war.
 
Questions of Sanctions
 In stating that United Nations teams would no longer be allowed to fly into Iraq on United Nations planes, Iraqis are trying to force the United Nations inspectors to use chartered Iraqi planes.
To use Iraqi planes an exception would have to be made to the economic sanctions imposed on Iraq, which ban flights of Iraqi commercial aircraft outside Iraq. In condemning the Iraqi move, the Security Council condemned it as "clearly an attempt to impede" the United Nations inspections.
A senior Bush Administration official said that the Iraqi ban on United Nations flights was "potentially no less serious than what was talked about in the Jan. 6 demarche," which was the message demanding that Iraq's surface-to-air missiles be moved. This official said that he could not rule out that military force might again be threatened to try to compel Baghdad to comply.
The Iraqi ban on United Nations flights was the latest in a series of steps that Baghdad has taken to frustrate the inspections. According to a report issued last month by the United Nations, Iraq has not provided all the information that inspectors has sought on it programs to develop weapons of mass destruction.
 
Leaving With Documents
 In one recent inspection, a team of nuclear inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency who went to a site to look for documents found people leaving with documents.
"Upon arrival of the team, persons left the buildings carrying documents, despite the protests of the chief inspector," the United Nations report notes. "While the Iraqi counterparts promised to return the documents, and indeed did produce some, the inspectors were unable to verify that these were the documents taken from building."
Robert Gates, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has said that Iraq is continuing the efforts to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.
Iraq's frustration of the United Nations inspection effort is not the only source of concern. According to a United Nations commission on border demarcation, the Kuwait and Iraq boundary is to be moved north. United Nations border monitors have told the Iraqis that the boundary should be in force by Jan. 15, an Administration official said. In the meantime, Iraqi soldiers have also been crossing the newly demarcated Iraq-Kuwait border and destroying structures that are to end up on the Kuwaiti side of the line.
 
Relief Official Slain
 And last week, a official with the CARE relief organization was shot and killed. While the group has said it has no evidence that the killing was arranged by the Iraqi Government, Administration officials strongly suspect that Iraqi agents were responsible.
Iraq has continued to make public statements in a bellicose tone. Abdul-Jabbar Mohsen, the chief press secretary to the Iraqi leader, wrote in the official al-Jomhuriya daily in Baghdad that Iraqis "have no choice but to resist and fight for survival."
"The highest degree of preparation is required for an honorable holy war, the timing of which will be decided by our leadership," he said.
The pattern of Iraqi behavior suggests that Baghdad is likely to continue to test Washington in the early months of the Clinton Administration, on the assumption that Mr. Clinton wants to focus on his domestic agenda and does not share Mr. Bush's attitude toward Mr. Hussein.
 
Shwowing Its Power
 Baghdad may be trying to demonstrate that it is still a power to be reckoned with in the region, has the initiative in the foreign policy confrontations with the West and can provoke an international crisis almost at will.
By demonstrating his ability to create an international crisis, Mr. Hussein may be seeking to regain control over the Kurdish enclave in the north, to end the air-exclusion zones of its territory, to stop the United Nations inspections and to end the economic sanctions.
In issuing its statement, the White House said it hoped its threat to use force made clear that Iraqi interference with the United Nations and coalition operations would not be tolerated.
"I hope Saddam Hussein won't put us in this position again," President-elect Clinton said Friday night in Little Rock, Ark. "There is no point in it and he shouldn't do it, and it would be a serious misreading of our political system to think that just because President Bush has a week left in office, that either he or I would somehow be deterred from doing what's right here."

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse/New York, New Jersey, Connecticut;
Though End of Recession Is Here, Prosperity Isn't Even Near Corner

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Amid strong signs that the recession was lifting its grip elsewhere in the nation, Martin A. Gardner braced against a cold wind here the other day, waited for his train to Manhattan and described the ordeal of being out of work for 20 months.
"Maybe, if I were a carpenter, I'd go to Florida," said Mr. Gardner, 55 years old, who has a doctorate in communications and 30 years' experience in advertising, sales and management. So far, he has sent 300 resumes to New York area companies. 
 "I'm optimistic," he said, but added that "there are an awful lot of us out here" looking for executive positions in New York City and its suburbs.
"New York has certainly lost some of its luster," he said.
 
Deep, Enduring Recession
 Mr. Gardner's problems finding work, despite his strong corporate credentials, are emblematic of the depth and enduring nature of the recession that has battered New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for four years. And his ambivalence about his own future comes at a time of sharply mixed signals about the economic prospects of the region.
Experts say there is some good news: The region's recession has finally hit bottom, or at least come close. The number of jobs in the region began to rise in November and December, and there are other signs of improvement, including a slight drop in office vacancies in midtown Manhattan.
But from Montauk to Trenton, and from New London to Atlantic City, the economic landscape has forever changed from the robust years of the mid-1980's.
Compared with most parts of the nation, the region's downturn has been extraordinarily deep, bringing huge job losses, a torrent of business failures and the worst real-estate slump in 50 years. Now, the analysts say, recovery will take five years or longer, and some segments of the regional economy will never regain their strength of the 1980's.
For thousands like Mr. Gardner -- out-of-work executives who once had high-paying jobs in the nation's largest concentration of banks, law firms, brokerage houses and corporate offices -- full recovery may never come. They are victims of a permanent reordering of the region's job market, in which technology has displaced many senior executives in the same way it once made assembly-line workers obsolete. Companies in almost every field are determined to do more with fewer employees.
In what has widely been described as the nation's first "white-collar recession," the carnage has been the worst within a 100-mile radius of midtown Manhattan, and it has not confined itself to white-collar workers. Connecticut has lost 12 percent of its jobs since the beginning of 1989; New Jersey has lost 9 percent and New York has lost 7 percent.
"Recovery is going to be a slow and painful affair," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for the Shawmut National Corporation, a bank in Connecticut. "Sad to say, a lot of the jobs of the 1980's are just gone."
Still, there is widespread evidence that the worst has passed.
"New York City's recession came to an end during the summer of 1992," concluded a study in late December by the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University, where a team of economists analyzed what they called the "leading indicators" of the city economy, ranging from airport traffic to stock trading volume.
Others are less precise about timing, but no less confident that the recession has ended.
"The numbers clearly indicate that the tri-state region has turned the corner and is now poised for economic recovery," said Lou Salvatore, director of the New York office of Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, which surveyed 500 business owners in December. Seventy-five percent of the executives reported either stable or improved sales in 1992, and 66 percent had increased profits.
 
Christmas Cheer
 Glimmers of hope abound. Macy's, Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Strauss and retailers in many suburban shopping malls say Christmas sales were the strongest in four years.
"Finally, people are spending money again," said Rick Marino, manager of Dodge auto sales at Stevens Auto Supermarket in Milford, Conn. His gauge of the recession is simple: beginning in late 1989, he said, most of his customers purchased used cars costing under $5,000; since July, most have been been buying new cars, typically costing over $15,000.
Some pockets of the regional economy are particularly robust. Heading the list is Wall Street, where stock brokerages and investment banking firms have compiled two years of rising profits, record trading volume and lofty executive bonuses, typically over $100,000.
In central New Jersey, home to the nation's largest concentration of pharmaceutical manufacturing, companies like Johnson & Johnson and Merck have been expanding rapidly. And 1992 was a successful year for Broadway, with rising attendance and growing income.
 
Hold Off on Celebration
 Still, experts warn against any surge of good cheer.
"There is reason for hope, but you have to place that on the canvas of what has happened over the last three years," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The job losses have been staggering."
According to the Federal Government, the metropolitan region lost 806,000 private-sector jobs from February 1989 to November, when employment rose slightly. The huge losses wiped out 12 years of gains, leaving the region with no more jobs than it had in 1976, when New York City was close to bankruptcy. Most of the losses were in manufacturing, construction, finance, and retail and wholesale trade. Service jobs and government work remained flat.
Despite the national scope of the recession, the Government said, 92 percent of the nation's job losses since the beginning of 1989 have been in 10 states, 9 of them in the Northeast: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The lone outsider was California.
In the New York region, the downturn has been as wide as it has been deep. The cuts since 1988 have been almost equally divided between the city and the suburbs, which are now suffering harsh setbacks after attracting thousands of corporate offices and executive jobs over the last two decades.
Even more important, economists say, is the range of industries that have been damaged by business failures and lost jobs.
 
Manufacturing
A Painful Plunge In a Long Decline
 For manufacturers, the recession has turned a long, relentless period of decline, beginning in the 1950's, into something closer to collapse. The Government said 270,000 manufacturing jobs, 24 percent of the region's total, have been eliminated since November 1987, with the pace of decline showing no sign of subsiding.
The most recent jolt came last week, when International Business Machines, based in the Westchester County suburb of Armonk, said it would eliminate 3,500 jobs at its plants in Peekskill, Kingston and Poughkeepsie, N.Y. That announcement came two weeks after the company said it would lay off 25,000 workers around the world, acknowledging that a major share of its market for mainframe computers had been overtaken by other companies that make personal computers and small work stations.
I.B.M.'s bad news came a year after General Motors said it would close the largest factory in the region, its assembly plant in North Tarrytown. The closing, by 1996, will eliminate 3,400 jobs.
Elsewhere in the region, manufacturers have fallen prey to problems that have stalked them for decades: wages that are far higher than in other regions and abroad, and the cost of maintaining old, inefficient plants.
 
'Nothing to Cheer About'
 But since the recession began in 1988, one of the last large segments of the region's manufacturing economy -- the military suppliers of Long Island and Connecticut -- have had a new problem to contend with: the sudden decline in the Government's military spending.
"I see nothing to cheer about in 1993," said Greg Frisby, the chief executive of Frisby Airborne Hydraulics in Freeport, L.I. His company, which has produced fighter-jet parts for more than 30 years, is struggling to find non-Government markets for its products.
Frisby, with 85 workers, now makes hydraulic parts for commercial aircraft, supplying the Boeing Company, the Beech Aircraft Company and others that are themselves being hurt by weak demand for finished aircraft. Mr. Frisby said sales of his company's parts, weak in 1992, will be weak again in 1993, but should rise in 1994 as the national economic recovery gains momentum.
 
Surprising Bright Spot
 One unlikely corner of optimism among manufacturers is among small and specialized garment makers, the stubborn survivors of a far larger garment industry that until the 1960's supported huge plants in New York City and New Jersey, but has since faded almost into extinction.
"The signs have turned quite encouraging," said Ralph Shomer, owner of the Young American Clothing Company, which employs 52 immigrants from Portugal in an industrial loft in downtown Newark. Because of intense competition from garment makers in the Far East and Mexico, he had planned to close his company this year.
But now, he said, Young American has had a sudden increase in orders, mainly because his small plant, which specializes in women's coats, can turn them out for American buyers more quickly than its foreign competitors. Retailers, who have been caught off guard by a sudden increase in consumer demand, are turning to Mr. Shomer for help.
Instead of closing, he said, he may hire more workers. "It looks to me," he said, "like 1993 will be a good year."
 
White-Collar Careers
Lawyers, Bankers And Job Searches
 The most damaging legacy of the recession in the region, economists say, may be its impact on the same industries that were responsible for much of its growth in the 1980's.
Law firms, accounting firms, advertising agencies, management consulting firms, banks, real-estate brokerages and corporate headquarters have long given the region the nation's highest concentration of finance and professional services, and its highest paid work force.
"Our strengths have become our weaknesses," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist for the Chemical Banking Corporation of Manhattan. "Five years from now, even though the economic climate will be brighter, we will look back and see permanently lower levels of employment."
 
All Segments Vulnerable
 Since Chemical Bank merged in December 1991 with Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, Chemical has eliminated 5,438 workers, many of them professionals in finance, commercial lending and real estate.
Government data show that companies in the region engaged in finance, insurance and real-estate sales have shed 72,000 jobs since November 1987, or 8 percent of their total, and that other large cuts have been made in fields, like law and accounting, that had been considered the least vulnerable to recession.
At one of New Jersey's largest law firms, Greenbaum, Rowe, Smith, Ravin & Davis, based in Woodbridge, Paul Rowe, the managing partner, said the extent of the downturn was underscored for him late last year, when he was stopped for speeding near East Hampton, L.I.
When Mr. Rowe told the officer that he was a lawyer, the patrolman responded that he too was a law school graduate but could not find work as a lawyer. (Mr. Rowe didn't get a ticket.)
"In the 1980's, the mere thought that law firms would stop growing never popped into anybody's minds," said Mr. Rowe.
 
Some Losses Permanent
 Although a recovery is certain to bring back some of the professional jobs, the experts say some of the losses will be permanent. One reason is technology, which has made many jobs obsolete. While phone mail systems have displaced telephone clerks, and fax machines have claimed central spots in most mail rooms, corporate executives have turned increasingly to tele-conferencing systems and computers to cut the time and expense of management.
"The New York region will epitomize the corporate philosophy of the 1990's," Mr. Kellner said. "Companies will do more with fewer people."

 
 
Real Estate
Reaching Bottom Is Called Victory
 Executives say the prospects for recovery are the weakest in the region's real-estate industry, particularly among the developers and landlords of commercial office space. Despite a slight improvement in 1992, vacancy rates in Manhattan remain above 10 percent. And in some suburbs, including Fairfield County and northern New Jersey, vacancies are over 20 percent -- among the highest in the nation.
The downturn "has been so deep that any signs that we have reached bottom have to be considered a victory," said Hugh Kelly, director of economic research for Landhauer Associates, a real-estate consulting firm in Manhattan. And because of the vast surplus of office space, he said he did not expect a full recovery until 1998.
The market for homes and condominiums shows stronger signs of recovery. Although the inventory of unsold homes remains huge and prices have declined by as much as a third across the region, experts say there is pent-up demand among buyers who have been waiting out the recession and hoping to take advantage of low interest rates.
Still, no one is predicting a sudden upswing in sales.
"Buyers are still scared to death," said Carl Peek, a broker in the Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill sections of Brooklyn, two enclaves of brownstones that attracted waves of affluent buyers during the 1980's.
"The same kind of people who would have been anxious to buy five years ago now say they want to rent, and rent at the lowest price they can," he said. "We are a long way from out of the woods. I think it will take at least five years."
 
Wall Street
On the Way Back After Crash of '87
 Perhaps the single brightest segment of the region's economy is Wall Street. Since the stock market collapse of Oct. 19, 1987, which economists say led the region into its long recession, business has largely rebounded for stock brokerages and others in the securities industry.
According to the Securities Industry Association, a trade group that represents all members of the New York Stock Exchange, the industry has grown steadily for two years. Trading volume on the exchange reached records in both 1991 and 1992, and profits of member firms hit new highs in both years.
But even Wall Street has so far failed one crucial test of a recovery. New York City brokerage houses and investment banking firms laid off 38,000 workers between the stock market collapse of October 1987 and January 1992, but have restored fewer than 4,000 of those jobs, despite the robust business over the last year.
"Wall Street is to New York what the oil industry is to Houston, and it is now this region's strongest sector," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "My hunch is that those big salaries and bonuses have been used over the last two years for savings and to reduce personal debt. The big question for the region in 1993 is whether people on Wall Street will become bigger consumers."
 
Different Indicators
 Some executives find reason for optimism in unusual measures of the economy's performance. For instance, a study was conducted recently by a research team at Columbia University, which dispensed with past methods of analyzing economic trends and instead looked at things like the number of passengers traveling through the region's three major airports, trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, stock prices and retail sales.
Some demonstrated little or no improvement by the summer of 1992, when the Columbia team now says New York City's recession ended, but most make clear that "a slow to moderate recovery has begun."
"Recoveries never take place in a straight line," said Anirvan Banerji, a member of the Columbia team. "You take two steps forward and one step back. But it has begun."
One indication of the region's strength is that its huge network of corporate executives and professionals do not see better prospects elsewhere. Although their companies and industries are mired in a long, slow period of recovery, many say they are determined not to leave.
One is Mr. Gardner of Hastings-on-Hudson. "The way I see it, the problems in the economy are nationwide," he said. "For me, New York is still the place to be."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Greg Frisby, chief executive of Frisby Airborne Hydraulics. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times); For manufacturers, the recession has turned a long, relentless period of decline into something closer to collapse. About 24 percent of the region's manufacturing jobs have been eliminated since November 1987. After retooling to build minivans in Tarrytown, General Motors announced a year ago it will close the plant, eliminating 3,400 jobs. (Associated Press); Martin A. Gardner, who has been out of work for 20 months. (Susan Harris for The New York Times) (pg. 32)

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Banking Industry;
Bankers Lining Up Lobbyists Tightly Aligned With Clinton

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In a striking example of how an interest group can lay the groundwork to influence the Government, the banking industry has assembled a powerhouse team to take on the Clinton Administration and the new Congress.
The bankers are keenly interested in seeing banking regulations relaxed and in being allowed to branch out across state lines and to compete more directly against securities firms. They are also watching carefully to see if new consumer protections will be enacted. 
 The industry's biggest lobbying organization, the American Bankers Association, has lined up bankers and lobbyists who have been closely associated with President-elect Bill Clinton and who wield great influence in the Democratic Party.
 
Challenge to Special Interests
 At the same time, people who worked for Mr. Clinton when he was Governor of Arkansas, advised his Presidential campaign and the transition team or have close ties to the banking industry are also under consideration by the new Administration for crucial regulatory posts.
Mr. Clinton has repeatedly promised to challenge the special-interest groups that seek to turn campaign contributions and political connections into influence over public policy. "I think there is going to be a great reluctance by the Administration to let the banking lobbyists be effective," said one banking lawyer who has advised the Clinton organization.
But since the election, Mr. Clinton has been criticized for accommodating lobbyists and power brokers as he assembles his economic team and designs his economic policies.
The lobbying team also faces an uphill fight in Congress: lawmakers have little appetite for undoing provisions of the 1991 banking bill that the industry has complained bitterly about. That law makes many new demands on bankers, setting standards for how much capital they must have on hand and what kind of risks they can incur.
The bankers association recently named to its board Curt Bradbury, head of Worthen National Bank, an Arkansas institution that has long provided financial support for Mr. Clinton's political aspirations and lent the Clinton campaign millions of dollars at crucial junctures in the campaign.
Even before the election, the association named as its new president William Brandon, an Arkansas banker who has known Mr. Clinton for many years.
Shortly after the election, the association hired two prominent lawyers with close ties to Mr. Clinton. One was Charles Manatt, a former banker and Democratic Party chairman who was co-chairman of the Clinton campaign and whose law partner is the campaign's director, Mickey Kantor, whom Mr. Clinton has selected as the United States trade representative. The other was Thomas Boggs, an influential lobbyist whose law partners include Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, who has been chosen to be Commerce Secretary.
"The A.B.A. rightly thinks that it is time for an enlightened rethinking of several banking issues, including the regulatory burden and structural issues," Mr. Bradbury said in an interview on Thursday. "You see here the precursors of a pretty good lobbying campaign."
Mr. Manatt said Friday that like Mr. Boggs he had been retained by the banking association to lobby Congress to ease regulations that the bankers consider burdensome, a role he called "perfectly appropriate." He said he would not lobby the Clinton Administration or its regulatory agencies, an effort that will fall primarily to Edward Yingling, the association's full-time lobbyist. (Mr. Yingling was once an aide to Senator J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas.)
And a leading candidate to become Mr. Clinton's point man on banking, either as Comptroller of the Currency or as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, is Mr. Clinton's chief of staff in the Arkansas Governor's office, William Bowen, a banker and former chairman of the First Commercial Corporation of Little Rock.
 
Getting Clinton's Ear
 Industry leaders believe they have already got Mr. Clinton's attention. Easing regulations, they say, would spur lending to small businesses, helping economic recovery without costing the Government anything.
At the December economic meeting in Little Rock, Mr. Clinton asked Mr. Brandon to describe the stimulative effects that might be gained by relaxing certain bank regulations. The banker's remarks were warmly received by Mr. Clinton, who has said repeatedly that the rules make it costly for banks to make loans to small businesses and reward them for investing in Government securities instead.
But the House and Senate banking committees are tilting away from the industry. The committees have been assigned newly elected members who are more attuned to spurring lending in impoverished cities than they are to changing the capital standards that apply to banks or to allowing greater interstate banking.
Banks are also focusing on several major revisions of banking standards imposed by the year-old Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act, Congress's response to the wave of bank failures in recent years.
For example, under the law, regulators are devising "trip wires" to identify problems with audits, with the documentation of collateral for risky loans and with other flaws that contribute to the bank failures.
In some areas the banks have defensive battles to fight. For example, it is widely expected that the securities industry and its allies in Congress and in regulatory agencies will campaign against allowing banks to increase their securities business.
On several other issues, including restrictions on interstate banking, the banking industry is deeply divided.
 
Advisers With Industry Ties
 Among the members of the Clinton economic team who have ties to the banking and securities businesses are Roger C. Altman, the choice for Deputy Treasury Secretary, who is now vice chairman of Blackstone Group, an investment banking firm on Wall Street, and Robert E. Rubin, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, who is to head the new National Economic Council.
Mr. Clinton's top advisers are also being aided by people with close ties to the banking industry.
H. Rodgin Cohen, who is playing an advisory role, is a partner in Sullivan & Cromwell, which has represented many major banks, including Bank of America. Eugene Ludwig, a partner at Covington & Burling, which represents Nationsbank, the fourth-largest American banking company, heads a working group making recommendations on banking regulations. And Cantwell F. Muckenfuss 3d of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher represented the financier Ronald O. Perelman when he bought five failed Texas savings institutions. The Wall Street Journal reported their roles last month.
Mr. Muckenfuss, a former official of the F.D.I.C. and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, was mentioned on Friday by American Banker, a trade publication, as one of several candidates being considered for chairman of the F.D.I.C.
Another possible choice is Karen D. Shaw, a Washington banking consultant who advised the campaign and who, along with Mr. Manatt, worked hard to assemble support for the campaign from commercial bankers, an effort that produced only modest success.
Terrence J. Murray, chairman of Fleet Financial Group Inc., a Rhode Island banking company, supported Mr. Clinton early in the campaign and met with him several times; Hugh L. McColl, chairman of Nationsbank, endorsed Mr. Clinton near the end of the campaign. Both men advocate expanding the authority of banks to operate across state lines.
Mr. Clinton must make an appointment by the end of February.

HEADLINE: A Harsh Start to a New Beginning for Winnowed Daily News

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
After two days of canceled editions, missed deadlines and other disruptions caused by a change in ownership and the dismissal of scores of reporters, editors and other staff members, news operations at The Daily News returned to near normal yesterday as a smaller staff got out a full Sunday newspaper.
But problems of adjustment were expected to linger. With a smaller staff, news assignments will be made more carefully, editors said. And to minimize problems during the staff's transition this week, publication of the Brooklyn, Queens and suburban sections has been suspended for five days, starting tomorrow. 
 Some of those who lost their jobs in a sweeping economy move by the new owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, returned yesterday to The News offices at 220 East 42d Street to clean out their desks and say farewell to colleagues who remained on the job.
"The mood?" said one editor, who insisted upon anonymity. "There aren't enough of us here to have a mood." Asked if the daily routines of putting out the paper were returning to normal, he said: "It's been so long since anything has been normal around here that it's hard to say."
James P. Willse, the newspaper's editor, acknowledged that The News ran into a series of minor production and distribution problems Thursday and Friday as Mr. Zuckerman completed his $36.3 million purchase and began by dismissing 170 of 540 news, advertising and circulation employees represented by the Newspaper Guild of New York.
On both days, as discharged staff members were ordered out and those who remained were caught up in the turmoil, deadlines were missed and some articles by wire services were run in place of those normally written by staff members.
Mr. Willse said the management had anticipated that both days would be "fairly chaotic" and planned for it by canceling the paper's 48-page first edition, known as the national edition, which carries the news and editorial content of the regular paper, but no advertising. About 50,000 copies are distributed in areas beyond a 75-mile radius of New York City, he said.
Most of the technical problems were overcome yesterday as the normally smaller Saturday staff put out The Sunday News, and the national edition resumed full circulation.
But some editors said that with the news staff cut by a third and Mr. Zuckerman's plan to hire new employees weeks or months away, continuing problems were anticipated.
Editors said they would have to make assignments more carefully. "Before you commit a reporter and photographer to a fire in the depths of Brooklyn," said one editor, "you have to let it go to four alarms. When we had a plethora of reporters and photographers, you didn't have to do that."
Mr. Willse acknowledged that problems would arise. "But we've been through this before," he said. "You just reshuffle the guard and do the best you can."
Mr. Zuckerman, in a letter to readers in today's edition, promised new columnists and features and a Daily News that would be "tough, sassy, full of outrage at injustice and street smart." And he said that layoffs had been required to save The News, which lost $100 million in the last decade and has been in bankruptcy for 13 months.
 
Guild Plans Boycott
 Barry F. Lipton, president of the guild, said yesterday that a reader and advertiser boycott of The News and a broader campaign against other Zuckerman properties to win back jobs, salaries and benefits would be in full swing sometime this week. The guild set aside $100,000 for the fight and hired Ray Rogers, a labor consultant, to run the boycott.
But other newspaper unions were not supporting the guild's effort. "That's like shooting yourself in the foot," said George E. McDonald, president of an umbrella group of newspaper unions. "We want to save the paper, not kill it."
