HEADLINE: Price of European Unity Is Reckoned in Lost Jobs

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LILLE, France

 BODY:
Few towns are better placed than this northern French industrial capital to benefit from Europe's push for unity. The Channel Tunnel and high-speed rail links will soon put Paris, Brussels and London within 90 minutes. Blue-and-gold European flags, a new train station conceived as a European hub and a massive conference center called EuraLille demonstrate the point.
But in an example of the problems accompanying the establishment of a single European market on Jan. 1, all the fanfare has left the four million inhabitants of the Lille region cold. The billions of dollars spent on transport, the relentless promotion of the European ideal and the recent removal of border guards at the nearby Belgian frontier have all been overshadowed by a single fact: more and more people do not have jobs. 
 Indeed, battered by the decline of its coal, steel, textiles and shipbuilding industries, the region now has an unemployment rate of 13.3 percent -- almost double that of the United States and well above the French national figure of 10.3 percent. Asked to vote on European unity in a national referendum last September, people in the region here sent an unequivocal message that work comes before European dreams: 55.7 percent voted no.
The Lille region is not alone. Unemployment has become the scourge of Europe. About 14.6 million people, or 9.8 percent of the work force, are now out of a job, according to the European Commission in Brussels, the administrative arm of the European Community, compared with 13.3 million, or 9 percent, a year ago and 12.1 million in 1990. Companies, including Ford of Europe and International Business Machines, continue to slash thousands of jobs in Europe as the economic slump endures.
 
16 Million Jobless
 As a result, about 16 million people are expected to be jobless by the end of next year, when Europe's unemployment rate could hit 11 percent. In France alone, 3 million people are now without work; among people under 25 the country's unemployment rate is over 20 percent, according to European Community figures.
The Lille region's vote on the unity treaty, which went against a national result that narrowly favored European union, shocked the local authorities.
"We thought we had convinced people of the opportunities offered by Europe, but they just don't feel it," said Jean-Claude Aurousseau, the prefect, or top state official, in Lille. "When people are out of a job, it's hard to convince them that Europe offers them a chance. Instead, they see Europe as a threat. They say, Europe's done nothing for me, so what will it do for my children?"
The consequences of Europe's unemployment are already widely felt. Instead of the optimism that was expected to accompany the creation of a borderless market of almost 350 million people, insecurity and mounting racism appear to be Europe's dominant sentiments. Such feelings in turn feed the rise of extreme right-wing movements, now growing in several European countries, especially those like Germany and France with large numbers of immigrants.
"I try to tell workers that the single market will eventually create jobs and opportunities," said Bruno Creton, a labor expert in Lille. "But all I hear is how immigrants and competition will take away more jobs."
 
Job Mobility Hits a Wall
 Such grim popular sentiment is not surprising. European integration was supposed to stimulate employment by promoting job mobility across a vast area, inspiring investment by companies able to sell into a much larger market and stimulating growth.
But the effect, since the boom of the 1980's ended, has been markedly different. Faced by the combined impact of a world economic slowdown and the increased competition stemming from the creation of a single market, companies in Europe have been cutting back in ways that seem likely to be lasting. Meanwhile, barriers of language and culture have meant that job mobility has proved to be largely an illusion. Just two million European Community citizens work permanently in other community countries.
As in the United States, recent job cuts have hit not only manufacturing but also white-collar and service-sector employees, who had been relatively immune to past recessions.
"Job separations may be more permanent than in past downturns," the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development stated in a recent report. Asserting that American companies are cutting jobs to insure greater competitiveness in a tougher world economy, the organization said, "There may be a similar pattern to layoffs in Europe."
 
Treaty Could Worsen Problem
 Moreover, the Treaty on European Union, signed 13 months ago in the Dutch town of Maastricht, threatens to worsen unemployment. As a prelude for the planned introduction of a single currency in 1999, it calls on all 12 member countries to balance their budgets and eliminate inflation.
Thus, just as President-elect Bill Clinton is limited in his economic options by the size of the United States deficit, European governments are effectively constrained from giving fiscal boosts to their economies -- and thereby creating jobs -- by the need to reduce their budget deficits to meet the demands of the Maastricht treaty.
"Maastricht is deflationary and anti-employment," said Jean-Pierre Chevenement, a French politician who opposed the treaty. "It gives no hope to those without work."
At the Valdunes steel plant in Valenciennes, a town 35 miles from Lille where unemployment is running at 17.7 percent, the effect of job cuts is sharply apparent. About 340 people work at this factory producing wheels for trains, half the number there were a decade ago. At a neighboring steel plant, all 6,000 jobs have disappeared. Rusting debris, scrap metal and a half-capsized blast furnace litter the landscape.
"The only people who have done well out of this area recently are the scrap-metal merchants," said Georges Herbin, a technician, as he surveyed a production line that has slowed almost to a standstill as result of slumping orders for the first quarter of 1993. "It seems the meat is for somebody else, and we are left with the bones."
 
Few Young Workers
 Mr. Herbin, who is 50, has been with the company 20 years and amounts to a survivor. Because of a long hiring freeze, 72 percent of the workers at Valdunes are now over 40, and just 2 percent are under 25. Such freezes, often prompted in part by the high cost to employers of medical, social security and other payments for full-time workers, have had a devastating effect on employment prospects for the young in Europe.
The steel industry job losses in the Lille area result in part from European integration. As borders have come down, the Continent's overcapacity has been evident, and pressure has increased from the community's Executive Commission in Brussels to eliminate state subsidies and close plants that are not viable in the open market.
In the Lille region, over 30,000 steel and metalworking jobs have been eliminated in the last decade, as well as over 50,000 jobs in a textile industry that was once a world leader but is now unable to compete with cheaper plants in Southeast Asia. The coal industry, which employed over 200,000 people in the 1950's, has disappeared because it was uncompetitive, and a shipbuilding plant in Dunkirk has been closed.
"In the last 10 years, this region has lost 140,000 industrial jobs," said Richard Merlen, an economist at the national statistics office in Lille. "New jobs, mainly in the service sector, have partly compensated, but we still have a net loss of 60,000 jobs."
 
Threat From East Europe
 At the Valdunes plant, the latest threat is cheap competition from Eastern Europe. Michel Cassou, a director, said factories in what was formerly Czechoslovakia with much lower wage costs were offering wheels at 30 percent below the prices of the French manufacturer. This threat has contributed to a devastating 20 percent fall in in orders for next year and feeds resentment among workers now facing possible layoffs.
When an economic upturn does arrive, perhaps in the second half of 1993, the current bleak outlook should lift somewhat. The European market, the world's largest, is certainly a stimulus for investment. Even in the current climate, Coca-Cola, Toys-R-Us, Haagen Dazs and American Can are among the companies that have recently opened plants in the Lille area.
Moreover, concerned by unemployment, European governments this month agreed on a multibillion-dollar growth package based around new spending on infrastructure like roads, bridges and telecommunications.
 
Need 10 Million Jobs
 But any substantial improvements still seem a long way off. With the labor pool growing as more women join the work force, it would take the creation of some 10 million jobs by the end of the century merely to cut European unemployment to current American levels, and nobody believes that is possible. The high costs to employers of full-time hires continues to feed a shift to part-time and temporary employment.
"Everyone is worried," said Mr. Aurousseau, the Lille prefect. "The other day I had a delegation of nurses in here complaining that Belgian nurses were going to take their jobs. I told them they could also work in Belgium, but they were unimpressed."
He said one basic fear shared by many people is that their children will not live better than they have. "When I got into a good school, my father told me I had my foot in the stirrup," the prefect said. "But today even highly educated young people in Europe are asking: where are the horses?"

HEADLINE: On Long Island, Little Girl Lost;
Even Before She Vanished, Katie's Plight Touched Hearts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST ISLIP, L.I.

 BODY:
The last time Cathy Rossi saw Katie Beers was at 10:30 on a chilly October night in 1991. The 8-year-old girl had come over on her own to her neighbor's house to bid a tearful farewell.
A bank had foreclosed on the Beers family home here, in a tight-knit suburban neighborhood of split-level ranch homes and manicured lawns. Katie, who had already endured neglect, poverty and family fights, was being uprooted once again. 
 And on that cold night, the little girl, jacketless and shivering, wanted just one thing.
"I couldn't believe that she had come over alone that late," said Mrs. Rossi. "I tried to send her right back home. But she insisted she had to give me a hug and a kiss before she left."
Katie disappeared almost two weeks ago, two days before her 10th birthday, after a family friend said he had gone with her to a video arcade in Nesconset. The police do not know what happened to her and are looking for clues in her troubled past and difficult family situation, including the tug of war for custody between her mother and godmother and charges that the godmother's husband had sexually abused the girl.
Whatever the circumstances of her disappearance, interviews with friends, neighbors and county officials make one thing clear: Katie, kind and bright and hungry for affection, had already had far more than 10 years' worth of trouble in her life.
People who knew her said Katie frequently skipped school and often wandered the streets alone early in the morning and late at night. Children in one neighborhood where she lived would tease her, calling her "Dirty Katie" and "Roach Girl," because of the squalid condition of her home.
And as she moved from home to home in the last year, Katie's life veered from the poverty of her mother's apartment in Mastic Beach, where Katie, her mother and grandmother shared a bedroom, to the middle-class comfort of the home in Bay Shore where she lived with her godmother, Linda Inghilleri, and her husband, Sal. There she had her own bedroom, Barbie dolls, stuffed bunnies and a play vanity. But the authorities have also accused Sal Inghilleri of sexually abusing her.
The case has wrenched the hearts of Long Island parents, who have seen the pictures of the cute blond girl with rosy cheeks and a shy smile. Across the Island, it has frightened children, who have followed the story daily on television.
The public's concerns were heightened by the apparent inability of county social-service workers to help Katie, even though they had closely watched the family and knew that the girl was in a difficult situation.
 
She Wasn't Ready
 Marilyn Beers, 43 years old, admitted recently she was not prepared to raise a child on her own when she gave birth to Katherine Marie Beers. The father, whom she has refused to identify publicly, was "out of the picture," she said. Her first child, John, born six years earlier, had been raised by Miss Beers's parents, but her father had died and her mother was too old to resume such a burden.
There was not even anyone to drive Miss Beers home from the hospital, and she and her newborn girl had to take a cab, Miss Beers recalled. When she got to the house, where she herself had grown up, it had almost no baby supplies, and Miss Beers, an unemployed taxi driver, had no money to buy them. Her neighbor, Mrs. Rossi, remembered bringing over a used cradle and some old baby clothes.
While Mrs. Rossi and other neighbors described Miss Beers as a good-natured, generous woman, they added that she was too preoccupied with her own problems to watch Katie properly. Mrs. Rossi said that one winter morning, when Katie was still a toddler, she discovered the little girl in front of her house wearing only a diaper, breakfast food smeared on her face. No one in the Beers household had noticed that she was gone, Mrs. Rossi said.
 
Brief Stints at Home
 But for most of her first six years, Katie spent only brief stints at home. Instead, she was largely raised by Miss Beers's friend Mrs. Inghilleri, who says she tookher role of unofficial guardian almost by accident.
At a chance meeting about two months after Katie was born, Miss Beers told Mrs. Inghilleri she had a headache and asked her to baby-sit for a few hours, Mrs. Inghilleri said. "It changed from a few hours to a night to a few weeks to forever," she said. "Since then, I have nurtured her like a mother."
Sal Inghilleri, who is now 39, said there were few problems in the early years, until he suffered a heart attack in 1988, forcing the Inghilleris and Katie to move in, rent-free, with the Beers -- Marilyn, her son, John, and her mother, Helen -- in West Islip.
Mr. Inghilleri said the house was a "pigsty," infested with cockroaches, and had fallen into disrepair. Soon after they arrived, the ceiling over the den collapsed and the heater broke, he added.
"We were constantly fighting with them to get it fixed," Mr. Inghilleri said. "It was a very bad environment there. Katie had never lived in anything like that."
 
Children Teased Her
 Mrs. Rossi said this weighed heavily on Katie. Some parents in the neighborhood would not allow their children to play with her, Mrs. Rossi added.
But the girl remained friendly and was clearly independent. Several described her as "street smart" and said they would see her out by herself as late as 10:30 at the delicatessen around the corner. One neighbor, who spoke on condition of anonymity, recalled seeing Katie as a 7-year-old, hauling the family's dirty clothes to a self-service laundry.
Paul Bartley, 58, whose 10-year-old daughter, Linda, became friends with Katie last year, called the girl "street wise" and a "little rough around the edges," but basically a "normal, good kid." Linda Bartley said that Katie had once tried to get her to smoke a cigarette, "was fun to play baby dolls with" and was a "good friend."
Linda said she had been watching television news every night since Katie disappeared and cried when she first saw Katie's picture on the screen. She told her father that she would no longer walk down the block alone.
 
'CravedStarved for Attention'
 Another neighbor, Cynthia Vanderveer, 29, who lives across the street from Miss Beers's current home in Mastic Beach, said that the girl seemed starved for attention. She recalled how Katie clung to her leg and tugged at her shirt when she took Katie and her own daughter to a video store earlier this year. "Katie didn't want to let go," she said.
Mrs. Rossi said: "She was a very sweet, very bright girl who craved attention. She couldn't come near you without wanting a hug and a kiss."
"She's such a friendly kid that she would go off with anyone who was nice to her," she added.
Katie moved to her mother's one-bedroom apartment in Mastic Beach a year ago and seemed to have quickly become friends with a group of neighborhood children. Miss Beers said her daughter was happy, and her complaints were no different from those of any other girl her age.
But the move occurred as the quarrel between her mother and Mrs. Inghilleri over who would have custody of the girl grew more intense, and both said they told county officials that the other woman was not providing a sound environment for Katie.
An official involved in the case, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said social workers had been monitoring Katie's situation for the last two years and had observed a series of problems and a strange relationship between the godmother and the mother. "She is a needy child," he said. But while he acknowledged that there were problems at Katie's mother's house, he added that social workers had not thought that the child was in any "imminent risk" there.
After a bank foreclosed on the Beers's house in West Islip, Katie and her grandmother moved in with the Inghilleris. But in January of last year, Miss Beers, who had always been Katie's legal guardian, came and took them away, forcibly removing the girl, Mrs. Inghilleri said.
Mr. Inghilleri accused Miss Beers, who had been unemployed for long periods, of taking her daughter and her mother because she wanted access to Helen Beers's pension money and was jealous that her daughter preferred living with the Inghilleris. Miss Beers denied both accusations.
Meanwhile, Miss Beers told Suffolk County Children Protective Services that Katie had been sexually abused by Sal Inghilleri. Mr. Inghilleri was arrested 10 months later, in October, on felony sexual abuse charges and has pleaded not guilty. He is scheduled for trial in February, and the Suffolk County District Attorney's office has ordered him to have no contact with Katie.
Despite the accusations, Miss Beers continued to allow Katie to visit the Inghilleris, letting the girl spend the month of August there as well as frequent weekends. Miss Beers said she thought that Mr. Inghilleri was separated from his wife and no longer living in the house. While Mr. Inghilleri said that the two were separated for financial reasons, he said their marriage was intact and that he frequently stayed at the house in Bay Shore.
Katie, in fact, had spend the weekend with the Inghilleris before her disappearance on Dec. 28. She had been picked up by a longtime family friend, John Esposito, who said the girl disappeared about 4:30 P.M., minutes after he took her to the Space Plex video arcade in Nesconset. Mr. Esposito, who pleaded guilty about 15 years ago to charges of unlawful imprisonment of a 12-year-old boy, has been questioned by the police, who have been unable to find witnesses to corroborate his account.
Mrs. Inghilleri had also complained to Children Protective Services that Miss Beers was an unfit mother. For example, she said, Katie had head lice this fall, a common affliction among schoolchildren, and then had failed to attend school for weeks.
Mrs. Inghilleri complained that Miss Beers's one-bedroom apartment, a converted garage, was unhealthy. When a reporter visited recently, the floor was covered with trash, piles of dirty clothes and dozens of empty sarsaparilla bottles. The phone was disconnected and the bedroom light did not work. Katie's empty Christmas stocking was still hanging on the wall by the Christmas tree.

Linda Inghilleri, left, held a picture of the missing girl, her goddaughter. HEADLINE: Rostenkowski Inquiry Widens, Lawyers Say

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Eight months after Federal prosecutors subpoenaed Representative Dan Rostenkowski's expense records as part of their inquiry into the House post office, the investigation has steadily grown into a broad review of the Congressman's public and private finances, lawyers involved in the case said today.
The grand jury investigation involving Mr. Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House tax-writing committee, began in May, focusing on his purchase of stamps from the House post office. 
 The lawyers said the prosecutors suspected that someone in Mr. Rostenkowski's office, along with employees at the poorly run mail service, stole cash from the post office, disguising the thefts as a stamp purchases. Investigators have been examining the post office since mid-1991 when they learned that a clerk had traveled to Puerto Rico on a stolen money order.
But in a series of steps taken since the Election Day, a team of prosecutors headed by Jay B. Stephens, the United States Attorney here, has subpoenaed nearly 20 aides, including nearly all of Mr. Rostenkowki's current and former employees at his offices in Washington and Chicago to testify to the grand jury along with some employees of the Ways and Means Committee.
 
What Prosecutors Suspect
 Prosecutors appear to suspect Mr. Rostenkowski himself of possible misconduct and have sought his personal financial records as well as records from his campaign organization, the lawyers said.
In a report today on the widening inquiry, The Washington Post quoted Mr. Rostenkowski as saying that he is not a target of the investigation. In an interview with the newspaper, he complained about news leaks about the inquiry, insisting that no evidence against him had been uncovered. "They don't have anything, but it makes me look guilty," he said.
Mr. Rostenkowski has agreed to pay the legal bills of several of his aides who have been summoned to testify, including some staff members who have resisted efforts to testify to the grand jury without a grant of immunity from prosecution, the lawyers said. Mr. Rostenkowski's own lawyers, Abbey D. Lowell and Stanley M. Brand, obtained another lawyer's legal opinion saying the arrangement was proper.
But prosecutors are said to be angered by the practice, questioning whether the Congressman has bought his subordinates' silence, an assertion that Mr. Rostenkowski's lawyers and lawyers representing his aides deny, pointing out that Mr. Stephens has obtained testimony of several of the lawmaker's aides.
Although Federal law enforcement officials have said they are pursuing solid leads, it is not at all clear if they have any concrete evidence tying Mr. Rostenkowski or any of his aides to a crime.
 
$55,000 Worth of Stamps
 Public records show that Mr. Rostenkowski's campaign and Congressional offices purchased more than $55,000 worth of stamps in recent years, and former staff members have said they did not recall ever seeing postage stamps purchased in such quantities. Mr. Rostenkowski has never explained the large volume of stamp purchases, except to assert that his office mailed a large volume of correspondence without using the free mail privileges of his office.
Some lawyers who have followed the case have said that the expansion of the inquiry may not signal gathering momentum, but that prosecutors are resorting to a scattershot approach in a final effort to bring a criminal case against the lawmaker after months of futile digging.
Mr. Rostenkowski's allies on Capitol Hill have questioned Mr. Stephens's motives, suggesting that the Republican official was trying to complete his tenure as the top prosecutor in Washington with a case against an important Democrat who is likely to figure prominently in economic and health-care policy in the new Clinton Administration.
Mr. Stephens, who has denied any political motivation in any of his prosecutorial efforts, also supervised the investigation of former Washington Mayor Marion Barry.
That case used a hotly debated sting in which Mr. Barry was lured to a hotel room by a former women friend and arrested while smoking crack cocaine.
In July, prosecutors summoned Mr. Rostenkowski to testify, but he refused, citing his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself. At the time, he offered to talk informally with investigators, but they declined.
At the time, it appeared the investigation was building toward a potentially serious case, as prosecutors appeared to be working up the chain of command at the post office, obtaining guilty pleas from several clerks and their superiors.
Their cooperation seemed to lead to the subpoenas for the records of Mr. Rostenkowski and two other Democratic lawmakers, Austin Murphy and Joe Kolter, both of Pennsylvania. But so far no elected official has been formally accused of any wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Labor Department;
Nominee Devoted Years To Rehearsing for Role

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Robert B. Reich will no doubt be the first Secretary of Labor who ever staged a production of The Fantasticks.
And he is probably the first to serve as a top economic adviser to three Democratic Presidential candidates, and the first to write seven books in 10 years. 
 Everything about Mr. Reich -- his love of the theater, his hyperkinetic intellect, his close and longstanding friendship with the President-elect -- suggests that he will not play Labor Secretary as a bit role.
 
Top Supporting Actor
 Indeed, President-elect Bill Clinton has cast Mr. Reich (pronounced REISH) in what might prove to be a leading role, implementing one of the new President's fundamental economic strategies: improving the skills of the nation's workers.
Mr. Reich, a 46-year-old lecturer on public policy at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, has devoted much of his adult life to that cause, churning out books and articles about how Americans are ill prepared for the workplace of the 21st century.
"Global investors will come and create good jobs if we have a well-trained work force," he said in an interview. "I am interested in Americans gaining skills in computer technology, in biotechnology, not in learning how to produce buggy whips."
 
'Useful Intellectual Source'
 Though critics dismiss him as a pamphleteer and propagandist and point out that he is a lawyer and not an economist, Mr. Reich has shaped Democratic thinking on the economy more than any other academic in the last decade. Walter F. Mondale turned to Mr. Reich for advice during his 1984 Presidential campaign, as did Michael S. Dukakis in 1988.
But his advice made a more indelible mark on Mr. Clinton, who was with him at Oxford University when both were Rhodes Scholars and was a classmate at Yale Law School.
"Nobody dominates Bill Clinton, but Bob has had a very significant influence on him," said John Isaacson, a Boston executive who was a Rhodes Scholar with the two men. "He has been a very useful intellectual source for Bill and probably always will be."
Large parts of Mr. Clinton's Putting People First economic program seemed to be plucked out of Mr. Reich's latest book, "The Work of Nations" (Knopf, 1991). The book argues that improving America's work force and infrastructure like airports and highways is crucial to keeping and attracting high-paying jobs.
He was one of the main authors of Mr. Clinton's economic program, the centerpiece of which was spending $220 billion over the next four years to improve the infrastructure and job skills. When Mr. Reich was in a Boston hospital last June for a double hip replacement operation, Clinton aides in Little Rock faxed him copies of the plan so he could review it as it was reworked.
 
Bonded by Chicken Soup
 The President-elect and Mr. Reich became fast friends on the ship to England for their Rhodes scholarships. Mr. Reich is fond of recounting how when he became seasick, a knock on his cabin door introduced him to an affable young Arkansan bearing chicken soup.
"They are two very similar kinds of minds and similar kinds of people," said Nancy Bekavac, a law school classmate who shared an apartment with Mr. Reich and two other friends in New Haven. "They both have first-rate analytical minds, but their communications skills are even better."
While Mr. Clinton is a champion political networker, Mr. Reich is an astute intellectual networker. He is a contributing editor to The New Republic, chairman of the board of the American Prospect, a liberal economics magazine, and a board member of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington.
In addition to churning out books and articles, Mr. Reich is a talented speaker who is frequently a guest on the MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour and on various National Public Radio news programs.
 
Opposing Voices
 He has also attracted a number of critics. Not all of them are conservatives, and several point to his constant presence on newspaper Op-Ed pages and television as evidence of an outsized ego.
A far more serious assertion is that Mr. Reich is sloppy with facts and shifts his ideas from book to book.
"His use of statistics is abusive and demagogic," said George Gilder, an author who helped popularize conservative ideas during the Reagan era. "And I don't think he is very rigorous on domestic policy."
Last month a writer for The New Republic attacked a 1989 Reich article that had accused American companies of having little loyalty to their homeland. The Reich article had stated that when an American bought a Pontiac LeMans, $6,000 of the $20,000 paid to General Motors went to South Korea. At the time, a LeMans cost about $10,000, the New Republic article stated. It also asserted that Mr. Reich erred in writing that Honda's assembly plants in the United States ship about 50,000 cars a year to Asia. The real number turned out to be a fourth of that, The New Republic said.
 
'You Make Some Mistakes'
 Mr. Reich declined to discuss this criticism, but a longtime colleague, John D. Donahue, a professor at the Kennedy School dismissed it. "You process 20,000 facts a year, you make some mistakes," he said.
The New Republic article also criticized Mr. Reich for inconsistency. In the early 1980's, he was suspicious of Japanese investment in the United States, stating, "Americans working for foreign owners do not get the kind of technical learning they need."
But his newest book rejects the notion that Japanese companies keep their best jobs in Japan when they own American operations.
He has also changed his mind about industrial policy. A decade ago, he supported the vigorous use of tax incentives and job-training funds to aid promising young industries. He now balks at that approach, saying the Government should provide fertile ground for all.
 
Lacks Degree in Economics
 Mr. Reich denies that he has been intellectually inconsistent, insisting that like any good academic he has updated his views in response to changing circumstances.
His lack of a doctorate in economics, and the belief among some Harvard faculty that he plays loose with his facts and theories have prevented him from receiving a tenured professorship at the Kennedy School, several colleagues said. He was instead offered a lifetime contract for the lesser position of lecturer.
The lack of an economics degree also prevented him from attaining his goal of becoming Mr. Clinton's chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, although he directed Mr. Clinton's economic transition team.
Mr. Reich said that as Labor Secretary he hoped to pay special attention to Americans without college degrees. "The noncollege-educated worker is on a downward escalator," he said. "We have to try to change that."
 
'Dominant Figure on Campus'
 Mr. Reich was born in Scranton, Pa., and grew up in South Salem, N.Y., near the Connecticut border, where his parents ran a women's clothing store. Valedictorian of his high school class, he went on to Dartmouth, where he was student-council president. Although he was a vocal opponent of the Vietnam War, his classmates say he was more a conciliator than a confrontationist.
"I remember vividly at Dartmouth what a charismatic and galvanic person he was," said Mr. Isaacson, who was a Dartmouth classmate as well as a fellow Rhodes scholar. He was probably the dominant figure on campus."
When not protesting, he kept busy directing plays and writing theatre reviews. Some friends expected that he would become a producer or theater critic.
 
Small Physical Stature
 He did not have Bill Clinton's problems with the draft. When he showed up for his physical, he was disqualified for being too short at 4 feet 10 inches, a result of a rare spinal disease.
He jokes freely about his height, saying he was long on Mr. Clinton's short list and taunting conservative critics by asking how they could think a man so short could stand for Big Government.
After law school, he worked for the Solicitor General, Robert H. Bork, who had been one of his law professors at Yale, then moved to the Federal Trade Commission, where he became director of policy planning under President Jimmy Carter.
"He challenged a lot of the orthodoxies at the commission," said Michael Pertschuk, who was the trade commission's chairman at the time. "He left a lot of the staff people feeling uneasy, but that was partly his role."
 
Praised as Administrator
 Mr. Pertschuk said Mr. Reich did a good job administering a staff of 30. (At the Labor Department, he will oversee a staff of 18,000.) Mr. Reich's colleagues said he knew how to listen, how to delegate and how to inspire.
After Ronald Reagan was elected President, he joined the faculty at the Kennedy School. His wife, Clare Dalton, whom he met when she auditioned for a play he was directing at Oxford, teaches at Northeastern Law School. They have two sons, Adam and Sam.
Throughout his writings, Mr. Reich's dominant interest has been how to strengthen the nation's economy as it faces increased foreign competition.
 
Economic Divisions
 In his latest book, he says the United States population is divided into three economic levels: a thriving group consisting of people who process information, including corporate executives, lawyers, doctors and investment bankers; a languishing second group consisting of service-industry workers; and the hardest-hit group, blue-collar workers like employees of the steel and rubber industries, who have been crushed by foreign competition.
"All Americans used to be in roughly the same economic boat" he wrote. "We are now in different boats, one sinking rapidly, one sinking more slowly, and the third rising steadily."
In his view, education and job training can rescue those who are sinking.
Although his agenda differs from that of the labor movement, union leaders have applauded his selection.
"We believe that he can make a superb Secretary of Labor," said Thomas R. Donahue, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s secretary-treasurer. "We have always argued that we need a Secretary of Labor who will be listened to in the Administration, and it seems clear that he will be listened to."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
When a Lawyer and Client Are Possible Rivals

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
When Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. denounced the economic and racial segregation of Connecticut's public school system in his State of the State speech last week, he did more than set a new legislative agenda for the General Assembly. He also threw a curve ball right at the state's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, an ambitious Democrat who has made no secret of wanting to succeed Mr. Weicker next year as governor.
As the state's chief civil lawyer, Mr. Blumenthal has been defending Connecticut in a lawsuit filed by a group of public school students who say that racial isolation in the schools is a violation of the state's Constitution. Mr. Weicker, in a powerful speech full of moral thunderbolts, came down firmly on the side of the students and said the executive and legislative branches of government must take action. 
 By implication, that puts Mr. Blumenthal on one side of the issue and Mr. Weicker on the other, even though technically Mr. Blumenthal is still Mr. Weicker's lawyer at the trial, which began in State Superior Court in West Hartford last month. Mr. Blumenthal, a former volunteer legal counsel to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, was considered one of the more liberal members of the State Senate, where he served before until 1991.
Mr. Weicker has not even said for certain whether he will run for a second four-year term, though he has hinted that he may not.
 
Er, Um, Uh
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo rarely seems discomfited or lackluster, particularly when he has the chance to speak to a crowd. And so people watching him deliver his 11th State of the State address last Wednesday in Albany were surprised to see him peering tentatively ahead several times.
Technical difficulties, the Governor said, combined with poor lighting.
"Three different times the thing just kind of disappeared," he explained later, comparing the words on the prompter screen he was watching to movie credits, where "the words come up very big and when they get to the top of the screen they fade away and then they get small and smaller, or they reverse direction."
Nonsense, said the prompter operator, Alfred Lettieri. Mr. Lettieri said his machine worked fine, but that the Governor, in departing from his text, had made a low-technology, old-fashioned error and simply lost his place.
"No one's better at speaking than the Governor," Mr. Lettieri said. "But if you ad lib, the hardest thing in the world is to come back to the prompter and pick it up."
 
Caribbean Constituency
 Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, a veteran Queens legislator who is planning a second run for New York City comptroller this year, went to Puerto Rico with Mayor David N. Dinkins last week to celebrate the inauguration of the island's newly elected Governor, Dr. Pedro Rossello. But he he was clearly working on his own agenda.
In 1989 Mr. Hevesi lost in a four-way race to Elizabeth Holtzman. Ms. Holtzman ran very well among Hispanic voters, taking more than 55 percent of their votes. This time around, Mr. Hevesi is trying to making inroads among those voters, and he has persuaded Dennis Rivera, the politically powerful Hispanic head of the hospital workers union, to help him. Mr. Rivera also went to Puerto Rico.
"The Latino community is a crucial and vital constituency," Mr. Hevesi said. "They will be a major part of the coalition I intend to put together in the comptroller race.
Ms. Holtzman said through a spokeswoman that she was not worried about her Hispanic support. She did not attend the inauguration because she had longstanding plans to spend the New Year's weekend with her family, said the spokeswoman, Andrea Bernstein. Still, she does plan a Caribbean trip soon.
"She doesn't have anything on the schedule now, but chances are very good she will visit Puerto Rico before the year is out," Ms. Bernstein said.
 
Dial-a-Quote
 Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign popularized a gimmick last year in which reporters who were anxious for a personal quotation from the candidate could call and get a recorded statement from Mr. Clinton himself, speaking on the news topic of the day.
The 16 Republicans in the Connecticut Senate have now latched onto the idea. Perhaps their notion is that reporters could avoid an actual conversation with one of the senators, whose business and home telephone numbers are routinely printed by local newspapers as a public service.
Or perhaps they think the recorded messages are profound enough to rise above the clutter of other news.
Senator William A. Aniskovich, a Republican from Branford, and the minority president pro-tem in the Senate, said in his recorded message last week, for example, that he wants to "help the Republican Party form a message that restores the people's hope in the institutions of government and government's ability to solve problems."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Fashion Scene;
More Inaugural Dresses Change Into Pumpkins

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Some will glitter, others will shimmer, certainly a few will trip on their unusually long hemlines. On inauguration night, nothing less than an absolutely elegant dress will do for the women lucky enough to land ball invitations.
But when the party is over, many of these dresses will go back where they came from -- the rental shop. 
 All over the country, women from a very select group are rushing on their lunch hours to dress rental shops to pick up something slinky, something scoop-necked, something full-skirted or something simple for this prom of all proms.
Men have been renting tuxedos for formal affairs since time began, and now women are taking their cue, renting dresses here and in other major cities for $100 or so that would cost them upwards of $1,000 to buy.
"I do not go to many functions," said Sandra Zweig, a 29-year-old television producer in New York. "It seemed to me kind of ridiculous to buy something that I would never wear again." Ms. Zweig said she had rented her strapless black gown from One Night Stand, a rental store on Madison Avenue near 72d Street, for $250. "I can't imagine how much this dress would have cost me to buy," she said.
 
'Very Good for Us'
 Joanna Doniger, owner of One Night Stand, said that 90 percent of her business over the last few weeks had been from women plowing through her 800 dresses each day, looking for something to wear to the balls. "Democrats tend not to have a wardrobe of evening dresses, and this has been very good for us," she said. "Why should they buy when they can rent something equally fab?"
One other advantage of renting a dress is that rental companies pick up the cleaning bills.
"Renting makes sense for an event where anything can happen," said Joan McGettigan, co-owner of Just One Affair in Washington. "People can bang into you with a drink or something. You never know. This way you won't have to worry about it."
As with most of these rental shops around the country, Miss McGettigan rents dresses from $70 to $300. With that comes a week with the dress, plus fitting, cleaning and minor alterations. Store owners around the country said that scooped necks and slim-fitting dresses had been very popular and that women were more concerned with a flattering fit than with the name of the designer on the label.
 
'The Frenzy Is On'
 While there are no hard numbers to back them up, most dress rental store owners said that four years ago renting for the inauguration was almost unheard of. "This just wasn't the thing to do here in Little Rock, , last time around," said Sharla Eudy, co-owner of Just For Tonight. "But we have been nonstop snowed in since the day of the election. I've got four ladies standing here right now for fittings. The frenzy is on."
The American Rental Association said renting formal wear to women is a fast-growing phenomenon. Janet Wynn Snyder, owner of Jandi Classics, a manufacturer and distributor of rental dresses in Knoxville, Tenn., said her business was up 70 percent since last spring. "Since the recession, people have had to adjust their priorities," she said. "They are renting for everything now.
"Just the other day," she said, "Our society column was going on and on about two emerald green dresses worn at a museum opening. We were so tickled because one of them was ours. The other was probably $5,000."
One of Mrs. Eudy's clients, Jill Huggins, said she could not care less if the whole world knew she rented from the shop, through she would not reveal who her date for the balls will be. "I have been all over town to look for dresses," she said. "I found two black gowns here for $175 apiece. I doesn't bother me if people know about it."
Retailers say they are not worried about the rental trend. Denise Greene, manager of the fine-dress department of Nordstrom's department store in McLean, Va., said the women who rent were those with very expensive tastes. "These are the women who want to wear a $2,000 gown but do not want to buy it," she said. "Middle-class and upper-middle-class women will still purchase."
Miss Greene predicted that nearly 75 percent of her January business would be from women attending inauguration balls.

HEADLINE: Martin Barell, 71, Who Headed State Board of Regents, Is Dead

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Martin C. Barell, who served as chancellor of New York State's Board of Regents from 1985 to 1992 and developed new programs amid controversy over education's failures and the effectiveness of his agency, died yesterday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 71.
He died of heart disease, his family said. 
Among the many issues that arose during Mr. Barell's tenure were debates over multiculturalism, coeducational athletics, urban school financing, the academic freedom to voice racially divisive views and school distribution of condoms to students to help prevent the spread of AIDS.
Soon after Mr. Barell took over as chancellor, the Regents came under attack from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and several legislators who said the board had failed to address high dropout rates, illiteracy and other education problems. The Governor said he was "incredibly unhappy" with the board, and some called for its abolition.
 
'Compact for Learning'
 Mr. Barell defended the board's record and vowed redoubled efforts, saying "we will, I'm sure, show results." In 1987 the Regents recruited Dr. Thomas Sobol as the state's new education commissioner and with him formed the 1991 "compact for learning."
That program is intended to improve education by imposing higher standards for students and giving local schools both more accountability for meeting the goals and more flexibility in the means they used.
Another innovation under Mr. Barell's tenure was the development of "community renewal schools." Several dozen model schools across the state are now open from early morning through the evening as community centers, with numerous activities and social services for children and adults.
The Board of Regents, the nation's oldest education agency, founded in 1874, has broad policy powers. It has general supervision over all public and private primary and secondary schools, colleges and universities, museums, libraries, historical societies, archives and vocational rehabilitation agencies. It also licenses and disciplines physicians, architects, engineers, dieticians, social workers, psychologists and members of 31 other professions.
 
Rejection of VouchersgFocus of Broad Powers
 Mr. Barell, elected a Regent by the State Legislature in 1976 at the age of 54, contested William A. Genrich for the chancellor's post in 1980 and lost. After Mr. Barell made amends, Mr. Genrich nominated him for vice chancellor in 1983. He succeeded Mr. Genrich on his retirement.
Under Mr. Barell's leadership, the Regents allowed girls on previously all-male teams, barred commercially sponsored classroom television programs and rejected a "voucher" proposal that would have allowed public payment of private school tuition. He said the plan would "aid and abet the liquidation of the public school system."
Mr. Barell helped broaden curriculum to include more about other cultures and the role of minorities. He said: "We ought to tell it like it is, and not gloss everything over."
But the Regents were embarrassed when Dr. Sobol commissioned a report that turned out to be racially provocative. It was prepared in part by Leonard Jeffries Jr., a City University professor who espouses black superiority. Further controversial remarks by Dr. Jeffries led critics to call on the board to renounce him. Mr. Barell urged it to refrain, saying, "This is not a macho organization. We don't want to stand tall."
 
Active in Civic Affairs
 When the Regents required an AIDS curriculum in 1987, he said, "Every child, regardless of what the community says, ought to have a minimum knowledge of AIDS." But in 1991 he defended the board's refusal to require schools to offer condoms, as recommended by the state AIDS agency.
In 1989 he assailed New York City's central school board and administration and suggested its dismantling. Later, in a reversal, he praised the initial efforts of the new city Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez.
Among his civic activities, Mr. Barell was chairman emeritus of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, chairman of the Synagogue Council of America, past president of the Jewish Community Services of Long Island, a member of the National Commission for Unesco and an active Democrat.
The father of two institutionalized children, he supported organizations to help the handicapped and was a past president of the the Reece School for retarded and disturbed children. Nassau-Suffolk Services for the Autistic opened a school in Levittown, L.I., named for him.
 
Background in Law
 Mr. Barell was born in Brooklyn. He graduated from Columbia University and, after serving in the Army in World War II, graduated from Harvard's business and law schools.
In 1951 he cofounded a Manhattan law firm, Golenbock & Barell, where he specialized in real estate and business law. He was the firm's senior partner when it merged in 1990 with Whitman & Ransom, where he was of counsel.
His first marriage ended in divorce.
Surviving are his wife of 10 years, the former Phyllis Sotnick; two sons, Allan, of Manhattan, and Steven, of Langhorne, Pa.; four daughters, Deborah Spandorf of Queens, Marian Nelson of Falls Church, Va., Barbara Silpe of Lido Beach, L.I., and Naomi Barell of Jerusalem, Israel; two stepchildren, Lesly Steinman of Glen Head, L.I., and David Sotnick of Brooklyn; a sister, Gladys Barr of Oak Beach, L.I., and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Reduced Dollars, Reduced Hope

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
What does it take to rescue a person from the despair and frustration of unemployment, homelessness, drug addiction or mental illness? Are these problems so overwhelming that their victims are condemned to spend the rest of their days in misery?
Voices from every corner of New York City -- from people like Patricia K. of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, who has battled depression, and Simon Rutledge of the South Bronx, who has AIDS -- would insist that the answer is no. These New Yorkers would describe how their lives have been transformed by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 And from their stories might come a realization: it does not take a million dollars to save a person in crisis. Through hundreds of seemingly minor efforts, the seven charities assisted by the fund sow change across the city. It could be a visit from a social worker. A grant to stave off an eviction. Help in buying medication.
 
Decline Threatens Services
 But this year, the ability of the fund to aid thousands of New Yorkers is threatened by a sharp decline in donations. Today, the fund stands at $3,218,788.60; last year on this date it had taken in $4,043,747.60. This year, the drive ends on Feb. 28. There is still time to help.
If the appeal does not pick up, the seven charities linked to the fund might have to reduce or even eliminate programs at a time when the recession has pushed the unemployment rate in New York City to 11 percent. With the budgets of social service agencies squeezed, people who need emergency grants to remain in their apartments might find that they have no place to turn.
And for children growing up in some of the city's bleakest neighborhoods, the decline might mean going to bed some nights with empty stomachs. For other boys and girls, it might mean life with less health care, clothes, or books and toys.
The drop in donations "will have a very definite effect," said Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, a Neediest Cases charity.
 
Already, Government Cuts
 "Since there have been government cuts and since we're barely holding our own in our fund-raising," he said, "we are not in the position to make up for what will have been lost from the fund. It will force us to consider what was the intolerable before: actually reducing the level of services to those who need us the most."
Dr. Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, another Neediest Cases charity, said she feared that the decline might prevent some social-service agencies from even letting people know where they can find help.
"I just finished reading an annual report from an agency about the importance of giving information," she said. "We take information for granted, but when you're in a crisis, that's a major problem."
To be sure, some of the fund's benefactors increased their donations this year because they realized that with the recession, charities were facing tight budgets and increasing poverty. They gave whatever they could spare -- from $5 to $5,000. The New York Times pays the expenses of the Neediest Cases campaign, so all contributions are given directly to the seven charities.
 
'Suffering Is Overwhelming'
 Sidney Sutter of Manhattan sent $4,000. "We have contributed for years because we know how the support is needed," he wrote. "Due to the economy, we felt obligated to increase our contribution this year."
Even though he is retired and on a limited income, George Ginsberg of Springfield, N.J., doubled his donation to $6.
Lawrence and Patti Bauer of Short Hills, N.J., also increased their donation, sending $1,500. "In our letters to the fund, we have always noted that the needs of those less fortunate than we seem to grow inexorably from the year before," they wrote. "What was true then continues, unfortunately, this year. The number of people suffering is overwhelming."
Donations to the fund this year have been inspired by a host of people and events. Some contributors wanted to honor friends, relatives, co-workers or strangers who came to their aid. Others sent money to help victims of the fierce storm that swept through the New York area last month or in memory of Patrick Daly, the principal in Red Hook, Brooklyn, who was slain in the crossfire of a drug dispute.
 
Triplets and Troubles
 If contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund do not rebound, the charities might have to turn away people like Joane V.
In 1991, Joane had just given birth to triplets -- two boys and a girl -- when her doctors told her that she had a degenerative muscular disease. Then she found out that the two boys had cerebral palsy and that the girl's mental development was lagging.
She had to quit her job as an administrator because of her illness, which left her tired constantly, and was soon forced to raise the children on her own after she separated from their father. She could not cope with chores like washing diapers, and sometimes she became so exhausted that she could not pick up the babies.
"The first six months were terrible," said Joane, 28, who lives in Coney Island. "I had no help whatsoever. It's overwhelming to anyone with one child, but with three children, it's impossible."
The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, a Neediest Cases charity, provided her with a homemaker five days a week to care for the babies and help with cooking and cleaning.
"Without the homemaker, nothing would get done," she said. "My chores for myself wouldn't get done. Now it's a lot easier. It was hard at first to accept help, but it's made a big difference."
 
Tragedies on the Doorstep
 Such assistance reflects the primary mission of the Neediest Cases Fund: helping people get back on their feet. The Brooklyn Bureau sends nearly 150 homemakers to families across the borough who are in danger of collapse because of physical, medical and emotional crises.
"Many times without the homemaker service, children would end up in the foster care system," said Gem D. Wiltshire, a senior administrator at the Brooklyn Bureau. "This service helps to keep families intact and it's a more cost-efficient intervention than foster care service."
Mr. Coltoff of Children's Aid Society said he realized that many people felt overwhelmed by the growing number of disasters that have prompted calls for donations: the hurricanes in the United States, the famine in Somalia, the war in the Balkans.
But he added that Americans should not overlook the tragedies on their own doorsteps.
"I know it's hard -- that people's pockets are only so deep, even for New Yorkers, the most generous people in the world," he said. "But we're saying to people: Let's not forget the poor around us, who may be a little bit more invisible than some of the things that we see on television about problems abroad."

HEADLINE: A Pattern of Increasing Student Segregation

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The state of Connecticut, at the urging of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., is about to confront one of the most divisive issues in American life, school integration. How long delayed the debate has been, and how segregated the state's schools have become, is suggested by a single set of numbers.
Black children are more likely to attend predominantly white schools in Virginia, Georgia, Louisiana and Alabama, where they make up more than 30 percent of the enrollment, than in Connecticut, where they are less than 15 percent. 
 Nearly 40 years after the United States Supreme Court declared that "in the field of public education, 'separate but equal' has no place," the nation's most segregated schools are found not in the South, but in Northern industrial states like Connecticut.
 
'The Level of Total Separation'
 "The level of total separation that had been seen as the essence of the Southern racial system is now much more characteristic of Illinois, Michigan and New York than of any state in the Deep South," Gary Orfield, a Harvard professor of education and social policy, wrote in a 1992 report on segregation for the National School Boards Association.
But if the Legislature acts on Mr. Weicker's call to develop regional integration plans across the state, local officials and residents in the overwhelmingly white towns that surround Connecticut's cities will discover a world of racial and ethnic change that upends traditional black-and-white thinking about integration.
Declining birth rates among whites, combined with strong migration and high birth rates among other groups, make it inevitable that Connecticut will look different 10 or 20 years from now, regardless what is accomplished this year in Hartford.
 
Hispanic Enrollment Is Up
 For instance, while blacks are increasingly segregated in urban schools, Hispanic children are even more segregated and increasing more rapidly, following a nationwide trend.
Already Hispanic students, mainly Puerto Rican, outnumber blacks in three of the state's five largest cities: Hartford, Bridgeport and Waterbury. In New Britain, the seventh-largest city, they outnumber blacks by nearly 3 to 1.
And while the percentage of minority students in the state increased to 25.7 percent in 1991, from 18.7 percent in 1981, Hispanic students grew to 10.4 percent, from 6.3 percent, gaining on blacks, who grew to 12.8 percent, from 11.1 percent.
One reason that minorities make up a larger part of the state's enrollment is that the number of white students declined after the postwar baby boom, falling by a third between 1976 and 1991. The increase in minority students -- 27,517 -- was one-sixth of the decline in whites -- 179,892.
 
Two Large Groups
 Still, according to the State Department of Education, more than half of the state's 169 school districts had fewer than 5 percent minority students in 1991, and the vast majority fewer than 10 percent. As those communities take part in integration plans, they will have to address the needs of two large minority groups, one of which, Hispanic residents, has greatly different needs from the traditional focus of desegregation, blacks.
In Hartford, where lawyers representing 19 city and suburban children are suing to integrate the city's schools with those of 21 surrounding towns, Puerto Rican children are poorer than blacks, have higher dropout rates and need special language instruction. More than half live in homes where English is not spoken.
Mr. Orfield, who is scheduled to testify for the plaintiffs in the Hartford desegregation case, Sheff v. O'Neill, has suggested that the nation may have to devise a new definition of desegregation as not only Hispanic residents, but also Asians, increase from New York to California.
He suggested that groups that have suffered discrimination, remain segregated, and have inferior schools -- like blacks, Mexican-Americans, Puerto Ricans and American Indians -- could benefit by integration not only with whites, but also with Asians and Hispanic students of higher socioeconomic backgrounds.
 
Economic Factors Too
 A key element in the Hartford lawsuit, Mr. Orfield said in an interview, is that it is focusing on not only racial, but also economic, segregation in Hartford's schools, where nearly two-thirds of the students live below the poverty line.
"This isn't just about race, it's about race and poverty," he said. "I think it's been a long time getting those issues together, and it describes the reality much better."
Governor Weicker, in his proposal to the General Assembly this week, acknowledged the link between racial and economic segregation. He also agreed with the Hartford plaintiffs in proposing regional integration plans. Such plans, covering dozens of communities, would serve to prevent a new round of segregation that could occur if, for example, only Hartford's inner ring of suburbs was included in a desegregation plan for the city.
Mr. Weicker has received praise in Connecticut for declaring the need to address the racial and economic divisions between cities and suburbs. "This is not something you do for political gain," said Ronald Ellis, a lawyer with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund who is working with the Sheff plaintiffs.
 
Rare Outside the South
 But the kind of city-suburban plans he has outlined are rare outside the South, because Federal courts have refused to order plans that cross city lines unless intentional segregation can be proved, and virtually all desegregation plans have been developed under pressure from a judge.
Mr. Weicker is proposing a framework that would allow towns to preserve local control over schools, mixing city and suburban students voluntarily by offering parents a variety of ways to send their children beyond their own neighborhoods.
That a governor has appealed for school integration is not remarkable, said Gordon Foster, director of the Southeastern Desegregation Center, a federally financed institute in Miami, because the record of Northern states is to "talk a lot and make nice policies" when it comes to integration.
"Connecticut's been screwing around with this for a long time," Mr. Foster said. "Unless a state either puts some teeth in it, or makes the financial incentives great enough, they're not going to get far enough."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
No Lockout? No Strike? No Way to Really Tell Until the Labor Talks Begin

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
In 1981, the owners' chief labor negotiator, Ray Grebey, assured his employers that the players wouldn't strike. When they did, Grebey assured the owners that once they missed their first pay check, the players would return to work. Fifty days later, the owners ended the strike when their strike insurance ran out.
The moral of the story: Don't believe everything that is said or thought in baseball labor negotiations.
The story and the moral are relevant now because the latest negotiations between the owners and the players are scheduled to begin Wednesday. The first meeting between Richard Ravitch, the owners' latest labor executive, and Donald Fehr, the players' veteran union leader, will not produce any dramatic developments. 
 Ravitch will not enter the meeting with proposal in hand. He will discuss philosophy and economics, explaining why baseball's system of player compensation must change (all the while hoping Fehr forgets that the Detroit Tigers just gave Cecil Fielder a $10 million signing bonus amid a myriad of related cases of management largesse).
The proposal to give the players a percentage of the clubs' revenue and turn that into a cap on players' salaries will come later. More critical for the moment are the two prevailing thoughts entering the talks:
1. The owners will not lock out the players, as they have done three previous times, most recently during the last negotiations three years ago.
2. The players will not strike, as they have done four times, most recently in 1985, because they are making too much money.
The players should not believe the first thought; the owners should not believe the second.
The players, in fact, do not believe the first thought; the owners, unfortunately, do believe the second.
 
Bad Public Image?
 Some segment of ownership even appears to be confused about the players' right to strike. One owner expressed the view the other day that not only didn't he think the players would strike -- they would look bad in the eyes of the public, he said -- but he also didn't think they could strike because there is a contract that doesn't expire until the end of this year.
Under terms of the collective bargaining agreement, however, with the owners reopening it today on matters of free agency, salary arbitration and minimum salary, either side is free to engage in "concerted action," that is, a lockout or a strike.
Ravitch acknowledged that there might be confusion on that provision of the agreement and he would make sure to explain it again at the owners' meeting in Texas on Tuesday. But given the rights they have, Ravitch himself believes the players are not prepared to do anything that would cost them the millions of dollars they earn in salary.
Henry Aaron, the Brookings Institution economist who served on baseball's economic study committee, quoted Ravitch on the subject of the upcoming talks.
 
Backing Good Leadership
 "He said he thought the players as a group would have exceeding difficulty walking away from their total salaries from missing a whole season and it was likely they would agree," Aaron said. "Don Fehr, on the other hand, believes this is a most unfortunate view if held by a significant number of owners because he is persuaded that the players as a group are quite willing to stick behind good leadership and do what needs to be done."
Ravitch said he did not recall making that comment to Aaron directly. "I only remember one discussion at the study committee," he said, "where I made the point that it was neither in the interest of the owners or the players not to play baseball. That's the same thing I've said publicly. I can't understand why rational people can't reach agreement."
As for the owners and a possible lockout, they themselves say there will be no lockout because 21 of 28 owners would have to approve it and 13 voted against reopening the agreement. Others, even some on the players' side, hold that view, too.
"They'd have to be insane to lock out," one player agent said. "They have two expansion teams starting play, they're in the last year of their big television contract, the public would kill them."
Union people, however, feel anyone who believes the owners won't lock out the players are naive. If they weren't prepared to lock out, they say, why would they reopen? They have reopened, Ravitch says, because it is the only way they can get a new agreement that would have an impact on the 1994 season.
But they didn't have to reopen to negotiate a new agreement that would take effect next year, the union thinking goes. They could have simply begun talks early enough, even now, to work out an agreement that would take effect next Jan.1.
There are two other views on a potential lockout, both of which have to be considered seriously:
1. Forget the apparent obstacle of the three-fourths vote Ravitch and the hard-line owners would have to overcome to get approval for a lockout. For one thing, one player agent said, the three-fourths vote could revert to a simple majority by a simple-majority vote.
For another, if Ravitch were to tell the owners at a mid-February meeting that the players have been intransigent and flatly refuse to accept their new salary-cap system and that by not locking out, the owners would be passing the bargaining leverage to the players, who could strike at some point (forgetting the current popular belief), he could -- with the aid of his allies -- get the necessary votes.
2. This one is an even more intriguing scenario.
A stipulation in the reopener provision states, "There shall be no change in any terms or conditions of employment prior to such concerted action" -- lockout or strike -- "and prior to a bona fide impasse in negotiations."
Labor law permits an employer to impose new terms and conditions unilaterally if the two sides have reached a legal impasse in negotiations, but this agreement has added an extra step, a work stoppage.
By locking out the players at some point this year, in spring training or later, the owners would have achieved the first step. Then they could continue negotiating and, failing to reach agreement, impose new terms consistent with their last offer.
Salary arbitration would disappear, who knows what would happen with free agency and a salary cap would be instituted.
 
Time Enough to Play
 A lockout wouldn't have to last forever. It could begin at the start of spring training and be ended by mid-March, leaving the players enough time, as in 1990, to prepare for the season. The executive council could order camps opened, saying the clubs didn't want to deprive the fans of the season.
In that event, the owners would put themselves in position to incur a strike, just as they would if they hadn't locked out. The players have struck at different times in their work-stoppage history, and this time they could listen to Ravitch. They could earn all of their millions, then strike just before the playoffs begin.
The bulk of the $401 million in 1993 television revenue comes from post-season games.
Of course, all work stoppages or threats could be avoided if both sides agreed to a no-action pledge. A member of management floated the idea with the union -- and the union very likely would go along with it -- but nothing came of it.
 
One Guest Uninvited
 The Rev. Jesse Jackson will speak to the major league club owners at their meeting in Texas on Tuesday, but Sharon Jones will not.
Jones, the former Oakland Athletics employee who has accused Marge Schott, the Cincinnati Reds' owner, of making racist comments, had been scheduled to speak after Jackson, but yesterday she said that she had been uninvited.
Jones said that Bill White, the National League president, called and told her that Schott's lawyer, Robert Bennett, had "raised a question of the propriety of a witness involved in the case speaking to the owners before a resolution of the case."
Jones said White told her she would be invited to speak at an owners meeting tentatively scheduled for Feb. 3. Presumably, the executive council will have acted in the Schott matter by then.
In 1987, when club owners were waiting for Peter Ueberroth, then commissioner, to begin a telephone conference call in 1987, Jones has said, Schott spoke disparagingly of blacks, saying, "I'd rather have a trained monkey working for me than a nigger."
Jones has been interviewed by members of the committee investigating the alleged comments of the Reds' owner, but she said White told her recently that "none of the owners came forward and said they remembered the call."
"I took that to mean 25 people didn't remember the call," she said. "I'll invite them to do the right thing and come forward. I want to let them know I was uncomfortable on the call and I knew they were, too. We have to get beyond the discomfort."
Noting that baseball is called the national pastime, Jones added, "It is past time that we do something about racial issues in sports."

HEADLINE: BOATING;
No Fish Story: Many Boats Available

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
Penny Berryman of Dardanelle, Ark., a world-class bass fishing champion, spends 300 days a year with rod and reel in hand. She caught her biggest fish, a bass nearly 15 pounds, during a pre-tournament practice session in Florida.
Berryman threw the fish back in the water in hopes of luring it again during the coming tournament. But she never saw the potential prize bass again. 
 "From that day on, I took a camera with me while fishing," Berryman said about the catch.
It is that kind of story that lays the foundation for Berryman's fishing seminar, at the New York National Boat Show, which began yesterday and runs through next Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on 11th Avenue between 34th and 39th Streets.
And it is an indication of the continuing blues in the boating marketplace that a fish story is sharing showtime at a marine trade exhibition. Marine manufacturers, still trying to drag themselves out of a four-year economic slump, are counting on the fishing segment of boating to help bail the industry out.
Organizers have lined up several experts like Berryman, plus a wide array of fishing boats and electronics, fishing gear and accessories for the show.
 
An Inexpensive Sport
 "There's one thing in a recession," said Kevin VanDam of Kalamazoo, Mich., the 1992 bass angler of the year. "Fishermen, they don't give up fishing. It's a sport that doesn't cost that much. I fished a lot of years from the side of a bank before I got a small aluminum boat."
VanDam, who now fishes from a $20,000 sport-fishing craft, also plans to speak at a seminar at the boat show. Although his boat is a top-of-the-line model with a 150 horsepower engine, VanDam says that a suitable package of boat and motor can be found for less than $5,000.
It is small-boat sales that have given the industry a shot of optimism lately. Sales of relatively inexpensive canoes, small jet-powered boats and inflatables were up in 1992 while sales in the marine industry overall declined by 2 percent from 1991, according to estimates of the National Marine Manufacturers Association, boating's national trade organization.
Mike Waninger, senior vice president of the Yamaha Marine Group, a division of Yamaha Motor Corporation, U.S.A, said recently that the jet-powered water vehicles market has grown by 500 percent, to $500 million in sales, in the last five years. Yamaha is one of several companies that manufacture the solo and two-person boats, which look and ride like waterbound motorcycles and cost about $5,000.
 
Jet Power Is In
 Numerous companies will be displaying jet-powered personal craft at the show, as well as new jet-powered runabouts that carry four people and cost about $13,000. Models being shown include the 13.5-foot Rage by Boston Whaler, the 14-foot Jazz by Bayliner, and the 13.5-foot Sea Rayder by Sea Ray. Another company, Zodiac, will show its new Pro Jet, a 14-foot semi-rigid inflatable jet boat.
While small boats will be predominant, the New York show also plans on big-boat displays. The largest vessel will be Bluewater Marine's new 62-foot motor yacht, which will sell for about $700,000 fully equipped. While there are more than nine times more powerboats than sailboats at the show, manufacturers of both craft plan to show new 1993 models.
Among the sailboat companies with boats on display will be Hunter Marine, Beneteau, American Sail and Island Packet, a firm that will show its new 35-foot cruising catamaran.
 
Hundreds of Boats on Display
 Powerboat companies will have hundreds of boats on display, including models by Blackfin, Trojan, Four Winns, Mako, Baja, and Chris-Craft. The 46 RacerX, a speed boat by Cigarette, is propelled by three 1,000 horsepower engines, and is capable of speeds exceeding 100 miles an hour.
Boats designed with family cruising in mind include a new model from Wellcraft, the 243 Prima. A 24-foot power cruiser, suitable for four people, the boat comes with a full galley for cooking, a queen-sized main berth, and additional berths midship.
Electronics continue to dominate the marine industry as sophisticated equipment becomes increasingly miniaturized and affordable. The New York show will display the latest in Global Postioning Systems, electronic hand-held units that use satellite readings for navigation. The newest in sonar and radar units are also being exhibited.
For information on boat show times and seminars, telephone organizers at (212) 216-3616.

HEADLINE: Why Not Pay Equity for All Women?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The women's economic agenda described in "Economics as if Women Mattered" (Dec. 13) doesn't go far enough. We believe in equal pay for work of equal value for all employees, not just government employees. 
 Take a look beyond our northern border -- almost 800 United States corporations with offices in Ontario live under the terms of Ontario pay equity legislation. How can their employees' paychecks be closer to parity in Canada than here?
In the United States, in spite of the 30-year-old equal pay act, the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows men making more money than women in almost every job category. Even where women dominate a job -- such as registered nurse or secretary -- the average pay for males is higher than for females.
Within the rising pool of temporary, part-time and contingent workers, a predominantly female and people-of-color work force, you will find the problems of unequal pay, uneven health care and virtually no pension benefits.
Serious attention to enforcing current laws, learning from what has worked elsewhere, and creating greater opportunity to be heard without fear of reprisal could go a long way to achieving fair pay.
 
SUSAN BIANCHI-SAND
Washington, Dec. 24
 
Susan Bianchi-Sand is executive director of the National Committee on Pay Equity.
