HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Not A Movie

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
It was a free ride for the headline writers. Take one sure-fire human interest story of parental abandonment and one hit movie, and the words almost wrote themselves: Home Alone.
Overnight David and Sharon Schoo, who went to Acapulco and allegedly left their two little girls to fend for themselves, were billed as "the most hated couple in America." When they were arrested at the airport and led away in handcuffs, one bystander hissed "Scrooge!" And across America parents asked aloud: How could anyone leave a 9-year-old and a 4-year-old by themselves and go off on vacation like that? 
 But there were other voices, too, and they are the ones that bear hearing. A delivery man called a radio station in Pennsylvania to say he habitually delivered packages to households in which small children were home by themselves.
Police in Texas discovered an 8-year-old in a hotel room on Christmas Day. He had apparently been left there for two days by his father, alone with a jar of peanut butter, a loaf of bread and a box of cereal.
And a teacher in New York City reported that she once taught sisters whose mother worked a night shift and who, she suspected, were left alone all night long, locked in the apartment for their own well-being. She said she believed there were many such stories in her school. "These are not bad mothers," she said. "They're trying to support their kids."
Whatever the reason, America is a country in which, child welfare advocates have been warning for years, many children are home alone. It may not be for nine days, which is how long the Schoos were gone. But it might be every afternoon from 3 P.M. to nightfall. The estimates on kids who come home from school to an empty house vary widely, but all are in the millions.
What we do know is that childhood has changed since many of us were children. Ten years ago Marie Winn, in "Children Without Childhood," posited the end of an Age of Protection and the beginning of the Age of Preparation. "The new era," she wrote, "operates on the belief that children must be exposed early to adult experience in order to survive in an increasingly complex and uncontrollable world."
As parents are home less and children know more -- about sex, about drugs, about how to run the microwave -- the lines between child and adult blur. It even shows in our clothes; once mothers wore hose and heels and their little girls wore anklets and Mary Janes. Today it is different: 4-year-olds, 14-year-olds, 40-year-olds -- the Gap dresses us all alike.
In this atmosphere treating kids as quasi-adults becomes easier earlier. And it makes life easier for working parents; we are naturally more comfortable, at our desks, on the night shift, with the idea of the competent child rather than the dependent and vulnerable one.
When we think of the dangers of children home alone, we think of the physical: the fires, the accidents. But what stays with me from the Schoo episode is what the elder girl said afterward, when she and her sister had run next-door after a smoke alarm went off. She said that she had been lonely.
People were shocked that such a thing could have happened in a prosperous neighborhood. But in her book on America's children, "When the Bough Breaks," the economist Sylvia Ann Hewlett cited a California study of 5,000 eighth graders that concluded it was the affluent children who spent the largest amount of time on their own, apparently because their parents' careers were so time-consuming.
The traditional school schedule is not set up for today's world; more after-school and summer programs would provide at least a safe haven for many children. Nor are traditional work schedules conducive to family life; more flexible arrangements are needed for both mothers and fathers.
But ultimately the issue of how we treat our children is more complex than matters of education and economics. It goes to the question of how much childhood we are willing -- and able -- to allow them. We should not confuse the toughness and savvy we impose out of our own need and fear with real maturity. What the Schoos are accused of doing is an aberration and an outrage, but they did it in an atmosphere that openly treats young children as quasi-adults. Perhaps, more often than any of us realize, many of America's kids are home alone -- and lonely.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 3-8

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Little Leftover Untidiness From President Bush 

As President Bush scurries around trying to leave the White House policy agenda as tidy as possible for the next occupant -- he concluded an arms agreement with Russia and is nearing a possible trade agreement with the rest of the world -- one unsightly blemish remains from his Administration: the Federal deficit. The latest figures, released last week, put it at $290.2 billion for 1992, a record. That was less than the White House had originally projected, but its new forecasts were really scary -- a deficit of $292.4 billion in 1994, rising to $305 billion in 1997. What is even worse, unpublished reports from the Office of Management and Budget say the deficit could grow to $400 billion by 1997 if current programs simply keep pace with inflation. So much red ink -- interest payments alone were $199 billion last year on the nation's $3 trillion debt -- will make it more difficult for President-elect Bill Clinton to embark on aggressive spending plans to reanimate the economy. The "math does not work," said the White House budget director, Richard Darman.

Finally, a Season to Celebrate
 
The nation's beleaguered sales clerks and package wrappers -- not to mention its Santas -- knew it was a better shopping season than any recent Christmas past. Last week the statistics confirmed their hunches. Christmas 1992 was the best since 1988 -- the last of the go-go years. December sales at Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's No. 1 retailer, were up 27 percent from last year; the Kmart Corporation said sales rose 9.1 percent for the season. Other department stores prospered as well. December sales "ran ahead of expectations in virtually all areas of our business," said Allen Questrom, chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc.

The Jobless Rate Sticks
 
Most economists, seeing the upturn in the economy, expected to see some improvement in the unemployment rate. Instead, according to the Labor Department, unemployment held steady in December at 7.3 percent, the same as the month before. Though a wash is better than a loss, the signfiicance of the figures is open to interpretation. "The labor force actually contracted in the fourth quarter from the third quarter," said Charles McMillion, president of MBG Information Services in Washington. "That's why unemployment has not risen even though so few jobs have been created."

Reich Replays His Theme
 
When Labor Secretary-designate Robert B. Reich, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School, addressed Congress last week during his confirmation hearings, he reiterated themes he had been developing for years. He talked about pushing companies to spend more on job training and job safety and to invest in other measures to spur competitiveness. An investment "strategy is needed not only to create more jobs, but better jobs," Mr. Reich told a Senate committee. But one proposal from the campaign was absent from Mr. Reich's up-with-business remarks: Bill Clinton's proposal to require major companies to spend 1.5 percent of their payroll on training. "I am not yet sure of the best combination of carrots, sticks, and educational outreach," Mr. Reich said.

Milken, Halfway to Freedom
 
After serving 22 months in a minimum security prison, Michael R. Milken, the financier who virtually invented the junk-bond market, was moved to a halfway house in Hollywood. Mr. Milken's final release will be on March 2, when he will begin community work. Mr. Milken has paid $1.1 billion in fines and settlements, but is still believe to have substantial wealth.

Construction on a Roll
 
At last a little lift in the construction sector. According to the Commerce Department, spending on new construction rose 2.1 percent in November to $441.8 billion from $432.8 billion in October. November's rise was the third monthly increase in a row. But while residential outlays grew by a solid 1.4 percent in the month as prospective home owners took advantage of low mortgage rates, spending on the over-built apartment sector fell by 4.8 percent. "I would expect the residential numbers will continue to climb modestly as the housing market continues to strengthen," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. Mr. Berson was not so optimistic about commercial real estate because of the "high vacancy rates."

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Boeing Is Talking to . . .
 
Which European company will be joining the Boeing Company to build the next-generation jumbo jet? It depends on whom you ask. Last week, John Hayhurst, a vice president at Boeing, said it would soon sign an agreement with Deutsche Aerospace A.G., a unit of Daimler Benz, to determine the feasibility of building a 550- to 800-passenger airliner. Deutsche Aerospace holds a 38 percent stake in Airbus Industrie, Boeing's arch rival in the skies. Airbus is also examining the feasibility of building a super-jumbo jet and some analysts wonder if Boeing's decision to work with Deutsche Aerospace might be part of an effort to draw an important company away from the Airbus project. But according to a report in The Wall Street Journal, British Aerospace P.L.C., which has a 20 percent stake in Airbus, is also talking with Boeing. But that's not all. At a news conference, Airbus said it was considering working with Boeing on a super-jumbo jet. Mr. Hayhurst would confirm only that talks with Deutsche Aerospace were under way.

Pushing Through a Tariff Deal
 
In the diplomatic equivalent of a blitz, the Bush Administration has been trying to cobble together an agreement by the end of this week for a comprehensive reduction in tariffs. The deal would cover a wide range of goods from clothing to fine crystal. Negotiations began when Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, made a quiet visit to London. She met there with Sir Leon Brittan, the British politician, and senior European officials. If a deal can be hatched, it would be brought to Geneva on Friday for the meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. To add to the urgency of the deal, Mrs. Hills has been reminding the Europeans that the free-trading Bush Administration is still legally in charge -- but not for long.

A Get-Together a la Reagan
 
When he was still President-elect, Ronald Reagan had a tete-a-tete along the Texas border with Mexico's then President, Jose Lopez Portillo. Last week, President-elect Bill Clinton carried on the tradition by meeting with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in Austin at the Texas Governor's mansion. Though the meeting was not designed as a negotiating session, the North American Free Trade Agreement was on the agenda. Mr. Clinton supports the agreement with the proviso that rules regarding the environment and labor be strengthened. "It's basically a get-acquainted session," said a Clinton spokesman, George Stephanopoulos.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Next's Next Deal
 
When Steven P. Jobs founded Apple Computer in 1976, he was a revolutionary. Then he started Next Inc., with its Mac-on-steroids software and heavy-duty Motorola hardware. The world's computer mavens appreciated Next's futuristic workstations, but they didn't exactly beat a pathway to the stores. To really take off, Next needed an alliance with a large manufacturer, analysts said. Word leaked out last week that the Hewlett-Packard Company was talking to Next about licensing its innovative Nextstep software. Though the talks began with discussions about a broader relationship between the two companies that would have included hardware, insiders said a software deal would be it -- at least for now.

A Videophone White Sale
 
Love that clever videophone technology but hate the price? Has A.T.& T. got a deal for you. Last week A.T.& T. said it would chop the price of its Videophone 2500 by a third, to $1,000, and send a $500 rebate to anyone who already bought the phone. It takes two videophones, but no special wiring, to hold a televised conversation. But if that deal doesn't grab you, A.T.& T.'s rival, MCI, plans to sell a videophone for $750 with a discount of up to 10 percent for those buying two or more.
 
To the Root of Airline Problems
 
Even the nation's strongest carriers are feeling balance-sheet pain from the fare wars. To cut costs by $400 million a year, United Airlines announced a package of layoffs, fewer flights and other measures like pay cuts for top executives. But United's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, said its problems were those of the industry and called upon President-elect Clinton to appoint a national commission to study the airline business.

Bragging Rights for Taurus
 
After slugging it out for more than a year, it's official: The best-selling car in America is a domestic make. According to figures released last week, the Ford Motor Company's Taurus finally surpassed the Honda Accord as the nation's No. 1 selling car. Ford and Honda were neck and neck in the sales race going into December. But then Ford began offering cut-rate leases and marked-down sticker prices. It also offered large rebates to retail customers -- as high as $1,750 -- and rebates to car-rental companies. That pushed the Taurus over the top. For 1992, 409,751 Tauruses were sold compared with 393,447 Accords. Why go to all that effort -- not to mention expense? "We know that being able to say you are No. 1 makes a difference in the minds of many consumers," said Phil Novell, Ford's general sales manager.

Honda Heads for the Indy

Back in the old days, race cars zipped around the brick yard at Indianapolis powered by big American four-cylinder Offenhauser engines. Then came the svelte Europeans, led by Lotus, with 12 slim cylinders and lots of torque. Last week, Honda said it would begin building its own Indy engine, a big 6.5-liter V-8 model. "Challenges have always been important to the growth and success of Honda," said Thomas G. Elliot, executive vice president of the America Honda Motor Company.

The Airport Builder
 
It was quite a win for Bechtel Civil Inc. The big San Francisco-based construction and engineering company was awarded a $2 billion, 10-year contract to redevelop and expand the Miami International Airport and five neighboring aviation facilities.

HEADLINE: Travel Agencies See Smoother Sailing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
RECESSION has taken a high toll among travel agencies. Many have merged or closed their doors. Yet the worst may be over, according to an assessment of current activities in the industry.
"Clients are very budget conscious and searching for bargains," said Alberta D'Aloia Wort, owner of the Yonkers Travel Bureau. "Still, many say a winter vacation has become a necessity, more important to them than one in the summer. We have just come off the best holiday season we've had in the past three years. And the most popular destination was Disney World." 
 Mrs. Wort, who has headed Yonkers Travel for 34 years, grew up in the industry. The company began as the Yonkers Steamship Bureau in 1920. "It was started by my father and uncle," she said. "Their original customers were Italian immigrants who were members of families being reunited in the United States."
Norman Sherman, a travel consultant who is vice president of the Hudson Valley chapter of the American Society of Travel Agents, and a principal in the Suburban Travel Center in Larchmont, said he sees signs that this year will be a better year for travel agencies.
 
A Turnaround in Sight
 "And just in time, too," Mr. Sherman said. "In the 38 years I have been in business, last year, 1992, was the worst year I have ever seen. In ASTA's Hudson Valley Chapter, which includes Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Sullivan Counties, about 50 or 60 travel agencies either merged or went out of business. Nationwide that figure was 5,000."
In commenting on signs of a turnaround, Mr. Sherman said, "Although most people are still extremely budget conscious and looking for the best travel buy, they are shopping for travel earlier, which is good. The Caribbean is coming back, and Disney World as a destination is very strong. And the best value of all can be found in the cruise market because there are so many new ships operating. There is an excess of cruise capacity, and discounts abound."
 
An Extremely Competitive Industry
 Through the years, Mrs. Wort's company widened its base to serve a more diversified clientele. "We sur ved wars, terrorists and volatile air fares because we've always been quick to adapt to the market," Mrs. Wort said. "We're generalists, not specialists, and we are currently serving three generations of clients. For some, we book African safaris; for others, Amtrak trips."
Mrs. Wort said, however, that the travel industry is extremely competitive.
"In order to stay in business you not only have to give clients a lot of personal service, but you have to be imaginative in opening new markets," she said. "I think it's interesting that one new market we've developed has its roots in the earliest days of the company." It is, she said, the business of booking family reunions, in which people from different parts of the country get together at a resort or on a dude ranch or on a cruise ship for a family celebration. Family reunions also stimulate repeat business, she added.
"Recently we arranged a dude ranch stay for a couple celebrating their 45th wedding anniversary," she said. "The family and members attending ranged in age from a 3-year-old grandchild to the anniversary couple in their 60's, and all of them reported that they had a terrific time."
Equally successful, she said, are packages for couples embarking on second marriages.
"Many couples getting married for the second time are glad to dispense with the traditional ceremony and reception in favor of a wedding trip to an exotic setting," she said. "They're usually accompanied by some friends and family, and all of them will go to Hawaii or St. Thomas for the wedding and a vacation. New types of honeymoons have become very big, and they aren't necessarily expensive. For instance, we just sent eight people in a wedding party to Hawaii on a $500 package per person, which included everything."
Although word-of-mouth recommendations generate considerable business, Mrs. Wort said, she still aggressively pursues new clients. "I feel it's important to use everything at your disposal to keep the business growing," she said. "For instance, we have a toll-free line to make it easy for customers who have moved out of the area to book with us, and I frequently speak to groups about travel, and that stimulates business. I'm also very visible in the community through my activities with civic groups." Her tactics have paid off, she said. "Our fiscal year ends in March, and so far we have been running 10 percent ahead of our best year."
 
A New Mass Market
 What he calls a new mass market is also a reason for optimism, Mr. Sherman said.
"We're beginning to get a lot of younger clients," he said. "The baby-boom generation is coming into its own. They're people who have been around. They're repeat travelers. For them, travel means more than a once-in-a-lifetime trip to Europe, which is what it might have meant to their parents. They value travel and allot a higher percent of their disposable income to it. And while I find they're not necessarily looking for bargains, they are looking for the best value. Value is the key to that market."
Susan Kantor agrees. Mrs. Kantor, a veteran of 40 years in the travel industry, is owner of Noto Travel Service in New Rochelle.
"Our clients, even those taking expensive trips, are more conscious of value than ever," she said. "And, for instance, although Europe is expensive, we have been successfully selling an all-inclusive $600 seven-day package to London. And that's value."
Because of the number of new ships, cruises are the biggest bargain of the season, Mrs. Kantor said, but she added that cruises are not for everyone. "I tell clients, once you're on a ship, you're stuck, you're a captive audience," she said.
 
An Emphasis on Service
 "Ours is a service business and a big part of it is giving clients good advice," she added. "For instance, Cancun is a good value; it's inexpensive now. And there is also great interest in Costa Rica. The Caribbean is expensive, and many people find it boring. The important element in the travel business, I'm stressing, is to help the client make the right decisions."
It is by stressing service, Mrs. Kantor said, that her agency has weathered the recession. "Repeat business and word-of-mouth advertising are the life blood of every travel agency," she said. "However, I'm encouraged by the number of new companies that have moved near our office on Main Street that have been giving us walk-in business. I feel that we will have a good year."
The strongest agencies have been service-oriented agencies, said Mildred Stoker, president of the Alliance of Westchester Travel Agencies, a trade group with more than 100 members in Westchester and Rockland Counties.
"They are the ones who managed to keep their volume high during 1992, which was a most difficult year," Mrs. Stoker said.
As the owner of Stoker Travel in New City, Mrs. Stoker said that at her agency family vacations and winter travel were stronger this year than last.
"We are also doing more group travel, special interest travel and incentive travel," she said.

HEADLINE: At 50, Rights Panel Catches Up to Itself

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THOUGH almost a century after his death Frederick Douglass's vision for an end to racial injustice still eludes the world, to celebrate the anniversary of the oldest racial relations agency in the United States, the words of Mr. Douglass will be brought to Connecticut.
"Presenting Mr. Frederick Douglass: From Slave to Statesman," a one-person show by the actor Frederick Morsell, will be performed at 8 P.M. on Saturday at the Lincoln Theater at the University of Hartford, to begin the 50th-anniversary celebration of the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. 
 Patricia J. Jackson, education and outreach representative for the commission, said there would be several events through the year to commemorate the anniversary, including an awards banquet in June to honor people who have actively worked on civil rights issues over the years, and an international human rights day to close the year in December.
On Jan. 18, Martin Luther King Jr. Day, there will be a bell-ringing ceremony at the Capitol in Hartford, where a replica of the Liberty Bell will be rung in a ceremony from 11 A.M. to noon that the commission will sponsor with the Martin Luther King holiday commission.
Founded in 1943 as the result of an attack on two men on their way to a convention in Memphis, the Connecticut commission predated by more than 20 years the civil rights groups in most other states. Today, the commission investigates about 3,000 allegations of discrimination each year, 90 percent or more involving job discrimination based on age, race, sex or religion.
"Not every state has a commission like this, even today," Ms. Jackson said. "We are fortunate here in Connecticut to have an agency that's been established for so long, and that has the enforcement powers that it has."
 
Progess Noted
 Carroll E. Brown, first vice president of the Connecticut branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which is co-sponsoring "Presenting Mr. Frederick Douglass," said the N.A.A.C.P. appreciated the progress toward racial justice that had been possible in Connecticut because of the commission's work.
"The commission is very effective at letting people know that discrimination is not going to be tolerated, in any form," Ms. Brown said.
Louis Martin, the director of the commission, said the civil rights agency was founded to improve relations between white people and minority groups, but has expanded considerably, becoming the office that enforces civil rights laws for women, people with disabilities, and others.
"The commission has done an outstanding job in its first 50 years," Mr. Martin said. "We've put in place the framework to guarantee people their basic civil rights, but what we need now is something that addresses civil attitudes.
 
50 Years Ago or Today
 "The people who did not have basic political or economic power 50 years ago are the same people who do not have political or economic power today," he said.
The commission was established in 1943 after Dr. John C. Jackson of the Union Baptist Church in Hartford, and the Rev. S. A. Young of Washington, D.C., were attacked on a train on their way to a national Baptist convention in Memphis. They were trying to go from a Pullman car for black people, to a day coach for black people, when they tried to pass through a day coach for white people only.
"There was considerable outrage in Connecticut over the attack, and one of the results was to establish an agency to address race relations in this state," Ms. Jackson said.
The Governor of Connecticut, Raymond E. Baldwin, set up what he called the Connecticut Interracial Commission to conciliate racial disputes, said James Jedrziewski, who has produced a videotape on the history of the commission that will be shown on local access channels on cable television networks around the state.
The commission's enforcement powers began in 1959 with the passage of what was known as the Big Stick bill, Mr. Jedrziewski said. That bill, which passed the legislature after several attempts, allowed the commission to impose injunctions and financial damages in civil rights cases.
"As the civil rights laws were expanded through the 1960's, the focus of the commission expanded," Mr. Jedrziewski said.
 
Promoting Housing
 Mr. Jedrziewski said it was interesting to see how the commission seemed ahead of its time. In the 1960's and 1970's, for instance, it promoted scattered-site public housing for low-income families, reasoning that the only way for people of different backgrounds to get along was for them to live together and get to know one another. But Federal regulations encouraged high-rise public housing complexes that in most cities have become minority ghettos.
"Today we're turning back to the approach the commission preferred many years ago," Mr. Jedrziewski said. "With few exceptions, the high-rises didn't work out at all."
The commission also adapted to changes in society, becoming one of the first to extend civil rights protection to people with AIDS.
"We always took the approach that people with AIDS were protected based on laws prohibiting discrimination against people with disabilities," Mr. Jedrziewski said.
 
Blatant Segregation of Past
 "We still have to get beyond the way people regard each other," he said, "but there has been a lot of progress. When you go back 50 years, as I did researching the video, it's quite surprising how blatantly, totally segregated some sections of society were."
Saturday's presentation should point out some of the progress that has been made. Mr. Douglass, who lived from 1818 to 1895, was a black American born into slavery who rose to lead the fight against it. He escaped his masters in 1838, taught himself to read and write, and became publisher of the Abolitionist newspaper "The North Star." He was later an advisor to Abraham Lincoln and a proponent of women's rights.
Mr. Morsell's portrayal of Mr. Douglass came about when a black clergyman from Los Angeles asked him in 1984 to develop programs that would give ghetto children hope. From that evolved the Frederick Douglass Foundation.
 
'Meaning of the Fourth'
 Mr. Morsell began performing as Frederick Douglass, and has recorded two albums in a series on the Abolitionist's greatest speeches: "The Meaning of the Fourth of July for the Negro," an anti-slavery speech delivered July 5, 1852, and "The Lesson of the Hour," delivered at the World's Fair in 1892 in Chicago. "The Lesson of the Hour" traces how, during Reconstruction, racism developed into attitudes and behavior that remain today.
Mr. Morsell likens the misery ofcities and their drug problems to the conditions of pre-Civil War slavery, and contends education today, as it was then, is the only way out.
Tickets to the event are $19, $15 for students and elderly people, with proceeds benefiting the Roy Wilkins Scholarship Fund of the N.A.A.C.P. and the Martin Luther King Jr. Youth Foundation.
Mr. Jedrziewski said that as the jurisdiction of the commission grew, it evolved. "By the 1970's our caseload had become our major focus; we had turned away from the education and outreach that the commission was founded to do."
Mr. Martin said it has become more and more difficult to keep up with the caseload, particularly given the state's budget problems. Over the last year the commission's staff has shrunk to 99 employees from 112. "Programs like civil rights enforcement and civil rights advocacy are seen as soft programs, and when the budget ax falls it falls on the soft programs first," Mr. Martin said. "I'm anticipating more cuts this year, which means we have to work smarter with the resources that we do have."
 
Few Outright Critics
 Though the program has few outright critics -- "I don't think anyone disagrees with the intent of anti-discrimination laws," said a Bridgeport lawyer who has represented defendants in discrimination cases, Robert B. Mitchell -- some companies which have come under the commission's scrutiny have reservations concerning its investigations. For instance, Mr. Mitchell proposed that if a one-armed homosexual man with AIDS were to file a discrimination complaint against a company the company might receive a request to disclose how many other one-armed homosexual men with AIDS were employed. Other than the physical handicap, he said, a company might not even know whether it had any other homosexuals, or people with AIDS, in its employ.
"You get these requests for tremendous volumes of information," Mr. Mitchell said. "If they would just let us explain what happened in a specific case, a lot of these cases could be a lot simpler."
In the last year or so Mr. Mitchell observed that the commission had sent more cases directly to Superior Court, rather than go through administrative hearings in an attempt to resolve differences. And he said he thought that some of the commission's duties could be assumed by Federal agencies with the same jurisdiction.
"I don't know if any of that translates into a desire to get rid of the commission, because we'd only need something to take its place," Mr. Mitchell said. "As long as society is, quite properly, focused on these kinds of issues, we're going to need something like the commission."
 
Strength and Timeliness
 Even the commission's strongest supporters agree that it could be stronger, particularly in terms of resolving cases in a more timely manner.
"No matter how effective" the commission, "people get frustrated when it takes six months or a year to get results, and it can take longer than that in some cases," Ms. Brown said.
In addition, she said, she would like to see the commission do more self-promotion, and open more regional offices; it now has offices in Waterbury, Bridgeport and Norwich. "They need to be located in every major city," Ms. Brown said. "People in New Haven should not have to drive to Waterbury or Hartford to get a problem solved."
But she said the commission's problems were rooted in its finances. "It's a question of staffing right now, they've got to have more people," Ms. Brown said. "I want to see the commission do more about educational desegregation, to end real estate 'steering,' and to end job discrimination. There are still minorities doing the same job as someone else and being paid less.
"But that takes staff, and more staff means spending more money," Ms. Brown acknowledged.
The commission's director, Mr. Martin, said that was one reason the commission's focus was changing from attacking discrimination case by case to the kind of educational programs that could change people's attitudes. His hope, he said, is to reduce the number of cases coming in, by educating people about the damage discrimination does.
"I think we need to continue to have a strong, vigorous enforcement policy, but what we've done the last 50 years is to say that law enforcement is the method that we're going to use to eliminate discrimination, and it hasn't worked," Mr. Martin said. "What we really need to do is alter the structure that creates the problem. If we don't do that, we're going to see the same problems 50 years from now."

ORGANIZATION: UNIVERSITY OF HARTFORD (57%); UNIVERSITY OF HARTFORD (57%);

HEADLINE: Businesses Join Hospitals to Curb Medical Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SQUEEZED by escalating health care costs and growing pressure from the business community to curb costly expansion programs, Connecticut's hospitals are embarking on a wave of cooperative ventures with one another and with the businesses that help pay their bills.
This new mood of cooperation comes after years of intense competition among hospitals across the state, each trying to offer new services and lure patients from the other, and after frequent clashes between hospital and business leaders over the need for rising hospital budgets and expensive building projects. 
 The reason for the thaw in relations, hospital and business officials say, is primarily a growing awareness that hospitals and businesses have more to gain financially by cooperating than by fighting. The result, they say, could be a more moderate climb in health care costs over the next few years.
At Danbury Hospital, for example, a program started to control the cost of employees out on injury leave has worked so well that it has been adopted by dozens of businesses.
 
Satellite Pharmacies for Employees
 "We started the program just to keep ourselves solvent," said James Gravius, vice president for workers' compensation services at Danbury Hospital. "But no one has anything to lose by working together, and you have everything to gain."
The parent company of Bridgeport Hospital has offered to set up satellite operations of its pharmaceutical department at area companies so their employees can get prescriptions without ever leaving the office.
"If we can get them to sign up all of their employees we can offer them a significant discount," said John K. Evans, the president of NovaMed Corp., a Bridgeport Hospital affiliate. "And we're using our pharmacy to its maximum efficiency."
Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London and William W. Backus Hospital in New London recently agreed to share a single laundry department, rather than each operating its own.
"The Backus laundry reached the end of its life, and it would have cost them $400,000 or more to put in a new one," said a spokesman for Lawrence and Memorial, Kelly A. Anthony. "We give them a better price for four million pounds of laundry a year than they'd get anywhere else.
"Any time we can avoid duplication of services, everybody saves money," Mr. Anthony said.
 
Clash Over Costs
 Hospitals and the business community clashed throughout the 1980's, arguing over whether hospital budgets and building projects were imperative or inflated. Spokesmen for businesses, which pay the bulk of health care costs through their insurance premiums, would show up at health care hearings and demand cutbacks, while hospitals would counter that they had cut back as far as they could. Among the hospitals, the competition was fierce, as each tried to steal business from others. Today that seems to be changing.
"We're starting to see more of these cooperative arrangements," said a member of the State Commission on Hospitals and Health Care, Donald C. Pogue. "But there's a lot of good work still to be done," he said. "There's a lot of potential for savings, while at the same time providing care for people, through cooperation."
Janet C. Spegele, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association -- a group that has bitterly fought hospital rate increases the last several years -- maintained that it was in the best interest of hospitals and businesses to work together in order to realize savings.
Ms. Spegele said one reason for the thaw in the relationship was that hospitals had become more realistic. From 1980 to 1990, there were double-digit increases in hospital rates, some years approaching 20 percent on average. The average increase in 1991 was 8.7 percent and in 1992, 7.6 percent.
Businesses are also taking more of an initiative, Ms. Spegele said. "Business people have served on hospital boards for years, as a civic duty," she said. "Now they've realized they shouldn't be just talking about things like how to raise money for a new wing, but things like how to get injured workers back to the job quickly and safely."
 
Finding Common Ground
 Health care officials have different ideas about why cooperation is suddenly more prevalent. Some say it is because after years of conflict, hospitals and businesses are finally recognizing the things they have in common.
Frank A. Corvino, president of Greenwich Hospital, said that when he was seeking regulatory approval for a $116 million renovation project, he had spent considerable time explaining to the business community how it could actually save money through steps like energy efficiency and better use of space.
"It's a big project, and we want to make sure people understood it," Mr. Corvino said. Businesses are not taking an active role in supporting the project, but they are not going to the hospital commission to oppose it, either.
With 1,100 employees, all covered by a health benefits package, Mr. Corvino said, it was easy to sympathize with the business community about the need for cost control.
"We're a business also, and our health care costs rise at least as fast as everyone else's," he said.
Joseph Coatsworth, vice president of the Connecticut Hospital Association, said another reason for the cooperation might be that the poor economy was forcing people to work together.
"There are a lot of discussions going on," Mr. Coatsworth acknowledged. "Maybe being in a recession is bringing it out."
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has vowed to make Connecticut more competitive in terms of attracting business, Mr. Coatsworth noted. "One result of that has been hospital interest in meeting with business on controlling costs, which is a major issue in terms of competitiveness," he said.
 
Workers' Compensation an Issue
 One of the first areas hospitals are focusing on is workers' compensation costs. Danbury Hospital and several other hospitals around the state are offering programs that teach employers how to reduce the risk of injury in the workplace through proper training, and how to get injured employees back on the job more quickly.
"You spend a couple of hundred dollars now, and you can avoid a slipped disk and thousands of dollars in compensation costs a few years down the road," Mr. Gravius said.
He said that four years ago Danbury was paying an extra $750,000 a year in workers' compensation insurance costs because of excessive injuries. The Danbury Hospital program has worked so well that the hospital has been brought in to consult at 22 other hospitals, including one in California.
The program was also offered to a couple of businesses on a pilot basis two years ago, including Marcus Dairy in Danbury, where the dairy's president, Michael L. Marcus, said it has helped bring runaway costs under control.
"Our workers' compensation costs haven't gone up, but our employee payroll has gone up, and the cost of medical care in general has gone up, during the last two years," Mr. Marcus said. "Just to say our costs haven't gone up means the program has been a tremendous success because, up to the point we joined, our workers' compensation costs had been skyrocketing.
"Both parties have to realize there's more to be gained by cooperating than there is by fighting over who's to blame for rising medical costs," Mr. Marcus concluded.
Marcus Dairy has a satellite operation in New Haven, where the company remains at odds with the local hospitals, and the health care costs have risen, Mr. Marcus said.
 
The Facades Come Down
 "What we're developing in Danbury is a high level of trust between us and the hospital, and us and our employees," he said.
Mr. Gravius said that over the last year, the program has been fully implemented at 25 area companies, and parts of it have been incorporated into the health care plans of 150 other companies. Some are saving 50 percent from what they expected to pay in workers' compensation premiums.
"Once you get on a first-name basis with the people in industry and they realize you want to help them, the facades come down," Mr. Gravius said. "And once they see how this works, they're going to start asking themselves whether there are other areas where they can save by collaborating with hospitals."
MedSpan, a Hartford-based subsidiary of Connecticut Health System, the parent company of Hartford Hospital, is a company that grew out of increasing cooperation between businesses and hospitals. MedSpan has brought doctors, hospitals and other health care providers together into a network that offers companies a what is called "managed care" package, to insure that employees receive no more care than necessary, at the lowest possible cost.
Dr. Howard J. Wetstone, medical director of MedSpan, said hospitals welcomed increased corporate scrutiny of, and participation in, health care decisions, because it makes sense. If a company like United Technologies was buying titanium, he said, it could call on several metallurgists to see if it was getting the best material at the best price.
"But in the health care arena, it was not uncommon for a fairly junior person to be making decisions on the kind of benefits a company would be offering," Mr. Wetstone said.
 
'Tweak the System'
 What employers have done, over the last few years, "is tweak the system," said John R. McDonnell, director of marketing and sales for MedSpan. "They've said, 'if we're going to spend this kind of money, show us where it's going.' And they've sat down with us to figure out where the savings might be."
In New London, the president of Lawrence and Memorial Hospital, William T. Christopher, said the hospital was also working on a plan to bring the hospital, the area's doctors and businesses into a network that would give health care providers the volume they needed to provide care at lower cost, so everyone wins.
Providers, insurers and employers are often at odds with one another, Mr. Christopher said, but it does not have to be that way.
"You've got to get at least two of the three players together, at least," Mr. Christopher said. "A providers-employers network is the best combination, because they've got the most to gain, or lose."
 
Push From Clinton
 Everyone agrees that with President-elect Bill Clinton promising to focus on making health care more accessible and affordable, the arrangements are likely to multiply quickly.
"The health care landscape is changing, and the changes are not in the direction of an island mentality, the belief that we can do it alone," Mr. Christopher said. "The change is, more people are thinking we can do more by joining forces.
"You can't do it by yourself anymore, and you don't want to," Mr. Christopher continued. "Hospitals have to look for strategic partnerships -- someone to share the risks, and the rewards."

HEADLINE: WHAT WORKS;
Creating a Space Called School

BYLINE: By JILL JORDAN SIEDER

 BODY:
AFTER 12 years of watching her students perform poorly and express open disdain for the concept of school, Cheryl Deaton, the principal of West Forest Intermediate School in Opelika, Ala., decided to make several radical breaks with tradition. All were designed to remove what she considered to be structural impediments to learning among her students, 57 percent of whom are black and 5 percent Asian, mostly Laotians, and 70 percent of whom come from one-parent, blue-collar families in a town where many adults never graduated from high school and unemployment is high.
Some of those impediments, Mrs. Deaton says, were rules and policies that were too rigid or impractical for her school. Other obstacles derived from the home lives of students, many of whom have never been read to by a parent. Together they produced an environment that was antagonistic toward children, she says. 
 Opelika is a manufacturing town of 21,500 that features textile mills and auto-parts makers; West Forest, which includes grades 3 to 5, had been stigmatized locally as the "backward mill school." But by late 1990 teachers there had assembled a reform plan that would tailor school programs to the needs of the students and their families. That plan was impressive enough to win a $750,000 grant from RJR Nabisco's educational foundation. Local and state school officials then gave the school a green light. Project Space was born.
 
Reading as a Goal
 The reforms had a simple set of objectives: to restructure the school and its teaching methods in a way that would increase student motivation to succeed, improve parental involvement in the learning process and reinvigorate the teaching staff. A primary goal was to increase the amount of time that students and their parents spent reading, individually and together, in hopes that scholastic improvement would follow. Another goal was to transform West Forest into an inviting, not a confining, place to spend the day.
First to go were such time-honored practices as reliance upon textbooks as the primary teaching tool and ability grouping, in which faster learners were channeled into one set of classes and activities while the physically handicapped and slower learners were channeled into another.
Mrs. Deaton did away with the standard classroom setup of rows of desks facing a blackboard and a teacher, which she says takes "ownership of learning" away from students, creating a prison-like atmosphere.
Bells do not ring and students do not change rooms. Children with learning, speech or hearing disabilities are not shuttled out of the main class to another room; the special education teacher comes to them. Anything that smacks of segregated learning, of what Mrs. Deaton calls "the caste system in public schools" that creates undue feelings of inferiority -- or superiority -- had to go.
In its place has come an educational approach based on teamwork and group learning, where teachers plan lessons together, students tutor one another and parents act as policy makers, classroom aides and at-home tutors. For most of the day students remain in the same room, organized into stations of five or six desks that face each other. Ideally, two children of average aptitude are clustered with one faster and one slower learner.
Teachers act more as "learning partners" than as classroom authorities, letting students direct discussions and plan class projects when possible. Disciplinary techniques that emphasize penalties for bad behavior have given way to less confrontational methods. Now, says Mrs. Deaton, a disruptive student is not automatically sent to the principal's office or hallway, but to a "time-out" corner in the classroom "where he can cool off and still benefit from the ongoing instruction." Later the teacher will talk to the student about his conduct and have him fill out a form explaining his actions.
 
Small-Group Lessons
 Many lessons at West Forest are taught with 20 children sitting cross-legged on the carpet in cozy circles, knees touching, encouraging more eye contact and participation. Recently, fourth graders presenting oral book reports in this fashion were so animated in their discussion of "My Girl," the book and the popular film starring the preteen idol Macaulay Culkin, that their teacher, Sylvia Gill, extended the session 20 minutes instead of turning to a scheduled math lesson. That simple move would not have been possible if the state had not waived a policy mandating a tightly segmented school day.
An 18-year veteran of the Opelika school system, Ms. Gill says she was used to having to pry comments out of pupils whose low literacy levels made a reading of a district-recommended classic such as "Charlotte's Web" a chore for many. She attributes the new-found enthusiasm to a curriculum flexibility that allows children and their parents to choose the books they read, noting that literature from the popular culture often reinforces the notion that reading can be fun.
"I was on the verge of early retirement before we changed things around," Mrs. Gill said. "Now I'm seeing the lights go on in their heads again, which is why I got into teaching."
One of those lights has illuminated Melanie Strozier, 11, a fifth grader at West Forest. Formerly shy and troubled about her mother's divorce, Melanie no longer cries in school. Now she leads class discussion and has starred in two class plays. "In the third grade we just went by the book," Melanie said. "It was kind of boring. Now we do all kinds of projects and plays, and read more exciting things, and it's a lot more fun."
Monica Hicks-Crump, 31, said her son, Robbie, a third grader, "began begging me to buy him a telescope and books on astronomy" after his social studies, science, math, art and music classes did an interdisciplinary study of the space age. "He's even asking for encyclopedias," Mrs. Hicks-Crump said. "It's hard to believe."
Elbert Smith, 8, described as a "sometimes mischievous and rambunctious" student, has been behaving better since he began participating in a group counseling session offered to all students every morning. "The counseling group is fun," Elbert said, "because you get to help other people solve their problems. We joke around a bit, and then we have a true talk. It gives us a chance to get to know each other."
One of the most popular features of Project Space is the extended school day, which begins at 7 A.M. with an enrichment period called "Blast-off," to accommodate the 75 or so children whose parents' schedules demand they be dropped off early. Children choose among board games, coloring books, rope-jumping and other activities that prime them for the start of school.
At 2:45 P.M., those enrolled in the "Odyssey" after-school program engage in art, music, athletic and club activities until 5:30, when their parents can pick them up. One day the Lovers of Construction were building houses out of Popsicle sticks, while the Young Astronauts were assembling small-scale working rocket ships.
About two-thirds of West Forest's 400 students participate in at least one of the programs, which cost their parents $7 per week. The financial break it gives single parents who cannot afford day care, much less music instructors, has generated measurable good will among parents. Mrs. Deaton says it is largely responsible for the dramatic increase in parental voluntarism, which zoomed from 25 hours logged among 5 parents in 1990 to 1,500 hours among 75 parents last year.
Tara Burton, for example, is a divorced 28-year-old mother of two who works the third shift, midnight to 8 A.M., on the assembly line of the nearby Uniroyal Tire plant. Ms. Burton, whose son, Anthony, was suspended several times last year for bad behavior, says she used to "cancel out" on parent-teacher conferences, because she had an image of school officials as snobbish. Now she is a regular volunteer in the school library, and a counselor says her presence in the school has helped Anthony to "settle down" in the classroom.
Wanda Lewis, a mother who coordinates a parent volunteer center in the school, says that parents are influencing more than morale. Recently they have brought such multicultural fare into the classrooms as the African-American celebration of Kwanzaa, a tradition emphasizing spirituality and African ancestry; Laotian cuisine and origami, and frank discussions of Malcolm X.
The result, Mrs. Deaton says, is that students are better motivated. Standardized test scores of fourth graders rose significantly last year, while disciplinary problems and suspensions schoolwide have been dramatically reduced. "These kids smile when they walk into the building now," she said.
 
$250,000 in Grants
 Perhaps the best news is that local school officials, politicians and businesses are buying into the project. Mrs. Deaton says she has secured $250,000 in grants from foundations and 13 business partners, including the College of Education at Auburn University.
Auburn students and faculty members are using West Forest for training and teaching purposes, extending professional development and library privileges to the West Forest faculty in turn. The Opelika City Council has appropriated one-third of the $3 million needed for a new school building. And Phil Raley, superintendent of Opelika city schools, says the school district plans to assume the costs of the extended day and parenting programs, and is replicating the cooperative teaching techniques in other district schools.
Still, Mrs. Deaton insists, "Even if we didn't have the money to keep up the wild growth, this school will never be the same again. We've just come too far."

HEADLINE: Open Markets Before Open Societies?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Schools in China Try a Sideline: Making Money" (news article, Dec. 27), on China's national obsession, coupled with your front-page report the same day on the struggle for a free press in Eastern Europe, suggests it is easier to start the pursuit of material well-being than to spread democratic ideas and practices in Communist societies, past or present. 
 Just a day earlier, a New Year's card arrived from one of my college professors, an idealist and traditional Chinese scholar in Beijing, telling of his tearful plea at an academic conference for more Government support to train more professional journalists. While declaring such pleas hopeless, he wrote with much more enthusiasm about the prospects of joint-venture businesses. He invited me and my husband, and our friends in the United States, to make business investments in these projects, for which he would then draw commissions.
From Beijing to Prague and Moscow, such contrasts of frustration and optimism are no rarity. Is there hope for democracy, for higher ideals, when intellectual pursuits operate not in a marketplace of ideas but in the marketplace of profits and losses? Is there hope for democracy, for a more open society, when those in power can still arbitrarily decide what the news media can and cannot say?
Perhaps hope lies elsewhere. Roper's public opinion surveys in the former Soviet Union point to the emergence of a new economic sector of men and women (some of the intelligentsia, some not) whose primary income comes from family businesses, private companies, shareholding or foreign-owned companies. A growing 10 percent to 15 percent of the adult population, they make at least three times as much money as their average compatriots. They are also more likely to support free expression and other individual freedoms.
They may not be spokesmen of democracy yet. But their growing importance in a more open market just might lead to a quest for freedom of information and expression, to political participation and to a more open society.
 
XIAOYAN ZHAO
New York, Dec. 28, 1992
The writer, a vice president of the Roper Organization, directs Roper's public opinion and leader surveys in Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The New Congress;
3 CONGRESSMEN SAY DEFICIT MAY DELAY CLINTON'S TAX CUT

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Three Democratic Congressional leaders said today that a tax cut for the middle class, one of President-elect Bill Clinton's major campaign promises, might have to be put off because of the soaring Federal budget deficit.
The leaders, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, and Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, all made similar comments in nationally televised interviews. 
 Their tone made it clear that the Congressional Democrats, who twice passed bills with middle-class tax cuts last year in efforts to embarrass President Bush, would not hold Mr. Clinton's feet to the same fire and would support his economic proposals, whether or not they emerge with promised tax cuts.
 
Fading Promise
 On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, used the new, sharply higher Bush Administration estimate of the 1997 deficit -- $305 billion instead of the $237 billion it had forecast in July -- to suggest that it might not be possible for Mr. Clinton to keep his promise to cut the deficit in half in four years.
Mr. Stephanopoulos did not mention the deficit's impact on the tax-cut pledge and would not discuss it directly when asked about it today, saying instead, "As circumstances change, you must examine every part of the program."
A top Republican, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said today that Mr. Clinton should have known by late summer that the deficit was going to be larger than the Administration's July estimate, and he indicated that he thought Mr. Clinton would have to raise, not lower, taxes.
 
Fairness Issue
 Throughout his campaign, Mr. Clinton said he favored a middle-class tax cut of a few hundred dollars a year. In September his campaign issued a plan saying, "We should cut middle-class taxes immediately by 10 percent." The plan did not define "middle class," but toward the end of the campaign, aides said it covered families with incomes below about $80,000.
The plan also called for "up to an $800-per-child tax credit" as a more valuable replacement for the existing $2,150 exemption. A credit reduces taxes; an exemption reduces the income base on which taxes are calculated.
Later the Clinton campaign said those two cuts were alternatives. Recently the President-elect has argued for a cut, not in hope of stimulating the economy but as a way to undo what he contended was the favoritism toward the rich of tax laws developed under President Ronald Reagan. If the tax system were fairer, he has said, Americans would be more inclined to make other sacrifices.
Mr. Clinton and his aides are developing their economic program but have offered few clues on their thinking. It is apparently taking longer than they had expected.
Congressional leaders have voiced no concern over the delay.
Today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Senator Mitchell said, "I think it's more important to make the right decision than it is to make a fast decision, of course, and I think he's doing the right thing in reviewing it very carefully."
 
Pessimism on Tax Cut
 Mr. Foley was asked on the same program if he still thought Congress would pass a middle-class tax cut. He replied: "I'm not sure, in the light of the present circumstances, that that shouldn't be rethought. I really think we might have to look carefully at how extensive a middle-income tax cut should be taken at this time in view of the problems of the deficit."
He said any cut should be aimed at families with children.
Mr. Mitchell said: "I will accept whatever decision President Clinton makes in that regard and support it. I would still like to see the tax code made more fair. If we can do it this year, fine. If we can't, and because of the deficit which you mentioned, which is a serious consideration, then at the earliest opportunity at the future."
Representative Fazio was asked on the ABC News program "This Week" if he wanted a middle-class tax cut. "Personally, I have been for it," he said. "Whether we can afford it under these circumstances is questionable."
 
Consensus Not Orchestrated
 A highly placed Democratic aide on Capitol Hill said there had been no consultation to make sure all three offered the same message. But he agreed that it would have been easy for the Congressmen to avoid answering the question at all, and that, planned or not, their answers reflected a consensus.
But Senator Dole scoffed at the Democrats' assertion that a bigger budget deficit was sudden news, saying Mr. Clinton had been warned in August that the earlier estimates were off.
Mr. Dole said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that the warning had come from the Congressional Budget Office. "Congressional Budget Office is Democrats," he said. "He relied on their figures, and they revised their figures in August by about $50 billion, but he ignored those figures. Now he's saying, 'Oh, this is worse than we thought.' "
Recalling President Bush's broken promise not to raise taxes, he said, "It could be 'read my lips' all over again."
Mr. Dole said he might support a gasoline tax increase "if it's dedicated, if you're certain it's going to go into building roads and bridges, or maybe half of it to reduce the deficit." But he said it would be politically difficult to enact.
Mr. Foley also said he favored a higher gasoline tax, but Mr. Mitchell said the time was not right.

HEADLINE: Castro's People Try to Absorb 'Terrible Blows'

SERIES: Cuba Alone -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
His island ever more an island, his scraggly beard gone gray, President Fidel Castro stands fast against the winds that have blown away most of the Communist world, along with its subsidies for Cuba and its markets for Cuban goods.
"Only socialism, only the revolution could absorb the terrible blows that we have received," the 66-year-old leader says. 
 Billboards and signs around the country proclaim the same faith. "Join us and you'll make it," promises one just outside Havana. On a wall not far from the Havana airport, the faded scrawl says, "We have Fidel."
 
Mood of Grim Sacrifice
 As the material cost of Cuba's isolation grows, however, its mood these days is less one of heroic struggle than grim sacrifice.
In the long, concrete-block apartment buildings that the revolution built and in the crumbling old Havana homes it subdivided for workers' housing, peoples' memories of meat have begun to fade. Pork, a Cuban favorite, cannot be obtained except on the black market, where one pound costs nearly a week's wages for the average person.
As a beef substitute, a television chef recommends "grapefruit steak." Carefully remove the rind, the recipe goes, season it, cover it with bread crumbs and fry. But in search of more solid food, several Cubans said they had eaten cats.
 
Long Wait for a Bus
 On weekdays, the capital's still-gracious avenues have become gantlets of blank, sullen stares. So many bus routes have been eliminated that the wait for a crosstown ride can take three hours or more. Not a dilapidated, Hungarian-made bus moves that does not spill riders from its doors.
In Trinidad, a quaint colonial town near the center of the island, a woman behind the bus station ticket window allows that the next available reserved seat to Havana is on a bus leaving in three months. But not to worry, she says, there is a waiting list.
To get people to their jobs, a million or so bicycles have been brought from China. Even on major thoroughfares, the workers riding them weave across all lanes of traffic, as though automobiles had never been a concern.
The cars are, in fact, relatively few. From 10 gallons of gasoline some months ago, the monthly rations for most drivers have been cut to about five gallons. In December they got none.
High school students and boiler repairmen can explain this as easily as Government economic officials: With the collapse of the Soviet bloc and its preferential prices for barter trade with the island, Cuba's income has fallen precipitously, while the cost of imports like oil has risen sharply. In 1992, officials said, the island took delivery on about 6 million tons of oil, down from 13 million tons in 1989.
Encouraged by a new trade protocol signed with Russia in November, Cuban officials said they expected about the same amount of oil in 1993. But in December, they extended electrical-power blackouts in Cuba's biggest cities from four hours a day to eight.
The important state offices and enterprises that earn dollars and are exempted from the outages -- hotels, tourist restaurants, certain factories -- flicker like candles in the night. At many intersections, the traffic lights dangle lifelessly from power lines. Television programming has been cut, and even night baseball games have become rare.
Slowly, as the island's imports have fallen by more than three-fourths, cherished social achievements of the revolution have also begun to erode. In the best hospitals, some medicines are being replaced by herbal remedies. Chalk, paper and even milk are sometimes scarce in the schools.
 
Castro Maintains A Core of Support
 In a society that prides itself on a literacy rate comparable to that of industrialized nations, shipments of new books are so infrequent that a modest book fair in December drew a line nearly three city blocks long. Many newspapers and magazines have been shut down for lack of newsprint, and the Communist Party daily, Granma, has become precious not only for its news but as a substitute for toilet paper.
For the first time, the Government has acknowledged a modicum of unemployment because of factories shut down and jobs eliminated. Of about 3.7 million state workers, they say, slightly more than 100,000 now stay at home; many more have been sent off to work in the fields. Foreign economists guess that real unemployment is considerably higher, and that close to half the work force is underemployed.
Still, in hundreds of conversations during a visit of nearly three weeks to the island, it appeared that the Government had managed to maintain a substantial, if unmeasurable, core of support even as it was running out of everything from antibiotics to soap and shoes.
Its health and education systems, although badly strained, continue to function. And while preserving a system of small rewards and perquisites for its partisans, the Government has managed to keep an extremely tight grip on dissent.
Faith that Mr. Castro can restore Cuba to even the relative prosperity it enjoyed with annual Soviet subsidies that once ranged upwards from $3 billion seemed rare even among Cubans supportive of the Government. But many people said they saw their options unchanged: tolerate the hardship or try somehow to leave.
Behind the counter of a grocery store on Havana's southern edge, a heavy-set 28-year-old worker looked out the other evening on the somber customers lined up before him for a cup of oil, some sugar, a few scoops of rice.
"To put up with things," he said, "is a national custom."
Although many Cubans have grown more desperate and some more open about criticizing the Government, there is almost no sign that they are any more willing to challenge its power.
"The level of disenchantment is very high," a Western diplomat said. "But the prospect of anybody doing anything about it is very low because of the danger involved."
In recent months, analysts say, the economy's dramatic contraction has begun to slow. But after a year that Mr. Castro pronounced the most difficult in the difficult 35 years since the revolution, the official forecast is that 1993 may well be even tougher.
 
U.S. Tightens Economic Embargo
 The United States, sensing a chance to succeed where it has failed for three decades, has sought to deepen the island's isolation by tightening its economic embargo. And increasingly, local inefficiency and the loss of solidarity prices from the former Soviet bloc have receded from the official explanation for Cuba's troubles.
Two years after Mr. Castro pronounced the economic crisis "a special period in time of peace," Cubans are being told more and more of an undeclared war being waged against them by the world's last superpower. America's weapon of destruction, the radio and television news repeat, is "the Torricelli Law."
The law, known on the island for its chief sponsor, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, prohibits foreign subsidiaries of American companies from doing business with the island, and bars foreign ships that trade there from docking at United States ports for six months.
But while economic analysts believe that the law will dissuade some American companies from trading with Cuba, many of them expect that it will merely inconvenience rather than threaten the Cuban Government in the long run.
In the meantime, diplomats and Cuban dissidents said the law had given Mr. Castro a political boost by making it look as though the United States was bullying a small, geopolitically harmless country and adding to the suffering of its captive people. In a vote of the United Nations General Assembly on Nov. 25, many allies of the United States backed Cuba in a non-binding resolution condemning the embargo.
"All the Torricelli law did was to strengthen the only argument that the Government had left for maintaining its intransigent position," said Vladimiro Roca, a moderate political dissident who is the son of one of Cuba's revolutionary heroes, Blas Roca.
As ever, the central theme of official propaganda is that imperialism rather than socialism is at the source of Cuba's problems, and a sense of siege is cultivated. Despite the shortages of materials that have crippled other construction projects, the Government reported that it was able this year to triple the number of "people's tunnels" to be used in the event of a United States attack.
 
Feeding a Family Is a Challenge
 Socialism, in the current formulation, is the guarantee that Cubans will suffer more or less equally.
"What we have, we distribute in the most equitable way possible," Mr. Castro assured members of an American religious group that defied the embargo to bring food to the island in early December. To feed and clothe a family, however, has become an almost herculean task.
"If you have to be at work at eight, you get up before 5 to get the bread," a 48-year-old housewife explained.
The bread allotment, one roll per person, is served with sugary hot water in lieu of coffee. "It does not taste very good, either, but if you don't eat that little bread, you won't have the energy to pedal to work," she said.
The woman, the wife of a once-devout Communist Party member grown disenchanted, looked both slightly haggard and vaguely stylish, and the same could be said of their 1950's-style ranch house in what was once an upper-middle-class neighborhood of Havana. The freezer contained only a brick-like bag of tomato puree; in the refrigerator there were a few eggs and water.
In theory, the woman said she needed to shop only once a month for the family's rice (five pounds per person), beans (one pound) and sugar (four pounds), although it usually took more than one trip to find even that.
Monthly rations of cooking oil (about two cups), soap (half a bar per person), coffee (four ounces) and Chinese toothpaste, which is sometimes used as a detergent substitute, rarely seem to arrive on schedule.
Since the 12-ounce monthly rations of chicken have dried up, the family's butcher has sold them only four items: eggs (four per person each week), small frozen fish, tomato puree and a concoction of soy, gristle and meat remains that is euphemistically called "soy hamburger."
 
Why Everyone Is Not DeadZ
 "If you look at the ration book and you look at what is in the stores, you have to wonder why everyone is not dead," a diplomat said. "The reason is that the black market is flourishing."
In some neighborhoods, the black market -- known as the bolsa, or "exchange" -- is merely the under-the-counter sale of items that are usually rationed over the counter but are skimmed off or otherwise procured by the grocer. Food is often sold surreptitiously from aged delivery trucks, and travelers returning from the countryside are often searched for food bought from farmers. But everyone, it seems, has "contacts."
Many Cubans have some savings in pesos. But since there is so little to buy and demand has risen so sharply, underground prices have spiraled upward with the black-market currency-exchange rate. With the dollar now trading at more than 40 times its official equivalency to the Cuban peso, a $2.75 chicken can cost about the monthly minimum wage of 108 pesos, and a $10 case of beer four times that.
To overcome the obstacles to consumerism or survival is to engage in the fundamental activity of Cuban life: resolviendo, or "resolving things."
One might "resolve" a few liters of gasoline from a relative who works at a service station. A piece of beef might be "resolved" from a pregnant friend who receives it as part of a special ration. But when one's jewelry, tennis shoes and other effects have been sold off, one generally must hustle the currency with which to resolve.
 
'Turned Us All Into Thieves'
 "They have turned us all into thieves," a 28-year-old engineer complained as he hid in a dark corner of a party. The man, who seemed distraught and slightly drunk, described himself as a committed socialist. But he said he had turned to repairing appliances and doing other illicit jobs in his spare time.
"You steal a little here," he said. "You sell a little there. Nobody wants to do it, but everyone does it. We are human. We are weak. We want a pair of shoes. Good cigarettes. And I find myself doing things that are very tough."
The man referred to the young free-lance prostitutes who have become a ubiquitous nocturnal presence in Havana, hissing loudly at tourist cars and offering their companionship to foreigners for a dinner, a dress, some shampoo. "I understand those little girls," he said.
For members of the Cuban elite, there are still special privileges: gasoline for cars, inconspicuous stores where they can shop for imported goods, trips abroad.
Workers who amass hundreds of hours of voluntary service in the fields or factories might still receive bicycles or motorcycles or modest vacations at the beach. But it is no longer unusual to see lieutenant colonels in the army or Interior Ministry riding bicycles, waiting endlessly for buses or even hitchhiking.
From time to time, Mr. Castro betrays what seem to be flashes of pain at seeing his countrymen delivered to a poverty that differs from that of their Latin American neighbors chiefly in that it tends to come with a job, free health care and small portions of food. But while even some Communist Party members express doubts about whether Cubans' patience might last the long years that any real economic recovery would take, their leader shows none.
"It is an epic struggle in which we find ourselves," Mr. Castro told an audience of construction workers recently. "We have had to give up many of the things in which we were involved, but what we will never give up is hope."
Next: Cuba tries to turn the ailing economy around.
