HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Fashion Neophyte Steps in at British Vogue

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
She has written for Tina Brown, been employed by Anna Wintour's stepmother and succeeded Elizabeth Tilberis as the editor of British Vogue. Can the top of an American masthead be far behind?
Alexandra Schulman got the job even though she has no fashion background. She was previously editor of British GQ, having gone there from Vogue where she was Ms. Tilberis's features editor. Now that she's back, British Vogue, which celebrated its 75th anniversary last year, seems to be thriving. 
 Stephen Quinn, its publishing director, says that since Ms. Schulman's first issue in June, circulation has risen more than 3 percent, to 186,000 from 180,000. Mr. Quinn says that 143,000 issues are sold in Britain and 43,000 are sold internationally, giving it the largest international circulation of any Vogue. "The essence of Vogue's authority here is as the fashion leader," he says, "though it has a bigger curiosity than just that of the fashion world."
 
A Lucrative Position
 The editorship of British Vogue is a job that led both of Ms. Schulman's predecessors to New York as winners of the publishing world's equivalent of the Lotto jackpot. When Ms. Tilberis became editor of Harper's Bazaar, her salary was estimated at $1.25 million, including a Manhattan townhouse and garden and private school tuition. When Ms. Wintour, who was Ms. Tilberis's predecessor, became editor of American Vogue, she was said to have had an equal compensation package, plus a clothing allowance rumored to be tens of thousands of dollars a year.
So, in what is becoming a grand tradition of British women dictating American fashion, Ms. Schulman, who is 35, has, as one slightly sour editor in New York puts it, "taken her place on the conveyor belt." Whether she will stay on it, however, remains to be seen. No one in New York has offered her a job -- yet.
"It's a new game, really, all these British people going to New York," Ms. Schulman says in her sparely decorated office, with clocks on the wall for London, Paris and New York. She is smart, serious and unsmiling. This is not a boss for anyone looking for a long, lazy lunch hour.
"The money there is certainly different," she continues. "I'll be interested to see how it all works out, who will survive, who won't. Everyone's looking for a chance to change their life. I changed mine when I came here."
 
'More Intellectual Range'
 That change, Mr. Quinn says, can only help the magazine. "Alex's contacts in literary society are pretty impressive and we like that," he says. "The incredibly upwardly mobile society of the 80's has come to a lurch in the road and we don't want an obsessive focus on designer this or that. We wanted more intellectual range, which we had slightly jettisoned and everything was just fashion, fashion, fashion. Vogue always had honored great painters, authors, film directors, but that sensibility had somehow diminished. Alex has the editing flair to bring that back without losing the sense of focus or direction in fashion."
Indeed, in 1992, he adds, 1,250 pages of advertising were sold for British Vogue, which is owned by Conde Nast. "That is in a recession year," he notes, "while its rivals -- Elle, Marie Claire, Harpers and Queen -- sold 1,000 pages or less. And we charge much higher rates than they do. So, we beat the pants off the competition, as you might say in the States."
The circulation is tiny compared with American Vogue's 1.3 million. But Mr. Quinn says that unlike the States where 50 to 70 percent of most magazines are sold by subscription, "the newsstand here is where the action is. Ninety percent of our sales are newsstand, which is a genuine response to the magazine, going back to the consumer every single month and winning that vote."
Which might explain how British editors have learned to keep their edges sharp. Of the British triumvirate that defines power in New York magazine publishing, Ms. Schulman speaks admiringly of Ms. Wintour and Ms. Tilberis. Though her tone does not change when it comes to Ms. Brown, the formidable former editor of Vanity Fair and the formidable new editor of the New Yorker, Ms. Schulman can sum up her success in two words. "Tina," she says, "is spiritually American."
 
'An Ineffable Glamour'
 Which leaves some American editors wondering where their spirits went wrong as they watch the job market shrink. When Susan Morrison, the new editor of the weekly newspaper The New York Observer, spoke of the publisher at its fifth anniversary party, she said, "I want to toast Arthur Carter for so consistently defying the conventional wisdom, and I'm not referring to his decision to hire an American editor."
In an interview, Ms. Morrison said, "Starting with Tina, there's an important track record. Anna has succeeded in revivifying Vogue. British editors are regarded as a proven formula. There seems to be a faddishness about it, though, something exotic. There is an idea that the British make better editors because they are more in tune with the language. But I think it has something to do with an ineffable glamour Americans associate with anyone or anything foreign."
Another American editor says the British bring the reckless quality of the outsider to their jobs: "They're willing to try anything, offend anyone. They're not on their home turf."
Ms. Schulman says: "English people go to America with the idea that you can get anything done, get what you want. In England you are always rather bound by notions of what you can and cannot do."
So far, at least, Ms. Schulman seems to have eschewed most rules and labels, defining her mission as one of range. "We are covering style and fashion in the broadest sense," she says. "And we don't have an age standard. In December we had Bono and Christy Turlington in leather jeans on our cover. In January it is a beautiful classic car coat. It is very important to do both."
Or she might just be hedging her bets. The British press has made much of the fact that when it comes to personal wardrobe, Ms. Schulman could learn a thing or two from Ms. Tilberis's trademark Chanel, and that she could also become better acquainted with a hairbrush. Her outfit is a short jacket the color of dried blood with a heavy velvet scarf coiled into the collar, long skirt, platform shoes. Her skin is very white, her hair is very black -- and uncombed -- and she is not wearing any makeup. She looks like a graduate student all dressed up to defend her thesis.
 
'A Subject for Chatter'
 "My lack of a traditional fashion background was a subject for chatter the first couple of months," Ms. Schulman acknowledges. "But I've always worked in glossy magazines, so words and pictures are a package with me. I like to featurize fashion, adding a story to give it another dimension, not just showing very expensive clothes floating around that people can't afford. We are very consciously trying to watch the price range and look at fashion in a broader arena, giving the reader options, not just one image."
And how old is the Vogue reader?
She seems caught off guard. She calls out to her assistant, "Do you know the average age of the reader?" The woman looks blank. Ms. Schulman shakes her head. "I don't know. 20-29 is strong. And 40-45 again." What happens in between? "They're all having babies and can't afford magazines," she says shortly, clearly irritated at not knowing the answer.
Raised in a family of journalists, there is not much about the business that escapes her. Milton Schulman, her father, was the drama critic for The Evening Standard before becoming a columnist there. Her brother Jason is an art director at Tatler, her sister, Nicola, a senior writer at Harpers and Queen. Her mother, Drusilla Beyfus, herself a former features editor at Vogue, now works part time as an editor for the Telegraph magazine and writes books.
Ms. Schulman's career began at Over 21 magazine, which was founded by Audrey Slaughter, who is married to Ms. Wintour's father. She was hired at Tatler in 1982 after writing an article for Tina Brown.
Maybe she's too deeply ensconced in the British magazine world to ever relocate to New York. Certainly, her work to broaden Vogue has only begun.
"Well, what's great about New York," she says, "is you just walk out the front door and there seems to be a story there." She hesitates. "I guess the ideal life would be to spend a certain amount of time in New York and here."
As all the clocks on the wall show that time is up, she walks to her office door. The conversation turns toward the evening and plans to see her boyfriend. She is told that it is the opening night of Kenneth Branagh's "Hamlet" at the Royal Shakespeare Company.
"Oh how lovely," she says brightly. But when she hears that the performance lasts four and a half hours, her tone shifts. And finally, she smiles.
"Even I'm not that broad."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Media Business page yesterday about changes at British Vogue magazine under its new editor identified her incorrectly. She is Alexandra Shulman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Everyone's looking for a chance to change their life," said Alexandra Schulman, editor of British Vogue. "I changed mine when I came here." (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Economics, a Subtle Exclusion

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 8

 BODY:
The glass ceiling for women in economics is rather thick. Only a handful are tenured professors at the nation's top-ranked universities. Men dominate the prestigious specialty of theorizing about how economies work. And whenever women ask the American Economic Association to set up a child-care center for the group's annual three-day meeting, their request is turned down.
How to break into the top ranks is a subject of endless discussion among women in the field. Lacking female mentors in the best graduate schools, burdened with child rearing and generally less interested than the men in becoming high priests of theory, the women view themselves as subtly excluded from the mainstream of their profession. 
 "I actually see young women being discouraged by men from trying to become top-ranked theorists," said Elizabeth Hoffman, an economics professor at the University of Arizona's business school and the chairman of the Committee on the Status of Women in the Economics Profession. "Their work is never considered by the men to be quite good enough."
Over the last decade, 22 percent of all Ph.D.'s in economics have gone to women. They move easily into entry-level jobs. At the 80 universities with graduate-level economics programs, 20 percent of the assistant professors hired soon after graduate school are women. But women account for only 8 percent of associate professors at these schools, and less than 4 percent of the tenured professors.
Even outside academia, there are barriers for women in economics, said Carol Carson, who heads the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. Though women are hired as often as men for entry-level economics jobs in the Federal Government, studies show that after five years, women receive fewer promotions than men, she said during a discussion of women's issues at the annual meeting here of the American Economic Association, which ended Thursday.
 
Changes Noted
 Now the discussions are moving beyond the economists themselves to a broader national audience. President-elect Bill Clinton's selection of Laura D'Andrea Tyson as the first woman to head the President's Council of Economic Advisers focused attention on how few women there are at the top of the profession. Women in economics, having congregated in what they refer to as the less prestigious people-oriented specialties -- the economics of labor, health care, trade, industrial organization and the like -- are finding these specialties to have gained new stature lately.
These specialties in economics have been pushed toward center stage because the theorists have so far failed to come up with effective solutions to the nation's intractable economic problems.
Ms. Tyson, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, is herself a specialist in trade and industrial issues. Partly for that reason, her appointment drew criticism from some theorists that she lacked the broad grasp of economics that a council head should have.
"What they really were saying is that women are not as good at serious economics as men are," said Sylvia Lane, a professor emeritus in agricultural economics at Berkeley.
 
Government Posts
 After the criticism of Ms. Tyson, Mr. Clinton invited a top-ranked male theorist, Alan Blinder of Princeton University, to work under Ms. Tyson as a council member. Professor Blinder's specialty, macroeconomics, tries to determine how the economy might respond to particular government policies or other economic developments. In the process, theory is translated into complicated mathematical formulas, and computers are used to simulate how the economy might behave. Often in recent years, this process has been inaccurate.
The theorists "are correct to be afraid of people like Laura Tyson," said Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee. "People like her know how to translate policy into effective action."
Increasingly, professional economists talk of melding theory and applied economics. Zvi Griliches, a Harvard economist and the incoming president of the American Economic Association -- representing mainly academic economists but also some in government and business -- made this point at the meeting here last week. Addressing a luncheon, he argued that some top theorists -- and he named a half-dozen men -- are also engaged in practical economics.
"It is just wrong to say that the major economics departments are not engaged in policy and are not interested," Mr. Griliches said.
Fewer people, in fact, are specializing in pure theory, said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics and a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where Ms. Tyson earned her Ph.D. in the early 1970's. And as theory and applied economics merge, women should advance more easily, he said.
 
The Next Generation
 "It is my very strong impression that as you come down the age level, among economists under 35 years old, you cannot tell the men from the women," Mr. Solow said. "You don't find today's crop of women Ph.D.'s clustering in the people-oriented sub-fields nearly to the extent that you did 20 years ago."
The women disagree. The Committee on the Status of Women surveyed 30 universities that have what the American Economic Association considers top-ranked graduate programs in economics. Of 572 tenured professors, 19 are women. Most of those, like Ms. Tyson, are not theorists.
The men do not dispute any of the figures. "Women have made gains thus far mostly at the entry level," said C. Elton Hinshaw, a Vanderbilt University economist who is also secretary of the association. "One obvious possible explanation is that they are discriminated against."
At the roundtable discussion at the association meeting, which was attended by more than 50 women, Beth Allen, one of the few theorists and mathematicians to have reached tenured professor at a top-ranked school, the University of Minnesota, said: "There is the feeling that everyone is watching for you to make a mistake. And you feel you have to be on university committees to prove yourself, rather than concentrate on theory."
Tenured professors serve on committees that recruit and promote teachers, and Ms. Allen and others at the session argued that until there are more tenured women professors, the men will not move women into the top ranks in great numbers. "We must work to protect our junior colleagues from death by committee," Ms. Allen said.
 
Parental Responsibilities
 Beyond discrimination, women in economics said that rearing children was an obstacle to specializing in theoretical economics, the avenue that often wins full professorships for men by their early 30's. Because of the prestige in being a theorist, the competition is considerable, and the men often put in workaholic hours. What's more, theory involves long periods of concentration to work out complex mathematical equations, and child-rearing makes this difficult, the women said.
It even gets in the way of attending the American Economic Association's three-day annual meeting. Women have periodically asked for child-care support, so they can bring their children and attend the daylong sessions undistracted. The association has turned them down, saying it does not have adequate liability insurance.
Some women at the roundtable suggested that child-rearing should be postponed, until after women gain tenure. Others favored entering graduate school after children are a few years old. Anne O. Krueger of Duke University, a theorist and trade expert, took the latter course. Her only child, a daughter, was 18 months old when Ms. Krueger began graduate work at the University of Wisconsin, earning her Ph.D. in 1958.
But the course she took, more by accident than design, was not really a solution, she said in an interview. "As long as the allocation of labor in the household is going to remain with the woman," she said, "I do not know what the economics profession can do about it."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 15, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about complaints of discrimination by women in economics misstated the numbers of men and women who are tenured full professors at four universities as well as percentages for the faculty totals of the 30 universities listed. Duke University has 2 women and 22 men who are tenured full professors of economics; the University of California at Berkeley 2 women and 28 men; the University of California at San Diego no women and 16 men; the University of Wisconsin 3 women and 20 men. At the 30 universities listed, 3.5 percent of the tenured economics professors are women.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Cowboys are Quicker on the Draw

 BODY:
Dallas's third touchdown, which gave them a 24-3 lead and put the game all but out of reach, came on a 23-yard run by Emmitt Smith in the third quarter. It came on a draw play that is one of the Cowboys' favorites; that also means they often execute it better than other plays because they enjoy running it. They have used it all season long and in both previous games against Eagles. No doubt Philadelphia had prepared for the play, so the fact that the Cowboys scored on it indicates how well it was executed.
 Basically, it's a cutback draw. The Eagles knew this draw would be run but did not recognize it from this formation, which was a formation Dallas had been using in this game but not running the draw play on. Dallas also says that this is Smith's best play and he makes things happen on it. 
Smith lines up deep in the backfield. He has a tackle-to-tackle, sweeping view. It is his decision to break the play off in any direction he wants, simply by reading the blocks. This time, he got excellent blocking from his linemen and a good block from his fullback, Daryl Johnston, who took care of the middle by stopping the Eagles' linebacker, ???. Once he reached the line of scrimmage he had two holes to choose from -- straight ahead, or off to the left. Smith cut left, his blockers opened a path for him, and he turned the corner and headed into the corner of the end zone.

HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL UNIONS AND NEW YORK CITY REACH PAY ACCORD

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
After months of stalled talks, the Dinkins administration reached a tentative three-year labor settlement yesterday with the largest municipal unions. It gives workers modest wage and benefit increases totaling about 8.25 percent but does not include the productivity concessions City Hall had sought.
The settlement, which is subject to ratification by the unions' rank and file, covers about 180,000 workers in 19 unions, the largest being Local 237 of the teamsters and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The contracts would be retroactive to January 1992 and for most of the unions would run to March 1995. 
 The tentative agreement marked a new, and considerably more amicable, chapter in Mayor David N. Dinkins's relationship with organized labor, which had been a major force in his election victory in 1989. In the fall of 1990, he granted a 5.8 percent increase in wages and benefits to the city's teachers union, setting the pattern for a costly round of labor settlements that forced him to threaten thousands of layoffs and deep budget cuts before finally moving to cut the labor force through attrition.
 
A Crucial Constituency
 By reaching a contract settlement now, before his re-election campaign begins in earnest, the Mayor appears to have gone a long way toward making peace with a crucial constituency. [News analysis, page B2.]
Despite Mr. Dinkins's firm pledge over the last year that workers would receive no raises unless the unions paid for them through greater efficiency, the city failed to wrest any significant work-rule changes or other concessions from the unions. Instead, the two sides agreed to set up a three-member panel that would continue to negotiate such changes and could arbitrate disputes.
 
A One-Time Cash Bonus
 On the other side, the unions did not receive the kind of wage increases they were seeking since under the agreement salaries are unlikely even to keep up with inflation. Workers would immediately receive a one-time cash bonus of $700, covering the first 18 months of the contract. Beginning in July, they would receive a 2 percent raise, with another 2 percent in July 1994 and a 3 percent raise that December, for the last four months of the contract.
After benefits are added, the total increase over 39 months would be 8.25 percent.
The agreement will cost the city about $321 million this spring and about $428 million in the fiscal year beginning in July, widening the expected shortfall to $2.1 billion in the nearly $30 billion budget for that year. By the end of the contract, the city's total labor costs will have risen by about $1.1 billion a year.
State fiscal monitors questioned whether the city could afford such high recurring costs and said the settlement did little to bring the city's long-term revenues in line with its expenses.
Labor leaders painted the wage settlement as the best they could hope for in a tough economic times, saying they did not believe the city had money for greater wage raises. "When you get all there is, you've done your job," said Barry Feinstein, the president of the teamsters local. "There is nothing left to take."
 
Retreat Acknowledged
 Mayor Dinkins acknowledged that he had retreated from his original pledge to pay for wage increases with concessions, but he added that he was confident that the new panel would yield greater productivity from city workers.
"I'm satisfied that while this is a fair agreement to labor, it is as good an agreement as management could achieve in the circumstances," he said.
Negotiators said this year's mayoral election campaign created extra pressure on the administration to settle. In addition, the teachers union's current contract is in arbitration before a state panel, and officials feared that the settlement, expected soon, could skew negotiations with other unions.
The administration also wanted to reach an accord before releasing its preliminary budget later this month.
 
Lump-Sum Payment
 Besides the wage increases, the union members would receive a one-time lump-sum payment for fringe benefits of $125 per employee in the next fiscal year and a $100 per worker increase in benefits in each of the last two years of the contract. The agreement also establishes a $20 million fund to be used to address problems the city and the unions have in recruiting and retaining professional and technical workers.
The city also agreed to help labor leaders lobby in Albany for changes in state pension rules that would allow employees more flexibility in choosing their pension plans.
Although labor leaders said they had made no firm commitment to work-rule changes, the settlement spells out that at least six productivity measures will be instituted by next June. A panel including a representative from management, labor and an impartial observer will oversee the initiatives and will be able to settle any disputes, city officials said. A part of the savings will be plowed back into wage increases.
"We think the agreement in effect has an enforcement mechanism as well as a system of accountability," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "What we're banking on is the fact that the workers will see this as an opportunity to take advantage of the gain-sharing incentive."
 
Avoiding Layoffs
 Both sides repeated their longstanding commitment in the pact to avoid layoffs, and specifically agreed that no layoffs would result from the productivity initiatives, labor and city officials said. The unions have also agreed to relax Civil Service rules to expedite transferring and retraining workers.
"It's not a no-layoff pledge," a senior mayoral adviser said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "We would seek to avoid layoffs and in return for that, the unions would give us relief from certain Civil Service restrictions."
On the issue of increased productivity, labor leaders said that the settlement merely sets up a forum for continuing negotiations and that nothing is etched in stone. "There are no givebacks," said Stanley Hill, president of District Council 37.
Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director, said the city had identified ways to pay for the extra costs from the contract for the rest of this fiscal year and the next fiscal year though a combination of bond refinancings, unspent revenues and unanticipated growth in tax revenues.
It was unclear how the city would be able to afford the last year of the contract. Mr. Michael said officials were banking, in part, on an upturn in the economy.
 
Further Spending Cuts
 But Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board, said the city would not be able to afford the contract without resorting to further spending cuts.
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group, questioned the wisdom of granting raises without firm commitments to make the work force more efficient. He said Mr. Dinkins had missed a major opportunity to revamp permanently the way the city does business.
"They put the old pay-raise cart before the productivity horse," he said.
But union leaders said it would be hard to persuade rank-and-file workers to ratify a contract that barely keeps up with inflation when most of them have not had a raise since late 1990.
"This is not going to be a piece of cake," Mr. Feinstein of the teamsters said. "This is not a contract we believe is rich."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Confirmation Hearings;
Budget Nominee Testifies Clinton May Set Aside Tax-Cut Pledge

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President-elect Bill Clinton's choice as budget director, Leon E. Panetta, told Congress today that Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to cut the taxes of the middle class was a lower priority than cutting the deficit and increasing spending for new projects the Democrats favor.
In Little Rock, Ark., as part of what may have been a coordinated effort by the Clinton team to back away from this central campaign pledge, two top transition advisers also suggested today that the tax-cut promise was being reconsidered. 
 Top Congressional leaders had said in television interviews on Sunday that they would not hold Mr. Clinton to his proposal to reduce by several hundred dollars a year the taxes of families making less than about $80,000 a year. Such a proposal could cost as much as $10 billion a year in lost revenue.
 
No Final Decisions Yet
 At his confirmation hearing today before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, Mr. Panetta rarely took policy proposals beyond points that Mr. Clinton had reached publicly, and Mr. Panetta emphasized that final decisions had not been made about the new Administration's economic plan.
But while he did not retreat entirely from the campaign promise to reduce the taxes of middle-income taxpayers, Mr. Panetta gave the clearest indication to date that it might be set aside, at least for now.
"Our first priority," Mr. Panetta said, "is to develop that deficit reduction plan."
Second in importance, he said, is to "lay out the investment path we want to follow and targeted investments we want to make."
He continued: "And then, I think, dependent on that lies the question of whether or not we can go any further with regards to any kind of further reductions on taxes."
No one on the Senate committee took issue with this, and all the Senators who questioned Mr. Panetta expressed support for confirming him. Mr. Panetta, a California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, is popular among lawmakers from both parties.
The tax-cut proposal was first made in the early days of the Presidential campaign last winter and spring, when Mr. Clinton emphasized it as being necessary to make the tax system fairer. As the campaign wore on, he gave less emphasis to the proposal but never abandoned it. As recently as his economic conference in Little Rock last month, Mr. Clinton said he still intended to fulfill the promise.
 
'He Was Very Careful'
 In a television interview broadcast tonight by the Public Broadcasting Service, Mr. Clinton was also more explicit than he had been before that he would probably break his campaign promise to cut the budget deficit in half in the next four years. And Mr. Clinton's staff has said in recent days that yet another pledge, to reduce the White House staff by 25 percent, might be difficult to fulfill.
Asked in Little Rock about the prospects for a middle-class tax cut, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, said: "We're committed to tax fairness, and President-elect Clinton will continue to work for tax fairness throughout his Administration. But he was very careful not to make read-my-lips pledges."
A top economic policy adviser, Gene Sperling, also took care to leave Mr. Clinton a way out of his tax-cut promise. "When the deficit gets worse, everything gets harder," Mr. Sperling told reporters.
In his testimony at the Senate hearings, Mr. Panetta said Mr. Clinton hoped to announce his economic plan next month and to submit a full-scale budget to Congress in March.
 
'Shooting Straight Up'
 "What we're looking at now is a deficit line that's shooting straight up," Mr. Panetta said. The new Administration's task, he continued, is to "turn that curve back down" so that eventually the deficit is no more than 1 percent of the nation's total production of goods and services. In the fiscal year that ended last September, the deficit was more than 5 percent of that figure.
He said that so far the Clinton economic team had been concentrating on developing a long-term program and had not decided whether to propose a temporary increase in the deficit this year to give the economy a quick stimulus.
In interviews, some advisers suggested that Mr. Clinton was leaning toward such a stimulus, despite recent data showing that the economy was improving. These advisers, who would speak only if they were not identified, said such a plan was needed to make sure the nation did not slide back into recession.
Mr. Panetta said that if a one-year deficit increase was proposed, it would be small, closer to $20 billion for one year than to the $60 billion that some economists had recommended.
 
Clinton Saying Same Thing
 He said the promise Mr. Clinton made during the campaign to reduce the budget deficit by half over the next four years might be unreachable now that new figures show the potential deficits for the 1996 and 1997 fiscal years to be significantly higher than had been projected when Mr. Clinton first set the goal.
Mr. Clinton himself made that point in the interview with PBS. He said that he still planned to reduce the deficit by as much money as ever -- about $145 billion by the last year of his term -- but that the sum might not be enough to cut the deficit in half. He and his advisers now think that without policy changes, the deficit, now about $300 billion, could be as high as $400 billion by 1996 or 1997.
Mr. Clinton also stressed in the interview the importance of controlling medical costs, and today he met in Little Rock with his top health-policy advisers.
 
Conflict With Federal Reserve
 In his Congressional testimony, Mr. Panetta said he favored a deficit-reduction ratio of about $2 in spending cuts for each $1 of tax increases. When programs are being examined for possible spending cuts, he said, "everything is on the table," presumably including programs once considered politically untouchable like Social Security, although he did not mention it specifically. He said he hoped a higher gasoline tax would not be necessary, but he did not rule it out.
Mr. Panetta cautioned that even the most rigorous effort to cut the deficit would be futile if the Federal Reserve, which controls interest rates, did not adopt a policy allowing strong growth in the economy.
Alan M. Greenspan, the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and other officials have suggested recently that they might favor a tight-money policy that many economists and politicians say could be a drag on the economy.
The only real control the White House has over the Federal Reserve is political pressure, and Mr. Panetta seemed to be applying that today. "If for any reason the Federal Reserve bails out on us," he said, "it's going to be very tough then to try to meet the targets that we've established."
Over the years, Mr. Panetta has been a more vigorous advocate of deficit reduction than Mr. Clinton and most other Democrats. While he did not even remotely take issue with the President-elect today, he displayed his familiar zeal for budget cutting. "We need to confront these deficits," he declared, "to make the tough choices and be prepared for some sacrifice, in order to make our economy more productive and provide greater opportunity for our children tomorrow."

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Social Scene;
A Highly Sensitive Post Is Filled by the Clintons

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
After weeks of discussion and deliberation and the selection of a Secretary of State and Attorney General, the Clintons have done something really important to Washington's high and mighty: They picked a White House social secretary.
Ann Stock, the vice president of public relations for Bloomingdale's, who divides her time between Washington and the New York department store, is Hillary Clinton's choice for a job that to some is as important as the White House chief of staff and, in its own way, wields almost as much power.
Nicki Hedrick, director of media relations at Bloomingdale's, confirmed today that Mrs. Stock had resigned to take the White House job, where she will hold sway over who gets invited to Presidential functions. Mrs. Clinton's office refused to comment on the appointment.
"If you care about going to the White House it's a very powerful job," said Carolyn Peachey, president of Campbell, Peachey & Associates, a public relations firm.
 
Intense Competition
 After 12 years in a city where the most sought-after invitation is to a White House dinner, there are a lot of Democrats clamoring to get on the list.
Competition for the social secretary's position was intense. "It always has been," said Sheila Tate, who was press secretary to Nancy Reagan and is now president of Powell Tate, a public relations firm. "The job has great cachet."
Mrs. Stock, a former deputy press secretary to Vice President Walter F. Mondale, was chosen from a list that included Ms. Peachey, who did not want to be considered; Susan O'Neill, daughter of the former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.; Liz Stevens, wife of the film director George Stevens, and Alma Viator, a vice president of the National Theater.
A number of people prominent in Georgetown's social circle were surprised by the choice, and telephone calls today soliciting their responses often began with comments like the one from Polly Kraft, wife of the lawyer and former White House counsel Lloyd Cutler: "Do I know her?"
 
She Knows Washington
 Mrs. Stock may not be a household name to the Georgetown crowd, but she has long experience in the capital. "It's good that no Georgetown ladies know her," said Ms. Tate. "She's fresh and unspoiled. She's a hard worker and she certainly knows Washington."
Everyone agrees that the White House social secretary should know Washington so as to navigate the treacherous political waters and the rocky protocol shores.
"It's very important," said Muffie Brandon, now director of corporate programming for the Ford Motor Company and social secretary to Nancy Reagan from 1980 to 1983. "The intricacies of this city, the nuances of political life and of protocol are not things you can learn on the job."
Mrs. Stock is not new to politics or to Washington. Besides working for Mr. Mondale, she volunteered for the Capital Children's Museum and helped raise the money to open it.
 
Other Qualifications
 Those who know Mrs. Stock describe her as energetic, enthusiastic and creative, highly organized and very professional, qualities that are important in such a sensitive job.
"There are toes that don't need to be stepped on," said Ms. Tate. "You need to genuflect to certain people. It's important that she knows the traps and avoids needlessly offending people, just in terms of the Hill and the traditions and all the protocol."
Mrs. Stock, who is 46 and lives in nearby Alexandria, Va., graduated from Purdue University, where she majored in elementary education. She has been married to Stuart Stock, a partner at Covington & Burling, for 22 years. They have a 13-year-old son, Chase, who is a student at the Potomac School in McLean, Va.
She is a member of the Overseas Economic Fund's Women in Business Committee and founded the Washington Woman Roundtable, a group of 1,000 female executives who meet every three months to network. She was founder of Washington's "Race for the Cure" against breast cancer, and helped to organize the same event in New York City.
Mrs. Stock could not be reached for comment. She was on her way back to New York from Little Rock, Ark.

The Economy
 
 A plea agreement for the central figure in the Salomon Treasury scandal appeared to fall apart. Government lawyers said they would seek to indict him. [D1.] 
 President-elect Clinton's choice as budget director told Congress that middle-class tax cuts were a lower priority than cutting the deficit and increasing spending. [A1.]
The Supreme Court let stand a ruling forbidding states to place limits on credit-card fees by state-chartered banks. [D2.]
A judge rejected Clark Clifford's bid to drop state charges in the B.C.C.I. scandal on the basis of his poor health. [D2.]
 
Companies
 
 Speculation over why Sunbeam-Oster's chairman was ousted centered on resentment raised within the company by his hard-driving management style. [D1.]
British Airways admitted to improper attempts to undermine Virgin Atlantic Airways and will pay damages. [D1.]
Chrysler will try to raise about $1.4 billion by selling 40 million new shares of common stock. [D1.]
Campbell Soup said it had no immediate plans to market a genetically engineered food product. [D4.]
Kodak broke with tradition by naming an outsider and turnaround specialist to be chief financial officer. [D4.]
Mitsubishi ended development of mainframe computers, reflecting the movement away from such large machines. [D4.]

International
 
 An industrial park on the U.S.-Mexico border promoted for years as a boom town has turned out to be a flop. [D1.]
 
Markets
 
 The Dow gained 11.08 points led by Kodak, closing at 3262.75 on moderately strong volume. [D8.]
The corporate bond market slowed from the feverish pitch of last week. Prices of Treasury issues rose. [D17.]
Livestock and lumber prices raced higher. [D18.] The dollar declined and gold fell to seven-year lows. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Anse a Galets Journal;
Haitians' Hope for Jan. 20: A Fair Wind for Florida

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANSE A GALETS, Haiti, Jan. 7

 BODY:
At the simple concrete wharf that is the only port of La Gonave, a desolate, rock-ribbed island off Haiti, two soldiers shadowed by a clutch of onlookers converged on a visitor to ask if he, like most of the foreigners who infrequently venture here, had come in search of boat people.
Even before the visitor could reply, a man shouted from the crowd, "We are all leaving, and that much is certain!" His words drew approving cheers, and a kind of answer to a question that has been hanging in the air since President-elect Bill Clinton promised to end the Bush Administration's practice of summarily returning Haitians intercepted at sea. 
 For decades La Gonave has slumbered in neglect and abject misery, its economic vibrancy a faint echo even compared with that of the rest of Haiti, which is the hemisphere's poorest country. But since waves of desperate Haitians began fleeing for the United States after a violent military coup in September 1991, the building of ships here and their launching for the long-odds journey to South Florida have given a rare breath of life to this horse-and-donkey economy.
At first approach, Lorphene Joseph, a stocky 40-year-old who was rushing to complete a cavernous 40-foot sailboat, the seventh such vessel he said he had built, said he did not know how it would be used. After a long chat, though, he offered a kind of confession.
"I can't stop building these boats because there is no hope for our people," he said. "They are forced to look for a better life somewhere else."
 
Waiting for a Savior
 With dozens of gaily painted wooden boats ready for launching and many more nearing completion, others on this barren island are not so coy, saying they are posed for a signal from Washington that will mean either that the United States will welcome Haitians with open arms or will throw itself into the rebuilding of their country and the restoration of their overthrown President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Since campaign statements promising a dramatic change from President Bush's approach to this country's refugee crisis, the Clinton team has sought to dampen expectations like these, warning in statements carried repeatedly on radio broadcasts here that the United States' doors were not suddenly being thrust open, while promising to work for Father Aristide's return.
But on La Gonave, as in much of Haiti, people continue to understand such things in their own fashion, and for many that means clinging to the belief that one way or another the new American President will be their savior.
"Bill Clinton is a democrat and Aristide is a democrat, so your President can bring our President back," said Robert Jean-Louis, a 24-year-old student who vowed to attempt a second trip to the United States if Mr. Clinton's inauguration was not accompanied by such news. "If I see things aren't changing, that same evening I'll be getting on a boat again. Ninety percent of the people here will tell you the same thing."
Indeed, although it is impossible to say how many of them will set out to sea on or shortly after Mr. Clinton's inauguration on Jan. 20, almost everywhere people agreed to speak to a visitor here, from the rock-strewn streets of the only sizable town, Anse-a-Galets, to the mangrove-shielded shallows where final coats of paint were being applied to curving hulls, they vowed to reach the United States.
[The Coast Guard returned 226 Haitians on Monday and investigated reports that a wooden boat carrying nearly 400 went down off the Bahamas in December, The Associated Press reported from Port-au-Prince. Cuba has told the Coast Guard that it rescued 8 Haitians from the boat but that 396 had apparently been aboard.]
 
Aristide the Key
 "The only news that could interest me is whether they send our President back," said Jean Andre, 22, who was asked if he had followed reports of the Clinton Administration's plans to avert a renewed surge of Haitian boat people. "If they can't bring us Aristide, the moment Guantanamo opens I'll be on the first boat I can climb aboard."
Mr. Clinton's aides have suggested in recent days that they will reopen the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to screen Haitian boat people. Those who are determined to have genuine political reasons for fleeing their country, they say, could be taken to the United States or housed temporarily at the base while a settlement of the country's crisis is sought. Those determined to be fleeing primarily for economic reasons would be returned to Haiti.
Calypso Mavis, a wiry entrepreneur who has grown rich in the last year by ferrying Haitians hoping to flee the country from the mainland to La Gonave, said, "All this time they have been unable to settle our crisis people have only gotten more desperate."
In addition to his wooden yawl used last year for the slow passage, Mr. Mavis now owns a sleek and powerful outboard, and his thick gold watch and gold caps on his teeth attest to his recent success.
"Aristide must come back, right now, because otherwise we will be eating each other soon," Mr. Mavis warned. "Either that, or we all end up in Guantanamo."

HEADLINE: States Lose Credit-Card Fee Battle

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Rejecting an appeal by Massachusetts and 37 other states, the Supreme Court let stand today a ruling forbidding states to place limits on fees that state-chartered banks charge their credit-card holders.
Without comment, the Court declined to review a Federal appeals court ruling that state regulation of bank credit-card fees was pre-empted by a 1980 Federal law. 
 That ruling, issued last August by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston, was a victory for the Delaware-chartered Greenwood Trust Company, which issues the Discover credit card to customers around the country. Greenwood does not charge an annual fee for the card, but does charge a $10 late fee when a monthly payment has not been made by 20 days past the due date. After the Massachusetts Attorney General told Greenwood that the fee violated a state law banning all such charges, the bank went to Federal court seeking a declaration that the state ban was pre-empted.
 
'Exporting' Loan Rates
 The basis for the bank's winning argument was the Depository Institutions Deregulation and Monetary Control Act of 1980. Congress enacted this law to help state-chartered banks escape the interest-rate ceilings that states were beginning to impose. The law explicitly pre-empts state laws "with respect to interest rates," permitting banks to "export" the loan rate ceilings of their home states.
While the law does not refer to late charges or other fees, the First Circuit concluded that it was logical to include late charges within the scope of the Federal pre-emption. The phrase "interest rates" was not limited to the numerical rate, the appeals court said, and should be interpreted as also including other loan-related charges.
Massachusetts and five other states -- Colorado, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Texas and Vermont -- prohibit late charges. Twenty-four other states, including Connecticut, impose percentage or dollar limits on the charges. New York has no limits.
 
State's Argument
 In its Supreme Court appeal, Massachusetts v. Greenwood Trust, No. 92-794, the state argued that the First Circuit went further than Congress intended when it passed the 1980 law, and threatened to disturb the states' role in regulating credit.
The state said that while the First Circuit's opinion referred only to late charges, the court's analysis also appeared to bar state regulation of other charges, like those for duplicate statements, replacement cards or as penalties for exceeding credit limits.
The only states affected by the First Circuit's ruling are the four within that circuit: Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire and Rhode Island. No other Federal appeals court has yet addressed the question. If a conflict does develop among the lower courts, the Justices may feel obliged to resolve the question.
 
U.S. Appeal Denied
 In another ruling, the Court refused without comment to hear an appeal by the Federal Government on whether it could continue to enforce a standard in Federal construction contracts requiring contractors to correct any nonconforming work regardless of the cost.
Courts typically interpret private contracts according to a doctrine known as "economic waste," under which strict compliance to the contract terms is not required as long as the nonconforming product meets or exceeds the needs of the project and the cost of replacement was disproportionate to any benefit.
But the Federal Government insisted on strict compliance, until a ruling last May by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit applied the economic waste doctrine to a Federal contract. The dispute involved a sealant used in a dam being constructed near Aberdeen, Miss., at a cost of less than $6,000.
The Army Corps determined that the sealant did not meet the contract specifications and insisted that it be replaced. The task cost the contractor, the Granite Construction Company, at least $400,000. Granite then sought compensation, and sued when the Government denied its claim. Granite won in the appeals court.
In its appeal -- the United States v. Granite Construction, No. 92-545 -- the Government warned that the court's approach threatened the "integrity of the public bidding system."
 
Ruling on Inventor
 In another ruling, the Court turned down without comment an appeal by an inventor, Jerome H. Lemelson, who had sued the toy maker Mattel Inc. over the patent for a popular Mattel toy, Hot Wheels.
Mr. Lemelson, a frequent plaintiff in patent infringement suits, had earlier persuaded a jury that Mattel had infringed a patent he owned on a flexible toy track. The jury awarded Mr. Lemelson $75 million in damages, but the Federal Circuit, in a ruling last June, set aside the award on the ground that "no reasonable jury" could have found infringement under the circumstances. Mr. Lemelson's Supreme Court appeal was Lemelson v. Mattel, No. 92-818.

HEADLINE: Making Peace Before the Election

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
By reaching a contract that provides modest raises for most of New York City's union workers before his re-election campaign begins in earnest, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday went a long way toward solving a big political headache and making peace with a crucial constituency.
But he did so by breaking his longstanding pledge to grant raises only in exchange for increased productivity by workers, and with that Mr. Dinkins may have also bought himself endless fiscal headaches in the coming months and years, even if he wins a second term. 
 "The significance of this contract isn't whether or not it's good or bad," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which has overseen the city's books since the fiscal crisis of the 70's. "It is reasonable by any standard. But the city's finances are structurally out of whack, and the large and unfunded costs of even a reasonable wage settlement underscores the urgency of significantly increased productivity and restructuring if the city is to avoid even sharper service cuts than are already needed."
 
Changing Fortunes
 It is a measure of both the Mayor's changing fortunes, and his city's, that the debate should be so framed. Ten months into his term, in the fall of 1990, Mr. Dinkins was roundly excoriated for a granting 5.8 percent increase in wages and benefits to teachers, which fiscal watchdogs said he could not afford, and then threatening thousands of layoffs and dire cuts in municipal services.
After that Mr. Dinkins vowed a much different approach. So this year's conservative raise, averaging well below the 3.5 percent annual inflation rate, is not enough to draw the watchdogs' praise. That is because the Mayor had promised for months that the city would grant no wage increases at all through June of 1994, except in exchange for improvements in workers' efficiency, in an effort to close gaps between expected revenues and expenditures that the city's own forecasts predict will grow steadily in the coming years.
By that standard, the Mayor reneged. Yesterday's settlement calls for a raise of 2 percent for the fiscal year that starts this July, and increases that would total an 8.25 percent increase in wages and benefits by March, 1995. There was a promise by management and labor to form a committee to agree on productivity improvements, or to submit to the binding rulings of a joint panel, but no specific savings were claimed.
 
Costs Are Clear
 Meantime, the costs are already all too clear: In the coming fiscal year, if all unions get similar raises, the city will have to spend $428 million on raises -- for which it had budgeted no money at all. That would increase its expected budget gap to well over $2 billion. City officials contend they will be able to bear the higher costs mostly through anticipated growth in tax yields because of an improving economy, and not resort to deeper spending cuts -- a proposition the fiscal watchdogs questioned. The Mayor's flexibility is limited by his previous pledges to freeze property tax rates, the city's main revenue source, for the next three years.
By the spring of 1996, the new contract will be costing the city an extra $1 billion a year, more than twice the amount the city had budgeted for raises in that period, and enough to increase the city's projected budget gap for that year from $2.6 billion to well over $3 billion.
Of course, the city almost always grants larger raises than it acknowledges it is willing to do, and Mr. Dinkins had compelling reasons to settle the contracts. He wanted to reach agreement with the bulk of city workers before beginning nonbinding arbitration with the city's teachers' union tomorrow, so that any settlement with the teachers, who are pressing for higher wages than their fellow workers, would not set the pattern for the rest. It was settling with the teachers first in the last round of bargaining that helped get Mr. Dinkins in trouble.
Mr. Dinkins called the settlement a "win-win" proposition, that would mean "a better-trained, more productive and better-paid work force."
Understandably, his rivals saw it differently. Victoria Streitfeld, chief of staff to City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who has vowed to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic primary, said, "Leadership is more than just writing a check."
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor's Republican challenger, said, "This is even more of a cave-in than I expected."
But Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, the largest city union and one of Mr. Dinkins's major backers in his last race, sounded a different note. Asked if this would make union members happy in August and September, when the mayoral primary will be in full swing, Mr. Hill just smiled broadly and said, "What's happening in August and September?"

HEADLINE: Wiring Into the Future;
The High Stakes of Telecommunications

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Fearful that the enemy will gain superiority, one side sinks vast amounts of money into building sophisticated weapons. Its adversary, now frightened that it may be vulnerable, agonizes over whether to match the investment or up the ante.
In this race, the contestants are New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. The war is over jobs. The weapons systems are advanced telecommunications networks capable of delivering an array of high-tech services. And the moves and countermoves all put enormous sums at risk. Yesterday, a Connecticut regulatory agency gave the Southern New England Telephone Company preliminary approval to increase capital spending on its telecommunications network over the next four years to between $1.2 billion and $1.4 billion. That would be an increase of 50 percent or more. The agency, the Department of Public Utility Control, said it hoped to make a final decision on the investment and deregulation plan -- and the service rates needed to pay for it -- in the late spring. 
 "At a minimum we want to be in the top 12 of the 50 states" in network sophistication, said Clifton A. Leonhardt, the department's chairperson. The higher end of the spending range "might put us in the top 8 by the end of '96," he said.
Last month, New Jersey approved a far-reaching proposal for building a $1.5 billion all-digital fiber-optics network by 2010. And in New York, leaders from business, academia and government are urging the state to follow suit by spending billions to accelerate investment in its telephone network. A task force that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo asked to make a recommendation met for the first time last month.
 
Seeking Intelligence
 "Advanced telecommunications are increasingly being recognized by states as a competitive weapon in economic development and business retention and attraction," said L. C. Mitchell, a telecommunications consultant at Deloitte & Touche. Mr. Mitchell advised New Jersey and is now working with Pennsylvania.
These states, like many others throughout the country, have agonized over how much to gamble on "intelligent" networks capable of simultaneously carrying voice, moving video images and data to and from homes and businesses.
These services, for instance, would make possible high-quality video telephones. They would enable a doctor treating a patient to transmit X-rays or scans to specialists elsewhere for a quick consultation. They would permit consumers to call up movies and tap dozens of libraries and data banks instantly, without leaving home. They would make it easier to work at home. And they would make it much easier and cheaper for businesses of all sizes to do everything from transmitting information to holding video conferences with people in different places.
The ultimate hope is that such a network would enable a state to attract new industries and jobs and improve the quality of life while lowering the cost of services like education and health care.
 
Fear of Falling Behind
 The great fear is that if a state falls behind others, it will not only fail to attract tomorrow's high-tech jobs but lose businesses and jobs it already has. This is an acute concern in the tri-state region, where telecommunications-intensive industries like financial and business services are pillars of the economy.
And the big unknown is just how quickly the envisioned services will arrive. If they come much more slowly than anticipated, a state risks being saddled with an expensive, underutilized telecommunications network that hurts its chances of attracting and retaining companies scared away by the resulting higher rates or taxes.
Regulators and government leaders in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, already high-cost states for companies, are having to confront these issues at a time when jobs and competitiveness are uppermost in their minds. The three were among those hardest hit by the recession, having lost nearly 1.1 million jobs.
With little money to spare, the three states are having no easy time figuring out a way to finance the advanced networks.
 
A Risky Investment?
 Connecticut regulators tried to steer a middle course. They rejected the least expensive and most expensive of four network-modernization proposals and chose the middle two as minimum and maximum goals. Unlike New Jersey, they also said Connecticut should only now commit itself to the first stage of a modernization program by accelerating the adoption of the digital switches, the signaling system and other technology needed for an envisioned advanced network. It did not commit Connecticut to installing a fiber-optic network as New Jersey has.
The reasons for this caution, Mr. Leonhardt said, were unanswered questions about the technology and the attendant financial risks.
"It's good for America that one state, New Jersey, decided to stake a very ambitious ground and have a kind of laboratory for the country, but that doesn't mean it's prudent for Connecticut," he said.
New Jersey's plan calls for a border-to-border network of fiber-optic cable -- the hair-like strands of glass that can carry millions of bits of information a second -- unless a technology that is more cost-efficient emerges.
To help pay for its network, Connecticut regulators said they wanted to give the state's three local phone companies the ability to earn more from monopoly services. They said they would seek to change the law to let local phone companies earn more by placing a cap on prices rather than limiting profits as they have.
But the department also signaled its intent to open portions of the market to competition, including toll calls inside Connecticut, which might be deregulated as early as July 1. It also said it would ask the Legislature to give it powers to open local service to competition. And it called for a gradual end to the practice of subsidizing residential service with business services.
New Jersey's plan, a combination of some deregulation and some rate freezes, is supposedly structured so customers of traditional phone services do not pay the bill. But if the cost of building the network seriously weakens New Jersey Bell, its customers could have to bail it out, analysts and regulators in other states say.
 
Call for Substantial Spending
 In New York, which now has one of the most advanced telecommunications networks, three proposals for modernizing the network are being debated.
A committee of leaders of business education, science, unions, charities, religious groups and the arts financed by the state telephone industry's trade association made the most ambitious proposal. It called for New York Telephone to increase annual capital expenditures, now running at about $1.3 billion, by $650 million to $700 million through the year 2000.
To help pay for the higher investment, it said, the state should continue to open the market to competition, should give the local phone companies more pricing flexibility and should reduce taxes on phone companies.
New York Telephone says slower modernization that would increase annual spending by $250 million to $300 million would keep the state's network competitive with those being built by other states.
But in a draft recommendation circulating for reaction, the staff of the Public Service Commission said New York Telephone's currently planned network investments would suffice and an accelerated program would be too risky.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Corporate Issues Slow a Little

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Activity in the corporate market slowed a little yesterday from the feverish pitch of last week. But based on the reception for a Canadian issue to be sold today, the demand continued.
This was clear when the Province of Ontario began marketing $2.5 billion of 10-year global notes and quickly increased the offering to $3 billion. 
 "The deal grew to fill the demand," said John Madden, the Assistant Deputy Minister of the Treasury of the Province of Ontario.
He also said that the pricing of the deal, based on the marketing that began yesterday, was at the low end of the range of 76 to 79 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the 10-year Treasury note.
The deal, which will be finally priced this morning, will be sold simultaneously around the world.
There were close to $1 billion of new issues sold yesterday, way down from more than $4 billion a day on Wednesday and Thursday. Traders said that prices of corporate issues edged up a little yesterday but that the spread between the yields on corporate bonds and the comparable Treasury securities widened a bit.
 
Credit Outlook
 While the credit outlook for companies and state and local governments is beginning to improve in the United States as the economy recovers, it is worsening in the rest of the world, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday.
In 1992, credit ratings were downgraded on $122 billion of debt from foreign companies, while only $1.7 billion of debt was upgraded. The downgrading of foreign debt accounted for 32 percent of all of S.& P.'s downgrades, up from 19 percent in 1991. Of the total, $113 billion was debt issued by financial institutions and a large chunk of it, $34 billion, was from Japanese banks. The next biggest group was nine Scandinavian banks, with a total of $32 billion of debt that had its credit ratings lowered.
Looking into this year, Hendrik Kranenburg, executive managing director of Standard & Poor's international finance department, said he expected the downgradings of financial institutions to slow a bit. But he said that the downgradings of corporate debt should accelerate, especially in the electronics, retailing and property sectors.
The picture in the United States last year showed a slowing of the slide for the first time in years.
 
Climbing Higher
 The companies that insure tax-exempt bonds had a sharp jump in their business last year, as the share of municipal bonds that are insured jumped to 34 percent from 30 percent.
The share of the market that is insured has grown from 17.8 percent in 1987 as the insurance companies have been able to convince issuers with medium level credit ratings that insurance lowers the cost of borrowing because buyers are more comfortable when the risk of default is removed.
The question now is how much more of the market can they get.
There are two portions of the market that the issuers are not doing well in. By choice, they ignore the lower rated municipal issues because of the risks involved.
According to David H. Elliott, the president of the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, the largest insurer with 33 percent of the insurance business, said this unwanted business amounts to about 11 percent of the $233 billion in municipal bonds issued in 1992. Another segment of the market the industry would like to have but is having trouble getting is the top rated issuers, for whom insurance does not appear to be a money saver. This segments amounts to about 30 percent of the market.
This leaves about 25 percent of the market that is still fertile territory.
Robert J. Genader, the executive vice president of the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, the second-largest insurer, with about 31 percent of market, said selling insurance for 34 percent of the municipal business was "very high but I think we can get up to 40 percent in the next two years."
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose in light and dull trading yesterday. The discount rates on Treasury bills also fell.
Traders said the market got a little lift from comments by Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California and President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
At his confirmation hearing, Mr. Panetta said any package of new spending and tax cuts to stimulate the economy would need to be "very limited." And he indicated that any plan the new Administration might propose would be closer to $20 billion in size than $60 billion.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32 after falling one point and 11/32 in the previous two trading days. the yield dorpped to 7.44 percent, from 7.46 percent Friday.

HEADLINE: Global Merger Value Up 33%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar value of international mergers increased 33 percent in 1992, led by big United States companies expanding overseas through inexpensive acquisitions, according to KPMG Peat Marwick, one of the Big Six accounting concerns.
Cross-border acquisitions rose to $72.6 billion last year from $54.4 billion in 1991. The number of transactions declined to 1,810 in 1992 from 1,960 a year earlier, Peat Marwick said. 
 The biggest of the transactions were the Philip Morris Companies' $1.4 billion acquisition of the Norwegian food company Freia Marabou; the $1.2 billion purchase of Transport del Sur Argentina, a gas distribution company, by a group led by the Enron Corporation, and the Asahi Glass Company's $1 billion acquisition of AFG Industries in the United States.
The total value of mergers in 1992 declined to $216 billion from $225 billion in 1991, according to IDD Information Services. In 1990, the value of mergers was $314 billion, IDD said.
Mergers declined in part because members of the European Community stayed at home, preparing for a single market. In addition, Europe is still in a recession while the American economy is recovering, Peat Marwick said. Purchases of United States companies by European concerns dropped to $4.9 billion in 1992 from $13.6 billion in 1991.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS REACHES MUNICIPAL LABOR DEAL
The Dinkins administration reached a tentative three-year labor settlement with the largest municipal unions. The settlement, which is subject to ratification by the rank and file, gives workers modest wage increases but does not include the productivity concessions that City Hall had sought. It covers 180,000 city workers in 19 unions and runs from January 1992 to March 1995. A1.
 
SOLVING A POLITICAL PROBLEM
By reaching a contract that provides modest raises for city workers before his re-election campaign begins in earnest, Mayor Dinkins went a long way toward solving a big political headache and making peace with a crucial constituency. News analysis, B2. 

RACE RELATIONS AND A NURSING HOME
Two distinct cultures exist at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale: the 782 residents, most of them Jewish and at the end of their lives, and the 982 employees, most of them immigrants, many black, struggling to build theirs. Racism is not a blatant presence, yet as in the countless hospitals, apartment buildings and offices where members of minority groups work as nurses, nannies or custodians, often for older whites, the dramas of a city stratified by color are played out every day. A1.
 
VALLONE'S VIEW ON ST. PATRICK'S PARADE
City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone weighed in against Mayor Dinkins, saying the St. Patrick's Day parade should have been left in the hands of its longtime sponsors despite their refusal to let a gay group march. B3.
 
THE EDITOR AND THE LABOR ORGANIZER
In the fight over The Daily News, two men will be foes of a sort: Richard Esposito, an editor who will be working to rebuild the paper, and Ray Rogers, a labor organizer hired by the Newspaper Guild to undermine The News with a reader-and-advertiser boycott. B3.
 
REGION
 
PHARMACIST WITH H.I.V. GETS A JOB
After a six-year legal battle, the Westchester County Medical Center agreed to hire a pharmacist infected with H.I.V. without restricting the work he can do. That means the hospital will not lose Federal financing of $107 million a year, which had been jeopardized under civil rights laws. The Board of Legislators approved awarding the pharmacist as much as $330,000 for back pay, legal fees and "emotional damage." B5.
 
LEGISLATOR SAYS SHE WAS HARASSED
A New York State assemblywoman said she had been sexually harassed by male colleagues -- including once last month, just hours after Assembly members attended a seminar on how to avoid harassment. The Assemblywoman, Earlene Hill, a Democrat from Hempstead, L.I., would not identify the men who she said had harassed her, but she said she had been verbally abused by colleagues three times since taking office in 1988. B5.

PENALTIES THREATENED IN GLEN RIDGE CASE
The judge in the Glen Ridge sex-assault trial threatened to impose penalties on several probation officials and prosecutors if he does not receive a full report on two young men originally charged in the case. B5.

HEADLINE: 2 Get Ready to Lock Horns at The Daily News

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
One is an editor and former police reporter who has worked on every tabloid in town, spinning slasher tales and municipal scandals into front-page scoops. The other is a tough labor organizer who has dragged corporate giants to the bargaining table with campaigns of innovative, often harsh, pressure tactics.
Tomorrow the two men, who have never met, take on new jobs and become foes of a sort in a titanic fight over The Daily News -- the editor, Richard Esposito, helping to rebuild it for a new owner; the labor organizer, Ray Rogers, trying to undermine it, at least temporarily, with a reader-and-advertiser boycott for a newspaper union that wants to win back some of the 170 jobs cut last week in an economy move. 
 Both men were hired last week -- Mr. Esposito by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the new owner of The News, as metropolitan editor, and Mr. Rogers by the Newspaper Guild of New York as a consultant and organizer for its planned boycott. Both men are known to associates as imaginative, dynamic and aggressive: the right stuff for what are expected to be Herculean tasks on both sides.
 
Coming From Newsday
 Mr. Esposito, a 37-year-old journalistic jack-of-all-trades who has been city editor of New York Newsday for the last three years, must rekindle a News metropolitan staff that was cut by a third last week, left in turmoil by reshuffled assignments and other changes and angered over what some called the brutal way colleagues were summarily dismissed after decades of service.
In a brief interview, Mr. Esposito declined to discuss his plans for the metropolitan staff, but associates said he would press hard to improve coverage of city government, neighborhoods, transportation and other aspects of life in New York, with writing that captures the wit, wisdom and tempo of the town.
Mr. Rogers, 48, a nationally known crusader who developed boycott techniques that rocked textile and food companies, airlines, banks and other corporations, faces other daunting problems. He must mount his campaign without the support of nine other unions representing newspaper crafts, and must defeat not just the financially ailing Daily News but also its multimillionaire owner, whose empire includes large real estate and publishing holdings.
 
Strategy Meetings
 With Newspaper Guild rank-and-file strategy meetings set for tomorrow and Thursday, Mr. Rogers said much remains to be decided about the direction and scope of his campaign. But he said in an interview that it would be aimed not only at readers and advertisers of The News but also at all of Mr. Zuckerman's businesses.
"You've got to look at his real-estate empire, at U.S. News & World Report, at The Atlantic Monthly," he said, referring to other Zuckerman properties. "You have to look into whether he's paying his fair share of taxes. I'd focus on every area where we could put pressure on him and his business and political alliances. We'll have hundreds of volunteers and we will certainly bring in community groups and other unions."
For all the difficulties they face, friends say both men have a fighting chance.
"I have a lot of respect for Richie Esposito," said Alice T. McGillion, a former Deputy Police Commissioner who knew him as a reporter and editor. "He's sensitive, diligent and accurate and most of all he knows New York. He has an appreciation for its different groups and neighborhoods."
Mr. Esposito was born in East Harlem, attended Fordham Prep and graduated from New York University in 1975, earning a degree in English literature, with honors, in three years while working as a teacher-counselor in a Federal drug program. After a year of graduate study at the University of California at Berkeley, he began his journalistic career as a copy boy for The News in 1977.
Promoted to reporter in 1980, he covered general and police assignments. He contributed to a major series on subways and once interviewed a man holed up in a hotel room who was wanted by the police in a series of attacks on nurses for which he had been dubbed "the Bellevue Slasher."
From 1982 to 1984, he worked for The Philadelphia Bulletin, CBS and a New York business magazine, and freelanced for The New York Post, Reuters and the Cable News Network. After two years as a full-time reporter for The Post, he joined New York Newsday in 1986 and was successively a reporter, assistant city editor and city editor.
Collaborating with Robert Stutman, then the head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in New York, he also wrote a book on drug policies, "Dead on Delivery," which was published by Warner Books last year.
Mr. Rogers was born in Beverly, Mass., into a working-class family that knew strikes and hardship first hand. He graduated from the University of Massachusetts in 1967 with a degree in sociology, was a Vista antipoverty volunteer in Tennessee and wrote a paper for a Federal agency on hunger and malnutrition in Appalachia.
 
Organized Store Picketing
 In 1973, he was hired by a clothing workers union then locked in a fight with the Texas-based Farah Company. In a preview of his later work, he helped organize picketing at stores that carried Farah slacks, prompting many to cancel orders and Farah to settle.
He became nationally known after a long struggle with J. P. Stevens, the textile company, in which he formulated his "corporate campaign" tactics. He encouraged union members to pull money out of banks that did business with the company; he mounted personal attacks on executives and trustees; he dragged other companies into the dispute, including Manufacturers Hanover Trust and Metropolitan Life. Eventually, executives resigned and in 1980 Stevens signed its first labor contract.
He has also led campaigns against Hormel & Company, American Airlines, the International Paper Company and others, often focusing on environmental, health and other non-economic issues. Few have doubted his effectiveness, although his often harsh tactics have dismayed some union leaders as well as the companies they were directed against.
In 1981, he founded Corporate Campaign, with its headquarters and a small staff in Manhattan. But in waging his campaigns, Mr. Rogers relies heavily on union volunteers and their sympathizers. Friends say Mr. Rogers, a bachelor, leads a monkish existence, living in a low-rent apartment, wearing clothing off the rack and staying in cheap hotels.
His asceticism is armor against opponents like Mr. Zuckerman, whose wealth, he believes, makes him vulnerable. "This is a man that has played with a lot of toys," Mr. Rogers said. "Well, people's lives are not toys."

He said the boycott would also be aimed at Mortimer B. Zuckerman's other businesses. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)
