HEADLINE: Weprin Picks Leadership Of Committees

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin filled two powerful chairmanships today, appointing Assemblyman Albert Vann to head the Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky to be chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee.
Senator Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader, was expected to name Senator Ronald B. Stafford, a Republican from Plattsburgh who is the current deputy majority leader, to be chairman of the Finance Committee, Senate officials said. 
 As chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee, Mr. Brodsky, a Democrat from Hartsdale, will play a central role in drafting laws relating to the disposal of garbage and hazardous wastes, the regulation of development in the area that supplies New York City's drinking water, and the protection of the Adirondacks.
 
Calls for Cooperation
 Describing himself as a "wild-eyed environmentalist" at heart, Mr. Brodsky, 46 years old, started his new job by calling for cooperation in the divided Legislature. "I'm not looking for a war with the Senate," he said.
Among his priorities will be to establish a trust fund to pay for a variety of environmental projects, to clean up Long Island Sound and to pass laws enforcing the Federal Clean Air Act, Mr. Brodsky said.
As chairman of the Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee, Mr. Vann, a Democrat from Brooklyn, will have broad oversight powers over independent commissions and authorities, including the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Public Service Commission, which sets utility rates. His committee also has jurisdiction over corporation law.
 
Opposes M.T.A. Fare Increase
 Now in his 10th term, Mr. Vann, 58, said he wants to use his committee to create economic opportunities in urban areas. But among his first concerns will be the complex budget negotiations under way to aid New York City's Transit Authority, which is facing a $265 million deficit. If the budget gap is not filled by April, the M.T.A. has said it will probably raise bus and subway fares to $1.50.
"Obviously, I'm against a fare increase," Mr. Vann said.
In other appointments, Mr. Weprin, a Queens Democrat, named Assemblyman Anthony J. Genovesi, a Democrat from Brooklyn, chairman of the Oversight, Analysis and Investigation Committee, a position formerly held by Mr. Brodsky.
To replace Mr. Vann, Mr. Weprin named Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, another Brooklyn Democrat, to be chairman of the Children and Families Committee.
 
Other Appointments
 Other appointments by Mr. Weprin included these:
Assemblyman Hector L. Diaz, a Democrat from the Bronx, chairman of the Cities Committee;
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Democrat from Manhattan, chairman of the Mental Health Committee;
Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, a Democrat from Queens, chairwoman of the Real Property Taxation Committee;
Assemblyman Joseph Crowley, a Democrat from Queens, chairman of the Racing and Wagering Committee;
Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, a Queens Democrat, chairwoman of the State-Federal Relations Committee.

HEADLINE: Big Leap by Kodak Helps Dow Regain 11.08

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Eastman Kodak and a crew of other unloved stocks of last year led a partial recovery yesterday from the round of selling that has beset the stock market in the new year.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.08 points, or 0.34 percent, to close at 3,262.75, on moderately strong volume of 217.9 million shares. 
 Kodak's 3 1/2-point gain to 45 1/4 in heavy volume accounted for more than two-thirds of the Dow's advance. The company hired a chief financial officer from outside who is known as a turnaround expert.
I.B.M. and several medical stocks, losers last year that kept falling last week, furthered the market's advance yesterday. Among the most active stocks, I.B.M. rose 1 1/4, to 47 3/4, and Merck 3/4, to 43 1/4. Even the oil stocks, dormant or declining of late, attracted some buyers.
Strategists who stayed calm despite the market's ungainly entrance to the new year, with the Dow off nearly 50 points last week, stepped up to claim vindication.
 
Selloff Called Excessive
 "We had an excessive selloff," said Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, rattling off a list of technical indicators, put-call ratios and such, that he said backed him up. "Now, they're looking for laggards."
Elaine M. Garzarelli, a Shearson Lehman strategist, recommended yesterday that investors take advantage of the declines in such diversified health care companies as Bristol-Myers Squibb and Johnson & Johnson.
Merck, its stock floundering and gasping as of late, had the benefit of artificial resuscitation yesterday, as the board approved a billion-dollar stock buyback in addition to the $3.7 billion spent since 1985. Mr. Canelo, surprised that Merck managed no more than a fractional gain, said some investors would stay away from drug issues until they saw what health programs President-elect Bill Clinton proposed.
Investors showed no such ambivalence about the computer stocks that propelled the Nasdaq composite average up 5.19 points, or 0.77 percent, to 682.40, its fourth record in six trading sessions this year. Intel, Microsoft, Apple Computer, Cisco Systems and Sun Microsystems each advanced a point or more, performances that have recently become routine.
Steep declines in several European markets produced hardly a tremor in the United States yesterday. Alan R. Ackerman, chief market strategist at Rich & Company, said his European clients were shipping more of their pounds, lire and marks across the Atlantic, fleeing their own weak economies.
Although foreigners have usually favored the big, reliable brand-name stocks, Europeans are shifting toward smaller issues, he said. What is more, the strengthening dollar has been adding to their gains.
As for Eastman Kodak, James Joyce, senior vice president for research at First Albany, could boast of having featured the stock in an interview in Barron's on Saturday. Boast he did.
"I knew it was going to go up today," he said, before adding a bit more seriously, "I've been recommending the stock for months."

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Helps a Survivor Who Helps Others

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
For 20 years, Jean Montoya flew with Pan Am airlines, as a flight attendant and then as a manager. She and her son Justin, 11, have spent school vacations all over the world. She saved up enough money to buy a co-op apartment on West 72d Street.
But several years ago, when Pan Am began asking its employees to take pay cuts to save the company, Mrs. Montoya's savings dwindled. Then when Pan Am went out of business last year, Mrs. Montoya, who was 47 years old, was left with no job, no money and few prospects. 
 "I'm not used to rejections," she said. "I worked for 27 years. And then they started coming right and left. I've had so many times when I'm completely without any energy to keep going. What's it all for?"
Now, with the help of a psychologist at the Catholic Charities of New York, Mrs. Montoya is trying to get back to work, by studying at a school for radiology assistants at Bellevue Hospital Center.
 
'She's a Survivor'
 Catholic Charities is one of seven organizations aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The Times pays all of the fund's overhead, so all donations go directly to the seven charities. This year's drive ends on Feb. 28.
Mrs. Montoya was referred to the Catholic Charities by the United Way. She wanted to start a therapy group for former Pan Am employees. Friends at other airlines that had closed told her that some people were so depressed that they withdrew and started drinking heavily. Some even committed suicide, she said. Mrs. Montoya was determined that would not happen to her or her friends.
"She has been a catalyst for others," said Dr. James Sabrino, the psychologist who runs the group, which brings together a few people each Thursday. "She's a survivor."
Last year Mrs. Montoya sold her apartment and moved into Stuyvesant Town in Brooklyn, where she had been on the waiting list for six years. Everything in the apartment is someone else's cast-off, she explains proudly: "I think it looks pretty good, don't you?"
After years of handling crying babies and cranky passengers, Mrs. Montoya now spends all her time studying. Over the holidays she struggled to write a 40-page paper on bone ossification.
 
A New Life Style
 "I'm floundering," she said. "It's tough when your brain's been on vacation for 30 years."
Mrs. Montoya still worries a lot. Unemployment checks will stop in about two months. Justin's father, who lives in England, contributes little to his care, Mrs. Montoya says. And now she has no health insurance. "If I end up in the hospital, we'll be out on the street," she said.
Justin has had to adjust to a new life style. After a lifetime of holidays in Africa and Hawaii, courtesy of his mother's job, he now has to get used to no travel, no movies, and few treats like trips to fast-food restaurants. When he needs clothes, he pays for them by baby-sitting.
A year ago, one of Justin's baby-sitters discovered his singing talent. He has since appeared at the Metropolitan Opera. But Mrs. Montoya does not have the time or the money to shepherd him around, so he has had to give up performing.
Still, with the help of Dr. Sabrino, Mrs. Montoya is learning to accept her life's new limitations and to help her son accept his.
"I feel sorry for my son," Mrs. Montoya said. "All his life he had the best. He still has the best; he just has less of it."

HEADLINE: Mitsubishi Drops Mainframe Computers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Mitsubishi Electric Company said today that it had ended development of mainframe computers, a decision that reflects the movement by computer users away from such large machines.
Mitsubishi's decision also stems from the stiff recession here that is forcing many Japanese companies, despite their long-term perspective, to shed marginal businesses that are unprofitable. Last month, for example, Isuzu Motors gave up development of passenger cars to concentrate on trucks and recreational vehicles. 
 "The development of mainframe computers cost hundreds of billions of yen," said Osamu Matsuo, a spokesman for the company, referring to a figure that translates into billions of dollars. "Since our share is not high, there's no merit in us putting such huge amounts of money into development."
The company will now concentrate on smaller computers and software.
Mainframes account for about 35 billion yen, or $280 million, of Mitsubishi Electric's total annual computer sales of about 300 billion yen, or $2.4 billion. The mainframe business is unprofitable for Mitsubishi, which lags far behind the leaders in the Japanese market -- Fujitsu, the International Business Machines Corporation, NEC, Hitachi and Unisys.
In 1991, Mitsubishi began reselling an I.B.M. mainframe computer in the Japanese market, the first time the American computer giant had let another company sell one of its most powerful machines.
Mitsubishi now offers two mainframe models in Japan, the EX800, which it developed itself, and the more powerful EX900, which it gets from I.B.M.
Mr. Matsuo said that Mitsubishi would continue to sell the EX800 as long as there was demand for it, but would not develop a successor. Customers that want more powerful machines will be directed to the EX900.
The move away from mainframes toward smaller machines like personal computers, work stations and central information repositories known as servers has dramatically reduced profit margins for many computer companies and is in large measure responsible for the severe problems of I.B.M., the world mainframe leader.

HEADLINE: Paine Loses $9.7 Million in Arbitration

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Paine Webber Inc. has been ordered to pay $9.69 million by a three-member arbitration panel of the National Association of Securities Dealers for misleading the nephew of the late Sam Walton, founder of Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
John Robson of Tulsa, Okla., the 38-year-old nephew of Mr. Walton, claimed damages for an errant trading strategy set up by a Paine Webber broker, which involved 403,300 Wal-Mart shares. "It's the only transaction I've ever done with them and it's the only transaction I'll ever do with them," Mr. Robson said of Paine Webber. 
 Paine Webber denied any impropriety in its business with Mr. Robson. "We strongly disagree with the panel's decision and we are considering an appeal," a Paine Webber spokeswoman said, reading from a prepared statement. "Paine Webber fully explained the transaction to Mr. Robson, who is a sophisticated and intelligent individual. We are confident that he understood the involved transaction."
The panel approved the award to Mr. Robson in early December. The granting of such awards by the association usually takes as much as a month to become widely known.
 
Award Part of a Trend
 The award is significant for its size and because it is part of an apparent trend among arbitration panels to award damages against brokerage firms -- not only to the proverbial naive widow or orphan. Mr. Robson is a real estate developer and the Wal-Mart shares involved in his case had a value of almost $23.78 million at yesterday's closing price of $59 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Paine Webber faced similar cases last year. Several wealthy investors won $2.25 million from the firm in September, including $1.67 million in punitive damages. Paine Webber said in September it planned to appeal the ruling in Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla.
Last June, the firm was ordered to pay $2 million in damages to a customer who held an M.B.A. degree from Harvard and had two outside investment advisers. The customer contended that his options positions were so risky that Paine Webber should have prevented him from taking them, even though he had initiated the trades.
Mr. Robson said he had opened an account with Paine Webber after meeting Stephen Brady, a broker, in April 1990. He opened the account with the intention of borrowing money from Paine Webber at interest rates lower than those available at banks.
 
Trapped in 'No Lose' Situation
 Mr. Robson said Mr. Brady had convinced him to engage in a transaction that would protect Mr. Robson from declines in Wal-Mart stock, according to Mr. Robson's filing with the N.A.S.D. The strategy did not work and caused losses as the price of Wal-Mart stock rose, the filing said. It was supposed to be "a no lose situation," Robson said. "Once I was in it, I couldn't get out."
Mr. Robson accused Paine Webber of misrepresenting the strategy and omitting information, according to the arbitration award. In the filing, he also contended that Paine Webber had committed fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, and violations of Oklahoma's deceptive trade practices act.
During the hearings, which ran from July to October last year in Oklahoma City, Paine Webber said the transaction had been "entirely appropriate" because Mr. Robson wanted to protect his investment "in a volatile down market" during the Persian Gulf crisis, according to the N.A.S.D. award. Paine Webber also said the loss had been due "solely to market conditions and the client's own negligence," according to the award.

HEADLINE: Coin-Tossing Computers Found to Show Subtle Bias

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
WHEN scientists use computers to try to predict complex trends and events, they often apply a type of calculation that requires long series of random numbers. But instructing a computer to produce acceptably random strings of digits is proving maddeningly difficult.
In deciding which team kicks off a football game, the toss of a real coin is random enough to satisfy all concerned. But the cost of even a slightly nonrandom string of electronic coin tosses can be devastating to both practical problem-solving and pure theory, and a new investigation has revealed that nonrandom computer tosses are much more common than many scientists had assumed. 
 Mathematical "models" designed to predict stock prices, atmospheric warming, airplane skin friction, chemical reactions, epidemics, population growth, the outcome of battles, the locations of oil deposits and hundreds of other complex matters increasingly depend on a statistical technique called Monte Carlo Simulation, which in turn depends on reliable and inexhaustible sources of random numbers.
Monte Carlo Simulation, named for Monaco's famous gambling casino, can help to represent very complex interactions in physics, chemistry, engineering, economics and environmental dynamics mathematically. Mathematicians call such a representation a "model," and if a model is accurate enough, it produces the same responses to manipulations that the real thing would do. But Monte Carlo modeling contains a dangerous flaw: if the supposedly random numbers that must be pumped into a simulation actually form some subtle, nonrandom pattern, the entire simulation (and its predictions) may be wrong.
The danger was highlighted in a recent report from Dr. Alan M. Ferrenberg and Dr. D. P. Landau of the University of Georgia at Athens and Dr. Y. Joanna Wong of the I.B.M. Corporation's Supercomputing center at Kingston, N.Y. In a Dec. 7 article in the journal Physical Review Letters, the scientists showed that five of the most popular computer programs for generating streams of random numbers produced errors when they were used in a simple mathematical model of the behavior of atoms in a magnetic crystal.
The reason for the errors, the scientists found, was that the numbers produced by all five programs were not random at all, despite the fact that they passed several statistical tests for randomness. Beneath their apparent randomness, the sequences actually concealed correlations and patterns, revealed only when the subtle nonrandomness skewed the known properties of the crystal model.
All five of these systems for producing random numbers have long been used by scientists and statisticians with generally satisfactory results, Dr. Ferrenberg said. Major flaws turned up only recently when Dr. Ferrenberg and his colleagues were testing an ultra-powerful network of computers operating in parallel. Unlike ordinary sequential computer operations that execute programs one step at a time, parallel computing systems break up tasks into separate parts, which can be attacked simultaneously, with enormous savings in time. Parallel computers are so much faster and more powerful than the conventional kind that subtle problems in the programs they are executing come to light relatively quickly.
"We knew what the results of this test should be, and when we got errors for each simulation we tried, I thought there was something wrong with my program," Dr. Ferrenberg said. "But Dr. Wong suggested that the problem was with the random-number generators we were using, and she was right -- a reminder that no known random-number system is foolproof for all applications."
Many relationships and interactions in science and engineering can be described by relatively simple mathematical equations that have definite solutions. But other systems are so complex that the equations describing their behavior, often containing many variables, cannot be solved by ordinary mathematical manipulations.
 
Disorder Hides Order
 During the 1940's, Dr. Stanislaw M. Ulam, a mathematician recruited by Los Alamos National Laboratory to work on the atomic and hydrogen bombs, faced problems in the physics of nuclear explosions that proved too complicated to solve by conventional means. He attacked the problem by inventing Monte Carlo Simulation, in which, by filling in the blanks in his equations with successions of random numbers, he obtained probabilistic approximations of the answers the project needed.
This statistical system created an immediate demand for random numbers used in Monte Carlo equations, and the Rand Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., published an entire book containing nothing but random numbers. But in today's complex simulations, a program typically devours as many as 100 million random digits (binary zeros and ones) per second, Dr. Ferrenberg said, and to satisfy this prodigious appetite, a separate computer program must spit out digits at lightning speed. The need for speed means that any useful random number generator must contain only a few steps and be easy for a computer to execute.
Dr. Ron Graham, a mathematician at A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., explained that typical random-number generators may add a long series of arbitrary digits together, divide the result by some large number, and use the remainder as the basis for computing the next digit in the sequence.
But neither this nor any other machine-based system can produce truly random numbers. If computer-generated number sequences are long enough, repeating patterns inevitably emerge, even though they may remain hidden from their human creators.
Such patterns are sometimes discovered by accident. One system was believed to produce very good "pseudorandom" numbers, until someone plotted the numbers it produced on a three-dimensional graph. When that was done, the numbers proved to lie on a small number of planes rather than being uniformly distributed; in other words, the sequences were anything but random.
Dr. James Reeds, a computer expert at Bell, said the flaws exposed by Dr. Ferrenberg had caused problems for many users of Monte Carlo Simulations, including himself. "We all must take to heart the advice by the great John von Neumann, who wrote in 1951 that anyone who believed a computer could produce truly random sequences of numbers was living in a state of sin."
 
Catch-22 of Randomness
 Random numbers are used not only by scientists but in primitive ciphers. Modern cryptographic systems, however, encipher secret messages between government officials and banks using techniques that do not depend on random numbers alone. Most modern high-level cipher systems are based on the products of two very large prime numbers, products that are enormously difficult to factor into the original primes.
Advanced cryptographic systems, besides hiding the content of secret messages, can produce sequences of random numbers that meet tests for randomness much more successfully than sequences from ordinary random number generators. But they are far too slow for use in ordinary mathematical modeling.
There have been other ideas for improving the randomness of number sequences. Theorists have proposed that true random numbers rather than pseudorandom ones could be produced by machines responding to the radioactive decay of atoms. The instant at which a radioactive atom breaks up is completely unpredictable, even in theory, because it obeys the statistical rules of quantum mechanics, rather than any kind of causal determinism.
But Dr. Persi Diaconis, a Harvard University mathematician famous for his deep analyses of card shuffling and other approaches to randomness, believes that even atomic decay could pose problems. "Suppose such a decay were used to actuate a rotary switch, which would pick a number for the sequence," he said. "The mechanical switch could have some tiny imperfection that would bias the numbers in some way, so you would back where you started."
Another problem that would arise with any system producing genuinely random numbers, Dr. Diaconis said, is that no truly random sequence could be reproduced by the process that created it. In many cases, scientists need to be able to reproduce exact random sequences used in simulations, so that their work can be checked by others.
"We face a basic dilemma," Dr. Ferrenberg said. "We can no longer trust various random number systems that we used to think were pretty good. Now we must test every pseudorandom number generator we use, to see if it works for the particular application we have in mind. But to test it, we must know what the right answer should be, and that's what we're trying to find in the first place.
"I'm getting a lot of gray hair."

HEADLINE: Let Those Economic Winds of Change Blow

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his "Economic Scene" column of Dec. 17, Peter Passell questions Laura D'Andrea Tyson's appointment to head the Council of Economic Advisers, concluding she is not among the "wisest economic heads" of this generation. Does the same discomfort come to the surface in your Nov. 21 Business Day article on Robert Reich, which stigmatizes President-elect Clinton's choice for Secretary of Labor for insights lacking in rigor and precision, relative to mathematical economists? 
 Mr. Passell offers the hypothesis that the President-elect has an economic policy and that those such as Ms. Tyson and Mr. Reich need fill only secondary roles as tinkerers on the already designed machine. I prefer a broader explanation.
American-style economics is getting the benefit of some empirical feedback that is often hard to come by in the social sciences. The evidence that fed back from this election was acrid, strong medicine. Your Dec. 21 Business Day article on economists dissenting from the Little Rock, Ark., conference quotes the viewpoint that the economy is in good shape -- when more than 60 percent of the electorate voted resoundingly for a change.
With such disparity between models and the real world, discomfort from the economics mainstream is not surprising.
In this light Mr. Reich's lack of an economics Ph.D. is an asset. The challenge is to escape the bounds of orthodoxy. The profession's fascination with the esthetics of mathematics has deflected the talents of a generation, and more, from the high-payoff core of the discipline: insights about human economic behavior, particularly economic social behavior. Such economists as Dick Nelson, Paul David, Brian Arthur, David Teece and Cristiano Antonelli in Europe are pursuing a new, more dynamic conception.
How do we recognize the economic wisdom Mr. Passell implicitly wishes for Bill Clinton's Administration? Mr. Passell notes that Ms. Tyson fails the ideology test (she lacks commitment to free trade) and is known for arguments that do not make enemies. If there is any hallmark of the academy most prized, it is that we leave ideology behind, that we invite those of different views to the dialogue.
In economics the seeds for new direction are sown, and the talent at work is nothing short of monumental. If we are to find some new direction, innovative suggestions must be part of the process, the reverse of contemptuous dismissal for being ideologically unsound.
 
DAVID ALLEN
Fellow, Kennedy School, Center
for Business & Govt., Harvard U.
Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 28, 1992

HEADLINE: False W.H.O. Charges

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"U.S. Moves to Replace Japanese Head of W.H.O." (front page, Dec. 20) reports a reference by a senior United States official to a State Department document alleging Japanese intimidation to secure re-election of Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima as director general of the World Health Organization.

Dr. Nakajima has earned a second W.H.O. term.

HEADLINE: Northwest Cuts Fares to Help Spur Leisure Travel

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines yesterday announced fare cuts of up to 40 percent for travelers who bring someone along when they fly.
The cuts in the 14-day advance purchase fares, which are not refundable and require a Saturday night stay, are an effort to stimulate leisure travel. The airline also said the new fares would help reduce attempts by business travelers to circumvent restrictions on current discount fares. 
 "Every airline needs more revenue in a soft economy," Michael E. Levine, the vice president for marketing for Northwest, said in an interview.
 
How It Works
 Under the cuts, which were effective yesterday, two travelers flying together would each receive 20 percent discounts off the lowest discount fares. Three people together would receive 30 percent discounts, and four together would receive 40 percent discounts. There are no discounts for five or more passengers.
For a round trip between Boston and San Francisco, for example, two people could travel for $448 each, three people $392 each and four people $336 each.
"If you travel with a family or friend you will get a very good discount," Mr. Levine said. He added that the cuts were not a short-term promotion but a long-term change in the airline's lowest discount fares. Analysts said the cuts would likely be matched by other carriers.
The fare cuts by Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, are another blow to an attempt initiated last spring by Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, to set up a simpler and more stable fare structure.
 
Undercut American Fares
 Last summer, Northwest undercut Mr. Crandall's plan with deep discounts that caused American to slash fares in an attempt to hold its new fare structure together. The move caused huge losses for the industry.
Mr. Crandall is not expected to react to the current Northwest move by cutting American's discount fares by a full 40 percent to match Northwest's deepest cut. Tim Smith, a spokesman for American, said the carrier was studying the Northwest move.
Mr. Levine of Northwest said that the decision to put in the new fares without an expiration date was a recognition that "fares need to increase for the airline industry to be viable, but that the industry needs to preserve volume leisure bookings without engaging in a constant procession of short-term deep discount sales."
He said that by requiring that one travel with another person for a discount, Northwest hoped to reduce the number of business travelers who have been overcoming restrictions on current deep discount fares, like having to stay over a Saturday night.
Some travelers, for example, were using what is called back-to-back ticketing. Under such a strategy, one would buy a round-trip ticket for travel between New York and Denver and another between Denver and New York and use one part of each ticket at different times. In this way, they could get around the restriction of having to stay over on a Saturday.

HEADLINE: $100 Million Stake in Saks Bought by Saudi Investors

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
A group of Saudi investors that includes Prince al-Walid has purchased a $100 million piece of Saks Fifth Avenue, the New York specialty store chain, through the United Saudi Commercial Bank, the bank reported yesterday.
The investment gives the Prince, who is the largest individual stockholder in Citicorp with 4.8 percent of its common shares, and his colleagues somewhat more than an 11 percent stake in the retailer, which has a book value of $900 million, according to the bank. 
 The bank said it bought the stake on Dec. 22 from Bahrain-based Investcorp Bank EC, which, with a group of Middle Eastern investors, acquired Saks in 1990 for $1.6 billion, $600 million of which was equity. Prince Walid is chairman of the bank, which is also partly owned by Bank Melli Iran, United Bank of Pakistan and the London-based Saudi International Bank, as well as other Saudi investors.
 
Equity Stake Unclear
 Investcorp is a secretive company that also owns Gucci and Color Tile and participated in an effort to resuscitate the Circle K convenience store chain. Last year, it added another $300 million in capital to Saks, but it has always been unclear how much equity in Saks is Investcorp's and how much belongs to other investors.
People familiar with the tight-lipped investment bankers who manage Investcorp said it had sold a piece of its stake to the Prince, who is the principal investor in the transaction.
As a privately held company, Saks does not publicly disclose its financial statements. Its suppliers have speculated for the last two years that the company, which sells high-priced merchandise, was struggling to keep itself in business during economic hard times.
 
Losses Incurred
 Last year, Investcorp issued a statement saying that Saks incurred unspecified losses because of the United States tax structure but said it was otherwise profitable. Suppliers in New York have complained that Saks was extremely late in paying its bills and that it had canceled or returned substantial orders at the last minute.
But this holiday season, the flagship store on Fifth Avenue was packed with shoppers, and Phillip B. Miller, the Saks vice chairman and chief operating officer, said that sales were exceeding the company's plans.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 25, 1993, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 12 about a group of Saudi investors that bought a $100 million stake in Saks Fifth Avenue misstated the relationship between Investcorp, the Bahrain-based investment company that controls Saks, and Gucci S.p.A., the luxury goods retailer. Investcorp owns a 50 percent stake in Gucci; Maurizio Gucci owns the other 50 percent.

HEADLINE: A New Question in Somalia: When Does Free Food Hurt?

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENALE, Somalia, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In this country of hunger, Faaduma Abdi Arush is cursed with corn. She has corn stored in barrels, corn stacked in sacks, corn to be tossed away as chicken feed.
Mrs. Arush survived Somalia's civil war, and she and the farm hands on her large holding even managed to tend her fields, producing a bountiful harvest of corn four months ago. 
 But when she took her crop to the market, she found that the infusion of food from relief agencies was cutting demand. With food prices falling in a bottomless tumble, no merchant wanted to risk buying her corn and then see the prices plummet still lower, she said.
"Nobody is interested," said the slender 52-year-old farmer, pointing in exasperation to the piles of corn already gone bad that had been thrown on a tarpaulin for chicken feed. "Everybody has his own relief supply."
 
When Charity Hurts
 This is the paradox of famine and famine relief. The international charity that stopped starvation eventually can become a problem in itself, threatening to destroy what little remains of the local farm economy.
Six months ago food was so scarce in Somalia that tens of thousands of people were dying of starvation, and the United Nations estimated that another 1.5 million people were in danger of death. Unscrupulous merchants speculated on the shortages, hoarding food to inflate profits and sending prices 500 times above normal.
There are still thousands of hungry and malnourished people in Somalia. But now, after a steady influx of relief food, market prices in the Mogadishu area and in the nearby agricultural regions of Afgoye and the Shebeli River valley have plummeted, especially for grains like rice, sorghum and corn, according to relief agencies, which have been monitoring the markets.
 
Rock-Bottom Prices
 The price of rice is said to be the lowest in the world, with the cost of a 110-pound bag of rice dropping to $5 over the past few months. By comparison, the same amount of a comparable grade of rice would cost about $11.70 in the United States and $120 in Japan.
The lower Shebeli valley, a three-hour drive from Mogadishu along rutted mud roads, normally produces 50 percent of the corn grown in Somalia. During the famine, only a few farmers in the region managed to keep producing, and now most farmers are just trying to get back on their feet and grow enough food for home consumption. But a new harvest is being gathered in the next few weeks, and the main growing season begins in April, threatening to add to the glut.
"We are terribly afraid the current trends in the market will hold and that the corn that's planted will be valueless," said Willet Weeks, a staff member of the American branch of the charity Save the Children, which has been working to resurrect farming in the lower Shebeli valley.
 
Breaking the Hoarders' Hold
 At first, the drop in food prices was considered a measure of the success of the famine relief program, showing that enough food had arrived in Somalia to break the monopoly of the hoarders and bring prices to a point where the middle and lower middle class could afford to buy. The falling prices also served as a disincentive to looting, since the bags of pilfered relief food no longer brought in the same kinds of cash windfalls as before.
But some relief agencies are starting to fear that the relief food will now cause another cycle of dependency by depressing the food market and making it unprofitable for farmers to farm.
"The quantities of relief food which have come flooding in here have devalued the market for local produce," said Mr. Weeks.
A sharp debate is underway among relief organizations on when to begin weaning Somalia from free relief food.
"There are big discussions," said Rhodri Wynne-Pope, the Mogadishu director of CARE. "Are we finished with relief? Are we in rehabilitation? The answer is no. We're not over the top yet."
 
2 Million Need Relief
 The International Committee of the Red Cross still estimates that two million people will continue to be dependent on relief food for the foreseeable future.
"They will need continuous feeding and nobody really knows for how long," said Horst F. Hamborg, the Red Cross spokesman in Mogadishu. "If the relief agencies would go out of the country, it would be a disaster."
But Mr. Weeks of Save the Children said it was time to start cutting back on the free food kitchens. "Prolonging free food distribution as the need is diminishing is a sure recipe for prolonging the famine," he said.
There are even disagreements over what foods to distribute. The International Committee of the Red Cross has been using a high-protein mixture of rice, beans and cooking oil in its feeding kitchens. But some other relief agencies have started to argue that the rice should be switched to wheat. They contend that Somalis are becoming accustomed to a higher-grade diet than normal, causing the devaluation of local products like corn and sorghum.
 
Some Food Sold
 As a first step toward reversing the precipitous decline in food prices, CARE and the United States Government's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance are starting a program to sell some relief food. According to Mr. Wynne-Pope, a third of the next 12,000 metric tons of food for Mogadishu will be sold, with two-thirds being distributed free of charge. The food for sale will be higher quality items like pasta and sugar. Most of the sales will be to small merchants who will be allowed to buy 20-bag consignments of food for resale.
In addition, CARE is taking bids from larger merchants on 350 metric tons of wheat flour arriving in the port shortly. The plans call for the profits from the food sales to be redistributed to the relief agencies in Somalia for projects that would create local employment.
"If you can create a reasonable price and generate employment so people can buy food, you're jump-starting the market," said Lauren Landis, a member of the United States' disaster assistance and relief team.
 
Crop Subsidies Discussed
 The relief agencies are also discussing the possibility of a price support program, in which they would buy the crops of farmers at prices that make farming profitable.
But such plans all come too late for Mrs. Arush. She said she has met with six relief agencies looking for one that would buy her corn instead of getting it from abroad. But she said they went away without any offers. She is resigned now to seeing her crop spoil.
With another harvest approaching, she is no longer producing corn. Instead she has gambled on sesame, reasoning that a sesame crop can keep longer without spoiling. Yet already the signs are troubling. She said food oil is also coming in from the relief organizations and in the past two months the market price for sesame, an oil seed, had dropped more than 80 percent.
With fields of green sesame plants, she is already dreading the moment when she will bring in her crop.
"When I have that," she said, "only God knows what I will do with it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Serbs Skimming 23% Of Bosnian Aid

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
An internal report commissioned by the State Department has concluded that the effort to send relief supplies to the Bosnians is largely a failure, with the Serbian forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina skimming nearly one-quarter of all the aid brought in by air.
The report, which is circulating within the Bush Administration, also complains that the United Nations peace force and refugee officials have often yielded to the Serbs, allowing them to determine what aid is provided and who gets it.
 
Appeasement Is Charged
 "Since the start of the humanitarian airlift," the report said, "the U.N. has also sought to appease the Serb militias by providing the Serb 'authorities,' a portion (23 percent) of all relief commodities arriving by airlift, and by according them the right to inspect each cargo delivered by air or road, to approve or disapprove each cargo.". 
 In addition, the report added, the United Nations has allowed the Serbs to "approve or disapprove the ethnicity of U.N.H.C.R. convoy truck drivers, and to dictate the road convoy's route of entry to Sarajevo; in effect, the U.N. recognized the Serb militias as the de facto authority in the region." U.N.H.C.R. stands for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, whose staff has been delivering aid to the besieged Muslims in Bosnia.
The report was completed last month by Thomas O. Brennan, a relief expert who was hired by the Office of Disaster Relief, a branch of the United States Agency for International Development. Mr. Brennan spent four months in the former Yugoslavia.
In his report, Mr. Brennan said the United Nations had only limited success in delivering aid to Sarajevo "and almost no success to date in reaching groups of people critically at risk in a number of other centers in central and eastern Bosnia."
Asked to comment on the report, a spokeswoman for the United Nations commission said it was true that some of the assistance had been diverted to the Serbs, and that the the Serbs had prevented United Nations workers from providing help to some parts of Bosnia. But she added that the United Nations had no information to confirm Mr. Brennan's estimate that almost a quarter of the supplies delivered by air had ended up in the Serbs' hands.
 
'All Necessary Measures'
 "There is a war going on and we are unarmed people," the spokeswoman, Barbara Francis, said. "The U.N.H.C.R. is doing is best to negotiate the passage of relief supplies under difficult conditions. We do not have enough personnel and we not have enough trucks. Our convoys are turned back by armed irregulars."
President Bush, while refraining from using force to quell the fighting in Bosnia, pledged in July that the United States would "do whatever it takes" to insure that aid is delivered to the besieged Bosnians. And the United Nations Security Council later adopted a resolution calling for "all necessary measures" to be taken to guarantee that the assistance would be provided.
In practice, Britain, France and Spain have deployed about 7,000 troops. This size force means that the United Nations must largely depend on the cooperation of the Serbian authorities to enable the delivery of aid.
The effectiveness of the force, or lack of it, was pointedly raised last week when a Serbian soldier assassinated a Deputy Prime Minister of Bosnia, Hakija Turajlik, who was traveling under United Nations guard en route to Sarajevo from the airport there.
 
Agreement on Assessment
 An Administration official, who insisted on not being further identified, said some American officials agreed with Mr. Brennan's general assessment about the increasingly desperate situation. The official noted a recent cable the American Embassy in Zagreb, Croatia, saying, "There is or very soon will be starvation or death from exposure or disease on a significant scale in central or eastern Bosnia."
Adding to this concern, American officials recently received an appeal from Zepa, a small town in eastern Bosnia cut off from all outside aid. The appeal was transmitted by an amateur-radio operator there, American officials in the Yugoslav region said.
"In Zepa there is no food any more for several months now," the radio dispatch reads. "Is the world at last going to do anything for these people or are they just going to be amazed and shocked when one day after all this somebody enters Zepa and sends from there that there are 35,000 people dead from hunger."
Bosnian officials have also been sounding alarms. Mr. Turjlic, before he was killed, sent a letter to Mr. Bush, appealing for help in getting assistance to small towns in central and eastern Bosnia. Bosnian officials said 198 people from Zepa had died from starvation, sickness and exposure in the last 72 hours. According to the reports, 119 have recently died in Srebrenica, 71 in Bratunac and 45 in Vlasenica.
The Serbs, the report notes, have used the authority given them by the United Nations to turn back several cargos for Bosnia, including firefighters' uniforms and cold-weather clothing flown in on German and American planes.
The Serbs did not allow the United Nations to deliver aid to Muslim towns in eastern Bosnia until December.
"Within Serb-controlled territories it is the Serb 'authorities,' not the U.N., who decide how and to whom relief will be distributed," the report said.
It asserted that workers for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees had accepted the diversion of supplies as the "price of doing business in the region."
 
Withdrawn From Baja Luka
 Some American officials said estimates of the amount of aid being diverted could reach 50 percent of all supplies intended for Bosnia. Noting the problems the United Nations has had operating in the region, they said peackeeping troops and the refugee officials had withdrawn from Banja Luka, where the non-Serb population is suffering from hunger and deprivation.
In recommendations that run counter to American policy, Mr. Brennan urged the West to intervene militarily both to insure the delivery of aid and to stop the killing of Bosnians.
The relief expert urged the Administration to establish havens in the towns of central Bosnia, defending them by the use of American airpower against Serbian artillery. Mr. Brennan also urged that American aircraft retaliate "immediately and massively to any interdictions of relief aid."
Some relief officials are urging military action, even amid the fears expressed by high-ranking officers about the potential of getting bogged down in a Balkan conflict.
Gen. John Shalikashvili, commander of NATO forces in Europe, warned today against trying to solve the Bosnian crisis with military force. In urging caution, he took a different position from that of President-elect Bill Clinton's nominee for Defense Secretary, Les Aspin, who has said that American air strikes should be considered.
"I'm very dubious," General Shalikashvili told reporters at a breakfast meeting, "that you can take these warring factions that are so loosely controlled, so driven by age-old hatreds that have been redoubled as a result of atrocities that have occurred in the last few months, and all of a sudden somehow through punitive action to get them to stop fighting." .
He added: "I'm just hard pressed to believe, particularly from the air, that you can somehow get them to say, oh my gosh, they're bombing that village over there, so let's stop killing each other."

GRAPHIC: Photo: About 25 percent of all Bosnian relief commodities arriving by airlift are given to Serbian "authorities" by United Nations officials, according to a State Department report. A resident of Sarajevo, left, and an aid worker warmed themselves by an open fire in an abandoned store as they awaited food supplies. (Associated Press) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: 'Down With Fidel!' Is Heard in Cuba, but There Is No Sign Yet of His Fall

SERIES: Cuba Alone -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL RINCON, Cuba

 BODY:
After walking for miles and sometimes crawling a last stretch on their knees, thousands of pilgrims began pouring into the Church of St. Lazarus as the sun set on Dec. 16. At midnight, a young priest took the microphone to hail the patron of Cuba's sick and downtrodden.
"Long live the Miraculous St. Lazarus!" he shouted over and over. "Long live Christ the King!" 
 The congregation at the church here, 12 miles south of Havana, burst into rhythmic applause and answered the priest with a more secular chant. "Libertad!" the crowd yelled, ignoring the hundreds of uniformed policemen and plainclothes agents surrounding the church. "Libertad!"
Then, as suddenly as it had erupted, the chanting stopped. More pilgrims pushed their way into the church, forcing others out, and the police agents scarcely moved. Within moments, it was as though the cry for freedom had never been heard.
 
Criticism of Castro From Man in Street
 Such protests, while still rare, have become somewhat less extraordinary as the country's economic hardships have pushed Cubans toward desperation. No longer is it remarkable for a foreigner to hear a Cuban stranger bitterly criticize the Government in a conversation struck up on the street. Occasionally, people wake up to find graffiti attacks on President Fidel Castro, although they are quickly painted over.
Yet three years after the fall of Mr. Castro's allies in Eastern Europe prompted Cuban exiles to begin thinking about packing their bags and making plans for a new Government, there is little indication that the country's growing discontent translates into a more serious challenge to Mr. Castro.
As Cuba's revolution enters its 35th year with the country more isolated than ever, the powerful instruments of political control that Mr. Castro developed with Soviet support remain firmly in place.
"In a whole series of senses, this is not Eastern Europe," said a diplomat who conceded that he had sometimes doubted that Communism would survive in Cuba as long as it has. "The economic situation may be more critical, but the political resources of the Government are greater."
In part, Mr. Castro has retained some popular support by keeping hospitals and schools running and maintaining a system of modest rewards for the loyal party members and military officers who form the the core of his regime.
The recent tightening of the United States embargo against Cuba has also helped the Government stir feelings of solidarity by reviving images of a tiny, heroic country fighting to determine its own fate in a hostile capitalist world. The advent of democracy in Eastern Europe seems only to have fed the Government's propaganda that free elections and free markets do not bring stability or food.
Mr. Castro's Government has also depended more heavily on a state security apparatus that has proved effective at crushing opposition. According to international human rights groups, the harassment and jailing of even the most moderate dissidents has risen sharply over the last two years.
Without resorting to the sort of murder and torture that characterized repression in many Latin American nations in the 1970's and 1980's, Mr. Castro has reduced the opposition to an array of small and mostly timid groups that struggle with one another almost as much as they do with the Government. One of their main problems, dissidents say, is that their sympathizers are so occupied trying to survive that they have little energy left for politics.
More than ever, perhaps, Mr. Castro also benefits from the fact that his most ardent opponents are in exile.
It is a reflection of the sense of powerlessness that has taken hold of many Cubans that some have begun looking to the eventual death of Mr. Castro -- a man of still obvious vigor at age 66 -- as one of the most likely prospects for political change.
Although younger people, especially, have grown more open in criticizing the Government, their sense of freedom seems limited.
Some Cubans critical of the Government do not speak freely even in their own homes. Even in conversations out of doors, it is almost second nature for people to make political references in sign language to avoid being overheard: a thumb and fingers pulled down and together from the chin to refer to the country's best-known beard; two fingers on the shoulder to denote the bars of an officer in the military or state security forces.
 
A Cry That Shocks: 'Down With Fidel!'
 After a former Cuban Air Force major who had defected to the United States in 1991 flew back to the island on Dec. 20 and stole off again with his wife and two children, a few people who had heard the news were making new signs: stretching out their arms, wing-like, or giving a thumbs-up.
As Cubans were choosing representatives to their local councils, the Municipal Assemblies of People's Power, on the day that the pilot defected, a gaunt man broke into a reporter's conversation with several voters at a polling place in the old Havana neighborhood of Regla.
To the shock of his neighbors, the man launched into a torrent of complaints. He had lost his job, he said. He wasn't getting enough to eat. He was tired of always being watched.
"I am not afraid to say it," he said. Then he nearly shouted words that were difficult to understand at first because he kept his teeth clenched tight. "Down with Fidel!" he was saying.
The neighbors scattered, trying not to run. The man went on complaining a while, then turned and walked home. When encountered hours later, he sat glumly on his porch, ignoring passers-by. His protest seemed to have ended as suddenly as it began.
According to the vote count watched by a reporter, nearly 20 percent of the man's neighbors had left their ballots blank or purposely nullified them, scrawling big "X" marks or writing "No." But in conversations around the neighborhood, voters suggested that not voting would have amounted to reckless defiance. According to official figures, the turnout was 97.2 percent.
 
If They Transgress, They Pay a Price
 Despite the fatigue and fear that often seem to dominate its mood, Cuba remains a Caribbean country, one in which people sustain themselves in some part with music and their own dark humor. But more and more, people say, the tension boils over.
Cubans say that fistfights break out for no good reason in the long lines of people waiting for buses or newspapers or the cardboardlike pizza sold from kiosks. Artists cross the unspoken but understood bounds of criticism, although they know it will mean they will have trouble obtaining materials or exhibitions or concert dates.
Many Cubans say such transgressions tend to generate little support because the authorities consistently respond, if sometimes only by tightening their scrutiny of presumed troublemakers.
A 31-year-old laborer, the thin, soft-spoken son of a former political prisoner, said he was certain that the occasional outbursts of protest were useful to state security officials.
"The times when somebody goes crazy and and stands up and yells, 'I can't take this! Down with Fidel!' they just come and calmly take the people away," he said. "Everyone who is there sees that. Do you think they are going to do the same thing?"
 
Castro Remains Larger Than Life
 The slow evaporation of the traditional perquisites for military and party officials and the defection of a few officers have led some diplomats to speculate that the economic crisis might begin to shake the pillars of Mr. Castro's support. There are occasional signs that the loyalty commanded by Mr. Castro may be strong but not permanent, and that he has had problems within his ruling circle.
"Many people abroad think Fidel is like our God -- that he's like Jesus Christ," said Lieut. Col. Helio Julin, the commander of an army detachment on the edge of Havana. "It is not that way. The day he is no longer capable, we will move him aside -- not only Fidel, but the entire leadership."
Last fall, Mr. Castro ousted the official considered his third-in-command, Carlos Aldana, and a full explanation has not yet emerged.
But it is also apparent that to many military officers and party members, the Commander in Chief remains a larger-than-life figure, elevated by his revolutionary deeds to a plane well above the one on which Government mistakes are made.
Diplomats also say that although Mr. Castro's support has fallen precipitously among Cubans, he remains a more popular leader and a genuine hero than his deposed Eastern European counterparts, most of whom were imposed directly by the Soviet Union.
 
The Social Gains Still Mean a Lot
 As ever, the pillars of social development under Mr. Castro -- health care and education, employment and social security -- seem to mean most to those Cubans who recall the poverty that preceded his takeover. But it is not entirely lost on their children, either.
A 24-year-old woman who works at a brewery in the western city of Pinar del Rio, for example, said that for the first time since her childhood she was having trouble getting the medication she takes for asthma. In a country of perhaps a million asthmatics, health officials said, the shortage has become chronic.
But the woman, who gave her first name as Niucha, was adamant that the system had not failed her. Though the daughter of peasants, she noted that state schools had enabled her to become a chemical engineer. She might lack for a little medicine, she said, but her stronger impression of Cuba's advantages was established by the year her father spent in one of Havana's best hospitals, free of charge, after being injured in a car accident.
"In what other country would they do that for you?" she demanded. "Tell me!"
Like recent authoritarian regimes in Chile, Paraguay and Nicaragua, the Cuban Government has sought to nourish its peoples' fears that change might prove worse than the suffering they know. Mr. Castro has also capitalized on Cubans' fears for their homes and farms if exiles from whom they were confiscated were to return.
 
The Dark Side Of Democracy
 From dozens of conversations around the island, it seemed clear that the Government is also having some success in reshaping peoples' views of what democracy had done for Cuba's former allies.
Reports from Eastern Europe play like a Greek chorus on Cuban state radio and television programs: President Boris N. Yeltsin locked in a turbulent battle with the Russian Congress after 80 percent of the country's people are plunged into poverty; disgruntled members of the Solidarity union strike in Poland to protest their lot.
"They have things now that no one has ever seen: unemployment, corruption, children working on the street instead of in school," Rolando Rodriguez, a 23-year-old Havana railroad worker, concluded of the Eastern Europeans. "What they call democracy doesn't work."
More insistent still are the Government's appeals to Cubans' deep nationalism and to the anger felt about the United States economic embargo, even by some of those opposed to Mr. Castro.
President-elect Bill Clinton, who campaigned hard for the traditionally Republican votes of Cuban-Americans, embraced a bill to toughen the embargo as "a big opportunity to put the hammer down on Fidel Castro and Cuba."
The law, called the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992, was enacted in October with the intent of aggravating the economic crisis and weakening the Government's hold on power.
But since its passage, diplomats and even some United States officials say, the measure has at least momentarily bolstered the political control of Mr. Castro and eased his isolation. In November, members of the United Nations General Assembly condemned the embargo by a vote of 59 to 3. Only Israel and Romania sided with the United States; 71 nations abstained.
"For the first time, I think the United States has been placed on the defensive on this issue," Cuba's Foreign Minister, Ricardo Alarcon, said in an interview.
The specter of a United States threat has also been used as justification for the Government's periodic crackdowns on the opposition. Human rights advocates who send abroad information on Cuban abuses, for example, are imprisoned for "enemy propaganda."
After a couple of months of relative tolerance, the Government began again on Dec. 10 to harden its treatment of more moderate dissidents. More than half a dozen people, including two former Communist Party members who are now openly critical of the Government, were surrounded in their homes by state workers, members of revolutionary groups and men carrying walkie-talkies who appeared to be plainclothes security agents.
As usually happens with what are called "acts of repudiation," the incident ended with shouted insults and thrown rocks. Two of the dissidents were arrested, and one of those, Elizardo Sanchez, the leader of one of the island's human rights groups, was also reported to have been badly beaten before being freed on bail.
 
A Mob That Says It's Judge and Jury
 When a reporter and photographer tried several times that day to visit the leader of the island's other tiny human rights group, Gustavo Arcos Bergnes, a mob converged from the street corners to block the way. Identifying themselves as "representatives of the people," the men informed the foreigners they were not welcome.
"What you can say is that we are not going to let anyone come here and change our situation," said one of the men, who identified himself as Rafael Rodriguez. "When you ask objective questions, you must find that Cuba has done more for human rights than any other country in the world."
The reporter asked if the men were not violating Mr. Arcos's freedom of speech.
"We are judge and jury," the man replied. "Today we have decided that there will be no counterrevolutionary press conferences."
The reporter asked what had occasioned that decision.
"Do you not know what day it is today?" the man asked, with no hint of humor. "It is International Human Rights Day."
When the men finally retreated from Mr. Arcos's apartment almost two weeks later, the 66-year-old former diplomat cautiously invited the reporter there.
In fact, Mr. Arcos said, he and other dissidents had intended to make a statement on Dec. 10 calling for democratic changes and freedom for political prisoners. But as he fumbled for a piece of paper on which he had copied something written by Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, it seemed difficult to imagine how the grandfatherly figure might threaten anything.
"I have the hope that we are in the final stage of this regime," he said.
After a pause, he added, "If you ask me on what that hope is based -- well, on hope."

HEADLINE: Arabs to Seek U.N. Pressure On Israel Over Deportations

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Resisting a call by the Palestine Liberation Organization to suspend peace talks with Israel, Arab foreign ministers ended a meeting here today instead with a recommendation that the United Nations Security Council impose sanctions on Israel for deporting 415 Palestinians to Lebanon.
The foreign ministers, who met for two days under the auspices of the 21-member Arab League, said they would push for sanctions if Israel refused to allow the Palestinians, who are Muslim fundamentalists, to return to the Israeli-occupied territories. Israel has rejected all such appeals. 
 In a reference to the Security Council's toughness in dealing with Iraqi violations of United Nations resolutions, the league's secretary general, Esmat Abdelmeguid, told reporters at the end of the meeting: "The law must be above everybody. We want an end to double standards."
 
Fraternal Feelings Fade
 Nevertheless, the evident lack of fervor in private comments by some of the diplomats reflected a deep antipathy, shared by the P.L.O., toward militant fundamentalists from the Hamas and Holy War movements.
The two groups have contested the P.L.O.'s influence in the occupied territories and vehemently oppose peace talks between Israel and Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians. They are also affiliated with wider Arab and Iranian groups trying to overthrow Arab governments and establish Islamic republics in the Iranian mold.
A statement at the end of the meeting said the ministers "call on the Security Council to take adequate measures, including the application of the rules of Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, to oblige Israel to implement Resolution 799 immediately."
Resolution 799, passed on Dec. 18, a day after the 415 men were deported, called for their repatriation; Chapter 7 entitles the Security Council to use sanctions and other methods to enforce resolutions.
 
No Deadline Set
 The United States had served notice that it would resist such a move, even though it has condemned the deportation. When asked what the ministers would do if the United Nations failed to force Israel's compliance, Mr. Abdelmeguid said, "This will come in the proper time," adding that the Arab League had not set a deadline.
The ministers also called for an international force to protect the 2 million Palestinians under Israeli occupation, a proposal that has been flatly rejected by Israel in the past.
By far the clearest indication of how tepid support for the deportees is among Arab countries came from the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, whose country is host to 10 maverick Palestinian groups opposed to peace talks with Israel. He suggested that Arab countries continue their bilateral talks with Israel next week as scheduled and argued that regardless of the fate of the deportees, these direct negotiations with Israel were in the Arab interest.
 
Syria's Counterproposal
 Diplomats said Syria had proposed instead that Arab countries suspend multilateral talks between Israel and various Arab and international parties. Syria has not taken part in such talks and their suspension would not affect its negotiations with Israel.
This suggestion was rejected by most of the ministers, including those of Jordan, Egypt and Saudi Arabia, who are involved in multilateral talks with Israel and who said they would continue them.
Several officials strongly suggested that the fate of the 415 fundamentalists was of interest only to the degree that they might embarrass Israel. The deportees are stranded north of what Israel calls its "security zone" in southern Lebanon: Israel will not take them back, and Lebanon will not let them in.
One P.L.O. official in Tunis went further, saying that Hamas and Holy War may now appreciate that support for their "extremist positions" against peace talks is "minimal."
 
Scorn From the P.L.O.
 The P.L.O. official described the fundamentalists as a "drop of water" in the Palestinian movement which, he argued, supports a peaceful settlement with Israel, despite its call today to suspend the peace talks.
Much of the resentment against Hamas has to do with its growing ties with Iran. Hamas has opened an office in Iran and receives what the P.L.O. describes as "substantial" support from the Sudan and Iran, which have fundamentalist Governments.
In Lebanon, President Elias Hrawi today reiterated Lebanon's position that the deportees were Israel's problem. "We have closed the door to the deportees," he said in a speech to Lebanese expatriates. "For the first time in 20 years, Lebanon has taken a stand."
Lebanese commentators have said that Lebanon, which already has 400,000 Palestinian refugees, was determined not only to block the door to more but to find ways to get many out of Lebanon, if and when there is a settlement that creates an independent Palestinian entity.
Writing in Al Hayat, a London daily, the foreign editor, Khirallah Khirallah, noted in an editorial shortly after the deportation that if Lebanon were to accept the 415 Palestinians, this would encourage Israel to expel "4,000 and then 40,000" more to Lebanon.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Program of Former Foes Feels a Peacetime Chill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Groups of students from Yale University and Moscow State University first met face to face in 1985 during the "evil empire" period of Soviet-American relations. The current academic year ushered in the "empty pockets" era and doubt about the exchange's future.
The program normally includes a two-week visit by 12 Yale juniors to Moscow State and St. Petersburg in March, and a fall visit by Moscow State students to Yale, with side trips to New York and Washington. 
 But the Yale exchange, the prototype for 20 other Soviet-American student programs, is now caught in a financial vise of air fares and what students and administrators say is waning international corporate interest in Russian-American outreach programs.
For the Moscow State delegation, the biggest obstacle is airfare, which surged from a few hundred rubles in the 1980's to several hundred thousand as the national airline, Aeroflot, brought its ticket prices for Russians into line with those of other international carriers. Tickets to New York are now out of reach of all but the wealthiest Russians.
During the first eight years of the exchange program, Moscow State was financed by the Soviet Government. But in 1991 the university's administrators voted to become independent, and that brought an end a plump student government budget for overseas exchanges.
"The Russian solution to this was to look for sponsors," said Brian Carter, the outreach and exchanges coordinator for the Council on Russian and East European Studies at Yale. "They essentially sold two slots on the exchange to nonstudents in return for those businessmen buying all the tickets" for students participating in the program.
But Russian sponsors who could afford to pay for 15 roundtrip tickets -- 12 students and 3 advisers -- to the United States proved so hard to find that the Moscow State delegation had to postpone its fall trip. Artur Demchuk, the Russian coordinator of the exchange, said Monday that he had finally found three sponsors and that the exchange was set for late February.
Russian businessmen understood the value of a tie with Yale, Mr. Damchuk said; "by participating in the exchange they hope to make contacts and find possible business partners."
Moscow State had indicated it would host a Yale delegation even if it was unable to finance the return exchange, but a tight economy also jeopardized the Yale exchange. New Haven participants must not only pay their own airfares but also raise at least $6,000 to cover the cost of being the hosts of their Russian counterparts.
The Yale group appealed to alumni with Russian ties, wrote 100 corporations, with "not a single positive response," and begged exchange alumni for donations, said Andrew Froberg, a senior from Naperville, Ill., who was in the exchange in 1992.
"We've just tried anything that we can possibly think of," Mr. Froberg said. "It's been enormously frustrating."
Two last-ditch appeals, one to a private donor and one to the university itself, yielded enough money for this year's program.
Yale and Moscow State are not alone in their troubles. A 4-year-old program between the University of Maine at Orono and Kharkov University has been suspended because the Ukrainian university cannot afford to participate, said Bill Whitaker, the project coordinator at Maine.
And an exchange between Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., and Tbilisi State University in Georgia has been indefinitely suspended because of the civil war in Georgia.
Yale alumni of the program hope that their university's exchanges and the others can survive current hard times. "I will always retain the memories as well as many newfound friends," said Stanley Wu, a Yale senior from Arlington, Va., who participated last year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Managing the Technological Frontiers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
For a hog breeder in Minnesota, it's using new ultrasound equipment to measure exactly how lean a hog is in a few seconds with a minimum of hassle to man and beast. To a metal processor in Cleveland, it's figuring out how to wield laser light like a blacksmith's hammer to pound extra strength into steel. To a company that tracks the popularity of radio and television programs, it's a device that automatically records any broadcast someone is listening to or watching, no matter where they are, without their touching a button.
No enterprise is without its technological frontiers. Command of those frontiers has long been recognized as a key to competitive success, but the globalization of national economies has stepped up pressures on business leaders and policy makers alike to manage the invention and use of new technology more effectively. 
 "The sea level of competency has been rising in many industries," said Richard N. Foster, a partner at McKinsey & Company who has written and consulted on innovation tactics and policy.
Spending by both business and government on research and development continued to grow through the recession, according to the annual surveys of the Battelle Memorial Research Institute in Columbus, Ohio.
Outlays are projected to edge up again this year to $70 billion by government and $83 billion by industry. It will not be known for years, though, whether the spending increases are supporting more innovators or better results per innovator.
The diversity of the technological frontiers is probably the biggest hurdle facing would-be technology managers and policy makers as they grapple with where to spend money and what tax policies and other rules should influence those decisions.
"There are always going to be fundamentally new developments but the real basis of innovation these days is finding what already exists and combining it in new ways to address a particular problem," said Patrick Nunally, partner in Intellisys Automation Inc., a new-technology development company in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., created by former employees of General Dynamics.
 
Adopting Military Systems
 Mr. Nunally's company has been working with the Arbitron Company to adapt signal-processing technology used in military systems like missile guidance to audience sampling. Currently, audience sampling depends on devices attached to particular television sets and hand-written diaries.
Arbitron plans to introduce a pocket-sized device next year that would automatically recognize any broadcast in the vicinity of the person wearing it from a slight alteration in the broadcast signal.
The fundamental breakthrough underlying the Arbitron device is also behind developments as diverse as smart bombs and lights that go on when someone in the room claps. It is the mathematical work nearly two centuries ago of Jean Baptiste Fourier, whose equations made it possible to separate out the sound or light waves of different frequencies and amplitudes that make up complex sounds and visual images.
Developments in microelectronics, sensors and high-performance materials continuously open up new applications of Fourier's work by allowing more precise signal analysis -- and adjustment -- at lower prices.
In the case of the Arbitron device, Intellisys cuts out snippets of inaudible sound waves that are part of a broadcast sound. Around 99.99975 percent of the signal is unaffected, Mr. Nunally said, but the changes are detectable for the recording device.
"The tricky part is making sure that the frequency you can't hear is still in the range that can get through the cheap speakers on the average TV or radio," he said.
Sophisticated tinkering is also the basis for a metal-pounding laser being developed by Battelle for Wagner Laser Technologies, a Decatur, Ill., subsidiary of the Wagner Casting Co. of Cleveland. The device is based on a high-powered laser Battelle acquired in the late 1970's for government-financed research on fusion energy. During the early 1980's, Battelle figured out how to use the pulses to vaporize paint on the surface of a part and create a small explosion.
By simply covering the surface with water, the explosive forces are channeled into the metal so that photons, as light particles are known, end up compressing the metal just as a blacksmith does when he pounds it.
The concept was useless economically until Battelle shrank the laser, which filled two rooms, and shortened the charging time between pulses from eight minutes to about a second.
New materials developed by fusion researchers at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and electronic controls developed for other applications in recent years have resulted in the prototype of the table-top device that Wagner believes it can turn into a valuable business tool.
"It's still too expensive to use on cheap parts for the auto industry like gears and brackets, but it will be useful for increasing the life of aircraft components," said John R. Koucky, the Wagner executive overseeing the development. Battelle is currently building the first commercial device.
In Chokio, Minn., Bruce Zierke is using ultrasonic images to figure out which of the hogs on his breeding farm are good candidates to help the booming pork industry toward its goal of leaner products. The devices send a sound wave into the animal that is reflected differently by bone, muscle and fat, allowing a receiver to form an image of the animal's insides.
The first device Mr. Zierke bought in 1988 cost $600 and could penetrate only far enough to give him a rough idea of how much back fat the hog had. Last summer, he spent $24,000 for new equipment and software that not only clearly details the back fat but also provides other useful data.
The new device is similar to those used by obstetricians to examine developing babies inside the wombs. But it represents decades of independent work, said James Stouffer, a former Cornell University animal scientist who recently became president of Animal Ultrasound Services.
"We went into a lot of blind alleys trying to overcome all the obstacles in an economic way," Dr. Stouffer said.
While a human will lie still in an ideal setting for capturing a good image, he said, pigs squirm and live in barns where dust, humidity or temperature variations are tough on machinery.
 
Innovation in Small Steps
 All three cases show how most innovation takes place in small steps that are built on years of work and, in most cases, by advances in other sectors driven by considerations over which the pioneers have no control. Experts point out that even if the pioneers could see a way to move farther faster, those they depend on for resources have a lot of incentives to be cautious.
"When you run a factory, for example, you are interested in technologies for everything from assembly to telecommunications to shipping to sweeping the floor, but you are probably only an expert in 2 percent of the technologies on which you are dependent," said George H. Kuper, president of the Industrial Technology Institute in Ann Arbor, Mich. "For the rest, you'll look for incremental opportunities that others bring to you and you won't buy any technological solution until you are confident that there is somebody to call at 3 A.M. if it doesn't work."
