HEADLINE: How Trade Pact Plays on the Farm

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASBURY, Mo.

 BODY:
Proving the adage that the devil is in the details, soybean farmers here are finding that their profits hinge on the fine print of a trade agreement.
In the two months since the Bush Administration struck a deal with the European Community on farm trade, it has become ever more apparent that the pact amounted to a victory for the United States on grain subsidies and a victory for Europe on subsidies for soybeans and other oilseeds.
 
Missing Passion
 Yet amid the brown stubble fields and oak and elm tree copses of southwestern Missouri, the soybean farmers seem to be remarkably indifferent. Their attitudes illustrate how Americans who are the most affected by trade talks are often the least impassioned. 
 By contrast, environmentalists and lobbyists for the soybean industry are angry, and tens of thousands of European grain farmers have taken to the streets of Paris, Bonn and Strasbourg in violent demonstrations against the pact.
"It's real nonproductive to get angry -- we've dealt with unfair trade for a long time," explained Mark A. Larson, a soybean farmer in Jasper, Mo. "As a farmer, you learn to kind of roll with the punches."
The punches, in this case, come in the form of technical details that can easily get overlooked in pressure-cooker negotiations: Was the million-ton limit on production from certain acres to be calculated based on raw oilseed or on the meal byproducts? American farm lobbyists are unhappy because the United States apparently relented to a European demand that the calculation be based on the byproducts, meaning subsidies for European production may decline less than initially believed.
"Every day that goes by, I get less and less pleased," said Steve M. Yoder, the president of the American Soybean Association, St. Louis, the industry's main trade group. "The agreement is getting less and less acceptable all the time."
Mr. Yoder recently sent a letter to Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, protesting the deal and calling it inadequate.
 
Key Support
 The opinions of American farmers and their lobbyists are crucial to winning Congressional approval of a 108-nation trade pact now under negotiation that is aimed at reducing global trade barriers and stimulating a weak world economy. American trade negotiators have long depended on farm groups for political support, because a quarter of American farm output is exported.
[Bush Administration trade officials are now racing to complete a second deal with the European Community that would reduce import tariffs on a broad range of manufactured goods and raw materials. They submitted on Friday a detailed list of tariff cuts to community officials and other international trade negotiators in Geneva.]
 
Confusion on Pact
 Soybean farmers here and in nearby towns said that they had heard few details of the November farm subsidy pact, and were pessimistic about the chances for changing it. They pointed out that soybean prices are now strong. And they said that the pact would not actually hurt them, although it would also not help them nearly as much as their lobbyists had hoped.
"We've been told that it should be to our advantage -- things have been unfair for the last several years," said Marvin L. Riley, who grows soybeans and corn on his 1,500-acre farm here. "I don't know enough about it to know if that's true."
And a few farmers said they understood European concerns, even though they may not like the agreement. "You can't blame the E.C.," said N. Scott Jarrett, who grows soybeans and wheat across the state line in nearby Baxter Springs, Kan. "They came out of World War II and they couldn't feed themselves."
 
Real Impact
 The agreement has two key provisions. It calls for a 21 percent reduction over six years in export subsidies, which the United States and the European Community use primarily to sell grain to poor countries. The pact also calls for a reduction in oilseeds acreage, although some oilseeds could still be grown for industrial purposes on the land set aside.
The oilseed deal has already taken effect, but the export subsidy deal will take effect only if an overall world trade pact is concluded and approved by Congress.
The deal on export subsidies was a modest victory for the United States, farm industry lobbyists said, because the 21 percent reduction would be calculated in such a way that the European Community would actually have to cut subsidies by 38 percent.
Oilseed production in the European Community soared during the 1980's because of the subsidies, depressing oilseed prices around the world. "Fifteen years ago we were in paradise, and since 1980 it has been pure hell," complained Ronald L. Crain, as he sat in a steel-frame barn on his farm in Carl Junction, Mo.
To be sure, the Bush Administration had sought the complete elimination of export subsidies. But the Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter and Reagan Administrations failed to win any reduction in European farm subsidies.
The reduction in soybean acreage was more modest than the cut in export subsidies. A key compromise, reached during the final hours of negotiations in Washington in November, was renegotiated in December.
Top American and European officials agreed on Nov. 19 that the European Community would take 15 percent of its oilseed acreage out of production, but that farmers could plant up to a million tons of oilseeds on this land for industrial use.
European officials then rushed to catch the last available flight that day to Brussels, and nobody bothered to mention how the million-ton limit would be calculated, said Jules Katz, the senior deputy representative for the United States.
 
Conflicting Calculations
 Soybeans and two related oilseed crops, rape seed and sunflower seed, are ground after harvesting. Their oil is used in vegetable oil and the production of paint and ethanol. The crushed residue, known as meal, is fed to livestock.
American negotiators assumed that the limit applied to the raw oilseeds, and drew up legal language accordingly. They also told farm lobbyists that the limit covered raw oilseeds. "When we wrote it up, we said a million tons of seed equivalent of meal," Mr. Katz said.
But after the agreement had been announced, European officials told American officials that they intended to limit production on the set-aside land to one million tons of meal.
Depending on the type of oilseed, 2.3 tons of raw oilseeds may be needed to make one ton of meal. So the European position would mean allowing the production of up to 2.3 million tons of raw oilseeds -- close to what the land might have produced if it were not taken out of production.
 
'A Misunderstanding'
 Mr. Katz called the dispute over measurement "a misunderstanding" and said the actual production on the set-aside land might be small. The community requires that farmers obtain a contract from an industrial user of vegetable oil before planting any seeds on land that has been set aside, and such contracts may not be available for even one million tons of raw oilseeds, he said.
But officials in the soybean industry warned that such contracts could become plentiful if the community encouraged the production of truck fuel from oilseeds.
Environmentalists have joined soybean lobbyists in voicing dissatisfaction with the agreement, and now find themselves in the unusual position of criticizing the Bush Administration for starting out with the right policies and then compromising. Greenpeace, for example, issued a report on organic farming in December that vehemently criticized the pact.
 
Greenpeace Objections
 Greenpeace said that limits on land in production may encourage farmers to use more chemicals and that continued export subsidies may undercut food prices in poor countries.
 A study earlier this year on the effects of a partial liberalization of farm trade predicted that the economic output of very poor, food-importing countries in Africa would be $7 billion less in 2002 with a global trade pact than without it.
But the same study, paid for by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of 24 industrialized nations, found that the output of other poor countries would increase by $91 billion. It concluded that the third world over all needed a global trade pact.

He was complaining about depressed oilseed prices. (Photographs by David Hutson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Municipal Labor Accord Is Seen As Budget Hurdle

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Fiscal experts and Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that the tentative labor settlement New York City reached on Monday with municipal unions, while reasonable, would make it much harder to close the city's budget gap next year and might force the city to cut services.
The fiscal experts also expressed skepticism that the contract would ever produce a more productive work force. But city officials said they believe they have built into the accord a powerful mechanism for hammering out productivity agreements between the city and its largest unions. 
 The three-year settlement, covering 180,000 workers in 19 unions, gives workers wage and benefit raises totaling 8.25 percent by March of 1995. Although it does not spell out productivity concessions, it sets up a three-member panel made up of labor, management and an independent arbitrator to negotiate work-rule changes that could save money.
 
$2.1 Billion Budget Gap
 The question of whether the pact will lead to a more productive work force has become crucial. Mayor David N. Dinkins has very little flexibility in finding ways to close a budget gap that, with the cost of the settlement, has now risen to $2.1 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. He has promised not to raise taxes, and his plan for closing the gap depends on nearly $700 million in highly uncertain aid from the state.
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation, said, "Since it is impossible to increase taxes again, paying for this settlement can only come from an unexpected improvement in the economy, which I certainly wouldn't bet on, or on productivity, or on other means which must involve some reduction in the size of the work force."
Mr. Dinkins, who vowed for a year to hold out on wage raises at the bargaining table until the unions agreed to work-rule changes and other concessions, acknowledged yesterday that he had backed down from that position, saying it had been "a negotiating stance of sorts."
 
Independent Arbitrator
 Mr. Dinkins said the contract sets up an independent arbitrator with power to issue binding decisions and bring the city and the unions together on productivity efforts, a productivity czar of sorts. In the settlement, the two sides have agreed to propose at least six ways to increase workers' efficiency by June, he said.
While city officials would not discuss details of the proposals the panel will consider, officials said the ideas included increasing some workers' caseloads in the Human Resources Administration, allowing the city greater flexibility in deploying custodians in city buildings and reducing the size of crews that repair roads.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group, expressed doubts the city and unions would quickly be able to agree on concrete reforms to raise productivity. Without them, the city will have to slash workers to balance the budget. "You're basically ending up with a situation where John Q. Public will pay for it in one of two forms -- either through higher taxes or service cuts," he said.
The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said it was still unclear whether the city would have to cut services to close next year's budget gap. The city, he said, can pay the $428 million cost of the labor settlement in the next fiscal year through bond refinancing and unanticipated revenues from taxes, fees and investments. But doing that would still leave a $1.7 billion budget gap.
The city is hoping the state Legislature will approve a $680 million package of new taxes, Medicaid relief and educational aid, as Mr. Dinkins has requested, but the state's own budget problems make that uncertain. Even if the state delivers the aid, the city "will still have additional stretching to do," Mr. Michael said.
 
Mixed Reactions
 Labor leaders had mixed reactions to the productivity panel.
"Certainly when you look at what we've had before, there has been a reluctance on our part to engage in this process because there was no clear independent measure of what constituted productivity," said Arthur Cheliotes, the president of the Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America. "It usually meant a reduction in the work force."
James Butler, president of Local 420 of the hospital workers union, said the panel was "window dressing" that allowed the Mayor "to save face." He said his union would not be receptive to proposals aimed at getting more work from fewer workers.
But Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, said creating a panel or a czar in effect guarantees there will be decisions made."
The city's Labor Commissioner, James Hanley, predicted the panel would work because for the first time the city has established a citywide method for negotiating work-rule changes and other concessions, with binding decisions by an arbitrator. "I think it's a breakthrough," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Everybody Loves a Winner, And Especially His Coattails

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
WHATEVER honeymoon Bill Clinton might enjoy after becoming the nation's 42d President, he will be hard pressed to match the outpouring of affection already being displayed along Madison Avenue.
Commercials and advertisements featuring Mr. Clinton, whether congratulating, celebrating or spoofing him, seemed to have begun appearing almost as soon as the final votes were tallied on Election Night. The main reason: To an industry that thrives on change, Mr. Clinton's victory embodies change, whether significant (the baby boomers succeeding the World War II generation in leadership roles) or frivolous (Socks the cat replacing Millie the dog as First Pet). 
 And how could executives whose boundless optimism makes Pollyanna look pessimistic not embrace a candidate who ended his acceptance speech by declaring, "I still believe in a place called Hope"?
"People wish the man well and hope for the best," said Pete Smith, a vice president and associate creative director at Martin Williams Advertising in Minneapolis. "It's a chance to express that good will."
Martin Williams created a print ad promoting 3M's Post-It Tape Flags line of color-coded tabs. The ad, which began, "It's a big job, Mr. President," called the tabs a tool to locate "the little points that might help frame a solution" to problems like the economy, the environment and education.
Using the President-elect in ads typifies a time-honored marketing strategy called borrowed interest, which tries to draw attention to a product by linking it to a larger event or personality.
"Any cause you can associate with him is to the benefit and value of that cause," said Dr. Jay Winsten, director of the Alcohol Project at the Center for Health Communications of Harvard University's School of Public Health in Boston.
Between Christmas and New Year's Day in 1990 and 1991, the broadcast TV networks ran a public-service commercial, furnished by the Harvard Alcohol Project, in which President Bush warned of the perils of drinking and driving. But after the election, Dr. Winsten said, the project decided to have Mr. Clinton participate instead.
"It was done to capitalize on the freshness, newness and excitement of the incoming Administration," he added. "At this point in time, Bill Clinton is a very attractive and popular spokesperson."
That thought was shared by Nat Whitten, co-creative director at Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano in New York.
"His approval ratings are still quite high, so it's a good time to use him," said Mr. Whitten, whose agency created a print ad for Moosehead beer pegged to the contretemps over Mr. Clinton's military service record. An excerpt from a newspaper report that he "ate a hamburger and drank a Moosehead draft beer" at a restaurant appears under the headline "Proof that President-elect Clinton didn't avoid the draft."
Mr. Whitten added, "If a year from now everyone has questions about Clinton's talents, we probably wouldn't run the ad."
Ads like Moosehead's also offer an inexpensive method for a marketer to become associated with Mr. Clinton, far cheaper than, for instance, spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to become an official sponsor of activities at his inauguration next Wednesday. And such ads can skirt problems that often accompany more intrusive promotions. For example, Anheuser-Busch is being accused of turning the inaugural parade into a "beer commercial" because its Clydesdale-drawn Budweiser wagon will take part.
Some marketers, though, are demurring at pitches carrying Clintonesque themes. Despite extensive coverage of the President-elect's penchant for visiting its restaurants, McDonald's "has no plans to use him in any of our advertising," said Jane Hulbert, a spokeswoman in Oak Brook, Ill., because "it's just not something we do."
Mr. Whitten said that made sense because "it's like the President-elect wanting to associate himself with McDonald's, rather than the other way around." Presidents come and Presidents go, but the Golden Arches, presumably, are steadfast.
And some marketers are already adopting other political figures, on the theory that Clintonmania will spawn a spate of lookalike ads.
General Mills, for example, is running a television commercial, by CME KHBB Advertising in Minneapolis, presenting a self-described "breakfast expert" who looks and sounds like Ross Perot, complete with flip charts, colorful colloquialisms and a toll-free "800" telephone number. He urges viewers to prove that Oatmeal Crisp with Apples "can beat the taste deficit" by calling the number to obtain a coupon good for $1 off a package of the new cereal.
Craig Shulstad, a spokesman for General Mills in Minneapolis, said response to the commercial, at 65,000 calls as of Monday, had far exceeded expectations. He said that the company would run the spot for three weeks instead of the planned two weeks.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aide Demurs on White House Staff Cuts and Recovery Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 12

 BODY:
Appearing to retreat on more campaign pledges, a top aide to Bill Clinton signaled today that the President-elect might not be able to cut the White House staff by 25 percent or have an economic-recovery plan in place by Jan. 20, Inauguration Day, as promised.
Mr. Clinton's spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, today described the White House cuts as a "goal," and said no more on the recovery plan than that it would be ready in "the next few weeks." The Clinton campaign had stressed that it would be vital to have a recovery plan in place on "day 1." 
 This comes after several days of suggestions from Mr. Clinton's economic advisers and other allies that the President-elect's promise of a tax cut for the middle class was less likely because of the worsening Federal budget deficit. It also comes after Mr. Clinton himself said the soaring deficit numbers meant he would have to modify his pledge to halve the deficit in four years.
While the Clinton team has explanations for these modifications, they nevertheless raise questions of which campaign pledges Mr. Clinton does or does not intend to keep.
 
When Demands Compete
 In his campaign platform book, "Putting People First," Mr. Clinton declared, "We will reduce the White House staff by 25 percent and challenge Congress to do the same."
Today, Mr. Stephanopoulos said such a reduction was a "goal" of the Clinton Administration but not an ironclad commitment. The issue seems to have come up because Mr. Clinton is having trouble satisfying competing demands about who will work where in the new Administration.
With a week to go before assuming office, he still has not named his White House staff because of what transition aides describe as wrangling over who gets in and who does not, although some Clinton aides say the staff announcements are finally expected Wednesday.
The Clinton people have also encountered legal and other obstacles that make cutting the staff more complicated than many expected. For instance, some White House positions exist by statute and can be dissolved only by Congress.
 
'There Will Be Some'
 "We are looking at the White House staff right now," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "We are trying to figure out where it is most appropriate to make cuts. I don't know where those cuts will be, but I am certain there will be some."
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton and his aides also repeatedly said they would have an economic-recovery plan ready by the time he took the oath of office. And on Nov. 24, Robert B. Reich, Mr. Clinton's choice for Labor Secretary, who was then heading the economic transition team, said in an interview that Mr. Clinton planned to present his economic package to Congressional leaders before Inauguration Day so they could get working on it immediately. That goal has now clearly slipped away.
"We are reviewing the exact situation we are dealing with in terms of the deficit," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Asked then when they would have a full economic program before Congress, he said, "I think what we are going to try to do is make sure we have the whole package and present it in a coherent way, and I think we will have that over the next few weeks."

HEADLINE: Campuses Are Hurt by Computer Giants' Woes

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The nation's two largest computer makers, I.B.M. and Digital Equipment, last year announced huge retrenchments, and the fallout has now reached America's college and university campuses.
Educators nationwide fear that high-technology education will sharply decline because the companies are reducing their financial and material contributions. In the mid-1980's, when the economy was booming, computing was the hottest major on many campuses, and computer makers, hungry for new markets and eager to have their latest systems adopted by future engineers and managers, were donating computers to universities by the truckload. 
 "Companies like I.B.M. and Digital Equipment would donate work stations to universities, and then they would staple a check to the outside of the box to support faculty research," said John Moussouris, a computer designer who was a co-founder of the Mips Computer Company, in Sunnyvale, Calif., part of Silicon Valley.
Now, the International Business Machines Corporation, based in Armonk, N.Y., and the Digital Equipment Corporation, based in Maynard, Mass., have been laying off thousands of workers or paying them to retire. And educators say that not only will graduates find scant job opportunities in the computer field, but that the financial support for innovative research, the supply of new hardware and fellowships for graduate study is rapidly drying up.
"We're at a watershed," said James H. Morris, chairman of the computer science department at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. "The restructuring of the computer industry has put academic computer science at a turning point."
 
Gloomy Outlook for Year
 Craig Smith, publisher of the Corporate Philanthropy Report, in Seattle, said he expected a new round of cuts in the corporations' giving next year. "Until now, I.B.M. and Digital have generally been able to retain levels of contributions," Mr. Smith said. "But now there's a sense that they are dealing with a structural problem, and in 1993 we might see some more significant declines."
Jean Bonney, Digital Equipment's director of external research, said, "There will be changes and there will be clearer goals and more scrutiny on projects, and our funding will be more closely tied to business."
But John A. Boudreaux, an I.B.M. spokesman, maintained: "We're not slashing our contributions dramatically. They're being reduced, but institutions will still be getting money from I.B.M."
 
Deeper Cuts Expected
 Administrators at those institutions, however, are running scared. At Massachusetts Institute of Technology, for example, administrators fear that I.B.M. financing of computer science, around $1 million a year for the past 20 years, may soon dry up. "Every time they come here it is like a funeral," said Michael Dertouzos, director of the M.I.T. Lab for computer science.
The cuts made by big computer makers are not likely to dramatically affect kindergarten through 12th grade. "There has been a lot less reliance on philanthropy in the past decade, because we haven't been doing research and development," said Leroy Finkel, director of media services for the San Mateo County Office of Education in California.
There is also less reliance on I.B.M. products in elementary and secondary schools, which have long been prime territory for Apple Computer. By contrast, Apple has contributed significant amounts of equipment to colleges and universities but has not provided as much financing for research and graduate work as I.B.M.
During the 1980's, I.B.M. and Digital Equipment lavished money on grand research projects, like Project Andrew at Carnegie Mellon and Project Athena at M.I.T., both of which developed software for tying powerful desktop computers known as work stations into networks that share data. Now such projects have ended or are being scaled back, Professor Morris said.
 
An Industry Redefined
 "I'm very concerned because I don't know how I can continue to be an institution that leads in information without the strong support of the computing industry," said John W. McCredie, vice provost for information systems and technology at the University of California at Berkeley.
In the redefinition of the computer industry in recent years, smaller, more nimble manufacturers than I.B.M. and Digital Equipment have come to the fore. But these companies, like Sun Microsystems and Apple Computer, which make machines and software, Microsoft, the world's largest software company, and Intel, the pre-eminent chip maker, have not picked up the slack.
The newer computer manufacturers have been slow in developing philanthropic programs, and the programs they have are comparatively small scale. And while hardware makers frequently donated money and equipment, hoping that faculty members and students would write software that would make their new computers more attractive to customers, powerful software companies like the Microsoft Corporation of Redmond, Wash., have little incentive to subsidize the development of software that might compete with their own, said Professor Morris.
The campus cutbacks by I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, and Digital Equipment, the second largest, are noticeable both in absolute dollar amounts and in the form the contributions take. I.B.M., which is still the largest corporate contributor to nonprofit and educational institutions in the United States, says that it has consistently given 40 percent of its contributions to education during the last seven years. But the company has cut its overall corporate contributions to nonprofit organizations and universities from a high of $189.2 million in 1985 to an estimated $120 million last year.
 
New Formula for Donations
 Digital's corporate contributions to nonprofit organizations and universities totaled $25 million last year, down from $30 million in 1991. Last year, the company announced support for a $15 million three-year project to develop advanced computer databases at the University of California at Berkeley, its largest current research investment.
In 1992, both companies changed the ratios according to which they match donations by employees. Digital now provides 50 cents for each dollar contributed by an employee to a university; it used to match dollar for dollar. I.B.M., which donated $2 for every employee dollar, has reduced that to 1-to-1. And where I.B.M. once matched some employee dollar contributions with $5 dollars worth of hardware, it now offers $3 worth.
Such matching contributions are an important source of corporate giving to the nation's universities, said Priscilla Lewis, an executive at the Council for Aid to Education in New York City. In 1991, matching grants accounted for 36 percent of all corporate giving, Ms. Lewis said.
Nationally, she said, corporate support for education is stagnant, having grown at an average inflation-adjusted rate of 7.7 percent a year from 1976 to 1987. Today, unadjusted growth rates are 2 to 4 percent.
 
Some Bright Spots
 While support for basic computer science and electrical engineering research may suffer, some educational institutions may benefit from computer makers' focus on specific technologies. For example, at M.I.T.'s Media Laboratory, a research institute that specializes in new multimedia computer technologies, I.B.M. doubled its financing last year, said Nicholas Negroponte, the laboratory's director.
"I.B.M.'s movement to consumer electronics and multimedia make us more of an attractive funding target than general computer science and electrical engineering departments," Mr. Negroponte said.
David Farber, a computer scientist at the University of Pennsylvania, commented: "In a funny way, the contraction of these companies seems to make them much more focused on where they should invest in the universities. They're much less willing to dump a million dollars of miscellaneous hardware, and they're much more willing to support research related to their interests."
The shift to research that can be quickly translated into new products is well suited to some computer scientists, but it has raised deeper concerns about the shift away from basic research. Some educators say they fear that the shift will be accelerated by the Clinton Administration's desire to harness technology policy to international competitiveness.
Educators at some campuses said they had anticipated some of the changes in the computer industry and had taken precautionary measures.
Richard E. Kaplan, the vice provost for research and academic computing at the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles, said the campus had made a commitment to phase out all mainframes by October.
Yet the problems faced by the biggest computer makers may still haunt his campus, Mr. Kaplan said. At stake may be a high technology library that U.S.C. has been planning for more than a decade. The project was to rely on donations of computer equipment and multimedia software when completed next year. Mr. Kaplan said now he does not know where the hardware will come from.

HEADLINE: U.S. Students Advance In Math, for a Change

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
After years of grim news about the academic performance of American elementary and secondary school pupils, a new preliminary report indicates that the nation's students made significant gains in mathematics achievement between 1990 and 1992.
Overall average proficiency among American students rose five points since 1990 in the 4th, 8th and 12th grades, the three grades tested, according to a preliminary report made public today by the National Assessment of Education Progress, a Federal testing organization. 
 The report found some unevenness in the gains. Students in the Southeast lagged behind students in the Northeast, the central United States and the West. There was a significant decline in the average proficiency of eighth graders in poor urban areas. At all three grade levels, private school students performed better than public school students.
While 37 percent of the students tested failed to reach what was considered a basic level of achievement, it was an improvement over the last test in 1990, when 43 percent failed to reach that level.
 
'A Half-Grade Increase'
 Though troubled by the setbacks among the poor, education officials were generally buoyed by the results.
"This is a big jump in math scores," said Education Secretary Lamar Alexander at a news conference announcing the test scores. "This is not like a one-point increase in the S.A.T. scores," the Scholastic Aptitude Test for college admissions. "This is more like a half-grade increase in achievement."
But Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, criticized both the timing and the results of the tests. Full state-by-state results will be issued in the spring.
"My reaction to the premature reporting of the results of the 1992 NAEP in mathematics is premature delight over the progress our students have made since 1990," said Mr. Shanker. But he added, "I would be curious to hear how the money-does-not-make-a-difference crowd of the outgoing Administration explains the fact that test scores in disadvantaged urban districts just happened to stall during the past two years of a recession."
Known as the nation's report card, the 1992 NAEP test indicated that the overall percentage of students who performed at or above the proficient level rose to 20 percent from 15 percent in 1990. Proficiency achievement by grades rose to 18 percent from 13 percent at the 4th-grade level, to 25 percent from 20 percent at the 8th-grade and to 16 percent from 13 percent at the 12th grade.
 
Effect of New Standards
 Mr. Alexander and several educators attributed the increases to the new standards adopted by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics two years ago. The standards detail a mathematics curriculum that all teachers should use nationally.
This is the second time that the NAEP report categorized students' performance by achievement levels: basic, reflecting partial mastery of fundamental knowledge and skills; proficient, indicating solid academic performance that represents competency over challenging subject matter, and advanced, meaning superior performance.
The percentage of students who reached the basic level rose to 63 percent this year from 57 percent in 1990. Achievement rose to 3 percent overall from 2 percent at the advanced level, at which students should be able to "generalize and synthesize concepts and principles."
Mr. Shanker noted that the standards for the different levels were under dispute. The General Accounting Office, the Government auditing agency, criticized the methodology of how the standards were set in 1990.
The National Assessment of Education Progress is working on setting standards for the other academic areas, including reading and writing, social studies and geography.
Critics fear that schools will be unfairly judged by the poor achievements of their children.
 
Highlighting Inadequacies
 But Mark D. Musick, chairman of the National Assessment Governing Board, an independent group that oversees the testing organization, said that setting standards would help demonstrate that American students, though improving, still lag behind students from other industrialized nations.
"We still have a long way to go," Mr. Musick said.
The 1992 achievement levels were established by the American College of Testing under a $1.4 million contract. The 1992 assessment tested 26,000 students in 1,500 public and private schools across the nation.
Ramsey Selden, director of the state education assistance center of the Chief State School Officers, said, "The most encouraging thing in this is that the percentage of kids who met the proficient level, an ambitious standard where we want the bulk of our kids performing, that's increased 4 to 5 percentage points."

HEADLINE: Phyllis Wallace, 69, A Labor Economist In A.T.&T. Lawsuit

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Phyllis A. Wallace, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died last weekend at her home in Boston. She was 69.
Officials at M.I.T. said yesterday that she had died of natural causes. 
 Dr. Wallace was Professor Emerita of Management at the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T. In a career that spanned nearly four decades, she achieved distinction in a field in which there were few women.
In the early 1970's she directed studies for a Federal lawsuit charging the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, then the largest private employer in the United States, with racial and sexual discrimination. The suit led to a 1973 decision that found the company guilty of discrimination and produced significant changes in its employment practices.
 
Two Funds in Her Honor
 Her book, "Equal Employment Opportunity and the A.T.&T. Case," published in 1976 by the M.I.T. Press, discussed the strategy and importance of the case.
Dr. Wallace retired in 1986. The Sloan School endowed two funds in her honor to support black doctoral candidates and black visiting scholars at the school.
She was born in Baltimore, and received a bachelor's degree from New York University in 1943 and a master's and doctorate from Yale University in 1944 and 1948, respectively.
Early in her career she taught at the City College of New York and at Atlanta University, and worked for the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Her appointment at the Sloan School in 1975 made her the first woman to gain tenure on its faculty.
She is survived by her mother, Stevella Wallace; a brother, Samuel Wallace, and three sisters, Lydia Mills, Ophelia Wallace and Margaret Campbell, all of Baltimore.

HEADLINE: The Opportunities of Incumbency

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
While incumbency surely carries its burdens, it also offers substantial opportunities, as Mayor David N. Dinkins has demonstrated repeatedly in the last two weeks.
In the first 12 days of the new year -- one in which the Mayor plans to run for re-election -- Mr. Dinkins unleashed a blitz of actions and initiatives intended to court constituencies central to the coalition that put him in office three years ago. 
 The Mayor began the new year in San Juan, P.R., attending the inauguration of a new Governor of Puerto Rico and in effect paying homage to the Puerto Rican New Yorkers who constitute about 80 percent of New York City's Hispanic voters. Two days later, he delivered his annual State of the City address, which offered a smorgasbord of inexpensive but carefully targeted new or enhanced city services, from day care to medical clinics for the poor.
 
Fulfilling Promises
 Mr. Dinkins followed that with an announcement of a new city registry for unmarried heterosexual and homosexual couples. The registry and some of the rights that will come with it, like the same access for registered "domestic partners" that spouses now enjoy at city hospitals and city jails, was intended to begin to meet campaign promises the Mayor made three years ago to gay voters.
Those same voters were no doubt also in mind the next day, when Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced he had awarded the permit for the St. Patrick's Day parade to a new coalition of liberal Irish-Americans who would permit lesbians and gay men to march as groups for the first time.
Then, the Mayor reached a tentative contract agreement on Monday with a coalition of municipal labor unions whose enthusiastic support was crucial to his narrow victory in 1989 over his Republican challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney who lost to Mr. Dinkins by 2 percentage points.
Mayoral advisers contended yesterday that important governmental considerations helped determine the timing and substance of many of the recent announcements. Some advisers argued, for example, that more immediate pressures -- including state arbitration of the teachers union's contract, which is to begin today, and the need to complete a preliminary city budget by the end of the month -- had more to do with the timing of the labor settlement than did political considerations.
 
'An Imperative'
 "Each one of these things has a rationale and an imperative of its own," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. The mayoral race is, of course, a significant part of the administration's calculations, Mr. Steisel conceded. "But to say that the election is the motivating factor would be wrong," he said.
Even so, in just a dozen days the Mayor managed to address major concerns of many of the critical elements of his political coalition: Hispanic New Yorkers, gay voters, liberal whites and municipal union members. Labor is in some ways particularly critical because it carries a second appeal for Mr. Dinkins since a major portion of the city unions' members are black New Yorkers, who make up his core constituency.
"Hey, it's election year," said Norman Adler, a political consultant and lobbyist. "Ed Koch did it, everybody does it. What he's done is good politics. He is strengthening his base, and that's what he's got to continue to do."
Of course, the Mayor did not offer these important constituents all that they want. Some representatives of gay and lesbian groups were dissatisfied last week when the Mayor's plan for registering domestic partners did not include what they view as a major campaign promise from 1989: the same health insurance benefits for the live-in partners of homosexual city workers as those for heterosexual spouses.
Mr. Dinkins also remains politically vulnerable to the efforts of his political opponents to make his incumbency work to their advantage.
 
Management Problems
 Mr. Giuliani and Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, who plans to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary next September, have already indicated that they will seek to tie the Mayor to the recession, unemployment, perceptions about crime in New York and a host of other urban ills, including what they consider Mr. Dinkins's failure to make local government more efficient.
Incumbency also leaves the Mayor subject to criticism over management problems in city agencies. Just yesterday, Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales said the city would hire 300 new caseworkers for the Child Welfare Administration, to increase by 20 percent the number of child-abuse investigators. The decision followed a series of articles in The New York Times that described how sharp reductions in the number of caseworkers had undermined the city's ability to protect children from abuse.
Mr. Dinkins's incumbency also allows political opponents to question his leadership, particularly during crises like the civil unrest in Crown Heights and Washington Heights. Some elected officials and political consultants, for example, think that the outcome of the mayoral race could hinge on the extent to which liberal Jewish voters turn against the Mayor in anger over his handling of the racial violence in Crown Heights.
Mr. Giuliani described incumbency as a double-edged sword for Mr. Dinkins. It allows the Mayor to tailor city initiatives to constituencies and to make ceremonial gestures, he said. But it also leaves a record, including the labor settlement, that Mr. Giuliani said would enable him to characterize Mr. Dinkins as a "status quo mayor" unwilling to make fundamental changes in how the city works.
"I would just ask people, 'Do you want four more years like this?' " said Mr. Giuliani. "If you want four more years like this, vote for him."
Mr. Adler argued, though, that incumbency gave Mr. Dinkins significant advantages, and he contended that, with the exception of President Bush, incumbents did far better than expected last November.
"Incumbency may have looked like an albatross, but the people who saw it as an albatross were looking at the wrong bird," Mr. Adler said.

HEADLINE: Bush's 'Courageous' Economic Error

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The President's top economic adviser said today that he had wanted the Bush Administration to take more aggressive steps to spur the economy's recovery from recession, but that Mr. Bush, despite the electoral risks, made a "courageous" decision to try to ride out the rough period without such measures.
This resulted not only in political defeat, suggested Michael J. Boskin, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, but also in an economy that is still growing too slowly. The current growth rate is about 3 percent, and the Administration predicts that rate will continue through 1993. 
 Mr. Boskin made his comments in briefing a small group of reporters on the release of the Economic Report of the President, an annual book-length document required by law, whose publication was speeded this year in light of the inauguration next week of President-elect Bill Clinton.
 
Rebuts Gloomy Notions
 Among other things, the report took pains to challenge two notions that its authors said had gained considerable currency -- that the United States is in substantial economic decline and that its recent problems can be traced to major policy mistakes over the last 12 years.
"The American economy is the largest and most productive in the world," the report states. "Not only does it have the highest per capita levels of productivity and output of any industrialized country, but even its modest growth in 1992 surpassed the performance of other major industrialized countries."
Germany and Japan slipped into recession in 1992, joining Britain and other countries whose growth has lagged.
 
Urges Caution on Health Care
 The report also cautioned against seeking solutions to the explosion in health-care costs that are not grounded in the economics of the marketplace.
Both national health insurance and so-called pay-or-play plans -- the latter requiring employers to either provide coverage for workers themselves or pay the Government to do so -- would have perverse results, the council said. Among them would be a slower pace of medical innovation, long waits for treatment and little, if any, reduction in the growth of total spending on health, the report said.
Until today, it had not been so clear that the chairman by late 1991 was actively urging greater stimulus for the lagging economy, though with little effect.
"It was a close call, economically," Mr. Boskin said, indicating that he thought an extra boost might turn out to have been unnecessary but would have posed little risk and thus "perhaps the political outcome would have been different."
 
Cites Bush's Biggest Error
 Acknowledging that "hindsight is seductive," as he put it, Mr. Boskin said the Administration's biggest error was failing to convey to the public a full and accurate picture of the state of the economy. While he did not elaborate, Mr. Boskin seemed to be referring to an extended unwillingness to declare publicly that the economy was not as bad as portrayed by the Democrats, for fear, perhaps, of being labeled out of touch or insensitive.
By Election Day, however, the economy had expanded -- albeit modestly -- for six straight quarters and inflation over the preceding 12 months had been held to 3 percent. And while job growth was extremely slow, the unemployment rate, 7.3 percent, was more than three percentage points below the 1981-82 peaks.
Still, as today's report also described, the nation's productivity growth has been extremely sluggish for more than two decades, and Mr. Boskin said he could not claim that a recent pickup represented anything more than normal post-recession improvement.
"I'm cautiously optimistic about that," the chairman said, "but it's way too early to tell."

Paul Wonnacott, left, and David Bradford, helped Mr. Boskin write the report. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gunman Killed in Chase Said to Have Violent Past

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 12

 BODY:
State police investigators today were trying to piece together what may have set off an Old Lyme man's rampage through rural Connecticut on Monday, and to determine whether the state troopers who cornered the gunman and shot him to death after a multicar chase acted appropriately.
It remained unclear whether a 13-year-old junior high school student who was wounded at the scene was shot by the gunman, Dwight G. Pink Sr., or by the troopers. The boy was riding in a school van that Mr. Pink, 42, apparently commandeered in East Haddam after a car he had stolen became disabled. 
 "As far as who was actually responsible for shooting the boy -- we still don't know," said Sgt. Scott O'Mara, a spokesman for the Connecticut State Police.
But the sergeant said that given the "extreme disregard for human life" that Mr. Pink had demonstrated, the decision to force the van off the road appeared to have been correct. "Quite conceivably there could have been some fatality in the van had troopers not intervened," he said.
 
Signs of a Violent Streak
 Meanwhile, some Old Lyme residents who knew Mr. Pink said flatly that they were glad he was dead. They described him as cruel man with a criminal history and uncontrollable violent streak that many neighbors had witnessed more than once.
"It should have happened a long time ago, before innocent people were hurt," said Ronald Rando, owner of Ron's Gunshop in East Lyme. Mr. Rando said his 82-year-old father was badly beaten by Mr. Pink in August, during a robbery at the store.
Mr. Pink was out on bail, awaiting trial in that case, and had a long criminal record before that of burglaries, robberies, and assaults, according to state police records.
The teen-age student who was wounded, Joshua Sawicki of Ledyard, was shot once through chest, but his doctor at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Jonathan D. Blancaflor, said that the boy was expected to fully recover and to be out of the hospital in perhaps a week. The bullet passed through the youth's body, making more difficult the task of deciding what caliber of gun shot him.
The police troopers were all firing 9-millimeter pistols, Sergeant O'Mara said. Mr. Pink had a small caliber handgun, the sergeant said, but he declined to identify it further.
 
Wounded Salesman Improves
 The other man wounded in the two-hour drama also showed improvement today. David L. Walden, 37, a car salesman from Old Saybrook who was accompanying Mr. Pink as he test drove a Mustang, was forced from the car along Interstate 95 in East Lyme and shot three times by Mr. Pink, according to the state police account issued today.
Mr. Walden, who was wounded in the face, the abdomen and the shoulder, underwent eight hours of surgery at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London on Monday night. His condition was upgraded from critical to serious about noon today. A hospital spokeswoman said Mr. Walden might lose the sight in his left eye.
Police officials today issued an appeal for the driver of sky-blue van, seen carrying Mr. Pink at one point in the afternoon, to come forward for questioning. Witnesses said the van, which had damaged rear doors and out-of-state license plates with dark letters on a white background -- possibly New York's -- gave Mr. Pink a ride to a gas station in East Haddam to buy a can of gasoline after the stolen Mustang ran out of gas.
 
'Just Happy He's Dead'
 The second student riding in the hijacked school van was not injured and the van driver, Irene Schott, of Norwich, was treated only for cuts from broken glass and released.
People who knew the dead man said they should consider themselves lucky. One neighbor who said she knew the family for 20 years vividly described seeing Mr. Pink viciously beating his dog with a baseball bat while the animal was tied up.
At Kelly's Silo Inn, a bar in Old Lyme from which Mr. Pink had been banned for several years for disturbing other customers, the manager, Joanne Stone, said Mr. Pink had threatened to kill her just last Friday for refusing to serve him.
"He lived the way he died; it didn't surprise me at all," Ms. Stone said. I'm just happy he's dead, and I'm relieved that I wasn't hurt and that more people didn't get hurt by him."
A lawyer who was defending Mr. Pink in the gun shop robbery case, Edward J. Peters, said today that Mr. Pink was unemployed, had been under the care of a state-employed psychiatrist and was taking lithium, a mood control drug.
Approximately 60 troopers -- some of whom were off-duty and responded to the scene after hearing radio reports -- were involved in the chase. It was unknown if any of them knew who was in the van or his record and reputation as they pursued it through the wooded roads in the south-central part of the state.
The communities involved are too small to have their own police departments and rely on the state police, based at Troop K in Colchester. Troop K is home to the state police's SWAT team and the hostage negotiation team, both of which were en route to the scene when Mr. Pink was killed.

HEADLINE: Where Have All the Flowers Gone?

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
In a move that may transfer a $70 million industry along with a dash of color from Manhattan to the Bronx, the four largest flower wholesalers in midtown announced yesterday that they would move to a new site that will be built in the next two years in an abandoned rail yard in the South Bronx.
They said they expected the 14 other wholesalers who remain in midtown to follow them, providing an economic boost to the Bronx while carving the heart out of the Flower District, for more than a century one of the few fragrant sections of Manhattan, where potted trees often crowd the sidewalks and men embracing bundles of roses bustle between storefronts and waiting trucks. The wholesalers are now concentrated in storefronts along the Avenue of the Americas, between 26th and 28th Streets. 
 "The city just got more and more congested, and the businesses have gotten bigger," said Victor Rallis, owner of George Rallis Inc., a wholesaler, and president of the group of the four wholesalers that signed the lease for the new space yesterday. "People say, 'Why did you pick the Bronx, of all places?' Well, we picked a location that happened to be the Bronx."
The wholesalers will be the first tenant of a development project project that sits on 90 acres in the moribund Penn Central Rail Yards across Bronx Kill from Randalls Island, in the Port Morris section. From there, Mr. Rallis said, it will be easier for wholesalers to truck their tulips and birds of paradise deeper into New Jersey and Connecticut, in addition to serving their present clients -- retailers who arrange and sell the flowers -- throughout the region.
 
'We'll Miss Them'
 Mayor David N. Dinkins praised the decision because it would keep the wholesalers, who had considered moving to New Jersey, in New York. But it was clear that the Bronx's gain was Manhattan's loss.
"We'll miss them," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "They added a great deal of life and color to their neighborhood." But, she said, "in the long haul, it's great for the industry, great for the Bronx, and great for the city." She said she did not know who would move into the vacated space.
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said the decision was a victory for his borough. "The South Bronx has taken a lot of hits over the course of decades, but I think one can argue that good things are happening now," he said.
Mr. Ferrer said that, for the Bronx, the wholesalers' move would mean "that a once nearly abandoned piece of land next to some of the city's soundest and most exciting and potentially profitable infrastructure will now be revived."
The city is providing no special incentives to the wholesalers beyond the standard package available to any city company that relocates in the city limits, said Neil Pariser, senior vice president of the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, a private, nonprofit economic development corporation that works closely with the city government.
 
350 Jobs Moving
 To help with the move, each of the wholesalers who moves will receive a grant from the city, probably of $30,000 to $40,000, Mr. Pariser said. In addition, the wholesalers will receive a tax credit of $500 for each employee they move to the new center.
In all, the wholesalers expect to move 350 jobs when the building is opened, and to create another 300 as they expand over the following three to four years. They expect the other 14 wholesalers to sign leases as the project proceeds.
Mr. Rallis said he regretted leaving the Flower District, where his father created his business in the 1940's. "Change is not always easy, but we're businessmen," he said. "We have to do what's best for our business. The market is not going to survive in its present location."
The three other wholesalers who have signed a lease are Paul Meconi Inc., Harry Vlachos and Kiamos & Tooker, according to the South Bronx group. The wholesalers will move into a 120,000-square-foot building to be constructed for between $7 million and $10 million. Construction is to begin this August and be completed by fall 1994.
Some of the handful of flower and plant retailers scattered through the Flower District said they were considering following the wholesalers up to the Bronx because it was cheaper and more convenient for them to stay near them.
 
To Move, or Not
 "We'll definitely move," said Susie Grohusky, manager of the Mornhurst Gardens Company, a retail and commercial landscaping business. "This is a place you're supposed to get good deals, and it makes no sense now."
But others said the wholesalers' move would not hurt them badly. "Wherever they move, they'll deliver anyway," said Anna Lebberes, manager of International Garden Inc. "The only problem is when we run out during the day." She said she also worried that she would receive inferior flowers once the wholesalers move, since she would have to rely on deliverers and would no longer be able to pick them out herself.
Mr. Rallis said the wholesalers may eventually be able to ship their flowers even farther from the New York region by using the rail lines, which the Galesi Group, the developer of the project, plans to revive.
"They're going to become a major modern rail terminal that's going to be able to compete with anything else in the region or the nation," said Francesco Galesi, president and principal owner of the Galesi Group. He said he expected a paper recycling and de-inking plant and a waste transfer plant to move into the rail yards alongside the flower wholesalers.

HEADLINE: First Student Testifies in Suit To Integrate Hartford Schools

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 12

 BODY:
Milo Sheff, the 13-year-old Hartford student who is the lead plaintiff in a lawsuit seeking to integrate his city's schools with those in 21 suburbs, testified today in Superior Court. His subject: his first experience at summer camp.
"Did you have trouble at first?" Wesley Horton, a lawyer for the plaintiffs in the suit, known as Sheff v. O'Neill, asked him. 
 "Yes," replied Milo, who had just testified that in eight years of school in Hartford, he has had one white classmate. "I was the only black. It was hard to relate because I didn't know what to talk about. I dressed different, I talked different, we had different interests."
 
Problems With Sports
 Mr. Horton asked if even sports posed a problem.
"They were really into baseball," Milo said of the camp's white children. "I have no idea what baseball is about."
After three weeks of testimony by teachers, principals, sociologists and education professors, Milo Sheff was the first child to take the stand. In a suit contending that the racial and economic segregation in Hartford's schools denies children an equal educational opportunity, Milo established a new voice in the courtroom, that of a young person convinced that he was missing something important by attending schools that have almost no white students.
Does it make a difference that you have not had white classmates, asked Mr. Horton, who in the 1970's brought a landmark suit, Horton v. Meskill, on behalf of his own son that won greatly increased state aid for schools in Connecticut's cities.
"It's hard to know about somebody if you haven't talked to him," Milo said. "I have had experiences, but what about those people who haven't had the experiences that I have had?"
Those experiences, he said, occurred during three years at a summer camp in Litchfield County operated by the United Church of Christ. His mother, Elizabeth Sheff, is a lay minister for the denomination and director of its Just Peace Ministries.
 
Experiences at Camp
 Life at camp became better after his first week, he said, once he got to know the other children. And in subsequent years the camp attracted a larger number of children from minority groups.
Would that kind of experience be good for other children in the city, Mr. Horton asked. More than 90 percent of Hartford's students are black or Hispanic.
"It would be good for everybody," Milo said, "so when they get to the workplace they won't be like I was, confused."
Milo is one of 19 children from Hartford and its suburbs who are named as plaintiffs in the suit, which is seeking to break up the racial isolation and concentration of poor children in Hartford's schools by linking them with those in surrounding towns.
The suit contends that white children in Hartford's suburbs, as well as black and Hispanic children in the city, are harmed by attending schools that do not reflect the racial and ethnic diversity of the society they will enter as adults.
The assistant attorney general leading the state's defense, John R. Whelan, had no questions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Corporate Debt Volume Still Heavy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The heavy volume of new corporate debt continued yesterday, but investor demand remained strong, pushing down the yield of a large new Canadian issue to the low end of expectations.
Activity also picked up in the municipal market with the pricing of a $1.6 billion bond issue by the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency. Most of the issue was a refunding of bonds previously sold when interest rates were higher. 
 Traders expect that the supply of new issues will continue to weigh on the Treasury market, though demand for many issues remains strong.
The Province of Ontario priced its record $3 billion deal yesterday. That offering in the corporate market and the $1.6 billion North Carolina Power Agency offering in the municipal market were the main focus of the day. Though the demand was strong for the new issues, the magnitude of the supply is expected to exert upward pressure on yields, traders noted.
Ontario's $3 billion global bond, which was marketed to large investors on Monday, was priced yesterday through the joint lead underwriters Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc.
The coupon for the 10-year global bonds was 7 3/8 percent. The bonds can be sold simultaneously in all markets and trade according to the domestic market's currency. Underwriters priced the bonds at 99.693 to yield 7.419 percent, or about 76 basis points more than the comparable United States Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The yield spread was on the low end of the range traders had expected for the Canadian issue. Some had seen a spread as high as 79 basis points.
In the municipal market, the tentative pricing of a $1.6 billion North Carolina Municipal Power Agency bond issue through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company was the centerpiece.
The maximum yield at pricing was 6.50 percent for a revenue bond due in 2021. For an investor in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent bond yield is about 9.03 percent.
Much of the debt included refunding revenue bonds. Yields on shorter-maturity serial bonds ranged from 3.85 percent for an issue due in 1995 to 6.30 percent in 2009. Longer maturities offered yields of 6.47 percent in 2012, 6.45 percent in 2013, 6.27 percent in 2017, 6.30 percent in 2018, 6.45 percent in 2022, 6.33 percent in 2023 and 6.42 percent in 206.
The revenue bonds to raise new cash were priced to yield from 4.60 percent for an issue due in 1997 to 5.65 percent in 2002, 6.25 percent in 2007 and 6.30 percent in 2013.
 
Treasury Securities
 In the government securities market, trading was steady but described as dull, as prices took an early dip about the time the Ontario deal was priced.
"There was some selling when the Canadian deal was priced as investors swapped into corporates, creating a downward draft," said John P. Costas, a managing director of the First Boston Corporation. He said many traders were preparing for today's auction of new seven-year Treasury notes.
Mr. Costas described the auction of new seven-year notes as the first significant supply for the Treasury market to absorb this year.
Traders said testimony yesterday by the Treasury Secretary-designate, Lloyd Bentsen, before the Senate Finance Committee, which recommended his confirmation, had little impact on government security trading.
Some of the strength in the movement off yesterday's lows was traced to the North Carolina Power deal, which may have caused some buying of Treasuries. The issuer bought government securities to put aside to pay for future interest and principal payments on the municipal issue.
By late in the day, the price of the 30-year bond was off 11/32 , the third decline in four trading sessions. The yield rose to 7.47 percent, from 7.46 percent on Monday. In when-issued trading, the seven-year note being auctioned today was offered at a price to yield 6.37 percent.

HEADLINE: Bank Money Market and C.D. Yields Down

 BODY:
Yields offered by banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week that begins today are slightly lower than in the week before.
In the metropolitan New York market, the weakness was mostly in money market returns; outside the area, it was in certificates of deposit, according to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates were down modestly for the second consecutive week. The auction is regarded as a harbinger of deposit rate changes at banks in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction was down 8 basis basis points for a three-month Treasury bill, to 3.07 percent, and down 9 basis points for a six-month bill, to 3.28 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the New York area, the average money market account is down one basis point, to 2.72 percent. Analysts note that the slide in money market accounts is now more than a month old.
 
6-Month Yield: 2.98%
 The average New York rate for three-month certificates remained unchanged at 2.82 percent, while the average yield on a six-month C.D. slipped another basis point this week, to 2.98 percent.
For the most part, commercial banks offered only slightly weaker rates than those at savings banks.
The banks posting the sharpest changes in C.D. yields this week included the Republic National Bank for the second straight week. Republic dropped the yield on its money market account by 16 basis points, to 2.58 percent.
River Bank America shaved 10 basis points off the yield on its three-month and six-month certificates, to 2.90 percent and 3.15 percent, respectively.
Outside the New York market, average money market account yields at 20 large banks are unchanged this week, at 2.68 percent, while the average six-month C.D. is off a basis point, to 3.02 percent.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
On the New Deal's Effort to Put Youth to Work

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The New Deal and American Youth
Ideas and Ideals in a Depression Decade
By Richard A. Reiman
253 pages. University of Georgia Press. $35.
Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal echoes down to our time because, once again, there's talk of action in the first hundred days after Jan. 20 to spur the economy and provide jobs by Government intervention. Roosevelt's alphabet agencies -- W.P.A. (Works Progress Administration); C.W.A. (Civil Works Administration); C.C.C. (Civilian Conservation Corps), and a half-dozen others -- were created to overcome the Depression and to lift spirits. 
 The N.Y.A. (National Youth Administration), one of the smaller agencies created during the Depression, is the subject of "The New Deal and American Youth," by Richard A. Reiman, a historian who teaches at Georgia Southern University in Statesboro. His well-documented book is an object lesson in what happens when a daring program has to leap the legislative and administrative hurdles in Washington.
Mr. Reiman writes that agencies like the National Youth Administration were considered dangerous and un-American by their opponents. Yet the National Recovery Act in 1933 and the N.Y.A. in 1935 were in the American grain; advocates of change could point to the Morrill Land Grant Act in 1862, which established over 70 land-grant colleges, laying the foundation for government-sponsored higher education.
The youth agency was intended to help Americans between the ages of 18 and 25. But what kind of help and toward what end? One group of officials in Washington considered it to be just another relief agency, with make-work jobs in schools and community centers. Another group saw it as a teaching tool to educate the young about how to function intelligently in a modern democracy.
The Roosevelt Administration wanted to do something for the hundreds of thousands of school dropouts and unemployed youths, particularly those whose families were on relief. Unlike the Civilian Conservation Corps, whose young men worked on specific projects to plant forests and clean rivers, the youth agency was treated with suspicion as a form of regimentation. The President's advisers feared that the public might not want a vague national organization for young people. Many Americans were aware that in Nazi Germany, millions of marching students served in the Hitler youth organization.
Mr. Reiman writes: "The humane liberal democrats who advised the President did not quite know what to make of the Hitler Youth and its equivalents. That such programs warranted condemnation was never in doubt. The question was whether the New Deal ought to establish a democratic alternative to the Hitler Youth. In other words, an important thrust of the early New Deal was to hold adults to their patriotic loyalties by demonstrating that a democracy was just as capable as a dictatorship of fulfilling the health and employment needs of its people. Should not the New Deal establish a program to impart this lesson to the young? A significant faction in the New Deal thought the answer to this question was yes."
At first, Aubrey Williams, the executive director of the youth agency, concentrated on relief for the unemployed, but eventually jobs and education were combined. The agency began to fill the educational void, with training as well as aid programs for high school and college students. New Dealers believed educators should supplement their middle-class-oriented curriculum, aimed at dispensing a traditional liberal-arts education, with job-training courses. Through the N.Y.A. and other agencies, the Roosevelt Administration started down the road toward transforming the Federal Government from a financier of schools to a schoolhouse itself.
The author points out that the youth agency came into existence by executive order, not legislative action. Needless to say, Eleanor Roosevelt worked behind the scenes to bring the the agency to life. The Emergency Relief Appropriation Act of 1935 had allocated nearly $5 billion for relief. From that pie $50 million was sliced for the N.Y.A., which was placed under the nominal jurisdiction of the Works Progress Administration. This was an administrative way to conceal the idealistic aims of the youth agency.
One of the little-known facts found in "The New Deal and American Youth" is that the youth agency was used as a conduit to aid a small number of refugees from Hitlerism; through the agency, they were promised the private sponsorship and support that was necessary to enter the United States. But President Roosevelt and the State Department stepped gingerly, as books like Arthur D. Morse's "While Six Million Died" have noted in detail. Mr. Reiman writes, "The N.Y.A.'s ability to rescue refugees was hampered by other factors, including the Administration's passion for anonymity, its obsession with 'Americanization,' and its focus on public opinion to the exclusion of the needs of the refugees."
"The New Deal and American Youth" would have been a stronger book if the author had gone beyond the libraries and archives and interviewed a number of people who, as young men and women, had been assisted by the National Youth Administration. This could have personalized the significance of the New Deal agency and explained its lasting effects. Nevertheless, there's enough here to recommend the book for the President-elect's night reading shelf.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Confirmation Roundup;
H.U.D. Choice Wary of Selling Public Housing

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Henry G. Cisneros, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, voiced strong reservations today about one of the Bush Administration's showcase programs, which is meant to sell public housing units to their tenants.
"I don't think we can outright endorse the concept," he said in an interview after a confirmation hearing before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. He said he feared burdening the tenants with expensive or decrepit homes. 
 Mr. Cisneros's predecessor, Jack F. Kemp, had placed the program at the center of what he called "a conservative war on poverty." But the program's critics, including those in the President's Office of Management and Budget, had called it dauntingly expensive, with renovations and financing costing as much as $100,000 per unit.
In testimony at today's hearing, Mr. Kemp enthusiastically endorsed Mr. Cisneros. Afterward, he was diplomatic when he learned that his signature policy might be in jeopardy.
"He doesn't have to be convinced by me," Mr. Kemp said. "I think he's going to be convinced by the residents themselves." About 250 tenant groups are in the stages of planning to buy their homes, but only one has signed a purchase agreement since the program begin in 1991.
Mr. Cisneros, the former Mayor of San Antonio, spoke approvingly of the community development block grant program, which allows mayors wide latitude in spending Federal money. But he criticized the Administration's budget office, saying it was holding up $2.5 billion for low-income housing because of disputes over regulations.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Confirmation Roundup
H.U.D. Choice Wary of Selling Public Housing;
Bentsen Promises Focus on Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for Treasury Secretary, joined a parade of appointees today in declaring that new forecasts of higher budget deficits would make it harder for Mr. Clinton to cut taxes for the middle class as he promised during the campaign.
Mr. Bentsen, who Mr. Clinton says will be his chief spokesman on economic matters, vowed to focus on cutting the budget deficit, saying that to achieve this goal, taxes would have to rise, spending would have to fall and growth would have to accelerate. 
 In a confirmation hearing before the Senate Finance Committee, which he headed for six years as a Texas Democrat, Mr. Bentsen added his voice to that of other Clinton aides who said the tax cuts for families earning less than $80,000 a year were being reconsidered.
Under gentle questioning from his colleagues, Mr. Bentsen suggested that one way to cut the deficit would be to hire more auditors to increase tax collections. He also said Mr. Clinton's advisers were considering a gasoline tax and accelerating plans to set an older age limit for receiving Social Security benefits.
Notwithstanding his vow to reduce the deficit over the long term, Mr. Bentsen left the door open to increased spending to spur the economy right away, saying the growth rate expected for this year would not be enough to make a large dent in the jobless rate.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, served as chairman of the committee today. In an unusual move, he asked the committee to vote to send the nomination to the full Senate even before Mr. Bentsen had answered any questions. Mr. Moynihan asked for a vote as soon as he saw there was a quorum -- and the vote was unanimous.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DAMON STOCK PLUNGES ON EARNINGS PROJECTION

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
Stock of the Damon Corporation lost nearly a third of its value yesterday after the laboratory testing company said it expected to report fourth-quarter results well below Wall Street estimates. Damon closed down $5.75 a share, or 28.9 percent, to $14.125, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. More than a million shares changed hands, representing 6 percent of Damon's stock outstanding. 
 Damon, based in Needham Heights, Mass., said fourth-quarter earnings and sales would be higher than 1991 levels but below expectations in part because of economic weakness in California and New England. Damon, which specializes in preventive health screening, AIDS testing and substance-abuse testing, also cited competitive pricing pressure and reduced sales during the dissolutions of join ventures in Michigan and Northern California.
