SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 4087 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY;
Excerpts From an Interview With Clinton After the Air Strikes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with President-elect Bill Clinton at the Governor's Mansion here by reporters from The New York Times.
Q -- Clearly Saddam Hussein has not got the message on complying with U.N. sanctions. What people would like to know is: What are you prepared to do -- what are you ready to consider doing beyond what has already been done -- to get this man to comply with U.N. sanctions? 
 A -- Well first, let's begin with today's events. I support the action that the United States took today. The President and his team in the White House consulted with us all along the way. The relationship we've had has been appropriate under the circumstances. That is, they have to make the tactical decisions. They have access to facts and information and resources that we don't.
I think that it was the right thing to do. I think a couple of times over the last year and a half we have sent mixed signals. I think that the hope is we will send a firm and consistent set of signals. So let me just say I wouldn't rule out reviewing our options in the future. But I want to see what he does in response to this mission today, and we'll see what happens over the next several days and we'll take it from there.
Q -- We have now introduced a battalion of ground troops in Kuwait. Would you rule out reintroducing ground troops into this theater?
A -- I wouldn't rule out any options. I think the actions in sending the battalion there, given the attacks of the last couple of days, was an appropriate action. And I hope that we can resolve the bitter disputes there. The Kuwaitis have made some overtures in areas they feel they are ready to discuss with Iraq about their investments in that area.
Q -- Clearly, the relationship between Bush and Saddam became a very personal one. Do you think there is the possibility for a fresh start between you and Saddam? If he were here on the couch, what would you say to him?
A -- If you want a different relationship with me, you could begin by upholding the U.N. requirements to change your behavior.
You know, I'm not obsessed with the man, but I am obsessed with the standards of conduct embodied in those U.N. accords, and I think that if he were sitting here on the couch I would further the change in his behavior. You know, if he spent just a half, maybe even a third of the time worrying about the welfare of his people that he spends worrying about where he positions his SAM missiles and whether he can aggravate Bush by violating the cease-fire agreement, what he's going to do to the people who don't agree with him in the south and in Iraq and in his own country, I think he'd be a stronger leader and be in a lot better shape over the long run.
Q -- Do you sense that he is also interested in pushing personal buttons, that he has done that with George Bush and wants to do that with you as well?
A -- I honestly don't know how to answer that. I've thought about it, obviously, a lot. And I thought to myself this last week: why is this man doing this? And I've asked others who've had more experience with him than I do. I'm genuinely interested. But I honestly don't know.
Q -- But you don't take the view that there can be no normal relations with this man or with Iraq as long as he is in power?
A -- Based on the evidence that we have, the people of Iraq would be better off if they had a different leader. But my job is not to pick their rulers for them. I always tell everybody, "I'm a Baptist; I believe in deathbed conversions." If he wants a different relationship with the United States and with the United Nations, all he has to do is change his behavior.
Q -- What is it that you can do, what can the United States Government do, to offer Saddam Hussein anything that moves us beyond the game we're playing now?
A -- I don't know the answer to that. It's obviously something that we'll have extended discussions on. But the main thing is we can't do anything to give him or anyone else the slightest indication that we are wavering. You know, look at what he did with this whole issue back a few months ago on who could be in the inspection teams in the government buildings. It's one of these deals where the Bush Administration, in an attempt to be somewhat reasonable, gave him some cushion about who gets to look in the buildings, and none of this seemed to have any effect.
If I knew what was motivating him -- is he sticking it to Bush at the end? Is he trying to test me? I just don't know. If I knew what was motivating him, I could come a lot nearer to answering your question. But since I don't know that, all I can do is deal with what I can see, and that is his conduct. I wouldn't rule out anything, except to say that I have no intention of seeing our nation back away from the adherence to the guidelines.
 
On Cooperation With Bush
 Q -- Walk us through what must be an extraordinary situation. You are a week away from coming into office. And you have found yourself not only with a hot spot, but many? What considerations went through your mind in deciding to support the Bush Administration policy?
A -- This one was easier than some. This was a harder-than-usual transition in the sense that we're involved in Bosnia (both the no-fly zone and the negotiations are showing some movement), hanging fire in Somalia (and what exactly is the parameter of our behavior there?), and our mission in Haiti, where our transition wants to do a little more there, with the cooperation of the Administration.
It's kind of an interesting thing. As far as I know, this level of interface and this level of activity is fairly unprecedented, especially when you change parties. I wish I could give you some high-flown issue. This was an easy deal for me. All during the campaign I took the position that we had to hold them to the guidelines, that in times past right after the war, the allies eased up, and he abused the Kurds.
When it was clear to me that he was doing things that he should not be doing with the placement of the SAMs and the incursion into Kuwait, it was clear the Administration was going to have a response and that the allies would support it. It was just easy to say, "You do it, and I'll support you." I didn't even give any thought to it. It was just the thing to do.
Q -- You talked about the unusual transition and the world practically blowing up around us. How do you keep yourself from becoming overwhelmed by world problems when you promised to focus on the economy and go all out from the first day in office on domestic issues?
A -- The answer is to set aside a disciplined amount of time to it, to be on the offense, international, you know. I did say that, but also if you go back, I gave a major foreign policy speech in 1991 at Georgetown, and then at several times during the course of the primary and the general elections talked about foreign policy and said basically that foreign and domestic policies were two sides of the same coin and that we had to be initiators in the world and that, you know, we're so caught up in the world that if I tried to sort of hunker down and pretend all this wasn't going on, eventually -- and I mean very near term -- I would simply be consumed by problems I was not taking the initiative on.
The answer that I would give the American people is: I still think our first priority is to rebuild America at home, economically and otherwise. I still intend to do those things which I laid out in the campaign to try to increase our investment focus, to try to make us more competitive, to try to generate jobs and raise incomes. But a part of my job, especially now at this moment in our history, is not only to tend to these fires that have been burning but also to develop an approach to the world which will permit us to have a post-cold-war world that is a good place for freedom and democracy and market economics and which supports global growth and minimizes global misery. I just think that's a part of the job.
So the answer to your question is the discipline with which I do it. The debates -- and I don't want to revisit the election, but I remember once someone asked me when President Bush and I were debating all this, someone gave me a chance to take a shot at him because of the number of days he had been out of the country. And I said -- I remember it very clearly -- I said I had no problem with the time he spent traveling abroad. My differences with him had to do with what he does with the time he is in the United States.
Q -- Are you going to find that just by shear number of hours, you won't have the time to spend on domestic problems?
A -- No. I disagree with you. If I organize it right, we'll do fine. We'll have to work hard, but we'll do fine. There are a lot of problems -- I mean, I ticked them off earlier -- you've got to deal with from Day One.
Q -- You said the easy deal for you was the decision today to take some action against Saddam. What of the other issues you've named? I guess Somalia and Bosnia come to mind. For instance, in Somalia, when you take office you've got to decide how long you're going to commit troops.
A -- In Somalia, that also was easy in terms of supporting the policy. I felt very strongly for a long time that the United States should do more to try to end the suffering there. And I thought it was a doable thing. I thought it was militarily manageable. And while tragically we've lost our first soldier there yesterday, the mission seems to me still to be appropriate. The real difficulty in Somalia was -- we were talking about it -- was I never believed that the Administration's optimistic hope that they could bring our combat force out by January the 20th could be achieved.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- How long can you imagine staying there?
A -- Well, I don't know. I think they'll be there several more weeks though, and I think what we have to work out is a peace-keeping force that's multinational, that's smaller, and where we're in a support role, maybe even offshore. I still think that the general outline of the mission can be accomplished. I have no reason to believe it can't. But it was somewhat more complicated than this response. I had to imagine what it would be like taking it over in midstream.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- Would you take us through, from Monday to today, the conversations that you had with the Bush Administration? Exactly what kind of contacts went on between you and the White House? How did it evolve?
A -- Well, I think all that I should say about that is that Brent Scowcroft has been very good throughout this entire transition to be in touch with Tony Lake and Sandy Berger in Washington. And Nancy Soderberg is here with me, and we just had daily conversations. And then this morning, when everything was approved for the mission to go forward, and the weather and everything cleared, the President called me and we talked about it.
Q -- What time was that?
A -- Sometime in the morning, sometime in mid-morning, and we talked. But he knew that he was formalizing an understanding that had already been developed at the staff level.
Q -- Was there a point when he said, "Governor, I'm going to do this. Do you approve of it?"
A -- No. He called me and thanked me for my support because he knew we had already given him our position and told him that we weren't sure he had any choice under the circumstances. And just, if that's what he wanted to do, then we'd support him.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- Saddam has shown that rationally or not, he doesn't seem to be afraid of the United States. If he's not afraid of George Bush, why should he be afraid of you?
A --: I don't know if fear is the issue. But all I know is he misread this country pretty badly in the days before the Gulf War. There was really an effort to try to work with him with a cease-fire agreement. Some of this Administration's critics thought we were cutting him a little slack.
I just can't say what he would do. All I can say is I expect as President I'll be tested in a lot of ways by a lot of people, at home and abroad. And part of my job is to meet the test. All I can tell you is, sitting here, is that would be a foolish thing to do. Because you know that's going to happen. I am not going to abandon the oath of office, and I'm not going to abandon my position and my convictions.

 	 	 		. . .	 	This is a United Nations effort in which there is strong solidarity. The Russians made a statement about this just recently.
We can't afford to let this endeavor disintegrate and dissipate because the United States has a lack of resolve.
Q -- Would you be willing to enter into a shooting war?
A --: I have to say I wouldn't rule anything in or out.
Q -- Could you imagine ever having normalized relations with Iraq as long as Saddam is in power?
A --: I can't imagine having normalized relations with Iraq with the sort of behavior that characterizes what they did.
 
On War-Crimes Trials
 Q -- Are you ready to support a Nuremburg-like war-crimes trial?
A --: I think what has gone on there certainly constitutes a war crime under international law. Now, who is a war criminal is a question of fact: Who knew what? What did the army do? What did the irregulars do? What did Milosevic support or not support from Serbia? But i don't think it's something we can let go; I think it's something that ought to be looked into. . . . There needs to be an investigation into violations of international law on this. The reason this Bosnian thing is so tough for me is that I understand the problems in Europe: slow economic growth; Germans have taken on a quarter of a million refugees . . . the military situation in Yugoslavia. But somehow the West has got to say something and do something about the idea of "ethnic cleansing," which is such an embracing idea that if you believe in it, it justifies the brutalization of women who aren't your women and the torture of children that aren't your children.
I think it is important to point out that this Bosnian thing has potential ramifications further away from the reach of the United States and Europe on the republics of the former Soviet Union, in central Europe. . . . There are some other things we can do if this process breaks down. There may be some things we can do militarily, short of the introduction of a large ground force, that would change the dynamics at play there. I don't want to rule any of those things out.
I want to say that even though I know a lot of it is maneuvering, I am still hopeful of what these parties have said about the Vance-Owen peace mission because there is a chance that if we do it right and they perceive their interests rightly that it can take on a life of its own and we can bring it to a successful conclusion.
Q -- When you say we've got to send a signal on "ethnic cleansing," something like considering war-crime trials is what you're talking about?
A -- Well there may be other things we can do. I don't want to foreclose my options by discussing them before I make a decision. I think that as horrible as the loss of life and the torture and the butchery and the starvation has been the potential for a bigger impact than that even, because it's all been done under the notion of "ethnic cleansing." I mean, here we are on the verge of the 21st century, and people who are literate, who can read and write, who are part of a very old, civilized tradition, think it's O.K. to slaughter the living daylights out of one another under the guise of "ethnic cleansing." It is a barbaric idea.
I mean, I know we've got a lot of problems in this country -- I know we do -- that I've got to address. I know the tensions, for example, in Los Angeles are still not what I wish they were -- they're not as good as I wish they were. But Lord of Mercy, there's 150 different racial and ethnic groups in Los Angeles County. I mean, we are at least making an effort to go forward. . . . I know that ethnic divisions are one of the strongest impulses in all of society, all over the world. But we've got to take a stand against it. It's an awful idea, and the potential ramifications are very very great, because they justify doing anything.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- There have been a lot of questions raised -- Ron Brown and the party that has just been canceled; Zoe Baird and whether she supports tort-reform that you didn't; Warren Christopher and whether he lied to Congress -- that have all contributed to a questioning not only of your selections but in general of your credibility in saying that you would change business-as-usual in Washington. Is that not fair?
A --: Well, it's not accurate. For one thing, when you appoint people, all questions should be raised about them. That's all part of it. I don't mind questions being raised about them. But keep in mind I did what I said I would do. We had the first code of ethics for people in transition. We had the toughest code of ethics for Cabinet members that they've all had to sign off on. I think that party should have been canceled.
Q -- Did they talk to you about it?
A --: No. I mean they did this morning when I knew about it. But my staff knew about it. We all thought it was the right thing to cancel the party. There's a big difference between being chairman of a political party where people may be supporting your political party or the other one, and having a Commerce job where you actually make decisions here. So i think it was exactly the right thing to cancel the party.
Q -- You don't question his judgment in agreeing to the party in the first place?
A --: Well, it wasn't part of my deal then. I mean, he was party chairman. They were going to have a party. He thought he was going out as party chairman. Whether it was or was not the right thing to do, it had nowhere near the magnitude of the Commerce Secretary-designate. That made it a very different issue.
On the other issue, I do want to say -- the other issue your paper editorialized about, which is what his standard ought to be for making decisions in cases involving his former clients -- as you probably know, each of these departments has an office of government ethics, and all we told our people to do was talk to the office of government ethics within each department and make sure they knew what the rules were, and then adhere to those rules, which is what he did. And that's what the office of government ethics told him to do. I think some good points were raised by the Times, and we are revisiting that. . . . He's revisiting too. It means he might come back to me and say the same thing. . . .
On this Zoe thing, I just think that's wrong. She represented her clients, taking the position that they took. It may be different from the position I took. I didn't agree with Dan Quayle on tort reform, but neither did I agree with the idea that no changes ever needed to be made. There were a lot of people I appointed to the Cabinet, and who I will appoint to other things, who may not agree with me on every single issue. I appointed her because I got to know her during the campaign, she did some very good work for us. I thought she was an extraordinarily able person, was one of the few lawyers I knew who had a reputation of being an excellent lawyer and who had real management experience, which I thought was sorely needed in the Justice Department. And everybody that I called about her who I knew well raved about her. I picked her because I liked her. . . . There is no ethical issue there at all. . . .
Wait a minute, wait a minute. This is an amazing thing to me. If someone comes to work for me and they once held a position when they worked for someone else, different from my position, why wouldn't you assume that my position would prevail? I mean, I've always been amazed by the notion that the President assumes the positions of the people he appoints.
 
On Keeping Campaign Promises

Q -- Tort reform aside, there is a series of issues where it looks like every day, you're backing more away -- gays in the military, the middle-class tax cut.
A -- I have not backed away from gays in the military. I have not backed away from -- I put out a book which said how much I thought I could cut the deficit. You're trying to move the target on me. You're trying to say that I have no right to pursue an investment budget, no right to grow the economy. The deficit is a lot bigger than it was when I put out my book, "Putting People First.'

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- What about a middle-class tax cut?
A -- I think that is the one thing I have to think about exactly how to do in light of the bigger deficit. But you can say again, "Well, he is backing away from a commitment," but the deficit is now 50 to 60 billion dollars bigger five years from now than we thought it was going to be. The American people expect me to deal with the circumstances as I find them, and if they are changing and hemorrhaging I have to deal with that.
Let me just say this: judge me by my performance. I said I would give the most diverse Cabinet in history, and we have one -- we have an excellent Cabinet. I think they're sailing through on confirmation, by and large, doing very well. I said I would impose ethics standards on my Cabinet secretaries, higher than anybody else, and I'm going to do that. I said I would present a bill to the Congress. I'd have a growth package. I'd have a deficit-reduction package that was rigorous and real. I would have ethics legislation and political reform. I'd do national service. And watch, I'm going to try to do those things. I've got to get the Congress to go along, but I think we can.
So I think that given the enormity of the challenges facing us and the fact that we have a challenge, interestingly enough, to do something that I don't think any previous President has faced -- that is, we've got to try to deal with the deficit and investment at the same time -- I think we're going to do quite well, and I feel good about it.
Q -- What about the criticism that you got too caught up in diversity in selecting a Cabinet and that you were micromanaging the selection of White House staff.
A -- I did micromanage the cabinet appointments. I spent more time on the Cabinet appointments than anybody in history had, and I plead guilty to that. I personally interviewed them all. But they're in my Cabinet, and I spent a lot of time talking about what we wanted the mission of the department to be. I plead guilty to that, because I want people who'd be more or less in synch with me so that I could define the mission, not that they could never take a position different from mine but so that once I put them there, they could move forward. But I think you'll see that in the next several days there will be a huge number of decisions made on the staff and the subcabinet, and that I'm not trying to micromanage that.
I do think that on diversity what I tried to do -- the reason it took longer, is that I wanted to get diversity and excellence and compatablity, and I think I achieved that. I think it will be very hard for people to argue after these folks have a chance to perform, that there have been many Cabinets in the past that have been more full of ideas or excellence. I think this is an energetic, diverse idea-oriented cabinet. I think they'll do very well.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q -- We have to ask about Mrs. Clinton --
A -- Ask about her.
Q -- What's she going to do? Is she going to have an office in the West Wing? A job outside the White House?
A -- No. I don't want her to have a job outside the White House. I want her to help me. You know, besides that, I want to support her. She's been supporting me for 15 years. This is going to be the first time -- we've been married since 1975, and the only year where I made more money than she did is the first year we were married. So I've got a lot of catching up to do. I haven't supported her very well all these years, so I want her to work there. I don't know that anybody's office has been fixed except mine. That's true. We're keeping looking at that. I wish -- the office structure in the White House is not the best. We're trying to figure out what to do about that. They won't let us knock down any walls, so we've got to figure out what to do.

The unemployment rate is actually higher than now reported and thousands of full-time workers hold only part-time jobs, according to new data-collection methods. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Higher Jobless Rates Likely in New Survey

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For the first time in 25 years, the Labor Department is revamping its monthly employment survey, and initial tests of the new questionnaire indicate that the United States has hundreds of thousands of people now listed as full-time workers who in fact hold only part-time jobs.
The tests also suggest that once the new survey replaces the present one, starting in January 1994, the unemployment rate may rise slightly. That is partly because unemployment is probably greater than the current survey can capture, and the new, more accurate one is likely to capture at least some of the additional unemployment, Government officials said. 
 "The results of our testing are very, very preliminary, and I would be more comfortable not saying it, but it looks like unemployment could be higher when the new survey is used," said Anne E. Polivka, an economist at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, who is helping to develop the new survey.
 
Impact on Policy
 Apart from the unemployment issue, the new survey will produce information not now available that could have an impact on Government policies. It might, for example, encourage the Federal Reserve to raise or lower interest rates sooner than it might otherwise act as a result of the labor force data now gathered each month in the Current Population Survey, run by the Census Bureau in collaboration with the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The Labor Department will distinguish each month between people holding full-time jobs and those who now seem to be full-timers because they put together two or three part-time jobs, or some overtime hours, to work a full 35-hour week or more. Some 95 million people were listed as full-timers late last year because they worked the requisite 35 hours in the week before a monthly survey.
But the initial testing of the new format, with its more detailed questions, indicated that 2 percent of these "full-timers" -- 1.8 million people -- held dual part-time jobs. An additional 5.3 million people held a full-time job and also moonlighted in a second job, another distinction not currently captured in the monthly surveys. Part-time jobs generally do not pay as well or offer as comprehensive benefit packages as full-time jobs, so that a labor force composed of a rising number of part-time workers is probably less well off than one composed of more full-time workers.
With the new information, if the Federal Reserve sees that people are losing their second jobs or their pay from moonlighting over a period of several months, it might decide that the economy is weakening and lower interest rates to stimulate economic growth. The nation's forecasters would also incorporate such data into their latest predictions.
"The degree to which people are able to get multiple jobs to make up for a shortage of hours in their primary employment is an indication of the strength and flexibility of our economy," said Glen Cain, a University of Wisconsin labor economist who participated last week in a discussion of the new survey at a meeting of the American Economic Association.
Or a rise in dual job-holding may be an early signal that the economy is getting stronger, and higher interest rates may be in order to slow growth. This could happen even while the total number of people holding jobs, now about 118 million, and the unemployment rate, now 7.3 percent, remain unchanged.
In the current survey, anyone holding any job for any number of hours in the week before the survey is listed as employed. Now people will also be asked whether they regularly work full time or part time or hold two jobs, questions currently posed only in surveys conducted every year or two. The last was in 1991.
This is the fourth major revision of the monthly Current Population Survey since it was begun in 1940 to estimate the unemployment rate and to collect other work-force data. Some 65,000 households, a cross section of the national population, are interviewed each month, and this number will remain unchanged in the new survey. But for the first time since 1967, the questions are being revised and labor economists familiar with the changes generally welcome them.
In the 1960's, men still dominated employment and full-time jobs were the norm. The new questions are intended to capture more accurately such changes as the huge rise in part-time work and multiple job holders, the rise in the number of people now counted as employed who in fact work without wages in small family businesses, and the rise in the number of mothers who work part time rather than full time because they lack child-care assistance.
Preliminary tests of the new survey suggest that roughly 900,000 additional people now recorded as wage earners should in fact be listed as working in family businesses without pay. And nearly two million women consider themselves forced to work part time because they lack child-care help. That is a breakdown not captured in current data.
Planning for the revised Current Population Survey began in the late 1980's and the new questions were tested in 1990 and 1991 in focus groups and in random telephone polling. Since last July, the survey has been tested monthly among 15,000 representative households. The Census Bureau, which conducts the monthly survey and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which interprets the data, are just beginning to release information about the revisions and the test results, and more is to be disclosed starting next month.
Some questions might tend to lower the unemployment rate. In the new survey, reading classified want ads, by itself, no longer constitutes active job-hunting, a condition for being counted as unemployed.
But other changes in the survey could push up the unemployment rate, Ms. Polivka said. Rather than record their answers on paper, the interviewers in the new system are equipped with laptop computers.
When interviewers revisit the same households, they can call up on their computers the previous month's answers. That is likely to encourage people to be more consistent and precise in their new answers. Greater accuracy in turn tends to push up the unemployment rate, officials say.

HEADLINE: College to Replace Mall in Downtown Bridgeport

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 13

 BODY:
In another attempt to jump-start the economically depressed city of Bridgeport, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced today that a community college on the east side of the city would move to a new $23 million campus in the heart of downtown.
Under the plan, the Hi-Ho Mall will be demolished to make way for the Housatonic Community Technical College. The two-story mall, with its card shops, dime stores and family restaurants, has almost as many empty storefronts as active ones. 
 "A downtown campus for Housatonic Community College will best serve the needs of its students and, at the same time, strengthen the City of Brideport," the Governor said in a statement from his office in Hartford.
 
Office in City
 The announcement comes one month after Governor Weicker announced that he would open an office of his own in downtown Bridgeport, which flirted with bankruptcy in 1991 and continues to suffer from poverty, crime, drug problems and cutbacks in municipal services. The purpose of his new office, the Governor said, will be "to focus on the economic development and revitalization" of the city and its surrounding areas.
Mr. Weicker said that he plans to spend "a considerable amount of time" at the Bridgeport office, which is to open Feb. 1. Representatives of other state agencies will also work out of the office, at 10 Middle Street, a few blocks from the Hi-Ho Mall.
Under the plan for the college, still subject to the approval of the city's Board of Aldermen and the Bridgeport Financial Review Board, the state will buy the 12-acre mall property for $7 million from the owner, D'Addario Industries. The campus would occupy three acres of the site.
Mayor Joseph Ganim of Bridgeport joined the Governor in making yesterday's announcement about the college. "This decision," the Mayor said, "represents a 'new lease on life' for Bridgeport's downtown."
But many at the college were unhappy. "Students go to school to learn and grow not to help make a downtown grow," said Scotty Edminston, a 48-year-old student majoring in criminal justice. "The mall is a terrible site. It's not safe. This is just a political decision made by the Mayor and the Governor with no concern for who it affects whatsoever."
Mr. Edminston and many other students and faculty members favored moving the campus to another site under consideration, on Sylvan Avenue away from the downtown area.
Housatonic Community College has been in rented space since it was founded in Stratford in 1966. Since 1977 it has been in an old sewing machine factory on Barnum Avenue in one of the most dilapidated parts of Bridgeport.

HEADLINE: A Slot Machine Parlay;
Weicker and Indian Tribe Make a Big Bet

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. signed an agreement today permitting slot machines at the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe's casino in Ledyard, and the tribe in turn agreed to contribute at least $100 million a year in gambling profits to a fund to aid troubled cities and towns.
With the agreement, Mr. Weicker, who has been a forceful opponent of casino gambling, and the tribe, which would face competition from expanded gambling venues, appear to have outflanked the gaming industry, which has been pushing the state to approve casinos in Hartford and Bridgeport. 
 If slot machines are legalized at any sites off the reservation, the tribe would be released from its $100 million obligation to the state. Legal experts said the cash-transfer agreement was the largest of its kind.
 
Powerful Lobbying Force
 With the money earmarked for municipalities -- a sensitive and powerful lobbying force in Hartford -- gambling supporters would likely face an instant new opponent at Mr. Weicker's side if the fund were threatened.
"The casinos are dead," said Representative Ernest E. Newton 2d, a Democrat from Bridgeport who had been a supporter of a casino to help his city. "Very slick."
Others were not so quick to roll over.
The Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas, which has offered to build a casino in Hartford or Bridgeport, issued a statement saying the agreement may be challenged.
 
Political Paradox
 And some noted the paradox of Mr. Weicker, who has opposed increased gambling on moral and economic grounds, signing off on an enterprise that the 250-member tribe estimates will take $400 million a year from gamblers' wallets. Mr. Weicker said such a concession was needed to fend off what he viewed as the even greater evil: the building of casinos throughout the state.
Time may have been running out on the Governor. Earlier this month, a legislative task force recommended permitting slot machines at dog tracks, jai alai frontons and tele-tracks.
Some lawmakers said the agreement also robbed the Governor of his moral authority on the issue.
"There's been a flip here," said the Senate majority leader, William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford who is also the Legislature's leading proponent of gambling as an economic development tool for cities. "He's come to the party and admitted that gaming revenues are acceptable."
Mr. Weicker denied that he had changed his position and said that because the tribe was a sovereign nation, the agreement with the Mashantucket Pequots does not represent an expansion of gambling in the state of Connecticut at all. In 1991, the tribe won the right to open a casino under Federal laws that govern Indian reservations. The casino opened last February.
Mr. Weicker also denied any overt attempt to block the Legislature from considering gambling legislation on its own.
"I can't think of a cleaner way to get additional revenues for the State of Connecticut," he said of the agreement. "It in no way takes away from the Legislature in pursuing whatever course it wants to pursue."
The agreement, signed by Mr. Weicker and the tribe's chairman, Richard A. Hayward, in a ceremony in Mr. Weicker's office, also opens the way for the tribe to begin an open war with Atlantic City for gambling dollars. Until now, the casino had only offered table games like poker, blackjack and roulette. The first 100 machines will be up and running this Friday, with at least 3,000 more machines by this summer, tribal officials said.
 
1,500 New Jobs
 The expansion will create 1,500 new jobs over the next nine months. A major advertising campaign aimed at Boston, New York City and northern New Jersey will begin this spring.
Gaming industry experts said that while slot machines would likely be a huge boon for the tribe -- in Atlantic City and Nevada, slot machines generally account for about 60 percent of a casino's gross revenue -- today's agreement would still leave Connecticut's casino as a distant and isolated competitor to Atlantic City.
"It's going to hurt, but it's not the big blow," said Paul M. Dworin, publisher and editor of Gaming and Wagering Business Magazine, a New York-based publication that tracks the industry.
But the Mashantucket Pequot tribe's growing economic clout within Connecticut cannot be denied. Late Tuesday, for example, the tribe began calling every bank in New England seeking to buy every Susan B. Anthony dollar in circulation. The first 100 machines will all run on Susan B. Anthony dollar coins, said G. Michael Brown, the casino's president and chief executive officer.
"We locked up $300,000 by this morning," he said.
Mr. Brown said the tribe also locked in an order for 700 more computer-controlled slot machines, also known as video slots, from the International Gaming Technology Company of Reno, which he described as the world's largest manufacturer of gambling devices. The first of those machines will come into use on Feb. 1, Mr. Brown said.
What the immediate application of the agreement means is that even if there is a legal challenge, money will already be rolling into the tribe's coffers and the fund for municipalities. The $100 million figure is based on the state receiving 25 percent of slot machine revenues. The tribe pledged $30 million in contributions over the next four months. Challenging the agreement could mean stopping that flow, and with the state budget facing an estimated $424 million shortfall in the year that begins on July 1, giving up what appears to be a sure thing may be a very tough sell for pro-gambling lawmakers.
 
Casino Schools
 Other provisions of the agreement could also be popular with some residents and legislators. The state, for example, had opposed having the tribe conduct a gambling school on nonreservation land to train casino workers. Today, Mr. Weicker said that opposition had been dropped, and the tribe, in turn had agreed to begin an active recruiting program in the state's largest cities.
A lawyer for the tribe, Barry A. Margolin, said tribal employment offices would be opened in Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven to interview people seeking jobs in this year's expansion. The casino already employees 3,500 workers, making it one of the largest employers in New London County.
Mr. Margolin said that by voluntarily offering the money to the state, and insisting that the money be spent on local government aid, the tribe and the state have avoided running afoul of Federal Indian gaming regulators who have struck down some state-tribe agreements. In those failed agreements, he said, the state's actions were interpreted as trying to coerce money from tribes.
Other legal experts said cases like the Connecticut one, in which the self-interests of a tribe merge so completely with a Governor that tribal leaders would voluntarily open their wallets, had never been challenged because they had never occurred.
"It's more like coercing the Legislature," said Jim Abourezk, a former United States Senator from South Dakata who now represents Indian tribes in gaming issues.

Machines which will be adding to the state's coffers are already in use at the Foxwoods Indian Casino. (Steve Miller) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Brady Warns Clinton On Spending for Jobs

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In blunt advice to President-elect Bill Clinton, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the economy was gathering steam and warned that it would be unwise for the new president to spur growth through a short-term program of increased Federal spending.
Though job gains are weak, "I don't think you ought to go at job creation by investment spending of the Federal Government," he said in an interview a week before he leaves office. "The Government doesn't create jobs. Two-thirds of the jobs are created by small business." He urged Mr. Clinton to rely on exports and small business for job creation. 
 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, who is the President-elect's choice for Treasury Secretary, told Congress on Tuesday that Mr. Clinton's advisers were weighing whether to increase deficit spending in the short term as a way to accelerate growth and create jobs.
 
 
Responding to Critics
 But Mr. Brady said today that growth was already fairly strong, averaging almost 3 percent last year. And he took pains to respond to all the critics who lambasted the Bush Administration's for doing little to spur the economy, which grew at an anemic rate of less than 1 percent a year during Mr. Bush's first three years in office. "All this kind of stuff that we had the worst record since the middle of the Depression is a lot of hooey," he said.
Mr. Brady said he was not sure what he would do after Jan. 20, beyond taking a vacation in February. He said he did not plan to work full time at his former investment bank, Dillon, Read & Company, although he said he would give it whatever help he could.
Mr. Brady praised the Bush Administration for facing up to what he described as several "torpedoes at the waterline" that threatened to wreck the financial system when Mr. Bush took office. He said the Administration had largely resolved the savings and loan crisis, which many economists say had roots in the high inflation under Jimmy Carter and grew worse when President Ronald Reagan deregulated the banking system. In addition, Mr. Brady took credit for defusing the third-world banking crisis, which threatened to drown several of the nation's largest commercial banks.
Many economists say that once the Bush Administration resolved these crises it largely ignored the economy, giving the impression that it was oblivious about the recession that began in the summer of 1990.
 Mr. Brady boasted that commercial banks and savings and loans enjoyed record profits last year and that the capital reserves of the commercial banks were the strongest they have been since the 1950's.
With relish, he walked over to his desk and picked up an editorial from The Financial Times of London. A man who rarely shows his pride, he read the editorial, which said the Bush Administration "economic management rates at least a beta-plus."
"A B-plus is O.K. to me in this game," he said.
Two years ago The Financial Times and other European newspapers lampooned Mr. Brady as an American cowboy for urging Germany and other European countries to focus more on sustaining growth and less on fighting inflation. He was concerned that Germany's central bank had pushed up interest rates so high to fight inflation that it would strangle growth throughout Europe -- a prediction that has turned out to be true.
"I fought these guys for two years, saying growth is not like a light switch that you decide some morning you want to turn on and it goes on," he said. "It's a flame you have to keep lit."
 The Treasury Secretary, who has had strained relations with the Federal Reserve, could not resist a parting shot at the central bank.
"Do I think the Fed has acted with great wisdom?" he asked. "I don't."
Time and again he has criticized the central bank for acting too little and too late to cut interest rates and for letting the money supply grow too slowly -- a development that helps push up interest rates and slow economic growth. At times, he noted, the size of the money supply fell instead of growing.
"Try to make a declining economy come back on a predictable schedule when the monetary authorities are dragging down M-2," the most closely watched gauge of the money supply, he said.
He said he sympathized with, but did not completely agree with, those economists who argue that the Federal Reserve exerts too much power over shaping the economy.

HEADLINE: Domestic Oil Demand Up in '92 and Import Rise Filled Gap

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil demand rose significantly in 1992 for the first time since 1988, the industry's main trade association said yesterday, attributing the rise to "the stirrings of a turnaround in the economy."
But domestic production continued its seven-year decline, hitting the lowest level since 1960. The gap between consumption and domestic production was filled by imports, which the trade association, the American Petroleum Institute, said rose by about 4 percent last year. 
 Edward W. Murphy, the institute's director of statistics, said domestic production declined 3.8 percent last year, to 7.132 million barrels a day, essentially because of "a very low level of drilling" and because "drilling is not allowed in places that people believe have large" reserves.
The energy bill passed by Congress last year gave some tax relief to drillers beginning on Jan. 1. But drillers also want access to restricted areas in Alaska and at sea on the continental shelf.
Last year's statistics show the share of the energy market filled by natural gas, which is clean and available on this continent, continuing to rise. Its use grew 2.7 percent, compared with overall growth in energy consumption of 1.1 percent.
Over all, deliveries of oil products rose 1.6 percent last year, according to the institute. Jet fuel use reached a new peak and demand was up for gasoline and for distillates.
Highway miles traveled rose 3.3 percent, the institute said, leading to a 1.4 percent increase in gasoline use, to 7.3 million barrels a day. The two percentages differ because average fuel economy is rising.
Gasoline prices averaged $1.13 a gallon for unleaded, less than early 1991, when the Persian Gulf war pushed up prices, but more than the figure later in the year. The institute said that the price of gasoline was up 18 cents a gallon over the last five years but that this was less than inflation and that 10 cents of the increase was taxes.
Demand for all oil products in 1992 averaged 16.985 million barrels a day, up from 16.716 million in 1991. Imports of crude oil and products were 7.847 million barrels a day, up 2.9 percent.
Last year's numbers were still below the peak of the late 1970's; the record consumption level, 18.847 million barrels a day, was reached in 1978. The peak year for import share of consumption, 47.7 percent, was 1977. In contrast, the fraction of domestic consumption represented by imports was 46.2 percent last year, up from 45.6 percent in 1991.

HEADLINE: Pier 1 Imports Sees a Role As an Exporter of Expertise

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
For 30 years, Pier 1 Imports Inc. has brought bits of the world into American homes -- brass from India, wicker sofas from Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines and an array of other tchotchkes from exotic locales.
Now, it plans to go into the export business -- exporting its merchandise and retailing expertise. 
 The company has already established a beachhead in Britain, taking a stake last summer in a fledgling store in London called the Pier. Since then, three more Pier stores have opened there. And tomorrow, during a lunch at "21" in Manhattan, Pier 1 will unwrap for analysts its plans for international expansion. The opportunities the company says it will seek include moving into other parts of Western Europe and beyond, either on its own or in partnerships with local retailers.
American merchants have been cautious in mining overseas markets, mindful of the difficulties of transferring retailing concepts from one culture to another. In fact, Pier 1 joins only a small band of American retailers that are testing the waters in Europe and Japan, including Toys "R" Us, L. L. Bean, Kmart, the Gap and Nicole Miller.
"There's a burgeoning improvement in standards of living around the world," said Clark A. Johnson, Pier 1's chairman and chief executive, adding, as he so frequently does, a statistic to support his contention: "In the 1990's, one billion middle- class people will be created in the world. And when people achieve middle class, they want to live like Americans."
Americans, meanwhile, are embellishing their homes after a long spate of making do with what they had. Citing another useful factoid, Mr. Johnson noted that Management Horizons, a market research company, predicted that sales of sofas, chairs, vases, pottery and other home-decorating items will grow an average of 5.3 percent annually between 1991 and 1996, compared with 2.7 percent
over the previous five years.
After two years of declining sales and paltry earnings, Pier 1 has enjoyed a solid run of sales increases over the last five quarters. Holiday sales were exceptionally strong, besting the previous year's weak holiday showing by 14.1 percent. And analysts and retail experts believe the company will continue to benefit from the recovering economy.
Few analysts are aware yet of Pier 1's expansion plans. But Walter K. Levy, chairman of Walter K. Levy & Robert E. Kerson Associates and a consultant who has done work for many retailers seeking to make their way in international markets, said such a strategy would probably work well for Pier 1.
"We developed a concept for a U.K. retailer that involved similar kinds of products that was quite promising," Mr. Levy said.
 
Approaching Saturation in U.S.
 In the United States, Pier 1 will bump up against a growth ceiling by the end of the decade, when it expects to have 900 stores here -- roughly 300 more than today. That ceiling is one reason why its stock price is devalued compared with younger home furnishings retailers like the Bombay Company, Williams-Sonoma and Lechters.
"It's a large company with a lot of stores in a lot of places halfway through its life cycle," said Peter Lynch, the superstar stock picker who used to manage Fidelity Investment's Magellan Fund and has long touted Pier 1 stock as undervalued. "A company like Bombay is in the first quarter of its life with 5 to 10 years of rapid growth ahead of it."
A group of 25 retail stocks is trading at a 6 percent premium to the group's growth rate, whereas Pier 1 trades slightly below that rate, according to Donald I. Trott, a retail analyst at Dean Witter.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Pier 1's shares closed at $12.50, down 12.5 cents.
 
Seeking a Balance
 The company's plan may also help Pier 1 balance the cyclical ebb and flow of the retail business. Its stores in the United States and Canada, for example, are starting to flourish as the economy revs up, while the Pier stores in London are waging a pitched battle with the weak economy there.
But the expansion may not completely appease Wall Street, which disapproved of Pier 1's purchase in 1990 of Sunbelt Nurseries, a chain of gardening and lawn-care stores in the Southwest and California. Pier 1 sold a 51.5 percent stake in the nursery business to the public last year and used the proceeds to retire its debt.
Mr. Johnson still hopes to reinvent Sunbelt in much the same way Pier 1 was reinvigorated starting in 1985, when he arrived with a team of new managers that set about closing old, tired stores, opening new stores under less expensive leases and transforming the company's image as a purveyor of beads and batik to a source for contemporary, affordable home fashions and furnishings.
Pier 1 has invested $10 million in refurbishing and building new stores for Sunbelt, which operates the Wolf Nurseries, Nurseryland and Tip Top chains. "We think going forward Sunbelt will make a solid contribution," Mr. Johnson said.
Pier 1's expansion abroad may be courageous, given retailers' failure rate in foreign markets. Galeries Lafayette, the French department store chain, has struggled to get its New York City store off the ground, although company officials note that a new advertising campaign and changed merchandising seem to have buoyed its business recently.
A few retailers have made a go of going global. Marks & Spencer, the giant British retailer, has had success in its stores on the Continent: its grand store in Paris is second only to its London flagship in sales.
Mr. Johnson said Pier 1 would use joint ventures and licensing agreements to open stores in the Far East, South and Central America and other countries where language and unfamiliar laws and business practices could present barriers to success. "We just think it's better to do business with a partner who's more familiar with the laws and speaks the language," he said.
In exchange, Pier 1 will supply its expertise in visual display, inventory selection and using computers to help manage the business.
The company also plans to open a office somewhere in Southeast Asia that will oversee production and sourcing of merchandise for its own stores and those operated by others.
"It's definitely exportable," Mr. Lynch said. "The things they sell are useful in Europe, in Asia, wherever."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Spend-Now, Tax-Later Orgy

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
The disciples of John Maynard Keynes have long been urging President-elect Bill Clinton to adopt a policy of benign neglect toward the Federal deficit. The national debt, they say, was far bigger relative to the economy during the early years of the the postwar economic boom than it is today. So, this thinking goes, the mounting debt should not keep the new Administration from spending its way to a more robust economic recovery or bankrolling more public investment.
But a powerful new tool for analyzing how tax burdens are spread across different generations -- called generational accounting -- shows that this sanguine view is shortsighted at best. Learning to live with the deficit amounts to forwarding the bills for today's spending orgy to the nation's children and grandchildren. 
 If you're a baby boomer born, say, in 1950, your average lifetime tax rate is about a third higher than that of your parents, 31 percent versus 24 percent.
In dollars and cents, you can expect to pay $200,000 more in taxes than you collect in benefits over your lifetime.
The truly terrible news, according to new calculations by two economists: if current tax and spending policies continue, your grandchildren could end up paying 71 percent of their incomes to the government.
Most Americans understand that doubling taxes on future generations to pay for today's spending would be immoral, as well as infeasible. But traditional budget accounting -- estimating revenues and expenditures year by year -- says little about the long-term effects of fiscal policy and nothing at all about who ultimately picks up the tab.
"Any sustainable policy has to stabilize the future tax rate," said Laurence Kotlikoff, an economist at Boston University, one of the co-inventors of generational accounting and author of a recent book by that title. "The real constraint on fiscal policy is that you can't take more than 100 percent of future income."
He added, "Rising taxes rates on future generations -- not the debt per se -- show us that we're in a mess."
The notion of quantifying myopic fiscal policies is the brainchild of Professor Kotlikoff and Alan Auerbach at the University of Pennsylvania. Their ideas are just beginning to attract attention outside academia. This year, the Bush Administration's last budget report and the Economic Report of the President included a set of generational accounts.
Here's how they work: The economists add up all the taxes -- Federal, state and local -- paid over an individual's lifetime. They subtract all the cash benefits the person gets from the Government, including Social Security, Medicare and welfare. The difference is the lifetime tax rate.
The real message of these projections is that Washington's current path simply isn't sustainable.
"Obviously, taxes are going to go up and benefits will be under extreme pressure," Professor Kotlikoff said.
What's the solution? Cutting expenditures on current generations, especially the baby boomer's parents, or raising their taxes.
According to the White House budget report, "the generational imbalance between the newly born and future Americans could be largely eliminated by imposing a cap on mandatory spending (excluding Social Security) from 1993 to 2004 or by an appropriate tax surtax."
"Both policies significantly increase net taxes -- the taxes paid less transfers received -- by current Americans," the document continues. Specifically, tax rates on baby boomers and their children would rise to as much as 40 percent, but taxes on future generations would remain under 50 percent.
Some Clinton proposals -- to raise taxes on the rich, increase the gasoline levy or slow the growth of health-care spending -- amount to steps in the same direction.
"Getting control of health-care spending is essential to keeping tax rates far away from 100 percent," said Barry Anderson, assistant director of the Office of Management and Budget. "You could make a huge contribution by simply limiting benefit increases to the elderly to inflation."
On the other hand, a proposal long favored by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, could make things worse from a generational point of view. His idea to cut payroll taxes -- but not benefits -- would ease the burden on baby boomers but increase it enormously for their children.
Critics of generational accounting, like Henry Aaron at the Brookings Institution, say it's intriguing, but impractical. There's just too much uncertainty about future interest rates, demographic trends and a host of other assumptions needed to figure future tax bills that generational accounts shouldn't be used to screen policy proposals.
But fans of the novel method see it as a consciousness-raising device.
"I wouldn't advocate this stuff being written into a new rule," Professor Auerbach said, "but I'd be overjoyed if every time a signficiant budget proposal was introduced, it's long-run implications would have to be considered."
